   I, Janice M. Frank, City Clerk of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, hereby certify
that the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Williamsport as
revised, rearranged, compiled, renumbered as to sections, codified and printed
herein in component codes are correct as and constitute the Codified Ordinances
of the City of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, 1961, as amended to September 4,
2025.
                                       Janice M. Frank
City Clerk

I.   ZONING CHANGES
Editor’s note:
   The Codified Ordinances of Williamsport cover all ordinances of a general
and permanent nature. The provisions of such general and permanent ordinances
are set forth in full in the Codified Ordinances.
   References must be made frequently to many special ordinances particularly
those related to property, such as dedications, vacating of property,
easements, purchase, etc. In the following Tables A through I, all such
ordinances are listed. These tables list ordinances chronologically by subject,
and include both a citation to and brief description of each ordinance.

ARTICLE 101: CODIFIED ORDINANCES

Statutory reference:
   Codification of ordinances, see 3rd Class Charter Law § 609 (53 P.S. §
41609); 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 11018.1
§ 101.01 CODIFICATION ADOPTED; PROCEDURE.
   (a)   The ordinances of the City of Williamsport, Pennsylvania of a general
and permanent nature, consolidated and codified with minor non-substantive
changes as attached hereto and made a part hereof are hereby ordained as the
general ordinances of the city, and are hereby approved, adopted and enacted as
the “Codified Ordinances of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, 2017”.
   (b)   This ordinance shall be introduced in Council, notice of introduction
shall be published, and legal advertisement of the contents of the codified
ordinances shall be made in conformity with subsections 11 Pa.C.S. § 11018.9.
(Ord. 2904, approved 11-9-1961)
§ 101.02 COMPONENT CODES; SHORT TITLE; CITATION.
   (a)   The Codified Ordinances of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, 2017, hereby
adopted, shall be comprised of the following component parts:
      (1)   Part One - Administrative Code;
      (2)   Part Three - Licensing and Taxation Code;
      (3)   Part Five - Traffic Code;
      (4)   Part Seven - General Offenses Code;
      (5)   Part Nine - Streets, Utilities and Public Services Code;
      (6)   Part Eleven - Public Health Code;
      (7)   Part Thirteen - Planning and Zoning Code;
      (8)   Part Fifteen - Fire Prevention Code; and
      (9)   Part Seventeen - Building and Housing.
   (b)   The Codified Ordinances of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, 2017, may be
referred to as the “codified ordinances”; any component code of the codified
ordinances may be referred to by its name, such as the “traffic code”; and
sections of the codified ordinances may be cited by their number, such as §
101.01.
(Ord. 2904, approved 11-9-1961)
§ 101.03 AMENDMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTS; NUMBERING.
   (a)   The Codified Ordinances of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, 2017, may be
amended or supplemented at any time and, when any amendment or supplement is
adopted in such form as to indicate the intention of Council to make the same a
part thereof, such amendment or supplement shall be incorporated in, and deemed
a part of, the codified ordinances, so that a reference to the codified
ordinances, shall be understood and construed as including the Codified
Ordinances of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, 2017, and any and all such amendments
and supplements.
   (b)   All amendments and supplements enacted as a part of the codified
ordinances shall be integrated therewith by following the form of arrangement
and plan set forth in the original codified ordinances as follows: each code
shall be subdivided into titles; each title shall be subdivided into articles;
and each article shall be subdivided into sections which shall be numbered in
accordance with the decimal numbering system. The numbering of all sections
except the penalty sections shall be consecutive within each article commencing
with the first section of
Art. 101, which shall be numbered §
101.01, the first “1” signifying Code 1, the two figures “01” before the
decimal signifying the article within the code, and the two figures “01” after
the decimal signifying the first section in
Art. 101 of the code. Penalty sections shall be designated “99” and shall be
the last section of the article.
(Ord. 2904, approved 11-9-1961)
§ 101.04 INTERPRETATION.
   (a)   In the construction of the codified ordinances the following rules
shall control, except those inconsistent with the manifest intent of Council as
disclosed in a particular provision, section or article:
   (b)   Except as otherwise provided in this section, words and phrases shall
be construed according to the common usage of language. However, technical
words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a special meaning in the
law, shall be construed according to such technical or special meaning.
   (c)   For the purpose of this code, the following definitions apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADOPTING ORDINANCE. The ordinance of the city adopting the Codified
Ordinances of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, 2017, in conformity with the Third
Class City Code of Pennsylvania, and this
Art. 101.
   AND/OR. “And” includes “or” and “or” includes “and” if the sense so
requires.
   AUTHORITY. Whenever in the codified ordinances authority is given to an
officer or an act is required to be performed, such authority may be exercised
and such act may be performed, at the instance of such officer, by a deputy or
subordinate unless contrary to law or to the clear intent of any such
particular provision.
   CALENDAR, COMPUTATION OF TIME. The terms “month” and “year” shall mean the
calendar month or year. The time expressed in days within which an act is to be
done or a period is to expire shall be computed by excluding the first and
including the last day, except if the last be Sunday it shall be excluded. If
time is expressed in hours, the whole of Sunday shall be excluded.
   CHARTER LAW. The Optional Third Class City Charter Law, Act of 7-15-1957,
P.L. 901 (53 P.S. §§ 41101 et seq.)
   CITY, MUNICIPALITY. The City of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
   COUNCIL. The Council of the City of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
   COUNTY. The County of Lycoming, Pennsylvania.
   FIRE BUREAU. The Bureau of Fire of the City of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
   GENDER. Words importing the masculine shall extend and be applied to the
feminine and neuter genders.
   JOINT AUTHORITY. Words giving authority to a board, commission, authority or
to three or more officers or employees or other persons shall be construed as
giving authority to a majority thereof unless otherwise specifically provided.
   KEEPER or PROPRIETOR. Persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and
copartnerships, whether acting by themselves or as a servant, agent or
employee.
   LAND or REAL ESTATE. Include rights and easements of incorporeal nature.
   MUNICIPAL ELECTION. The election required by the Constitution of
Pennsylvania to be held in odd-numbered years.
   NUMBER. Words in the plural include the singular and the singular includes
the plural number.
   OATH. Includes affirmation. When an oath is required or authorized by law,
an affirmation in lieu thereof may be taken by a person having conscientious
scruples to taking an oath. An affirmation shall have the same force and effect
as an oath.
   OWNER. When applied to property includes a part owner, joint owner or tenant
in common, of the whole or any part of such property.
   PERSON. Extends to and includes associations, clubs, corporations, firms,
partnerships and bodies politic, as well as to individuals.
   PERSONAL PROPERTY. Includes every kind of property, except real property.
REAL PROPERTY includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
   POLICE BUREAU. The Bureau of Police of the City of Williamsport,
Pennsylvania.
   PREMISES. When used as applicable to property extends to and includes land
and buildings.
   PROPERTY. Includes real and personal, and any mixed and lesser estates or
interests therein.
   REASONABLE TIME. In all cases where provision is made for an act to be done
or notice to be given within a REASONABLE TIME, it shall be deemed to mean such
time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such act or giving
of such notice.
   SIDEWALK. Any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent
property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways.
   STATE or COMMONWEALTH. The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
   STREET. Includes highways, alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads,
streets and other public ways in the city.
   TENANT or OCCUPANT. As applied to building or land extends and includes any
person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or any part of
a building or land, alone or with others.
   TENSES. The use of any verb in the present tense shall include the future.
   THE THIRD CLASS CITY CODE. The Pennsylvania Act, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 10101 et
seq., as amended. The sections of the Third Class City Code may be cited herein
as “3rd Class Section”.
   WRITTEN or IN WRITING. Includes any representation of words, letters or
figures, whether by printing or otherwise.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 101.05 TIME EXPIRATION FOR ACTION.
   Whenever any time established by the codified ordinances for the taking of
any action expires on a Sunday or any legal holiday, such time shall not expire
on such day, but shall expire on the next work day.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 101.06 SEPARABILITY OF PROVISIONS.
   Each section and each part of each section of the codified ordinances is
hereby declared to be an independent section or part of a section and,
notwithstanding any other evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared
to be the controlling legislative intent that if any such section or part of a
section, or any provision thereof, or the application thereof to any person or
circumstances, is held to be invalid, the remaining sections or parts of
sections and the application of such provision to any other person or
circumstances, other than those as to which it is held invalid, shall not be
affected thereby, and it is hereby declared to be the legislative intent that
the codified ordinances would have been adopted independently of such sections
or parts of a section so held to be invalid.
(Ord. 2904, approved 11-9-1961)
§ 101.07 IMPRISONMENT AS ALTERNATE OR ADDITIONAL PENALTY.
   Whenever in the codified ordinances or in any city ordinance, the penalty of
imprisonment for violation is conditioned in default of fine payment, it is the
intent of Council to amend all such penalty provisions to provide that the
stated term of imprisonment may be imposed as an alternate or additional
sanction to any stated fine provided for. Any stated fine or any stated
imprisonment, or both, may be imposed for the violation of any city ordinance.
(Ord. 4566, approved 3-22-1973)
§ 101.08 MAXIMUM PENALTY DEFINED.
   Whenever in the codified ordinances, any reference is made to “the maximum
penalty provided by state statute”, this shall mean a fine not exceeding
$1,000, for a violation of a building, housing, property maintenance, health,
fire or public safety code or ordinance, and for water, air and noise pollution
violations; and a fine not exceeding $600, for a violation of any other
ordinance.
(Ord. 5541, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 101.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever in the codified ordinances or in any city ordinance any act is
prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in
the codified ordinances or in any ordinance the doing of any act is required or
the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty
is provided therefor, whoever violates any such provision or any ordinance
shall be fined:
   (a)   For a first offense: not less than $1, nor more than $100, or
imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both; and
   (b)   For all subsequent offenses: not less than $5, nor more than $300, or
imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both.
(Ord. 2904, approved 11-9-1961; Ord. 4566, approved 3-22-1973)

§ 111.01 COMPOSITION, MEETINGS AND PROCEEDINGS.
   (a)   Legislative power. The legislative power of the city government shall
be vested in and exercised by Council.
   (b)   Number and election of Council. Council shall consist of seven members
elected at large.
   (c)   Meetings of Council.
      (1)   Regular meetings of Council shall be held every other Thursday
throughout the year and shall begin at 7:00 p.m. prevailing time unless
otherwise noted. All meetings will be held in City Council Chambers/Trade &
Transit II, and/or remote. Meetings may occasionally be held at other locations
with the approval of the majority of Council. As with all meetings, they must
be properly advertised. The meetings may be scheduled for the coming year by
resolution and then properly advertised. Meetings may be held telephonically
and/or during circumstances such as a state of emergency or adverse weather
conditions at the discretion of the President of Council, or in his or her
absence the Vice President of Council. Special meetings may be called by the
President of Council, or in his or her absence by the Vice President of
Council, or as otherwise provided by law.
The notice shall specify whether it is for general or special business. If
called for special business, no other business shall be considered unless so
stated. Each member shall have notice of special meetings required by law. At
all meetings, a quorum of City Council must be present, either in person or
remotely to legally transact business. A quorum is a majority of City Council
members.
      (2)   All regular and special meetings of Council shall be open to the
public, and public notice of such meetings shall be given as required by the
Act of 6-21-1957, P.L. 392.
      (3)   The proceedings of Council shall be governed by rules and
regulations as fixed by resolution of Council.
      (4)   All meetings of City Council and all of its committees shall
operate under the Sunshine Act which was enacted by the State Legislature in
October 1998 and became effective on 12-14-1998 (See 65 Pa.C.S.A. §§ 701 et
seq.). The Act requires that all public agencies take official actions and
conduct all deliberations leading up to official actions at public meetings.
The Act provides for three exceptions to the open meeting requirement: (a)
executive sessions; (b) conferences; and (c) working sessions. The Act sets
forth five reasons for holding executive sessions:
         (A)   To discuss personnel matters, including hiring, promoting,
disciplinary or dismissing specific employees or officers, but not including
filling vacancies in any elective office;
         (B)   To hold information, strategy and negotiation sessions related
to collective bargaining agreements or arbitrations;
         (C)   To consider the purchase or lease of real estate;
         (D)   To consult with an attorney regarding litigation on issues where
identifiable complaints are expected to be filed; and
         (E)   To discuss agency business that would lead to disclosure of
information recognized as confidential or privileged under law, including
initiations and conduct of investigations of possible violations of the law and
quasi-judicial deliberations.
      (5)   In an executive session, under no circumstances should the
deliberations ever lead to a vote by the members.
      (6)   The holding of executive session by City Council or any of its
committees should be announced by the presiding officer stating the reason for
the meeting. If circumstances do not permit this, then announcement that an
executive session was held should be made at the next public meeting of City
Council.
      (7)   Closed work sessions by City Council or any of its committees may
be held to gather information only and shall conform strictly to the Sunshine
Act. There should never be any deliberations on any issue that may or may not
lead to a decision, either at that meeting or in the future. The Solicitor’s
office should be informed of all contemplated work sessions to be sure that
they are in compliance with the law.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972; Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005; Ord. 6426,
passed 2-17-2022)
§ 111.02 PROCEDURAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The following rules shall govern proceedings of Council.
   (a)   Rule 1. Calling Meetings to Order. The President or, when the
President is absent, the Vice President, shall call the meetings to order and
shall preside.
   (b)   Rule 2. Presiding Officer.
      (1)   The presiding officer of Council shall be the President. The
President and Vice President shall be elected annually at the first meeting of
each year by the members. The procedure shall be:
         (A)   Take all nominations for the office without a second;
         (B)   To entertain a non-debatable motion and a second to close the
nominations which is affirmed by a roll call vote; and
         (C)   To accept roll call votes cast for the candidates, the candidate
with the highest number of votes being declared the winner.
      (2)   The presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at
all regular and special meetings of Council. He or she shall vote on all
questions, his or her name being called last. He or she shall sign all
ordinances and resolutions adopted by Council during his or her presence. In
the event of an absence of the President, the presiding officer shall be the
Vice President.
   (c)   Rule 3. Voting. All votes shall be by roll call vote with the
exception of adjournment of the meeting, which shall be by voice vote. A member
must be present or attending remotely to participate and vote, provided that
both the present members and the remote members are able to communicate with
each other.
   (d)   Rule 4. Agenda.
      (1)   All reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions or other
matters to be submitted to Council by the Administration or others are to be
delivered to the City Clerk’s office no later than 12:00 noon on the Friday
before the City Council meeting; the tentative agenda should be compiled at 3:
00 p.m. and printed; and the packets should be readied and delivered at 4:30
p.m. unless exigent circumstances prevent these times from being met. The
amount of copies the Administration needs to supply and who they will go to are
as follows.
         (A)   Ordinances and resolutions.
            1.   One original document packet (official City Clerk file; and***
            2.   Eleven copies (seven Council, one Mayor, two Solicitors, one
Director of Administration).
         (B)   Land developments and subdivisions.
            1.   One original document with supporting documents and all maps;
and
            2.   Eleven copies (seven Council, one Mayor, two Solicitors, one
Director of Administration).
         (C)   Sewer modules.
            1.   One original resolution with supporting documents;***
            2.   Eleven copies (seven Council, one Mayor, two Solicitors, one
Director of Administration).
         (D)   Certificate of appropriateness applications with cover page.
(Include all HARB approved and denied applications with legible notations and
approved or denied line checked): eight copies (seven Council and one official
file).
         (E)   Minutes and monthly reports (committees, commissions and
boards). Nine copies (seven Council, one Mayor and one official file).
         (F)   Memos addressed to City Council President.
            1.   One original (correspondence file); and
            2.   Seven copies (one for each Council member).
   ***Original resolution form with “journal” area printed on reverse. This is
acid-free paper.
      (2)   After noon on the Friday before the City Council meeting,
additional items for the agenda must be approved by the President of City
Council and then must be received by the City Clerk no later than 3:00 p.m. on
Wednesday so that changes can be made to the final agenda and packets again
delivered at 4:30 p.m. In all cases, City Council must have all documents no
less than 12 hours in advance of the meeting unless there are special
circumstances approved by the President or in his or her absence, the Vice
President.
   (e)   Rule 5. Availability of the Agenda and Agenda Items to the Public.
      (1)   The final agenda for the City Council meeting will be made
available to the public at 10:00 a.m. on the Tuesday prior to the meeting.
Copies are provided at no charge and will be located on the news media table in
City Hall Council Chambers or can be obtained from the City Clerk’s office.
Copies of agenda items such as resolutions, ordinances and the like may be made
available to the public prior to the City Council meeting only if:
         (A)   The agenda item has been provided by the Administration for
release; or
         (B)   The agenda item has already been brought before a committee of
City Council for discussion.
      (2)   Copies of agenda items as well as any other materials are available
from the City Clerk at the prevailing rate based on the current schedule
available in the City Clerk’s office. This price is subject to change if costs
for reproduction were to increase.
   (f)   Rule 6. Order of Business.
      (1)   Invocation and pledge of allegiance;
      (2)   Roll call (noted by the City Clerk in the meeting minutes);
      (3)   Approval of regular City Council minutes of previous meeting(s);
      (4)   Presentations/recognitions;
      (5)   Proclamations;
      (6)   Limited courtesy of the floor;
      (7)   Appointments/reappointments;
      (8)   Public hearings;
      (9)   Ordinances on second and final reading;
      (10)   Ordinances on first reading;
      (11)   Resolutions;
      (12)   Conditional uses;
      (13)   Demolitions;
      (14)   Subdivisions;
      (15)   Land developments;
      (16)   Sewer modules;
      (17)   Certificates of appropriateness from the Historic Architectural
Review Board;
      (18)   Acceptance of reports, minutes and the like for filing;
      (19)   Announcements;
      (20)   Comments by:
         (A)   Members of City Council;
         (B)   Administration;
         (C)   General public; and
         (D)   News media.
      (21)   Adjournment.
   (g)   Rule 6A. Reading of Minutes. Unless a reading of the minutes of a
Council meeting is requested by a member of Council, such minutes shall be
approved without reading by a roll call vote if the City Clerk has previously
furnished each member and the Mayor with a copy thereof.
   (h)   Rule 6B. Limited Courtesy of the Floor.
      (1)   At each Council meeting, there shall be a limited courtesy of the
floor after the approval of the minutes of the previous meeting and
presentations/recognitions and proclamations, if any.
      (2)   The period of time allocated shall not exceed 30 minutes and each
speaker shall limit his or her remarks to Council to three minutes except as
otherwise directed by the presiding officer.
      (3)   The speaker shall confine his or her remarks to the items on the
agenda.
      (4)   Any person desiring to address Council during this period shall
notify the City Clerk by 3:00 p.m. of the day of the Council meeting or sign up
at the meeting before the stated time that the meeting is to commence.
      (5)   The City Clerk shall maintain a list of persons requesting to
address Council during these periods and will maintain a sign-up sheet prior to
the commencement of the meeting. The first ten names shall be permitted to
address Council, determined by order of the time their request is received
between both means of notification.
      (6)   The presiding officer must approve any request to speak that is
submitted after the deadline.
   (i)   Rule 6C. Courtesy of the Floor.
      (1)   At each Council meeting, there shall be courtesy of the floor
toward the end of the meeting after the comments, if any, by the
Administration.
      (2)   The speaker shall limit his or her remarks to three minutes and to
city business.
   (j)   Rule 7. Videotaping/Audiotaping. In addition to the televising of City
Council meetings, an individual(s) may videotape or audiotape the proceedings
during a meeting. He or she should first notify the presiding officer of his or
her intentions. All such videotaping shall be limited to the area around the
news media table and shall in no way disturb the meeting. All such audiotaping
shall be from the area around the news media table or in the public seating
section or such other area approved by the presiding officer.
   (k)   Rule 8. Rules of Debate.
      (1)   Getting the Floor; Improper References to be Avoided. Every member
desiring to speak shall address the Chair, and upon recognition by the
presiding officer, shall confine himself or herself to the question under
debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language.
      (2)   Interruptions. A member, once recognized, shall not be interrupted
when speaking unless to call him or her to order or as otherwise provided
herein. If a member, while speaking, is called to order, he or she shall cease
speaking until the question of order is determined and, if in order, he or she
shall be permitted to proceed.
      (3)   Time Limitation on Debate. A Councilman shall have an unlimited
time to debate a question. However, a member of City Council may offer a motion
to call the question thus ending any further debate. This motion must be
properly seconded and must be passed by two-thirds of the members of City
Council.
      (4)   Participation. Members of the public may be permitted to address
Council on any ordinance, resolution or other business before a vote is taken
and after debate of Council and comments by the administration at the
discretion of the presiding officer. Unless further time is granted each
speaker, the speaker shall limit his or her address to Council to three
minutes. A speaker who represents a group shall limit his or her address to six
minutes.
      (5)   Suspending the Rules. At the end of the agenda, if the presiding
officer desires to add an item to the agenda, he or she must discuss his or her
reasons for doing so and then ask for a motion and a second to suspend the
rules. If this is approved after a roll call vote, then proper action can be
taken on the item.
      (6)   Reconsideration of a Question. Once a question is decided, it is
not proper to bring up the same motion or one essentially like it at the same
meeting. However, the same question may be brought to the floor again during
the comments by members of City Council at the same meeting for reconsideration
at the next scheduled meeting or at a special public meeting, but no later than
the next regularly scheduled meeting of City Council. Only a member who voted
in the majority or who was absent when the question was decided may make a
motion for reconsideration of the original question. Any member may offer a
second once the motion is made.
   (l)   Rule 9. Manner of Addressing Council. Each person addressing Council
shall step to the podium, give his or her name and address in an audible tone
of voice for the records and, unless further time is granted by Council, limit
his or her address to three minutes. All remarks shall be addressed to Council
as a body and not to any member thereof. No person, other than Council and the
person having the floor, shall be permitted to enter into any discussion,
either directly or through a member of Council, without the permission of the
presiding officer. Scurrilous reference to persons, indecorous language or
improper behavior will not be tolerated, and the speaker may be declared out of
order by the presiding officer.
   (m)   Rule 10. Introduction and Passage of Ordinances and Resolutions.
      (1)   Every legislative act of Council shall be by resolution or
ordinance, and every ordinance which has passed Council shall be signed by the
President of Council or, in his or her absence by the Vice President, and
attested to by the City Clerk.
      (2)   All proposed ordinances shall be presented to Council in written
form and shall be numbered serially for the calendar year. They shall not be so
altered or amended on their passage through Council as to change their original
purpose. No ordinances, except general appropriation ordinances, shall be
passed containing more than one subject, which shall be expressed in its title.
      (3)   The title of every bill shall be read when introduced; provided,
however, that, any such bill shall be read at length when introduced upon the
request of any member of Council. The title of every bill shall be read on
final passage, except as to amendments or other changes which shall be read at
length. No bill shall be passed finally on the same day it is introduced. At
least three days shall intervene between its introduction and final passage.
Upon final passage, ordinances shall be numbered serially.
      (4)   Each ordinance or resolution shall be introduced in typewritten
form and will not be discussed until properly moved and seconded. All roll call
votes taken shall be recorded in the minutes. The presiding officer shall vote
last on all questions and may take part in the debate without leaving the
Chair. He or she shall also have the right to make motions and to offer seconds
to motions made by other members. No ordinance other than the budget ordinance
shall take effect less than 20 days after its final passage by Council and
approval by the Mayor, where such approval is required, unless Council adopts a
resolution declaring an emergency and at least two-thirds of all the members of
Council vote in favor of such resolution.
      (5)   The City Clerk shall record all ordinances and resolutions adopted
by Council and, at the close of each year, with the advice and assistance of
the City Solicitor, shall bind, compile or codify all the ordinances and
resolutions, or true copies thereof, which then remain in force and effect. The
City Clerk shall also properly index the record books, compilation or
codification of ordinances and resolutions.
      (6)   No rule or regulations made by any department, officer, agency or
authority of the city, except such as relates to the organization or internal
management of the city government or a part thereof, shall take effect until it
is filed either with the City Clerk or in such manner as may be provided by
ordinance.
   (n)   Rule 11. Committees of City Council.
      (1)   City Council shall have seven standing committees with the
representation as listed. They shall report directly to the City Council after
considering the questions referred to them. A committee shall be able to meet
electronically through video conferencing at the Chair’s discretion.
         (A)   Capital Budget and Finance Committee.
            1.   Three members of City Council;
            2.   Mayor;
            3.   Treasurer;
            4.   Controller; and
            5.   Director of Administration.
         (B)   Committee on Historic Preservation.
            1.   Three members of City Council;
            2.   Historic Preservation Officer;
            3.   Director of Administration;
            4.   Director of Community and Economic Development;
            5.   Member of the Historic Architectural Review Board;
            6.   Member of the Historical Museum Society;
            7.   Member from Preservation Williamsport; and
            8.   Member-at-large (appointed by the Committee).
         (C)   Economic Revitalization Committee.
            1.   Three members of City Council;
            2.   Mayor;
            3.   Director of Community and Economic Development; and
            4.   Representative from the Codes Department.
         (D)   Housing Needs Committee.
            1.   Three members of City Council;
            2.   Mayor; and
            3.   Director of Community and Economic Development.
         (E)   Committee on Public Safety.
            1.   Three members of City Council;
            2.   Mayor;
            3.   Director of Administration;
            4.   Police Chief;
            5.   Fire Chief; and
            6.   Director of Public Safety.
         (F)   Committee on Public Works.
            1.   Three members of City Council;
            2.   Mayor;
            3.   Director of Administration; and
            4.   City Engineer.
         (G)   Committee on Transportation Oversight
            1.   Three members of City Council;
            2.   Mayor
            3.   City Controller
            4.   Director of Finance and Administration
            5.   Director of Williamsport Bureau of Transportation / River
Valley Transit
            6.   Chief Financial Officer, Williamsport Bureau of
Transportation/ River Valley Transit
            7.   Controller, Williamsport Bureau of Transportation/ River
Valley Transit
            8.   Compliance Officer, Williamsport Bureau of Transportation/
River Valley Transit
            9.   Member of the WATTS Committee designated by that Committee
      (2)   The three members of City Council and the Chair of each committee
shall be appointed annually by the President of City Council and shall be the
voting members with the presence of at least two members being required for a
vote. The one exception is the Committee on Historic Preservation. In this
instance, each member shall have a vote.
      (3)   A committee shall meet at the request of the President of City
Council or one of its members, the Chair of a committee or the Administration.
The issues to be discussed should be pertinent to the interests of the
committee.
      (4)   Although the City Clerk may assist, the Chair shall be responsible
for:
         (A)   Scheduling all meetings;
         (B)   Verifying with each member their availability;
         (C)   Notifying the City Clerk of the date, time, place and agenda
items in time for the meeting to be properly advertised. Meetings that have
been prescheduled at the beginning of the year and already advertised are the
exceptions to this;
         (D)   Informing the Solicitor’s office that a meeting has been
scheduled; and
         (E)   Seeing that all members of the committee are supplied with all
of the items on the agenda no less than two days in advance to give them the
opportunity to read them and develop questions and/or comments.
      (5)   Although most ordinances and resolutions are prepared by the
Administration, they may also be crafted by a committee at a public session,
followed by a vote, and then a recommendation to City Council.
      (6)   All meetings should be audiotaped so that the discussion and votes
are recorded and the City Clerk can prepare the minutes. Instead of
audiotaping, the minutes may be taken at the time of the meeting.
      (7)   The President of City Council may from time to time appoint an ad
hoc committee of City Council composed of three members of City Council and
other representatives to study an issue and report to City Council. Such a
committee shall follow the same guidelines as a standing committee. After its
work is completed, the committee may be dissolved.
   (o)   Rule 12. Procedure. Robert’s Rules of Order shall govern the
proceedings of Council on all matters not specially provided for herein.
(Res. 2505, approved 2-10-1972; Res. 2969, approved 8-26-1976; Ord. 5423,
approved 7-27-1989; Ord. 5495, approved 8-23-1990; Ord. 5513, approved 2-14-
1991; Ord. 5568, approved 8-27-1992; Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005; Ord. 6050,
approved 1-25-2007; Ord. 6075, approved 9-6-2007; Ord. 6419, approved 12-2-
2021; Ord. 6426, passed 2-17-2022; Ord. 6440, passed 9-1-2022)
§ 111.03 SALARY.
   (a)   The salary of the City Council members, commencing on January 2024, as
follows:
 
                               2024  2025  2026   2027
President of City Council      3,500 3,500 10,500 10,763
Vice President of City Council 3,250 3,250 10,250 10,506
Other members of Council       3,000 3,000 10,000 10,250
 
   (b)   The city shall make available group health insurance through a
Preferred Provider Organization (PPO), which is consistent to what is provided
to employees, for the Council member. Effective January 1, 2020 Council members
whose current term of office started after that date and who elect to receive
health insurance through the city will pay five percent (5%) of the premium for
individual coverage and ten percent (10%) of the difference between the
individual and dependent coverage.
   (c)   The city shall not provide health insurance to members of the City
Council or their dependents as of January 1, 2026. Any member of Council who
elects to continue coverage after that date shall pay to the city the cost of
said coverage.
(Ord. 5767, passed 12-17-1998; Ord. 5897, approved 12-12-2002; Ord. 6013,
approved 12-8-2005; Ord. 6359, approved 3-14-2019, to be effective 4-3-2019;
Ord. 6452, approved 3-2-2023, to be effective 3-22-2023)
§ 111.04 TRAVEL.
   In the event Council provides in any of the city budgets a line item for
travel expenses or if the costs of any proposed travel is to be borne directly
or indirectly by the city, the member of Council seeking reimbursement shall
submit a request in writing prior to the planned event to the President or, in
his absence, the Vice President who shall, after consultation with the Director
of Administration, approve or disapprove the request. If the President of
Council is submitting the request, it shall be presented to the Vice President
of Council. The determination of the President or Vice President of Council
shall be final and binding.
(Ord. 5690, approved 7-11-1996; Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005)

§ 113.01 AUTHORIZING CONTRACTS BY RESOLUTION.
   (a)   The city shall have the power to make contracts for carrying into
execution the provisions of the Optional Third Class City Charter Law, Third
Class City Code, and the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and any other
contracts it may legally make by resolution.
   (b)   This section applies only to contracts in excess of $18,500 unless
amended by law.
   (c)   All contracts heretofore made by the city other than by ordinance, are
hereby ratified and validated.
   (d)   For contracts subject to public bidding the procedure for receipt,
opening and presentation to Council shall be as follows.
      (1)   All bids shall be sealed and submitted to the City Clerk in
accordance with the time deadlines set forth in the advertisements for such
bids.
      (2)   The opening of such bids shall be held at such time and at such
office in City Hall as set forth in the advertisement for bids, shall be
attended by the department head requesting the bid or his or her designee and
the City Clerk and shall be open to the public.
      (3)   (A)   A summary of the bids shall be provided to Council by the
City Clerk. The summary shall set forth the name and address of the bidder, the
amount of the bid and the security for the bid.
         (B)   Section 111.02, Rule 4, which requires all reports and the like
to be submitted to Council at least 12 business hours prior to each Council
meeting shall not be applicable.
(Ord. 5393, approved 6-9-1988; Ord. 5618, passed 2-24-1993; Ord. 6203, approved
12-15-2011)
§ 113.02 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   No rule or regulation, except resolutions and ordinances adopted by
Council, made by any department, office, agency or authority of the city,
except such as relate to the organization or internal management of the city,
shall take effect until approved as to form and legality by the City Solicitor
and approved by the Mayor. Council shall receive all such rules and regulations
which shall be filed with the City Clerk.
   (b)   All rules and regulations shall be published by posting in the office
of the City Clerk for 20 days and in whatever other manner Council deems
desirable.
   (c)   The City Clerk shall keep a current record of all rules and
regulations filed with him or her.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 113.03 DISPOSITION OF CITY PROPERTY BY ORDINANCE OR RESOLUTION.
   No city property, whether real or personal, shall be disposed of by sale,
gift or otherwise, nor shall the same be leased to any person except upon the
approval of Council by ordinance or resolution. This provision shall not apply
to any like exchange or trade-in of parts, components, supplies and the
disposition of scrap or recyclable products when done in the customary or
ordinary operation of city business.
(Ord. 5576, approved 12-21-1992)
§ 113.04 REFERENCES AND PRIOR ORDINANCES.
   (a)   Whenever in any statute of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania or
resolution or ordinance of the city there is a reference to the Department of
Accounts and Finance, the reference shall be construed to mean the Department
of Finance and Personnel. Where there is a reference to the Department of
Streets and Public Improvements, it shall be construed to mean the Department
of Public Services. Where there is a reference to the Department of Public
Affairs or to the Department of Public Safety, the reference shall be construed
to mean the Department of Public Safety.
   (b)   All references in any other ordinances to Council, or any other board,
body or office shall be construed to mean such body, officer or office to which
the respective functions, powers or duties are assigned by this Administrative
Code.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972)
ARTICLE 115: CONTRACTS
Section
   
115.01   Definitions.
   
115.02   Prohibited activities.
   
115.03   Conflict of law.
   
115.99   Violations.
Statutory reference:
   Contracts and purchases, see 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 11901 et seq.
   Public Official and Employee Ethics Act, 65 Pa.C.S. §§ 1101 et seq.
§ 115.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following words and phrases when used in this article shall have, unless
the context clearly indicates otherwise, the meanings given to them in this
section. Otherwise, the definition sections of the Conflicts of Interest Law
shall prevail.
   CONTRACT. An agreement or arrangement for the acquisition, use or disposal
by the city of consulting or other service or of supplies, materials,
equipment, land or other personal or real property. CONTRACT shall not mean an
agreement between the city and a public official or public employee concerning
his or her expense, reimbursement, salary, wage, retirement or other benefit
tenure or other matters in consideration of his or her current public
employment with the city.
   PUBLIC EMPLOYEE. Any individual employed on a full time basis by the city. A
full-time employee is an individual who works at least twenty hours a week or
1,000 hours per year. The term does not include retired or former public
employees who receive a pension or other disability payments from the city.
   PUBLIC OFFICIAL. Any person elected by the public to a city position or who
holds by appointment a city position elected by the public.
(Ord. 5569, approved 9-24-1992)
§ 115.02 PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.
   (a)   No public official or public employee or his or her spouse, parent or
child or any business in which the person or his or her spouse, parent or child
has a financial interest of more than 5% in value of the assets of such
business shall enter into any contract with the city or any subcontract with
the city or any subcontract with any person who has been awarded a contract
with the city.
   (b)   This provision shall not apply to nor prohibit any such person from
bidding on items of real or personal property at any publicly held auction of
the city property.
   (c)   This provision shall not apply to nor prohibit any such person from
participating in any program, loan or grant maintained or administered in whole
or in part by the city, subject to the following limitations:
      (1)   Any contract entered into pursuant to this subsection and which
does not require Council approval shall be reviewed and approved by the head of
the department which administers such program and the Mayor; and
      (2)   In the event the Mayor, Directors of Department or Chiefs of the
Bureau of Police or Fire or their spouses, parents or child have entered into a
contract pursuant to this subsection the contract shall be subject to approval
by Council.
(Ord. 5569, approved 9-24-1992)
§ 115.03 CONFLICT OF LAW.
   (a)   If the provisions of this article conflict with the Conflict of
Interest Law, as currently in effect or as may be amended, the more restrictive
provisions shall apply.
   (b)   If the provisions of this article conflict with any other ordinances,
regulations or rules of the city, the provisions of this article shall control.
(Ord. 5569, approved 9-24-1992)
§ 115.99 VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   Any contract or subcontract made in violation of this article shall be
voidable by the Court of the Common Pleas of Lycoming County if the suit is
commenced within 90 days of the making of the contract or subcontract.
   (b)   Any person who obtains financial gain from violating any provision of
this article, in addition to any other penalty provided by law, shall pay a sum
of money equal to three times the amount of the financial gain resulting from
such violation into the City Treasury.
   (c)   Any defenses available pursuant to the Conflicts of Interest Law may
be asserted for violations alleged to have occurred pursuant to this article.
(Ord. 5569, approved 9-24-1992)
ARTICLE 117: GENERAL FEE SCHEDULE
Section
   
117.01   Title.
   
117.02   Purpose and applicability.
   
117.03   Definitions.
   
117.04   Schedule.
§ 117.01 TITLE.
   This article shall be known as the “Williamsport Fee Schedule Ordinance”.
(Ord. 6088, approved 11-29-2007)
§ 117.02 PURPOSE AND APPLICABILITY.
   It is the purpose of this article to set forth fees representing the
reasonable reimbursement of actual expenses incurred by the city in the
provision of services or material generally affecting the health, safety and
general welfare of the residents of the city and to further consolidate into a
single article fees and charges presently in existence and set forth in prior
legislation. It is intended that this article shall, with respect to the amount
of the fees set forth herein, supersede all prior existing ordinances insofar
as they are contrary to, or in conflict with, the fees set forth in this
article. Further, it is the desire and intent of Council that amendments to the
amounts set forth in this article shall likewise act as an amendment to the
original legislation insofar as the fees set forth in the original legislation
are in conflict with the fees set forth herein.
(Ord. 5586, approved 6-10-1993; Ord. 5907, approved 12-12-2002; Ord. 5949,
approved 4-29-2004; Ord. 6088, approved 11-29-2007)
§ 117.03 DEFINITIONS.
   Unless otherwise expressly stated herein, words and phrases used in this
article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the original enabling
legislation wherein they are contained, as now in force or as hereinafter
amended, supplemented or re-enacted, except where the context clearly indicates
a different meaning.
(Ord. 5586, approved 6-10-1993; Ord. 5907, approved 12-12-2002; Ord. 5949,
approved 4-29-2004; Ord. 6088, approved 11-29-2007)
§ 117.04 SCHEDULE.
   There is hereby established in the city the following schedule of fees and
charges for services rendered or materials supplied that are deemed expedient
or necessary for proper management, care and control of the city and its
finances and for the maintenance of peace, good government, safety and the
general welfare of the city. A building permit is not required for items that

of the items listed.

§ 121.01 DEPARTMENTAL ORGANIZATION.
   The city shall have the following departments under the supervision of the
Mayor:
   (a)   Department of Finance and Administration;
   (b)   Department of Public Safety;
   (c)   Department of Community and Economic Development;
   (d)   Department of Public Works; and
   (e)   Department of Transportation / River Valley Transit.
(Ord. 5086, approved 11-25-1980; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6395,
approved 8-27-2020)
§ 121.02 DEPARTMENT HEADS; APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES.
   Each department may be headed by a director appointed by the Mayor and
approved by majority of all members of Council, solely on the basis of
executive and administrative qualifications appropriate to the duties of each
department. In addition to the duties prescribed in general law, each director
of a department shall, under the direction of the Mayor:
   (a)   Direct the performance of all duties and responsibilities required of
his or her department or its subordinate agencies provided by state law, this
Administrative Code or other city ordinance; and
   (b)   Prescribe the internal organization of the department and the duties
of subordinate officers and employees within the department;
   (c)   Assign functions, powers and duties to subordinate officers and
employees within the department, and modify such assignments as need appears.
   (d)   The Director of each department shall not assume any additional full
or part time positions within city government, including contracted services
with the city, without Council approval.
   (e)   The City Council may recommend the removal of a Director to the Mayor
upon failure to adequately perform their duties.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972; Ord. 5002, passed 12-20-1979; Ord. 5965,
approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6395, approved 8-27-2020)
§ 121.03 ONGOING REVIEW OF DEPARTMENTS.
   (a)   Every year the City Council shall review the department structure of
city government and update accordingly to ensure it properly aligns with the
needs of the city. This review shall be conducted during the annual capital
budget review process.
(Ord. 6395, approved 8-27-2020)

§ 123.01 POWERS AND VACANCY.
   (a)   Executive power. The executive power of the City government shall be
exercised by the Mayor.
   (b)   Appointments and removal. The Mayor shall appoint with the advice and
consent of Council department heads pursuant to Art. IV, § 415 of the Charter
Law. All appointments submitted by the Mayor to Council for approval shall be
submitted at least ten days prior to, and acted upon by Council at its next
stated meeting, if the Mayor so requests. Any employee of a department may be
removed by the head of the department with the approval of the Mayor.
   (c)   Vacancy in office. Vacancies shall be filled in accordance with 53
P.S. § 41414 of the Optional Third Class City Charter Law, being 53 P.S. §§
41101 et seq.
(Ord. 454, approved 2-17-1972)

to employees, for the Mayor. Effective January 1, 2020, if the Mayor elects to
receive health insurance through the city he/she will pay five percent (5%) of
the premium for individual coverage and ten percent (10%) of the difference
between the individual and dependent coverage.

§ 125.01 APPOINTMENT, DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   The City Solicitor shall be appointed annually by Council by a
majority vote of Council.
   (b)   The Solicitor shall have such duties and responsibilities as are set
forth in general law. One or more Assistant City Solicitors may be appointed
annually by Council by a majority vote of Council.
   (c)   The Solicitor(s) shall be responsible for providing general legal
advice and legal services to City Council, the City Administration, the city’s
own offices and the various City Council committees, upon request, and also
during the regular meetings of City Council. The solicitor(s) will be subject
to an annual written contract with the city and additionally governed by the
terms and conditions of that contract.
(Ord. 4530, approved 8-10-1972; Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005)
§ 125.02 MUNICIPAL CLAIMS.
   (a)   The City Solicitor shall be furnished by the heads of the various
departments with statements of claims which remain due and unpaid within 30
days from the date such claims become due and payable.
   (b)   The Solicitor shall enter the claim in the appropriate lien docket.
Upon payment of any claim so entered, the person receiving payment shall
forward to the Solicitor a satisfaction piece, and it shall be the duty of the
Solicitor to cause satisfaction to be entered upon the proper record.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972; Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005)

   The City Clerk shall be appointed by City Council and shall serve until
retirement, resignation or termination by Council. He or she functions as an
employee of City Council and should maintain strict separation from the
functions of the Administration.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972; Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005)
§ 127.02 OPEN RECORDS POLICY.
   (a)   Policy. Effective 1-1-2009, this policy is to provide legal residents
of the United States the right to request, inspect and obtain copies of public
records per Pennsylvania’s Right-to-Know Law. With respect to the policy, the
following requests shall be routed immediately to the City of Williamsport’s
Open Record’s Officer:
      (1)   A “right to know request” or an “open records request”;
      (2)   A request for any document(s) that would not be distributed in the
course of normal, everyday operations;
      (3)   A request for an item or items that may potentially be of a
confidential, proprietary or legal nature;
      (4)   All right-to-know requests shall be forwarded to the City of
Williamsport’s Open Records Officer by 4:30 p.m. on the date the request is
received by any department. Any questions arising from requests for records
must be directed immediately to the Open Records Officer; and
      (5)   In the event a provision of this policy conflicts with the Open
Records Act or any other state or federal law, that portion of the provisions
of this policy shall not apply.
   (b)   General rule.
      (1)   Unless otherwise provided by law, a public record of the city is
accessible for inspection and duplication by a requester in accordance with
this policy. A public record will be provided to a requester in the medium
requested if the public record exists in that medium; otherwise, it will be
provided in the medium in which it exists. Public records will be available for
access during regular business hours. Nothing in this policy will provide for
access to a record which is not a public record.
      (2)   The city will make its public records and copies thereof related to
City Council meeting agendas and city council meeting agenda items available
for inspection in accordance with established guidelines as noted in §
111.02, Rule 5, of the codified ordinances of the City of Williamsport with the
exception of those records exempt from such inspection and copying by law and
city policy.
   (c)   Procedure for access to public records.
      (1)   Requests for access to records may be made verbally or in written
form. If the requester wishes to initiate his or her appeal rights or pursue
the relief and remedies provided for in Right to Know Law, 53 P.S. §§ 67.101 et
seq., the request for access to records must be a written request. The city
will honor all written requests on the form provided by the city [Exhibit A] or
by the State Office of Open Records [Exhibit B] for access to city public
records. Such requests may be submitted in person, by mail, facsimile or email.
The request must be addressed to and received by the Open Records Officer and
must contain the name and address to which the city shall address its response
and a description of the records sought with sufficient specificity to allow
the Open Records Officer to determine which records are being requested. A
written request shall not include any explanation of the requester’s reasons
for the request and shall not include any explanation of the requesters
intended use of the records.
      (2)   When responding to a request for access, the city is not required
to create a public record which does not currently exist or to compile,
maintain, format or organize a public record in a manner in which it does not
currently compile, maintain, format or organize the public record.
      (3)   If a public record is only maintained electronically or in other
non-paper media, the city will, upon request, duplicate the public record on
paper when responding to a request for access in accordance with this policy.
   (d)   Redactions. If the city determines that a public record contains
information which is subject to access, as well as information which is not
subject to access, the city’s response will grant access to the information
which is subject to access and deny access to the information which is not
subject to access. The city will redact from the public record information
which is not subject to access and the response will grant access to the
information which is subject to access.
   (e)   Response to written requests for access.
      (1)   Upon receipt of a written request for access to public records, the
city will make a good faith effort to determine if the record requested is a
public record and will respond as promptly as possible under the circumstances
existing at the time of the request, but no later than five business days from
the date the written request is received by the city. Upon receipt of a
request, the Open Records Officer will:
         (A)   Stamp the date of receipt on the written request;
         (B)   Compute the day on which the five-day period will expire and
make a notation of that date on the written request form;
         (C)   Maintain an electronic or paper copy of the written request
including all documents submitted with the request until the request has been
fulfilled and all potential appeal time frames have expired;
         (D)   If an appeal is filed, keep the records until a final
determination is issued or the appeal is deemed denied; and
         (E)   Create a file and keep all of the following:
            1.   The original request;
            2.   A copy of the response;
            3.   A record of written communications with the requester;
            4.   Appeal made by requester if applicable; and
            5.   Final appeal determination from the State Office of Open
Records if applicable.
      (2)   If the city fails to send the response within five business days of
receipt of the written request for access, the written request for access shall
be deemed denied. The five-day time clock begins the day following receipt by
the city, excluding exceptions as listed below:
         (A)   The request for access requires redaction of a public record;
         (B)   The request for access requires the retrieval of a record stored
in a remote location;
         (C)   A timely response to the request for access cannot be
accomplished due to bona fide and specified staffing limitations;
         (D)   A legal review is necessary to determine whether the record is a
public record subject to access under this policy;
         (E)   The requester has not complied with city policies regarding
access to public records; and
         (F)   The requester refuses to pay applicable fees.
      (3)   If the request falls under any of the above exceptions, the Open
Records Officer will send written notice to the requester within five business
days notifying them that the request for access is being reviewed and requires
the 30-day extension along with the extension ending date. The response shall
include the exception(s) applicable.
   (f)   Denial/partial denial.
      (1)   If the city’s response is a denial or partial denial of a written
request for access, whether in whole or in part, a written response will be
issued and will include:
         (A)   A description of the record requested;
         (B)   The specific reason(s) for the denial, including a citation of
supporting legal authority;
         (C)   The typed or printed name, title, business address, business
telephone number and signature of the Open Records Officer on whose authority
the denial is issued;
         (D)   Date of the response; and
         (E)   The procedure to appeal the denial of access.
      (2)   It is not the intent of this policy to make a document a public
record that is not a public record by law.
   (g)   Open records office appeal.
      (1)   Appeals shall be sent to the below addresses:
 
Submit 2 Copies                Submit 1 Copy
Office of Open Records         Open Records Officer
Commonwealth Keystone Building Office of City Clerk
400 North Street 4th Floor     245 West Fourth Street
Harrisburg PA 17120-0225       Williamsport PA 17701
Fax 717-425-5343               Fax 570-327-7505
Email openrecords@state.pa.us  Email cityclerk@cityofwilliamsport.org
as a Word or PDF attachment    as a Word or PDF attachment
 
      (2)   You must include in your appeal the information as stated below:
         (A)   Your full name, address, telephone and fax number; and
         (B)   A concise statement of relevant facts including:
            1.   The name, title, address, telephone and fax numbers, if known,
of the city and any city official alleged to have denied the requester a right
conferred by the RTKL;
            2.   A description of the records requested;
            3.   The date of the right-to-know request;
            4.   The date of any response or date the response was deemed
denied;
            5.   A statement of the grounds upon which the requester asserts
that the record is a public record;
            6.   A statement addressing any grounds stated by the city for
delaying or denying the request, including any unusual circumstances or
emergency situations that may have contributed to the delay;
            7.   A copy of any pertinent correspondence or other documents; and
            8.   A statement that all material provided by the city has been
submitted with the appeal.
   (h)   Fee schedule. The following fee schedule is in accordance with the
fees as prescribed by the State Office of Open Records. Section 1307 of the
Right-To-Know Law, 53 P.S. § 67.1307 requires the State Office of Open Records
to establish a fee structure for local agencies.

§ 127.03 PUBLIC MEETINGS OF COUNCIL.
   (a)   The City Clerk shall advertise all City Council meetings and City
Council committee meetings as directed by the President or Chair. He or she
will also correlate the agenda and any information packets submitted by
Administration. Deadlines and guidelines are located in the Council
Administrative Code and are also available in the City Clerk’s office.
   (b)   The City Clerk shall be present at all public City Council and Police
Pension Board meetings. He or she will be available to attend City Council
committee meetings as requested by the Chair.
   (c)   The City Clerk will maintain recorded or transcribed minutes of all
City Council and City Council committee meetings. Meeting minutes shall be
transcribed and distributed to the committee members for Council acceptance on
the first Friday packet delivery following the meeting or as soon afterwards as
possible.
(Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005)
§ 127.04 RESPONSIBILITY FOR RECORDS.
   The City Clerk shall be responsible for the retention and preservation of
all resolutions and ordinances that are passed by City Council. He or she will
keep files on all agenda items of the City Council meetings along with the
Council’s meeting minutes.
(Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005)
§ 127.041 OPEN RECORDS OFFICER.
   (a)   The City Clerk is designated as the Open Records Officer (Res. 7642,
dated 12-18-2008) for the City of Williamsport with the contact information as
below:
 
   Open Records Officer
   Office of City Clerk
   245 West Fourth Street
   Williamsport PA 17701
   Phone 570 327-7504
   Fax 570 327-7505
   Email cityclerk@cityofwilliamsport.org
 
   (b)   In the absence of the Open Records Officer, the City Solicitor shall
handle questions and requests pertaining to the same.
(Ord. 6127, approved 3-5-2009)
§ 127.05 ATTESTING/CITY SEAL.
   The City Clerk shall be responsible for attesting to all ordinances,
contracts and agreements along with the signing of all resolutions. He or she
will execute all documents as passed by City Council. Passed ordinances,
executed agreements and contracts attested to shall be sealed by the City
Clerk.
(Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005)

§ 129.01 DUTIES AND BOND.
   (a)   The City Treasurer shall carry out such duties and exercise such
powers with respect to the receipt and disbursement of public moneys as are
provided by general law and, in addition thereto, shall receive for deposit
from the departments of the city government all city moneys collected by such
departments.
   (b)   The Treasurer shall disburse all city funds in accordance with
warrants presented to him or her therefor and duly signed by the City
Controller as approved by the Director of Administration, the head of the city
department or office requesting the disbursement.
   (c)   The City Treasurer is responsible for maintaining the file of
certificates of deposit for the first-time homebuyer’s accounts. The Treasurer
is responsible for closing the accounts when due and delivering the check to
the Community Development Department.
   (d)   The Treasurer shall furnish such fidelity bond and insurance as
required by general law. The fidelity bond and insurance shall be in the amount
recommended by the insurance consultant and set by City Council as is
appropriate due to the combined amount of the duplicates. The Treasurer shall
furnish insurance protection on employees in the amount that is consistent with
the recommendation of the current Tax Collector’s Manual and/or the insurance
consultant for the City of Williamsport.
(Ord. 4731, approved 1-2-1976; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6013,
approved 12-8-2005)
§ 129.02 DEPOSITORIES OF CITY FUNDS.
   The City Treasurer shall deposit all city funds and all city taxes collected
by him or her in such banks or other financial depositories as approved by the
Mayor, the Director of Administration and himself and herself acting as a body
for the designation of city depositories. All such deposits shall be made in
the name of the city.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1992; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6013,
approved 12-8-2005)

§ 131.01 DUTIES AND BOND.
   (a)   The City Controller shall be responsible for the administration of an
encumbrance system of the city budget operation. He or she shall receive from
the Director of Administration and department heads such information regarding
city properties and obligations and city income and expenditures as he or she
deems necessary to carry out these duties. He or she shall furnish the Director
of Administration and other department heads and Council a report concerning
these matters at least monthly and at such other times as deemed necessary.
   (b)   The Controller shall review all warrants for the expenditures of city
moneys and, if satisfied that such expenditures are within the budget allotment
pertaining thereto, shall sign such warrants before they are presented to the
City Treasurer for payment. In so doing, he or she shall also preaudit all
claims and demands against the city prior to payment and shall approve warrants
for payment thereof only if satisfied that such payment is in accordance with
law.
   (c)   The Controller shall give bond to the city as required by general law
in the sum of $2,000.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004)

§ 131.03 AUDIT.
   (a)   The City Controller shall be responsible for procuring a contract with
a reputable auditing firm to conduct the city’s annual audit. The contract will
be subject to City Council’s approval after review and recommendation by the
Finance Committee of City Council.
   (b)   Pursuant to § 421 of the Optional Third Class City Charter Law, Act of
7-5-1957, P.L. 901 (53 P.S. § 41421), all accounts of the city may be audited
following the close of each fiscal year by an independent certified public
accounting firm, with experience in municipal accounting, selected by
resolution of Council.
   (c)   When completed, the annual audit will be reviewed by the Finance
Committee and then referred to City Council for its review and acceptance.

   Department heads; appointment and duties, see Part One, §

§ 135.01 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   The Director of Finance and Administration shall perform the fiscal
and administrative service function for the city, in connection with the
management of the Department of Finance and Human Resources. The areas of
responsibility of this Department will include the supervision of established
standard personnel policies and practices, assisting the Mayor in the
preparation of the budget, administering a purchasing system for all aspects of
city government, maintaining and supervising the city tax program, and
addressing such other matters as may be assigned.
   (b)   The specific areas of city government which will operate under the
responsibility of the Director of Finance and Administration are as follows:
      (1)   Bureau of Budget and Fiscal Affairs;
      (2)   Bureau of Finance & Purchasing;
      (3)   Bureau of Human Resources; and
      (4)   Bureau of Information Technology.
   (c)   The Department of Finance and Administration shall be headed by a
director appointed by the Mayor and approved by majority of all members of
Council, solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications
appropriate to the duties of each bureau.
(Ord. 5086, approved 11-25-1980; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6344,
approved 4-12-2018; Ord. 6395, approved 8-27-2020)
§ 135.02 BUDGET.
   (a)   Pursuant to 53 P.S. §§ 41417 and 41418 of the Optional Third Class
City Charter Law, Act of 7-15-1957, P.L. 901, the city budget shall consist of
the following:
      (1)   General Fund Operating Budget; and
      (2)   Capital Budget.
   (b)   On or before May 1 of each year, the Mayor shall submit a proposed
six-year capital improvement program to the City Planning Commission for its
study and recommendations. On or before June 1 of each year, after receipt of
the report of the Planning Commission, the Mayor shall submit the program to
Council for its approval, incorporating any of the recommendations of the
Planning Commission which the Mayor deems advisable. The program submitted may
be modified by the affirmative vote of five members of Council. Passage of the
six-year capital improvement program by Council shall be subject to annual
revision by Council.
   (c)   (1)   The Director of Finance and Administration shall supervise the
administration of each annual budget. Immediately after the budget has been
enacted and after consultation with the heads of the departments, the Director
of Finance and Administration shall establish a system of appropriations to
each department. At the beginning of each allotment period, the amount
specified shall become available to each department for obligations due that
period.
      (2)   Such allotments for any department may be modified, upon request of
the head of the department, by the Director or by direction of the Mayor. The
Director of Finance and Administration shall file with the City Controller, a
copy of each allotment and modification thereof. An encumbrance system of
accounts to control all expenditures within the limits of budget appropriations
and to control such allotments shall be maintained by the City Controller. If,
at any time during the budget year, the Director shall ascertain the
probability of a cash deficit, he or she shall reconsider the work programs and
allotments of the several offices, departments and agencies. Upon such
reconsideration and with the approval of the Mayor, the Director shall revise
the allotments so as to forestall, so far as possible, the making of
commitments and expenditures in excess of the revenue to be realized during the
fiscal year.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6395,
approved 8-27-2020)
§ 135.03 BUDGET FORM AND TRANSFERS.
   (a)   Form of budget submitted to Council. The Mayor shall submit the
proposed budget to Council as required by 53 P.S. § 41418 of the Optional Third
Class City Charter Law in such a manner that all items of expenditure are
clearly delineated and categorized as to classes and objects of expenditure for
each department and bureau including, but not limited to, salaries for each
position of employment. The foregoing shall be construed to be a line item
budget.
   (b)   Effective date. This section shall apply to the budget of the city
commencing for the year 1974 and thereafter.
   (c)   Transfers by Director of Finance and Administration. Except as may
specifically be spelled out in any budget ordinance or except as to
expenditures from the legislative contingency fund, this section shall not be
construed to prevent transfers by the Director of Finance as provided.
(Ord. 4606, passed over veto 11-8-1973; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord.
6395, approved 8-27-2020)
§ 135.04 APPROPRIATIONS.
   No moneys shall be paid out of the City Treasury except upon appropriation
previously made by Council and upon warrant pursuant thereto, which warrant
shall explicitly state the purpose for which the money is to be drawn. No work
shall be hired to be done, no materials purchased, no contracts made and no
order issued for allotments for the payment of any moneys in any amount which
shall cause the sum appropriated to specific purposes to be exceeded. Council
may make supplemental appropriations for any lawful purpose from funds on hand
or estimated to be received within the fiscal year and not appropriated to any
other purpose. The Director of Finance and Administration shall have the power
to authorize the transfer of any unexpected balance of any appropriation item,
or any portion thereof, within a department; but if the amount transferred is
more than 5% or $500, whichever is greater, of the appropriation item, then the
Director shall not make such transfer without obtaining the approval of at
least four members of Council at a meeting of Council. Expenditures from the
contingency fund shall be made only upon the express approval of Council. All
administrative transfers shall be reported on a quarterly basis to the
Council’s Finance Committee.
(Ord. 4511, approved 2-17-1972; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6395,
approved 8-27-2020)
§ 135.05 CONTRACTS.
   Contracts administration for the city, including, but not limited to,
authority as to preparation of specifications, letting of bids, awarding of
contracts and payment of bills, heretofore vested in Council under 11 Pa.C.S.
§§ 11901 et seq. of the Third Class City Code shall be vested in the Mayor and
the Director of Finance. However, all contracts that are required to be let for
bid by the provisions of the Third Class City Code shall be awarded by Council
in a public meeting to the lowest responsible bidder.
(Ord. 4526, approved 7-27-1972; Ord. 4940, approved 12-14-1978; Ord. 5965,
approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6395, approved 8-27-2020)
§ 135.06 TEMPORARY INVESTMENT OF CITY FUNDS.
   The Mayor, City Treasurer and City Controller acting as a body for the
temporary investment of city funds, shall have the power to provide for such
investment in United States Treasury bills and for the disposal of such
securities when the moneys may be needed, or in savings accounts or share
accounts of institutions insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
or the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to the extent that such
accounts are so insured. It is further ordained that the Director of Finance
shall act as a non-voting member of the above body.
(Ord. 4662, passed over veto 11-14-1974; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord.
6395, approved 8-27-2020)
§ 135.07 RESERVED.
   Editor’s note:
      Former § 135.06, Annual audit, was relocated to §
131.03 by Ord. 6013, approved 12-8-2005.
§ 135.08 PENNSYLVANIA LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL INVESTMENT TRUST.
   (a)   The city shall join with other municipalities in accordance with the
Pennsylvania Intergovernmental Cooperation Act, 53 Pa.C.S. §§ 2301 et seq., by
becoming a settler of the Pennsylvania Local Government Investment Trust (the
Trust) and entering into the Declaration of Trust, which is adopted by
reference with the same effect as if it had been set out verbatim in this
section and a copy of which shall be filed with the minutes of the meeting at
which this section was adopted.
   (b)   The city is authorized to purchase shares in the Trust from time to
time with available municipal funds, and to redeem some or all of those shares
from time to time as funds are needed for municipal purposes. These actions are
to be taken by the officers designated for this purpose, pursuant to general or
specific instructions by Council.
   (c)   The Trustees of the Trust are designated as having official custody of
the city’s funds which are invested by the purchase of shares in the Trust.
   (d)   As required by the Intergovernmental Cooperation Act the following
matters are specifically found and determined:
      (1)   The conditions of the agreement are set forth in the declaration
referred to in subsection (a) hereof;
      (2)   The city’s participation in the Trust shall be terminable at any
time by ordinance;
      (3)   The declaration of trust and the purchase of its shares are for the
purpose of investing the city’s funds in obligations which are otherwise legal
investments as part of a pooled arrangement with other governmental units,
thereby achieving economic and other advantages of pooled investments;
      (4)   It is not necessary to finance the agreement authorized herein from
municipal funds except through the purchase of shares in the Trust;
      (5)   The Trust shall be managed by a board of trustees as set forth in
the declaration of trust and the by-laws provided for therein; and
      (6)   Shares may be purchased and redeemed from time to time as the city
may determine to be necessary or appropriate to meet its cash investment
requirements.
(Ord. 5104, approved 5-14-1981; Ord. 5965, approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6395,
approved 8-27-2020)
§ 135.09 TRUST CREATED FOR WORKERS’ COMPENSATION AND OCCUPATIONAL DISEASE ACTS.
   Editor’s note:
      Former 135.08 was repealed by Ord. 6154, approved 12-10-2009.
§ 135.10 EMERGENCY AND RESERVE FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created and established by the City Council of the
City of Williamsport a cash account within the City Council section of the
General Fund budget and which shall be known as the "Emergency and Reserve
Fund", which account is established to receive and pay out such funds as may be
appropriated in the annual budget for emergency or other urgent circumstances.
   (b)   Investment of funds. Any and all funds appropriated shall be placed in
a separate account by the Office of the City Treasurer and may be invested to
accrue investment income according to §
135.08 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Williamsport.
   (c)   Any tax revenues received by the City Treasurer in excess of the
budgeted amounts in the city's current adopted General Fund budget shall be
transferred into the Emergency and Reserve Fund on or before March 31 of the
subsequent year.
   (d)   Use of funds. Future appropriation of funds from the Emergency and
Reserve Fund shall require a vote of two-thirds of all the members of the
Williamsport City Council.
(Ord. 6447, approved 1-5-2023)
