its decision in writing to the person or persons whose claim has been denied.
The decision shall be final, conclusive and binding on all parties, shall be
written in a manner calculated to be understood by the claimant and shall
contain specific references to the pertinent plan provisions on which the
decision is based.
      (4)   Any notice of a claim questioning the amount of a benefit in pay
status shall be filed within 90 days following the date of the first payment
which would be adjusted if the claim is granted unless the plan administrator
allows a later filing for good cause shown.
      (5)   A claimant who does not submit a notice of a claim or a notice
requesting a review of a denial of a claim within the time limitations
specified above shall be deemed to have waived such claim or right to review.
      (6)   Nothing contained herein is intended to abridge any right of a
claimant to appeal any final decision hereunder to a court of competent
jurisdiction under 2 Pa.C.S.A. § 752. No decision hereunder is a final decision
from which such an appeal may be taken until the entire appeal procedure of
this subsection of the plan has been exhausted.
(Ord. 6176, passed 11-23-2010)
§ 151.11 THE PENSION FUND.
   (a)   Operation of the Pension Fund.
      (1)   The Council of the City of Williamsport is hereby authorized to
hold and supervise the investment of the assets of the Pension Fund, subject to
the provisions of the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and of this plan
and any amendment thereto.
      (2)   The Pension Fund shall be used to pay benefits as provided in the
plan and, to the extent not paid directly by the employer, to pay the expenses
of administering the plan pursuant to authorization by the employer.
      (3)   The employer intends the plan to be permanent and for the exclusive
benefit of its employees. It expects to make the contributions to the Pension
Fund required under the plan. The employer shall not be liable in any manner
for any insufficiency in the Pension Fund; benefits are payable only from the
Pension Fund, and only to the extent that there are monies available therein.
      (4)   The Pension Fund will consist of all funds held by the employer
under the plan, including contributions made pursuant to the provisions hereof
and the investments, reinvestments and proceeds thereof. The Pension Fund shall
be held, managed, and administered pursuant to the terms of the plan. Except as
otherwise expressly provided in the plan, the employer has exclusive authority
and discretion to manage and control the Pension Fund assets. The employer may,
however, appoint a trustee, custodian and/or investment manager, at its sole
discretion.
   (b)   Powers and duties of employer. With respect to the Pension Fund, the
employer shall have the following powers, rights and duties, in addition to
those vested in it elsewhere in the plan or by law, unless such duties are
delegated. Certain specific duties and responsibilities relative to the
investment of the fund shall be delegated pursuant to a separate investment
policy statement adopted by the Board, as amended from time to time.
      (1)   To retain in cash so much of the Pension Fund as it deems advisable
and to deposit any cash so retained in any bank or similar financial
institution (including any such institution which may be appointed to serve as
trustee hereunder), without liability for interest thereon;
      (2)   To invest and reinvest the principal and income of the fund and
keep said fund invested, without distinction between principal and income, in
securities which are at the time legal investments for fiduciaries under the
Pennsylvania Fiduciaries Investment Act, or as the same may be subsequently
modified or amended;
      (3)   To sell property held in the fund at either public or private sale
for cash or on credit at such times as it may deem appropriate; to exchange
such property; to grant options for the purchase or exchange thereof;
      (4)   To consent to and participate in any plan of reorganization,
consolidation, merger, extension or other similar plan affecting property held
in the fund; to consent to any contract, lease, mortgage, purchase, sale or
other action by any corporation pursuant to any such plan;
      (5)   To exercise all conversion and subscription rights pertaining to
property held in the fund;
      (6)   To exercise all voting rights with respect to property held in the
fund and in connection therewith to grant proxies, discretionary or otherwise;
      (7)   To place money at any time in a deposit bank deemed to be
appropriate for the purposes of this plan no matter where situated, including
in those cases where a bank has been appointed to serve as trustee hereunder,
the savings department of its own commercial bank;
      (8)   In addition to the foregoing powers, the employer shall also have
all of the powers, rights, and privileges conferred upon trustees by the
Pennsylvania Fiduciaries Investment Act, or as the same may be subsequently
modified or amended, and the power to do all acts, take all proceedings and
execute all rights and privileges, although not specifically mentioned herein,
as the employer may deem necessary to administer the Pension Fund;
      (9)   To maintain and invest the assets of this plan on a collective and
commingled basis with the assets of other pension plans maintained by the
employer, provided that the assets of each respective plan shall be accounted
for and administered separately;
      (10)   To invest the assets of the Pension Fund in any collective
commingled trust fund maintained by a bank or trust company, including any bank
or trust company which may act as a trustee hereunder. In this connection, the
commingling of the assets of this plan with assets of other eligible,
participating plans through such a medium is hereby specifically authorized.
Any assets of the plan which may be so added to such collective trusts shall be
subject to all of the provisions of the applicable declaration of trust, as
amended from time to time, which declaration, if required by its terms or by
applicable law, is hereby adopted as part of the plan, to the extent of the
participation in such collective or commingled trust fund by the plan;
      (11)   To make any payment or distribution required or advisable to carry
out the provisions of the plan, provided that if a trustee is appointed by the
employer, such trustee shall make such distribution only at the direction of
the employer;
      (12)   To compromise, contest, arbitrate, enforce or abandon claims and
demands with respect to the plan;
      (13)   To retain any funds or property subject to any dispute without
liability for the payment of interest thereon, and to decline to make payment
or delivery thereof until final adjudication is made by a court of competent
jurisdiction;
      (14)   To pay, and to deduct from and charge against the Pension Fund,
any taxes which may be imposed thereon, whether with respect to the income,
property or transfer thereof, or upon or with respect to the interest of any
person therein, which the fund is required to pay; to contest, in its
discretion, the validity or amount of any tax, assessment, claim or demand
which may be levied or made against or in respect of the Pension Fund, the
income, property or transfer thereof, or in any matter or thing connected
therewith;
      (15)   To appoint any persons or firms (including but not limited to,
accountants, investment advisors, counsel, actuaries, physicians, appraisers,
consultants, professional plan administrators and other specialists), or
otherwise act to secure specialized advice or assistance, as it deems necessary
or desirable in connection with the management of the fund; to the extent not
prohibited by applicable law, the employer shall be entitled to rely
conclusively upon and shall be fully protected in any action or omission taken
by it in good faith reliance upon, the advice or opinion of such persons or
firms, provided such persons or firms were prudently chosen by the employer,
taking into account the interests of the participants and beneficiaries and
with due regard to the ability of the persons or firms to perform their
assigned functions; and
      (16)   To retain the services of one or more persons or firms for the
management of (including the power to acquire and dispose of) all or any part
of the fund assets, provided that each of such persons or firms is registered
as an investment advisor under the Investment Advisors Act of 1940, is a bank
(as defined in that act), or is an insurance company qualified to manage,
acquire or dispose of pension trust assets under the laws of more than one
state; in such event, the employer shall follow the directions of such
Investment Manager or Managers with respect to the acquisition and disposition
of fund assets, but shall not be liable for the acts or omissions of such
investment manager or managers, nor shall it be under any obligation to review
or otherwise manage any fund assets which are subject to the management of such
investment manager or managers. If the employer appoints a trustee, the trustee
shall not be permitted to retain such an investment manager, except with the
express written consent of the employer.
   (c)   Common investments. The employer shall not be required to make
separate investments for individual participants or to maintain separate
investments for each participant’s account, but may invest contributions and
any profits or gains therefrom in common investments.
   (d)   Compensation and expenses of appointed trustee. If a trustee is
appointed, the trustee shall be entitled to such reasonable compensation as
shall from time to time be agreed upon by the employer and the trustee, unless
such compensation is prohibited by law. Such compensation, and all expenses
reasonably incurred by the trustee in carrying out his functions, shall
constitute a charge upon the employer or the Pension Fund, which may be
executed at any time after 30 days written notice to the employer. The employer
shall be under no obligation to pay such costs and expenses, and, in the event
of its failure to do so, the trustee shall be entitled to pay the same, or to
reimburse themselves for the payment thereof, from the Pension Fund.
   (e)   Periodic accounting. If a trustee is appointed, the Pension Fund shall
be evaluated annually, or at more frequent intervals, by the trustee and a
written accounting rendered as of each fiscal year end of the fund, and as of
the effective date of any removal or resignation of the trustee, and such
additional dates as requested by the employer, showing the condition of the
fund and all receipts, disbursements and other transactions effected by the
trustee during the period covered by the accounting, based on fair market
values prevailing as of such date.
   (f)   Value of the Pension Fund. All determinations as to the value of the
assets of the Pension Fund, and as to the amount of the liabilities thereof,
shall be made by the employer or its appointed trustee, whose decisions shall
be final and conclusive and binding on all parties hereto, the participants and
Beneficiaries and their estates. In making any such determination, the employer
or trustee shall be entitled to seek and rely upon the opinion of or any
information furnished by brokers, appraisers and other experts, and shall also
be entitled to rely upon reports as to sales and quotations, both on security
exchanges and otherwise as contained in newspapers and in financial
publications.
(Ord. 6176, passed 11-23-2010)
§ 151.12 AMENDMENT AND TERMINATION.
   (a)   Amendment of the plan. The employer may amend this plan at any time or
from time to time by an instrument in writing executed in the name of the
employer under its municipal seal by officers duly authorized to execute such
instrument and delivered to the Council; provided, however:
      (1)   That no amendment shall deprive any participant or any beneficiary
of a deceased participant of any of the benefits to which each is entitled
under this plan with respect to contributions previously made;
      (2)   That no amendment shall provide for the use of funds or assets held
under this plan other than for the benefit of employees and no funds
contributed to this plan or assets of this plan shall, except as provided in
subsection (e), ever revert to or be used or enjoyed by the employer; and
      (3)   That no amendment to the plan which provides for a benefit
modification shall be made unless the cost estimate described in §
151.13(c) has been prepared and presented to the Council in accordance with the
Act.
   (b)   Termination of the plan. The employer shall have the power to
terminate this plan in its entirety at any time by an instrument in writing
executed in the name of the employer.
   (c)   Automatic termination of contributions. Subject to the provisions of
the Act governing financially distressed municipalities, the liability of the
employer to make contributions to the Pension Fund shall automatically
terminate upon liquidation or dissolution of the employer, upon its
adjudication as a bankrupt or upon the making of a general assignment for the
benefit of its creditors.
   (d)   Distribution upon termination.
      (1)   In the event of the termination of the plan, all amounts of vested
benefits accrued by the affected participants as of the date of such
termination, to the extent funded on such date, shall be non-forfeitable
hereunder. In the event of termination of the plan, the employer shall direct
either:
         (A)   That the plan administrator continue to hold the vested accrued
benefits of participants in the Pension Fund in accordance with the provisions
of the plan (other than those provisions related to forfeitures) without regard
to such termination until all funds have been distributed in accordance with
the provisions; or
         (B)   That the plan administrator immediately distribute to each
participant an amount equal to the vested accrued benefit to the date.
      (2)   If there are insufficient assets in the Pension Fund to provide for
all vested accrued benefits as of the date of plan termination, priority shall
first be given to the distribution of any amounts attributable to mandatory or
voluntary employee contributions before assets are applied to the distribution
of any vested benefits attributable to other sources hereunder.
      (3)   All other assets attributable to the terminated plan shall be
distributed and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of applicable law
and the terms of any instrument adopted by the employer which effects such
termination.
   (e)   Residual assets. If all liabilities to vested participants and any
others entitled to receive a benefit under the terms of the plan have been
satisfied and there remain any residual assets in the Pension Fund, such
residual assets remaining shall be returned to the employer insofar as such
return does not contravene any provision of law, and any remaining balance, in
excess of employer contributions, shall be returned to the commonwealth.
   (f)   Exclusive benefit rule. In the event of the discontinuance and
termination of the plan as provided herein, the employer shall dispose of the
Pension Fund in accordance with the terms of the plan and applicable law; at no
time prior to the satisfaction of all liabilities under the plan shall any part
of the corpus or income of the Pension Fund, after deducting any administrative
or other expenses properly chargeable to the Pension Fund, be used for or
diverted to purposes other than for the exclusive benefit of the participants
in the plan, their beneficiaries or their estates.
(Ord. 6176, passed 11-23-2010)
§ 151.13 FUNDING STANDARD REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Actuarial valuations.
      (1)   The plan’s actuary shall perform an actuarial valuation at least
biennially. Such biennial actuarial valuation report shall be made as of the
beginning of each plan year occurring in an odd-numbered calendar year,
beginning with the year 1985. Such actuarial valuation shall be prepared and
certified by an approved actuary, as such term is defined in the Act.
      (2)   The expenses attributable to the preparation of any actuarial
valuation report or experience investigation required by the Act or any other
expense which is permissible under the terms of the Act and which are directly
associated with administering the plan shall be an allowable administrative
expense payable from the assets of the Pension Fund. Such allowable expenses
shall include but not be limited to the following:
         (A)   Investment costs associated with obtaining authorized
investments and investment management fees;
         (B)   Accounting expenses;
         (C)   Premiums for insurance coverage on fund assets;
         (D)   Reasonable and necessary counsel fees incurred for advice or to
defend the fund; and
         (E)   Legitimate travel and education expense for pension plan
officials; provided, however, that the municipal officials of the employer, in
their fiduciary role, shall monitor the services provided to the plan to ensure
that the expenses are necessary, reasonable and benefit the pension plan and,
further provided, that the plan administrator shall document all such expenses
item by item, and where necessary, hour by hour.
   (b)   Duties of Chief Administrative Officer.
      (1)   Such actuarial reports shall be prepared and filed under the
supervision of the Chief Administrative Officer.
      (2)   The Chief Administrative Officer of the plan shall determine the
financial requirements of the plan on the basis of the most recent actuarial
report and shall determine the minimum municipal obligation of the employer
with respect to funding the plan for any given plan year. The Chief
Administrative Officer shall submit the financial requirements of the plan and
the minimum municipal obligation of the employer to the Council annually and
shall certify the accuracy of such calculations and their conformance with the
Act.
   (c)   Benefit modifications. Prior to the adoption of any benefit plan
modification by the employer, the Chief Administrative Officer of the plan
shall provide to the Council a cost estimate of the proposed benefit plan
modification. Such estimate shall be prepared by an approved actuary, which
estimate shall disclose to the Council the impact of the proposed benefit plan
modification on the future financial requirements of the plan and the future
minimum municipal obligation of the employer with respect to the plan.
(Ord. 6176, passed 11-23-2010)
§ 151.14 MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Employment rights. Participation in this plan shall not give any right
to any employee to be retained in the employ of the employer nor shall it
interfere with the right of the employer to discharge any employee and to deal
with such employee without regard to the effect that such treatment might have
upon participation in this plan.
   (b)   Meaning of certain words. As used herein the masculine gender shall
include the feminine gender and the singular shall include the plural in all
cases where such meaning would be appropriate. Headings of articles and
sections are inserted only for convenience of reference and are not to be
considered in the construction of the plan.
   (c)   Information to be furnished by the employer. The employer shall
furnish to the plan administrator (and where applicable, the trustee)
information in the employer’s possession as the plan administrator and the
trustee shall require from time to time to perform their duties under the plan.
   (d)   Severability of provisions. Should any provisions of this plan be held
illegal or invalid for any reason, said illegality or invalidity shall not
affect the remaining parts of this plan, and the plan shall be construed and
enforced as if said illegal and invalid provisions had never been inserted
herein.
(Ord. 6176, passed 11-23-2010)
ARTICLE 152: POLICE BENEFITS
[Repealed]
Editor’s note:
   Former Art. 152 consisting of §§ 152.01 to 152.09 was repealed by Ord. 5342,
approved 2-12-1987.

Editor’s Note:
   Ord. 4744, approved 4-9-1976, as amended by Ord. 4771, approved 9-13-1976,
authorized the Fidelity National Bank of Pennsylvania to be corporate custodian
of the Police Pension Fund.
Statutory reference:
   Law provisions, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 14301 et seq.
§ 153.01 CREATION OF FUND; CONFLICT OF LAW.
   There is hereby created a police retirement fund in the city to be known as
the Police Retirement Fund which is to be administered in accordance with the
laws of third class cities that relate to police officers’ pension funds and in
accordance with the provisions of
Art. 153. Where the provisions of
Art. 153 are inconsistent with the police pension laws of third class cities
the provisions of third class city law shall prevail.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.02 REGULATION BY COUNCIL.
   (a)   The Police Retirement Fund shall be under the direction of Council and
applied under regulations as Council, by this article or subsequent ordinances,
may prescribe for the benefit of such members of the Police Bureau as received
honorable discharge by reason of age or disability and the families of such as
may be injured or killed in the service. Such age shall be in conformity with a
uniform scale.
   (b)   In addition to the members of Council serving as the Police Pension
Board, one member of the Police Bureau, to be chosen by the members of the
Police Bureau shall serve on the Board.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.03 ELIGIBILITY.
   The fund shall be used for the relief and pensioning of the members of the
Police Bureau, including the Chief of Police, captains of police, lieutenants
of police, captain of detectives and police detectives, sergeants, inspectors
of police, police woman or police women and all other ranks now or in the
future to be attached to the Police Bureau or their respective dependents, to
wit: for the benefit of such members of the Police Bureau as received honorable
discharge from the Police Bureau by reason of age or disability and the
families of such as may be injured or killed in the service. Allowance shall be
made to those who are retired by reason of the disabilities of age in
conformity with a uniform scale. No person shall be eligible for any allowance
from the fund, except those regularly in the service of the Police Bureau and
who give their time exclusively to the work of the Police Bureau or their
dependents.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.04 SERVICE AND AGE REQUIREMENTS.
   Every member of the Police Bureau may retire at the age of 50 years after 20
years of service. Retirement shall be mandatory for all police officers, except
the Chief of Police, who have attained the age of 60 years. Any police officer
after attaining 20 years of service may leave the force and his or her pension
rights are vested at that time and shall begin collecting retirement benefits
at the age of 50. Should an officer die after attaining 20 years of service,
but before attaining the age of 50 years, his or her widow and dependent
children would collect retirement benefits in the same manner as if he or she
were on pension at the time of his or her death. Members so retired shall be
subject to service from time to time as a police reserve until unfitted for
such service when he may be fully discharged by reason of age or disability.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.05 EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTION; PAYROLL DEDUCTION.
   (a)   For the support and increase of the revenues of the fund, there shall
be deducted from the monthly compensation of each member of the Police Bureau a
sum which shall be 4% of the month’s compensation to include overtime of each
of the members. The sum shall be deducted from each monthly pay by the City
Treasurer. The Treasurer shall cause the same to be paid into the Police
Retirement Fund and shall report the payment to the Director of Finance and
Personnel and the City Controller. No member of the Police Bureau shall be
entitled to any benefits of any retirement allowance who has not made the
monthly payments provided by this article or any past pension or retirement
ordinance.
   (b)   Each contributor, from and after the effective date of this section,
shall pay into the retirement fund a monthly service increment sum in addition
to his or her retirement contribution, which shall be equal to 0.5% of his or
her salary. However, such payment shall not exceed the sum of $1 per month, and
such service increment contribution shall not be paid after a contributor has
reached the age of 65 years.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.06 RETIREMENT PAYMENTS; SERVICE INCREMENT.
   (a)   Payments made under the provisions of this article shall not be a
charge on any other fund in the Treasury of the city or under its control,
except the Police Retirement Fund. The basis of apportionment of the fund shall
be determined by rate of the last 365 days of the members at the date of death,
honorable discharge or retirement and shall not in any case exceed in any year
one-half of the annual pay of each member computed at such monthly rate.
   (b)   In addition to the retirement allowance which is authorized to be paid
from the Police Pension Fund by this article, and not withstanding the
limitations placed upon such retirement allowances and upon contributions,
every contributor who becomes entitled to the retirement allowance shall also
be entitled to the payment of a service increment in accordance with and
subject to the conditions hereinafter set forth.
   (c)   Service increment shall be the sum obtained by computing the number of
whole years after having served the minimum required by this article during
which a contributor has been employed by the city and paid out of the City
Treasury and multiplying the number of years so computed by an amount equal to
one-fortieth of the retirement allowance which has become payable to such
contributor in accordance with the provisions of this article. In computing the
service increment, no employment after the contributor has reached the age of
65 years shall be included, and no service increment shall be paid in excess of
$100 per month.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.07 COMPUTATION OF ALLOWANCE.
   The retirement allowances granted to members of the Police Bureau shall be
paid monthly and shall be at the rate of one-half of the last 365 days pay of
the member as of the date of death, honorable discharge or retirement, or one-
half of the highest average annual salary which the member received during any
five years of service preceding injury, death, honorable discharge or
retirement, whichever is the higher, but shall not, in any case, exceed in any
year one-half the annual pay for such member computed at such last 365 days or
average annual rate, whichever is the higher. This limitation shall not apply
to the service increment provided for in § 153.06.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.08 BENEFITS TO SPOUSE, DEPENDENT CHILD.
   In situations where the determination is made by the Police Pension Board
that the spouse of a member of the police force or of a member who retires on
pension and dies or, if no spouse survives or if he or she survives and
subsequently dies, then the child or children under the age of 18 years of a
member of the police force or of a member who retires on pension who dies is
deemed eligible for pension benefits under this article, appropriated state
statutes and the rules and regulations of the Police Pension Board, then the
aforesaid eligible person shall be entitled to receive a pension calculated at
the rate of 50% of the pension the member was receiving or would have been
receiving had he or she been retired at the time of his or her death.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.09 APPLICATION PROCEDURE.
   (a)   Any member of the Police Bureau who has completed at least 20 years of
service in the Police Bureau and has reached the age of 50 years shall have the
right to make application to be placed upon the eligible list.
   (b)   Upon the application being filed with the City Clerk, the City Clerk
shall transmit it immediately to Council. When Council is satisfied that the
applicant has completed at least 20 years of service and has attained the age
of 50 years, it shall pass a resolution that it is satisfied the applicant has
completed at least 20 years of service and has attained the age of 50 years,
whereupon the City Clerk shall endorse the application by placing thereon a
copy of the resolution passed by Council.
   (c)   The City Clerk shall notify the applicant that his application has
been approved and that he or she has been placed upon the eligible list.
   (d)   Any member of the Police Bureau who desires to make application for
retirement under the terms of §
153.12 shall file their application in writing with the City Clerk. The
application shall set forth in detail the facts showing that the applicant is
entitled to retirement under the terms of §
153.12; the City Clerk shall transmit immediately the application to Council.
When Council is satisfied that the applicant qualifies for retirement under the
terms of §
153.12, it shall pass a resolution setting forth this fact and place the
applicant upon the eligible retirement list. The City Clerk shall endorse the
application by placing thereon a copy of the resolution passed by Council. The
City Clerk shall notify the applicant that this application has been approved
and that he or she has been placed upon the eligible retirement list.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.10 FORMS.
   All applications under this article are to be made on blank forms which
shall be furnished by the City Clerk.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.11 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   Benefit and retirement allowances shall be paid only after compliance with
the provisions of this article relative to application for such benefit or
retirement allowances and when such benefit or retirement allowances has been
granted by Council.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.12 RIGHT TO APPLY FOR INJURY RETIREMENT.
   Any member of the Police Bureau shall be entitled to apply for retirement if
he or she is permanently incapacitated from discharging the duties of his or
her position by reason of an injury received or by sickness or disease
contracted while a member of the Police Bureau and while in the actual
discharge of his or her duties as a member of the Police Bureau.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.13 INJURY REPORT.
   The fact of an injury, together with a statement of its nature and cause and
the names and addresses of any witnesses, were reported in writing by the
person receiving the injury or his or her authorized agent to the City Clerk
within ten days after the injury was received. The City Clerk shall immediately
transmit any notices of injury and applications for retirement to Council.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.14 ELIGIBILITY OF DEPENDENTS FOR BENEFITS.
   The spouse and the dependent child or children, under the age of 18, of the
member of the Police Bureau who was killed while in actual discharge of his or
her duties or who died after being injured from the effect of an injury or
injuries received while a member of the Police Bureau and while in the actual
discharge of his or her duties or by reason of sickness or disease contracted
while in line of his or her duty shall be entitled to apply for a benefit.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.15 APPLICATION BY SURVIVORS FOR BENEFITS.
   (a)   Application pursuant to §
153.14 shall, in order to receive consideration, be presented not later than
six months after the death of the member through whom the claim is based, but
Council may, when the application is presented, agree to consider an
application after the expiration of the six-month period provided just cause is
shown for the failure to make application within the specified time.
   (b)   The spouse or child, 18 or under, of a member who was killed while in
actual discharge of his or her duties or who died from the effects of an injury
or injuries received or from the effects of a sickness or disease contracted
while a member and while in the actual discharge of his or her duty, shall be
entitled to apply for a benefit. Such application shall be filed with the City
Clerk, and it shall be the duty of the City Clerk to transmit the application
to Council who shall consider the application and either approve the same or
deny the same as soon as reasonably possible. Council shall have the right to
require the spouse and child under 18 file with their respective applications,
certified copies of the certificate of death, marriage or birth, either or all,
as may in each case be required. Should the applicant be unable to furnish
certified copies of such certificates, then Council shall have the right to
require the applicant to furnish evidence and affidavits from at least two
disinterested persons in proof of the death, marriage or birth, either or all,
as may in each case be required.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.16 CESSATION OF MEMBERSHIP; REFUND AND REINSTATEMENT; DEATH.
   If for any cause any member of the police force contributing to the Pension
Fund ceases to be a member of the force before he or she becomes entitled to a
pension, the total amount of the contributions paid into the Pension Fund by
such member shall be refunded to him or her in full without interest. If any
such member has returned to him or her the amount contributed and afterward
again becomes a member of the police force, he or she shall not be entitled to
the pension designated until 20 years after his or her re-employment, unless he
returns to the Pension Fund the amount withdrawn, in which even the period of
20 years shall be computed from the time member first became a member of the
police force, excluding therefrom any period of time during which the member
was not employed by the police force. In the event of the death of a member of
the police force not in line of service before the member becomes entitled to
the pension aforesaid and such member is not survived by a spouse or child
under 18 and estate entitled to payments as hereinbefore provided, the total
amount of contributions paid into the Pension Fund by the member shall be paid
over to his or her estate.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.17 AFFIDAVITS TO BE FILED BY DEPENDENTS.
   (a)   In the months of January and July of each and every year, there shall
be filed with the City Clerk the following affidavit: from each parent or
guardian of minor members of the family of the deceased member of the Police
Bureau, an affidavit that the benefit receivers are living and that the minor
has not reached the age of 18.
   (b)   The failure or the refusal of the surviving spouse, parent or guardian
member of the family to file such affidavits before January 31 and July 31, as
required, shall cause a suspension of the benefits until such time as the
required affidavits have been filed.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.18 CITY APPROPRIATIONS.
   For the further support and increase of revenues of the Police Retirement
Fund, the city shall make an annual appropriation each year. The appropriation
shall be sufficient, when added to the contribution made by members of the
Police Bureau during the year, income from investments during the year and
payment received from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania during the year to pay
in full the retirement allowances payable during the year.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.19 FUND TO GET BUREAU REWARDS, GIFTS.
   There shall be placed in the Police Retirement Fund all bequests, gifts or
donations made to the fund, funds subscribed by the public, rewards offered by
the city or any individuals of the city, paid or given to the Police Bureau or
any member thereof for or on account of services of the Bureau or its members
for the performance of their duty.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.20 FUNDS; USE.
   The Police Retirement Fund shall be kept separate and apart from any other
funds of the city in a special account. No money shall be paid out of the fund,
except for the purpose of relief or pensions for the members of the Police
Bureau or their dependents, as contemplated in this article. Nothing contained
in this section shall be construed to prevent Council from investing or re-
investing moneys in the Police Retirement Fund in what is known as legal
investments for trust funds in Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.21 POLICE RETIREMENT FUND COMMISSION; CREATION; DUTIES.
   There is hereby created a Police Retirement Fund Commission composed of the
Mayor, City Treasurer and the Director of Finance and Personnel. It shall be
the duty of this Commission to register all persons employed as police
officers, to administer the collection and distribution of the funds herein
provided for, including interpretation of the provisions of the plans and the
eligibility requirements, give notification to the corporate custodian’s
duties.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.22 FUND CUSTODY AND CONTROL.
   The fund shall at all times be under the direction and control of the
Council, but the fund may be committed to the custody and investment management
of such officers of the city or citizens thereof, or corporations located
therein, as may be designated by Council by resolution authorizing the entry
into a contract for investment management purposes. In the event Council enters
into a contract for investment management purposes, Council shall retain the
right to pass regulations for investment management by duly enacted ordinance.
The officers, citizens or corporations vested with the right of investment
management shall have the investment powers with respect to the assets of the
aforesaid fund and may invest, re-invest and keep invested the principal and
earnings of the fund, in such stocks, bonds, securities, investments and other
evidences of indebtedness as may be deemed prudent. However, all such
investments shall be confined to those investments termed legal investments.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.23 CREDIT FOR SERVICE IN ARMED FORCES.
   (a)   Any qualified member of the Bureau of Police shall be entitled to have
full credit toward the calculation of retirement benefits for each year or
fraction thereof, not to exceed five years, for active service in the armed
forces of the United States.
   (b)   Such credit to be granted at the time of retirement, subject to the
laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, relating to pensions.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.24 LIMITED VESTING.
   A police officer shall have vested rights in the Pension Plan after 12 years
of service as set forth in § 4302.1 of the Third Class City Code.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.25 COLA.
   Pension will be subject to a cost-of-living adjustment based on increases in
the CPI-W for the year prior to the request in question. Cost-of-living
adjustments will be based on the CPI-W index for the prior year, October to
October, if available or the nearest available month if not, subject to an
annual cap of 3.5% and a lifetime cap of 35%. The pension calculation will also
be subject to any other limitations of the Third Class City Code, including the
limitation that the pension shall not exceed 50% of the highest paid member of
the Department, for any member retiring on or after 1-1-1998.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 153.26 MINIMUM BENEFIT.
   (a)   The Policemen’s Pension Fund will, in addition to any other payments
authorized or required by law, pay police officers retirees an additional
benefit as defined below.
   (b)   The benefit shall be calculated based on a figure of $20 per month for
each year of retirement for eligible members.
   (c)   Eligible members shall be limited as follows:
      (1)   Only those retirees who began receiving a retirement benefit on or
before 1-1-1989, are eligible;
      (2)   Only those retirees whose present benefit is less than $500 per
month are eligible; and
      (3)   The additional pension sum hereby authorized is available only to
the extent that the total pension benefit received by each eligible member from
all sources of the plan shall not exceed $500 per month.
(Ord. 5843, approved 2-15-2001)
ARTICLE 155: FIREMEN’S PENSION FUND
Section
   
155.01   Established; conflict of laws.
   
155.02   Employee contribution; payroll deduction.
   
155.03   City appropriations.
   
155.04   Board of Managers; members and term.
   
155.05   Eligibility for fund.
   
155.06   Mandatory retirement.
   
155.07   Financial report to Council.
   
155.08   Service and age requirements.
   
155.09   Fund custody, control and management.
   
155.10   Payments from Fund only.
   
155.11   Retirement payments; service increment.
   
155.12   Surviving spouse benefits.
   
155.13   Credit for service in armed forces.
   
155.14   Limited vesting.
   
155.15   COLA.
   
155.16   Minimum benefit.
Cross-reference:
   Transfer between pension plans, see Part One, §§
151.11 et seq.
Statutory reference:
   State law provisions, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 14319 et seq.
§ 155.01 ESTABLISHED; CONFLICT OF LAWS.
   There is hereby established a Firemen’s Pension Fund to be administered in
accordance with this article and the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania
as amended. Should there be any conflict in the terms of this article with the
laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, the terms of the state law shall
prevail.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.02 EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTION; PAYROLL DEDUCTION.
   The Firemen’s Pension Fund shall be maintained in part by the deduction of
5% from the regular compensation of each member of the Fire Bureau.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.03 CITY APPROPRIATIONS.
   For the further support and increase of revenues of the Fire Pension Fund,
the city shall make an annual appropriation each year. The appropriation shall
be sufficient, when added to the contribution made by members of the Fire
Bureau during the year, income from investments during the year and payment
received from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania during the year to pay in full
the retirement allowances payable during the year.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.04 BOARD OF MANAGERS; MEMBERS AND TERM.
   The fund shall be under the direction and control of a Board of Managers
consisting of the Mayor, the Director of Finance and Personnel, the Director of
Public Safety, the City Controller, the Chief of the Bureau of Fire, ex
official and two members of the Fire Bureau to be chosen by the members of the
Fire Bureau. The terms of the latter two shall be four years and their terms
shall be staggered so that each term shall expire every second year. In case of
vacancy among the members chosen by the Fire Bureau, a successor shall be
chosen for the unexpired term.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.05 ELIGIBILITY FOR FUND.
   The fund shall be applied, under such regulations as the Board of Managers
shall prescribe, for the benefit of such members of the Fire Bureau as receive
honorable discharge therefrom by reason of service, age or disability, widows
or retired members and the families of such as may be killed or who die in the
service.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.06 MANDATORY RETIREMENT.
   When any member has reached the age of 60 years, he shall be retired
automatically by the Board of Managers of the Firemen’s Pension Fund, except
the Chief who shall be automatically retired at the age of 65.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.07 FINANCIAL REPORT TO COUNCIL.
   An annual financial report showing income, disbursements and pensions paid
and to whom shall be represented to Council by the Board of Managers no later
than February 28 each year.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.08 SERVICE AND AGE REQUIREMENTS.
   Subject to such regulations as the Board of Managers of the Firemen’s
Pension Fund shall prescribe, which regulations shall be consistent with this
section, a firefighter may retire after 20 years service before attaining the
age of 50 years with the understanding that his or her pension payments shall
not commence until the member attains the age of 50 years. If any such
firefighter retires and dies thereafter and leaves survivors such as a spouse
or child under 18 entitled to receive benefits, the benefits for such surviving
spouse or dependents shall not commence until the time that such firefighter
would have attained the age of 50 years had he or she survived.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.09 FUND CUSTODY, CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT.
   The Firemen’s Pension Fund shall at all times be under the direction and
control of the Board of Managers of the Firemen’s Pension Fund, but the Board
shall be vested with the power to commit the fund to the custody and management
of such officers of the city, or citizens thereof or corporations located
therein, as may be designated by the Board by resolution. The power to delegate
the custody and management shall include the power to delegate investment
management with respect to the fund, and the custodian may be vested with the
power to invest, re-invest and keep invested the assets of the fund, in such
stocks, bonds, securities, investments and other evidence of indebtedness as
the custodian may deem prudent. However, all investments shall be confined to
those investments termed legal investments.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.10 PAYMENTS FROM FUND ONLY.
   Payments of pension shall not be charged on any fund in the Treasury of the
City or under its control save the Firemen’s Pension Fund as hereinbefore
provided.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.11 RETIREMENT PAYMENTS; SERVICE INCREMENT.
   (a)   The basis of the pension of a member shall be determined by the
monthly salary of the member at the date of retirement or the highest average
annual salary which he or she received during any five years of service
preceding retirement, whichever is the higher, whether such pension is awarded
for disability or by reason of age or service, and except as to service
increments as hereinafter provided, the pension awarded shall be one-half the
annual salary of such member at the time of retirement computed as such monthly
or average annual rate, whichever is the higher.
   (b)   In addition to the pension which is authorized to be paid from the
Firemen’s Pension Fund and not withstanding the limitations therein placed upon
such pensions and contributions, each member as shall be entitled to the
pension shall also be entitled to the payment of a service increment in
accordance with and subject to the conditions hereinafter set forth.
      (1)   The service increment shall be the sum obtained from computing the
number of whole years after having served the minimum requirement of 20 years
during which a contributor has been employed by the city and paid out of the
City Treasury, and multiplying the number of years so computed by an amount
equal to 1/40 of the retirement allowance which has become payable to such
contributor in accordance with the provisions of this section. In computing the
service increment no employment after the member has reached the age of 65
years shall be included, and no service increment shall be paid in excess of
$100 per month.
      (2)   Each member shall pay into the Pension Fund a monthly sum, in
addition to his or her pension contribution, which shall not exceed $1 per
month. Such service increment contribution shall not be paid after the
contributor has reached the age of 65 years.
      (3)   Service increment contributions shall be paid at the same time and
in the same manner as pensions and may be withdrawn in full, without interest,
by persons who leave the employment of the city, subject to the same conditions
by which retirement contributions may be withdrawn or by persons who retire
before becoming entitled to any service increment.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.12 SURVIVING SPOUSE BENEFITS.
   Payments to surviving spouse of members retired on pension or killed in the
service shall be the amount payable to the member or which the member would
have been paid had he or she been retired at the time of his or her death.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.13 CREDIT FOR SERVICE IN ARMED FORCES.
   (a)   Any qualified member of the Bureau of Fire shall be entitled to have
full credit toward the calculation of retirement benefits for each year or
fraction thereof, not to exceed five years, for active service in the armed
forces of the United Sates.
   (b)   Such credit to be granted at the time of retirement subject to the
laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania relating to pensions.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.14 LIMITED VESTING.
   A firefighter shall have vested rights in the Pension Plan after 12 years of
service.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.15 COLA.
   Pension will be subject to a cost-of-living adjustment based on increases in
the CPI-W for the year prior to the request in question. Cost-of-living
adjustments will be based on the CPI-W index for the prior year, October to
October, if available or the nearest available month if not, subject to an
annual cap of 3.5% and a lifetime cap of 35%. The pension calculation will also
be subject to any other limitations of the Third Class City Code, including the
limitation that the pension shall not exceed 50% of the highest paid member of
the Department. For any member retiring on or after 12-31-1998.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
§ 155.16 MINIMUM BENEFIT.
   (a)   The Firemen’s Pension Fund will, in addition to any other payments
authorized or required by law, pay firemen retirees an additional benefit as
defined below.
   (b)   The benefit shall be calculated based on a figure of $20 per month for
each year of retirement for eligible members.
   (c)   Eligible members shall be limited as follows.
      (1)   Only those retirees who began receiving a retirement benefit on or
before 1-1-1989, are eligible.
      (2)   Only those retirees whose present benefit is less than $500 per
month are eligible.
      (3)   The additional pension sum hereby authorized is available only to
the extent that the total pension benefit received by each eligible member from
all sources of the plan shall not exceed $500 per month.
(Ord. 5844, approved 2-15-2001)
ARTICLE 157: CIVIL SERVICE BOARD
Section
   
157.01   Civil Service Board.
   
157.02   Suspension, discharge and discipline.
   
157.03   Effective date.
Statutory reference:
   Appointment of Examining Boards, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 14402
   Examination of appointees, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 14401
   Examination of regulations, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 14404(a)
   Review of eligibility lists, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 14410
   Selection of appointee from list, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §
14406
   Suspension and discharge, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 14408(a),
(a.1)
§ 157.01 CIVIL SERVICE BOARD.
   (a)   Establishment; membership; term.
      (1)   Pursuant to the provisions of the Third-Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S.
§§ 10101 et. seq., there is created a Civil Service Board for the examination
of applicants for appointment to any uniformed position in the Bureaus of
Police and Fire, excluding Administrative Chiefs. For purposes of this
paragraph, Administrative Chiefs shall mean all ranks above Lieutenant for the
Bureau of Police, and all ranks above Platoon Chief for the Bureau of Fire.
Such ranks shall be appointed by the Mayor and are exempt from the examination
requirements of the Civil Service Board.
      (2)   The Board shall consist of three citizens who shall be appointed by
the Mayor with the consent of Council. In addition, three qualified electors
shall be appointed to serve as alternates. The terms of the members and
alternates shall be for four years, the terms of the members and alternates
shall be staggered with one person being appointed to each position for two
years, three years and four years respectively.
      (3)   Upon the expiration of the term of any member of the Civil Service
Board, one person shall be selected to serve upon the Board for the term of
four years and until his or her successor is elected. If any vacancies occur,
they shall be filled for the unexpired term. Each of the members, before
entering upon the duties of this office, shall take and subscribe to the oath
of office prescribed by the Constitution of Pennsylvania and the Act of
Assembly above mentioned, and files the same, duly certified by the officer
administering it. No salary or other compensation shall be paid to any member
of the Board. The alternate members of the Civil Service Board shall
participate as provided in 11 Pa.C.S. § 14403.1.
   (b)   Appointments and promotions. All appointments of employees to, and
promotions in, the Bureaus of Police and Fire, shall be made according to
qualifications and fitness, to be ascertained by examinations, which, so far as
practicable, shall be competitive in accordance with the provisions of Act 22
of 2014, and any supplement or amendment thereto.
   (c)   Rules and regulations.
      (1)   The Civil Service Board shall prepare and adopt such rules and
regulations for the promotions, reduction, removal and reinstatement of all
employees so appointed in the Bureaus of Police and Fire.
      (2)   The rules and regulations so prepared may, from time to time, be
added to, amended or rescinded. All rules shall be approved by the Mayor and
Council before they go into effect. When so approved, such rules shall not be
annulled or changed except by the Board with the approval of the Mayor and
Council. If the Mayor and Council take no action on a rule or amendment
submitted to them within a period of 20 days from the date of its submission,
then the rule or amendment shall become effective as though approved by the
Mayor and Council.
   (d)   Reports and recommendations. The Civil Service Board shall make an
annual report to the Mayor showing its own actions and rules and regulations,
and all exceptions thereto, in force and the practical effect thereof, and any
suggestions it may approve for the more effectual accomplishments of the
purposes of the Act of Assembly relating to appointments to the positions
referred to herein.
   (e)   Secretary and examiners. The Board shall have power, with the consent
and approval of Council to appoint a secretary and Civil Service Examiners who
shall receive such compensation as Council shall by ordinance prescribe.
   (f)   Eligibility lists.
      (1)   The Civil Service Board shall make and keep, in numerical order, a
list containing the names of all applicants for civil service positions who may
pass the required mental and physical examinations. Where more than one person
takes examinations for any of such positions at the same time, the names of all
those successfully passing such examination shall be entered upon the list of
eligible names in the order of their respective percentages, the highest coming
first. The Board shall furnish to Council a certified copy of all lists so
prepared and kept. Such lists shall be maintained for a period of two years.
      (2)   Whenever any vacancy shall occur in any civil service position, the
Mayor shall make written application to the Chair of the Board, who shall
forthwith certify to the Mayor, in writing, the three names on the lists of
applicants for such position having the highest percentage, where there are
three or more eligible names on the list, but if there are less than three
eligible names on such list, the Board shall certify such names. Thereupon the
Director of the department in which such appointment is to be made shall
nominate to the Mayor a person from the list submitted to fill such vacancy. If
the Mayor and City Council approves such nomination, the person nominated shall
be appointed to fill such vacancy, and shall be assigned for service in the
Bureaus of Police or Fire. If the Mayor or City Council does not approve such
nomination, then the Director of the department in which such appointment is to
be made shall submit another nomination for such position from the remaining
names, if any, and if such nomination is not approved by the Mayor and City
Council, he or she shall submit the third name, if any. The person whose
nomination by the Director is approved by the Mayor and City Council shall be
appointed to fill such a position in the department.
      (3)   In all cases, the Board may recommend those in the employ of a
department for promotion in case the person recommended is competent for the
higher position. The name of the person so appointed shall be immediately
stricken from the list of the Board, and the names of the rejected persons
shall immediately be restored to their proper place in such list; provided,
however, that, if the name of any applicant has been submitted to the Mayor and
City Council, and has been rejected three times, then such name shall be
stricken from the eligible list.
      (4)   The list of eligible names kept by such Civil Service Board shall
be annually examined by the Board for the purpose of deleting therefrom persons
who are permanently unavailable for or disqualified for the position or
positions involved, either by death, permanent removal from the area, written
desire to be removed therefrom, or by other permanent cause, in conformity with
the Board’s rules and regulations.
(Ord. 6259, approved 6-12-2014; Ord. 6491, approved 1-2-2025)
§ 157.02 SUSPENSION, DISCHARGE AND DISCIPLINE.
   All employees subject to civil service shall be subject to suspension,
discharge and discipline in accordance with 11 Pa.C.S. § 14408. Any such
hearing shall be before City Council.
(Ord. 6259, approved 6-12-2014)
§ 157.03 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This article shall be effective 20 days after final enactment.
(Ord. 6259, approved 6-12-2014)

§ 175.01 APPOINTMENTS AND REMOVALS.
   (a)   Where the appointment of members to authorities, boards or commissions
is vested in the city by statute or ordinance, such member or members shall be
appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of Council.
   (b)   Members of authorities, boards and commissions appointed by Council
may be removed by a majority vote of all the members of Council and the vacancy
thus created shall be filled for the balance of the unexpired term in
accordance with subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 4526, approved 7-27-1972; Ord. 4640, approved 5-31-1974)

ARTICLE 178: SHADE TREE COMMISSION
Section
   
178.01   Established.
   
178.02   Composition of Commission.
   
178.03   Expenditures, advisory powers and purposes.
   
178.04   Employment provisions.
   
178.05   Annual report.
§ 178.01 ESTABLISHED.
   A Shade Tree Commission is hereby established for the City of Williamsport.
(Ord. 5581, approved 3-4-1993)
§ 178.02 COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION.
   (a)   The Shade Tree Commission shall be composed of seven residents of the
city who shall be appointed by the Mayor, and shall serve without compensation,
three for a term of three years, two for a term of four years and two for a
term of five years. On the expiration of the term of any member of the
Commission, a successor shall be appointed by the Mayor to serve for a term of
five years. Vacancies in the office of the Commission shall be filled by the
Mayor for the unexpired term.
   (b)   A member shall not be eligible for reappointment after serving two
consecutive five year terms; provided, however, that, notwithstanding prior
service as a Commission member, an individual shall be eligible for
reappointment if he or she has not been a member of the Commission for one full
year prior to the date upon which he or she is appointed a member.
(Ord. 5581, approved 3-4-1993)
§ 178.03 EXPENDITURES, ADVISORY POWERS AND PURPOSES.
   (a)   The Shade Tree Commission shall be advisory only to the Mayor and
Council. The Commission shall advise the Mayor and Council on the planting,
care, maintenance, removal and protection of the shade trees of the city. The
Commission may recommend to the Mayor and Council the appropriation of funds
for such purposes as it deems advisable. The Commission may advise the Mayor
and Council with respect to the enforcement, implementation and amendments to
Art. 915 (Trees) of the codified ordinances.
   (b)   The Commission shall not be authorized under any circumstances to
enter into a contract on behalf of the city in itself, or in any way bind the
city with payment of any moneys.
(Ord. 5581, approved 3-4-1993)
§ 178.04 EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS.
   The Shade Tree Commission shall be advisory only and shall not enter into
any employment contracts.
(Ord. 5581, approved 3-4-1993)
§ 178.05 ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Shade Tree Commission shall annually report in full to Council’s first
stated meeting in October of its activities and recommendations for the prior
fiscal year of the city.
(Ord. 5581, approved 3-4-1993)
ARTICLE 179: BOARD OF HEALTH
Section
   
179.01   Creation.
   
179.02   Membership, qualifications and term.
   
179.03   Organization.
   
179.04   Duties of Secretary.
   
179.05   Health Officer.
   
179.06   Rules and regulations.
   
179.07   Duties and functions.
   
179.08   Medical Director. (Repealed)
   
179.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Rent withholding appeal procedure, see Part Seventeen, §
1743.10
Statutory reference:
   Board regulations effective as ordinances, see 3rd Class City Code, 11
Pa.C.S. § 12309
   State law provisions, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 12301 et seq.
§ 179.01 CREATION.
   The Board of Health for the City of Williamsport is hereby created.
(Ord. 4513, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 179.02 MEMBERSHIP, QUALIFICATIONS AND TERM.
   The Board of Health shall have five members appointed by Council. At least
one, and whenever possible two, shall be currently licensed or certified by the
State Board of Medicine, the State Board of Examiners of Nursing Home
Administrators, the State Board of Podiatry, the State Board of Veterinary
Medicine, the State Board of Osteopathic Medicine, the State Board of Pharmacy,
the State Board of Physical Therapy or the State Board of Nursing or be engaged
in a medical, medically related or health care profession or business and shall
be a resident or have an office in the city. If a licensed or certified medical
or health care professional cannot be identified to serve on the Board, Council
may appoint any individual who is a resident of the city and has experience or
knowledge of public health issues. Upon the creation of the Board, Council
shall designate for one appointee a term of one year, for another a term of two
years and so on up to five; thereafter, one member of the Board shall be
appointed annually to serve for a term of five years. There shall be at least
one alternate who shall serve for a term of five years. The alternate has no
voting rights, unless he or she is taking the place of a Board member who is
absent from a meeting. Council may remove members of the Board for official
misconduct or neglect of duty. Members of the Board shall serve without
compensation.
(Ord. 4513, approved 2-17-1972; Ord. 5575, approved 12-21-1992; Ord. 5984,
approved 2-3-2005)
§ 179.03 ORGANIZATION.
   The Board of Health shall organize annually and shall elect a President and
Vice President annually from among its members and shall appoint a Secretary
who is not a Board member.
(Ord. 4513, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 179.04 DUTIES OF SECRETARY.
   The Secretary of the Board of Health shall keep the minutes of the
proceedings of the Board and shall prepare, under the direction of the Board,
the annual report to Council. He shall make such reports to the State
Department of Health as are required by law or by rule or regulation of the
Department, and shall make such other reports and perform such other duties as
are required by him or her by law or by the Board.
(Ord. 4513, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 179.05 HEALTH OFFICER.
   The Health Officer shall be duly qualified as required by the Third Class
City Code and shall attend all stated and special meetings of the Board of
Health and shall be available for the performance of his or her official duties
at all times. He or she shall perform such other duties and functions as may be
required of him or her by law or by ordinance.
(Ord. 4513, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 179.06 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Board of Health may adopt such rules and regulations for the conduct of
its business and duties which are not contrary to any health code or laws of
the commonwealth and city ordinances.
(Ord. 4513, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 179.07 DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS.
   The Board of Health shall:
   (a)   Determine when a public nuisance exists or is about to exist and order
when such nuisance is to be removed, abated, suspended, altered or otherwise
prevented or avoided, in the manner and in accordance with the procedure
established by law. (See 11 Pa.C.S. § 12320(a) and (b))
   (b)   Require the removal of any nuisance or dangerous structure from public
or private places upon notice to the owner, and upon his or her default, cause
such removal and collect the cost thereof, together with a penalty of 10% of
such cost, from the owner. The cost of removal and penalty may be entered as a
lien against the property in accordance with existing provisions of law. In the
alternative such cost and penalty may be collected by an action in assumpsit.
Any party aggrieved by any decision of the Board shall be entitled to a hearing
before the Board within the time set for compliance with such order. (See 11
Pa.C.S. § 12414)
   (c)   Do such other acts pertaining to public health that are required or
permitted by law or ordinance now in existence and hereafter enacted.
(Ord. 4513, approved 2-17-1972)
§ 179.08 MEDICAL DIRECTOR. (Repealed)
Editor’s note:
   Former § 179.08, Medical Director, was repealed by Ord. 5984, approved 2-3-
2005.
§ 179.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any order of the Board of Health shall be fined for
the first offense not less than $25, nor more than $100, or imprisoned not more
than 90 days, or both; and on the second and subsequent offenses, shall be
fined not less than $100 nor more than $300, or imprisoned not more than 90
days, or both.
   (b)   Each separate day that an order of the Board of Health continues to be
violated shall be a separate offense.
(Ord. 4529, approved 7-27-1972)

§ 181.01 DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT PLAN PROCEDURE; REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY AS AGENT.
   (a)   The Redevelopment Authority of the city is hereby ordered and directed
to serve as the city’s agent to:
      (1)   Design the mall in accordance with the Williamsport Downtown
Development Plan;
      (2)   Prepare contract documents and bid the mall construction;
      (3)   Supervise mall construction activities; and
      (4)   Administer city funds granted to the Authority for the above work.
   (b)   The city irrevocably commits the sum of up to $1,185,000 to the
Redevelopment Authority to design and build the mall development.
   (c)   The city hereby expresses its intent to create a special assessment
district in accordance with the Pennsylvania Business Improvement District Act
of 1967, as amended, to finance the mall development.
   (d)   The city intends to maintain the mall improvements in accordance with
present practice of maintaining all public places.
   (e)   Council shall approve the following documents prior to execution by
the Redevelopment Authority:
      (1)   The contract for the design and inspection of mall improvements;
and
      (2)   The contract for the construction of mall improvements.
(Ord. 4705, passed over veto 10-23-1975)
ARTICLE 183: RECREATION COMMISSION
Section
   
183.01   Creation.
   
183.02   Members; term; vacancies.
   
183.03   Expenditures.
Cross-reference:
   Brown Memorial Park, see Part Nine,
Art. 913
   Park and playground curfew, see Part Seven,
Art. 721
Editor’s note:
   Ord. 4938, passed 11-29-1978, approved an agreement between the city and the
Williamsport-County Recreation Authority whereby the county assumed all duties
and obligations in connection with recreation. Res. 3352, approved 8-30-1979,
an agreement between the City and Williamsport Area School District whereby the
City Recreation Commission assumed the administration and operation of the
recreation program.
Statutory reference:
   State law provisions, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 13703 et seq.
§ 183.01 CREATION.
   A Recreation Commission is created:
   (a)   To equip, supervise, operate and maintain the playgrounds and pools of
the city. The term “playground”, as used in this article, includes Municipal
Playgrounds and all athletic fields and/or surfaces, but does not include any
golf courses.
   (b)   To plan, organize and supervise all special events sponsored by the
Williamsport Recreation Department.
(Ord. 1695, approved 5-31-1940; Ord. 6296, passed 2-4-2016)
§ 183.02 MEMBERS; TERM; VACANCIES.
   (a)   The Recreation Commission shall consist of seven members who shall be
appointed in the following manner.
      (1)   One member shall be a member of City Council who shall be appointed
annually by City Council, with the advice and consent of the Mayor. An
alternate Council member shall also be appointed.
      (2)   Six members at large shall be appointed by the Mayor with the
advice and consent of City Council.
      (3)   The Mayor and Recreation Director shall serve in an advisory
capacity.
   (b)   (1)   The member of the Commission who is a member of Council, and the
Council alternate, shall serve a one-year term, and members at large shall
serve four year terms. It is anticipated the Council Alternate should become
the following years Council Commission member, and a new Alternate appointed.
      (2)   The initial term of the at large members shall be appointed as
follows: two members for one year; one member for two years; two members for
three years; and one member for four years. Thereafter, appointments to the
Commission shall be for four-year terms.
   (c)   Vacancies in the Commission occurring otherwise than by expiration of
term shall be for the unexpired term and shall be filled in the same manner as
the original appointments.
(Ord. 5603, passed 12-16-1993; Ord. 6296, passed 2-4-2016)
§ 183.03 EXPENDITURES.
   The power and authority of the Recreation Commission shall not be construed
to, nor shall the Commission have any power or authority to make any
expenditures, but the Commission shall have the authority to recommend
expenditures to be made to Council and the Mayor.
(Ord. 5603, passed 12-16-1993; Ord. 6296, passed 2-4-2016)

185.01   Creation.

§ 185.01 CREATION.

(Ord. 4528, approved 7-27-1972)
§ 185.02 MEMBERSHIP; TERM.
   (a)   The Bowman Field Commission shall consist of five members, to be
appointed by a majority vote of all the members of Council. The initial
Commission shall be appointed as follows: one member for one year; one member
for two years; one member for three years; one member for four years; and one
member for five years.
   (b)   Thereafter, appointments to the Commission, except for filling
vacancies or cases of removal, shall be for five-year terms. Any vacancies in
the membership of the Commission shall be filled in the same manner as
appointments, but shall be for the unexpired term.
   (c)   Council shall have the power to remove any member of the Commission.
In addition to the five members of the Commission, the Mayor and the Director
of Public Services, or other designee of the Mayor, shall be ex-officio members
of the Commission.
   (d)   One member of the Bowman Field Commission shall be a member of City
Council.
(Ord. 4528, approved 7-27-1972; Ord. 6257, approved 5-1-2014)
§ 185.03 PURPOSE.
   The Bowman Field Commission shall be advisory to the Mayor and Council, and
shall promote and encourage the use of Bowman Field for the use and benefit of
all the residents of Williamsport.
(Ord. 4528, approved 7-27-1972)
§ 185.04 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Bowman Field Commission shall adopt suitable rules and regulations for
the government and operation of the Commission, subject to the approval of such
rules and regulations by the Mayor.
(Ord. 4528, approved 7-27-1972)
§ 185.05 DISPOSITION OF FUNDS; REPORT.
   All moneys received shall be payable into the City Treasury, and all
disbursements shall be reported to the Mayor and the Director of Finance and
Personnel on a monthly basis. The Bowman Field Commission shall have prior
approval from the Director of Finance and Personnel for any expenditures. The
Commission shall report on its activities on an annual basis to Council and the
Mayor.
(Ord. 4528, approved 7-27-1972)
§ 185.06 INSURANCE.
   All insurance on Bowman Field shall be placed through the Mayor and the
Director of Finance and Personnel. The Bowman Field Commission may advise the
Mayor as to proper insurance and recommend such.
(Ord. 4528, approved 7-27-1972)

contract on the behalf of the city or itself, or in any way bind the city with

the Department of Public Services, and shall be subject to the general

employees of the city.

ARTICLE 189: WAY’S GARDEN COMMISSION
Section
   
189.01   Deed acceptance for park purposes.
   
189.02   Commission duties; rules and regulations.
   
189.03   Park purpose limited to beauty and recreation.

§ 189.01 DEED ACCEPTANCE FOR PARK PURPOSES.
   The deed of conveyance from Mr. and Mrs. J. Roman Way for the two and one-
half acres of land situated in the Fifth Ward of the city, in trust for the
purpose of an open space for a park or public garden for the use of the public
forever, and to be called or known as “Way’s Garden”, is hereby accepted by the
city in accordance with the terms of such conveyance.
(Ord. 60-1913, approved 7-14-1913)
§ 189.02 COMMISSION DUTIES; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   Rev. Elliott C. Armstrong, Rev. Robert F. Gibson, H. Melick Foresman, J.
Roman Way and the Mayor are hereby appointed Commissioners of Way’s Garden to
serve without compensation and during good behavior, and whose duty it shall be
to prepare and report to the common and select Councils a plan for the
improvement, regulation and government of Way’s Garden, to supervise the work
of improvement of the park or garden, and expend the moneys which may be
appropriated from time to time by the city for such improvement, under the
direction and subject to the control of the city. The Commission shall make
report to Council at least once in every year as to the progress of the
improvements upon the park or garden and the condition of the same, together
with a statement of moneys expended and the purposes to which the same have
been applied. They shall take and subscribe to the oath of office prescribed
for all officers of third class cities. They are hereby empowered to make and
alter, from time to time, all needful rules and regulations for the maintenance
of order, safety and decency in the Garden, the prevention of any destruction
of property and misuse of the same, and the protection and preservation of the
Garden, and to affix penalties for disobedience thereto. Such rules and
regulations shall have the force of ordinances of the city; except that, no
such rules or regulations shall be of any effect until they have first been
approved by Council and published at full length in one or more of the daily
newspapers published in the city and also printed and posted in a conspicuous
place within the limits of the Garden.
(Ord. 60-1913, approved 7-14-2013)
§ 189.03 PARK PURPOSE LIMITED TO BEAUTY AND RECREATION.
   No circuses, menageries, athletic games for exhibition, nor any other kind
of public exhibition shall ever be allowed upon such park, nor shall the park
ever be used as a public playground, but only as a park or garden for the
beautifying of the city, and as a place of rest and recreation for the
residents.
(Ord. 60-1913, approved 7-14-2013)
§ 189.04 COMMISSION VACANCY.
   The Mayor by and with the consent of the majority of Council shall have
authority to fill, upon the nomination of the surviving members of the
Commission, all vacancies in such Commission which may be occasioned by death,
resignation or otherwise.
(Ord. 60-1913, approved 7-14-2013)
§ 189.05 FAITH OF CITY PLEDGED.
   The faith of the city is hereby pledged to the performance on the part of
the city of the terms of the acceptance from Mr. and Mrs. J. Roman Way of the
conveyance of Way’s Garden, in accordance with this article.
(Ord. 60-1913, approved 7-14-2013)
