ARTICLE 195: BLIGHTED PROPERTY REVIEW COMMITTEE
Section
   
195.01   Creation and purpose.
   
195.02   Blighted property.
   
195.03   Membership, appointment, term and regulations.
   
195.04   Duties.
   
195.05   Notice to property owner.
   
195.06   Hearing and disposition.
   
195.07   Certification to redevelopment authority.
   
195.08   Acquisition and disposition of blighted property.
   
195.09   Residential and related use.
Cross-reference:
   Planning Commission certification of blighted property, see Part Thirteen, §
1301.08(n)
Statutory reference:
   Blighted property removal, see 35 P.S. § 1712.1
§ 195.01 CREATION AND PURPOSE.
   The Blighted Property Review Committee is hereby created in accordance with
35 P.S. § 1712.1 in order to enable the Redevelopment Authority of the city to
acquire by purchase, gift, bequest, eminent domain or otherwise, any blighted
property as hereinafter defined, either within or outside a certified
redevelopment area, and the Redevelopment Authority shall have the power to
hold, clear, manage and/or dispose of such blighted property for residential
and related reuse and commercial or industrial reuse.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005; Ord. 6415,
approved 6-10-2021)
§ 195.02 BLIGHTED PROPERTY.
   Blighted property shall include:
   (a)   Any premises which because of physical condition or use is regarded as
a public nuisance at common law or has been declared a public nuisance in
accordance with the local housing, building, plumbing, fire and related codes;
   (b)   Any premises which because of physical condition, use or occupancy is
considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not limited to,
abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations and unsafe fences or
structures;
   (c)   Any dwelling which because it is dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe,
vermin infested or lacking in the facilities and equipment required by the
Housing Code of the city has been designated by the department responsible for
enforcement of the Code as unfit for human habitation;
   (d)   Any structure which is a fire hazard or is otherwise dangerous to the
safety of persons or property;
   (e)   Any structure from which the utilities, plumbing, heating, sewerage or
other facilities have been disconnected, destroyed, removed or rendered
ineffective so that the property is unfit for its intended use;
   (f)   Any vacant or unimproved lot or parcel of ground in a predominantly
built-up neighborhood, which by reason of neglect or lack of maintenance has
become a place for accumulation of trash and debris or a haven for rodents or
other vermin;
   (g)   Any unoccupied property which has been tax delinquent for a period of
two years prior to the effective date of this section, and those in the future
having a two-year tax delinquency;
   (h)   Any property which is vacant but not tax delinquent, which has not
been rehabilitated within one year of the receipt of notices to rehabilitate
from the appropriate code enforcement agency or Board of Health;
   (i)   Any abandoned property. A property shall be considered abandoned if:
      (1)   It is a vacant or unimproved lot or parcel of ground on which a
municipal lien for the cost of demolition of any structure located on the
property remains unpaid for a period of six months;
      (2)   It is a vacant property or vacant or unimproved lot or parcel of
ground on which the total of municipal liens on the property for tax or any
other type of claim of the municipality are in excess of 150% of the fair
market value of the property as established by the Board of Revision of Taxes
or other body with legal authority to determine the taxable value of the
property; or
      (3)   The property has been declared abandoned by the owner, including an
estate that is in possession of the property.
   (j)   A property shall be considered vacant if:
      (1)   The property is unoccupied or its occupancy has not been authorized
by the owner of the property;
      (2)   In the case of an unimproved lot or parcel of ground, a lien for
the cost of demolition of any structure located on the property remains unpaid
for a period of six months; or
      (3)   In the case of an unimproved lot or parcel of ground, the property
has remained in violation of any provision of local building, property
maintenance or related codes applicable to such lots or parcels, including
licensing requirements, for a period of six months.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005)
§ 195.03 MEMBERSHIP, APPOINTMENT, TERM AND REGULATIONS.
The Mayor is hereby authorized to create and appoint members of the Blighted
Property Review Committee, which such appointments shall be approved by
Council. Such Committee shall be composed of seven members and include the
following:
      (1)   One member of Council;
      (2)   One member of the Williamsport Planning Commission;
      (3)   One member of the City Redevelopment Authority;
      (4)   One representative of the executive branch of the city; and
      (5)   Three citizens at large.
   (b)   (1)   Members of the Committee shall serve the following terms:
         (A)   A member of City Council appointed each year at the
reorganization meeting;
         (B)   One member of the Planning Commission per their term determined
on the Planning Commission;
         (C)   One member of the Redevelopment Authority per their term
determined on the Redevelopment Authority;
         (D)   The Codes Administrator per term of employment;
         (E)   Three citizens at large for a three year term;
      (2)   So that the terms of the citizens at large shall continue to be
staggered, the initial appointments of the citizens at large shall be as
follows;
         (A)   One for one year;
         (B)   One for two years; and
         (C)   One for three years.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005; Ord. 6385,
approved 4-16-2020)
§ 195.04 DUTIES.
   (a)   The Blighted Property Review Committee, upon making a determination
that any property is blighted as defined in § 195.02, must certify such
blighted property to the Redevelopment Authority and to the Williamsport
Planning Commission.
   (b)   In conjunction with the aforesaid certification, the following rules
apply:
      (1)   No property shall be certified to the Redevelopment Authority
unless it is vacant. A property shall be considered vacant if:
         (A)   The property is unoccupied or its occupancy has not been
authorized by the owner of the property;
         (B)   In the case of an unimproved lot or parcel of ground, a lien for
the cost of demolition of any structure located on the property remains unpaid
for a period of six months; or
         (C)   In the case of an unimproved lot or parcel of ground, the
property has remained in violation of any provision of local building, property
maintenance or related codes applicable to such lots or parcels, including
licensing requirements, for a period of six months.
      (2)   No property shall be certified to the Redevelopment Authority
unless the owner of the property or an agent designated by him for receipt of
service of notices within the city has been served with notice of the
determination that the property is blighted, together with an appropriate order
to eliminate the conditions causing the blight and notification that failure to
do so may render the property subject to condemnation under this article. The
notice shall be served upon the owner or his or her agent in accord with the
provisions of a local ordinance pertaining to service of notice of
determination of a public nuisance. The owner or his agent shall have the right
of appeal from the determination in the same manner as an appeal from the
determination of public nuisance.
      (3)   No blighted property shall be certified to the Redevelopment
Authority until the time period for appeal has expired and no appeal has been
taken or, if taken, the appeal has been disposed of, and the owner or his or
her agent has failed to comply with the order of the responsible department or
other officer or agency.
      (4)   No single vacant lot or parcel of ground shall be certified to the
Redevelopment Authority under this section on which more than ten dwelling
units can be constructed under existing zoning regulations.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005)
§ 195.05 NOTICE TO PROPERTY OWNER.
   (a)   Whenever the Blighted Property Review Committee has determined that a
property is blighted as defined in §
195.02, notice of such finding shall be served upon the owner(s) by certified
mail, return receipt requested, mailed to the last known address of the owners.
   (b)   In addition to the mailed notice to the owner(s), the Committee shall
also direct the Health Officer or other appropriate city employee to
conspicuously post a copy of the notice upon the premises for a period of at
least ten days.
   (c)   The notice of the Committee finding shall clearly specify:
      (1)   The name of the owner(s) of the property;
      (2)   The basis for finding the property blighted;
      (3)   The date of the Committee finding and the number of days the owner
(s) has to eliminate the conditions causing the blight. In no event shall the
time for compliance be less than ten days from the date of mailing of the
notice;
      (4)   The alternative remedy of the Committee in case of failure to
eliminate the cause of the blight, that is, the failure may render the property
subject to condemnation under this article;
      (5)   Notice that the owner(s) may apply, within the time set for
compliance with the notice, to the Committee for a hearing on the issue of
whether the property is blighted and may request a stay of execution or
modifications or rescission of the notice; and
      (6)   Such notice shall be signed by the Chairperson and attested to by
the Secretary.
   (d)   Any application for a hearing shall be in writing and shall be filed
with the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Administrator within the time
limitation set forth in the notice. The application shall set forth the address
to which notice of the hearing shall be mailed.
   (e)   The Administrator shall promptly notify the Chairperson of the
Committee of the application for hearing for the purpose of scheduling a
hearing to be conducted as hereinafter set forth.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005)
§ 195.06 HEARING AND DISPOSITION.
   (a)   Upon receipt of a written application for hearing, the Chairperson
shall set a hearing date and notify all interested parties of the date, time
and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed to the owner(s) by
ordinary mail addressed to the address indicated in the written request for
hearing. The hearing shall be public and the owner(s) shall have the right to
be represented by an attorney and to cross-examine witnesses and to present
such evidence through witnesses and exhibits as the Committee deems relevant.
Formal rules of evidence shall not apply.
   (b)   As soon as possible, but in no event later than 15 days after the date
of final receipt of evidence, the Committee shall render a decision with
respect to the issues presented at the appeal.
   (c)   The property owner(s) shall be notified of the Committee’s final
determination and within ten days of the mailing of such final determination
may appeal therefrom to the Court of Common Pleas of Lycoming County in
accordance with the Local Agency Law.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005)
§ 195.07 CERTIFICATION TO REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY.
   After a determination of blight, after notice of the blight as set forth in
§
195.05 after final disposition of the appeal or the passage of the period of
appeal without an appeal having been taken, and the blighted condition not
having been eliminated, the Committee shall submit the property to the
Williamsport Planning Commission for a consideration by that body as to whether
the property is blighted. Upon determination by the Planning Commission that
the property is blighted, a joint certification of the Planning Commission and
the Blighted Property Review Committee that the property is blighted shall be
made in accordance with this article and the state act.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005)
§ 195.08 ACQUISITION AND DISPOSITION OF BLIGHTED PROPERTY.
   (a)   Acquisition and disposition of blighted property under this section
shall not require preparation, adoption or approval of a redevelopment area
plan or redevelopment proposal but, at least 30 days prior to acquisition of
any property under this section, the Redevelopment Authority shall transmit
identification of the property to the Planning Commission and shall request a
recommendation as to the appropriate reuse of the property. The Redevelopment
Authority shall not acquire the property where the Commission certifies that
disposition for residential or related use would not be in accord with the
Comprehensive Plan of the city.
   (b)   Power of eminent domain shall be exercised pursuant to a resolution of
the Redevelopment Authority and the procedure set forth in the Act of 6-22-1964
(Sp. Sess., P.L. 84, No. 6), known as the “Eminent Domain Code”, as amended.
   (c)   Property disposed of within a redevelopment area shall be disposed of
under a redevelopment contract in accordance with the provisions of this
article.
   (d)   Property disposed of outside an urban renewal project area shall be
disposed of by deed in accordance with the provisions set forth in applicable
law.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005)
§ 195.09 RESIDENTIAL AND RELATED USE.
   Residential and related use shall include residential property for sale or
rental and related uses, including, but not limited to, park and recreation
areas, neighborhood community service and neighborhood parking lots.
(Ord. 5038, approved 5-1-1980; Ord. 6005, approved 10-13-2005)

ARTICLE 199: EAST THIRD STREET GATEWAY REVITALIZATION ADVISORY COMMISSION
Section
   
199.01   Creation.
   
199.02   Membership; term.
   
199.03   Purpose.
   
199.04   Expenditures.
   
199.05   Effective date.
§ 199.01 CREATION.
   The East Third Street Revitalization Gateway Advisory Commission is hereby
created for the city.
(Ord. 6256, approved 3-20-2014)
§ 199.02 MEMBERSHIP; TERM.
   (a)   The East Third Street Revitalization Gateway Advisory Commission shall
consist of 12 members who shall be appointed in the following manner: four
members shall be residents of the city or own property in the area designated
in §
199.03(a) and appointed by the Mayor; four members shall be residents of the
city or own property in the area designated in §
199.03(a) and appointed by a majority vote of Council; one member shall be a
member of Council’s Economic Revitalization Committee who shall be appointed
annually by the President of Council; one member shall be the Mayor or the
Mayor’s designee; one member shall be a Lycoming County Commissioner or a
designee; and one member shall be the President of Lycoming College or his or
her designee.
   (b)   The initial term for the members appointed by the Mayor and by a
majority of Council shall be as follows: two of the mayoral appointments and
two of the Council appointments shall serve a three-year term; and two of the
mayoral appointments and two (2) of the Council appointments shall serve a
five-year term. Thereafter, appointments to the Commission shall be for five-
year terms.
   (c)   Vacancies in the Commission occurring otherwise than by expiration of
term shall be for the unexpired term and shall be filled in the same manner as
the original appointments.
(Ord. 6256, approved 3-20-2014; Ord. 6300, passed 4-14-2016; Ord. 6301,
approved 5-12-2016)
§ 199.03 PURPOSE.
   (a)   The Commission shall be advisory to the Mayor and City Council on the
revitalization of the east end of the city in an area bounded by the alley
north of Washington Boulevard and Lycoming College along the northern edge,
Market Street on the west, Interstate 180 on the south, and Catherine Street at
the city border on the east. The duties of the Commission will include, but not
be limited to, examining the effects of zoning, planning, parking and the
seeking of grants and other sources of funding for this area of the city.
   (b)   City boards commissions, authorities are authorized and directed to
cooperate with and assist the Commission.
   (c)   The Commission is authorized to create advisory sub-committees and
appoint its members one of whom shall be a member of City Council.
(Ord. 6256, approved 3-20-2014; Ord. 6300, passed 4-14-2016)
§ 199.04 EXPENDITURES.
   (a)   The Commission shall not be authorized under any circumstances to
enter into any contracts on behalf of the city or itself or in any way bind the
city with payment of any monies.
   (b)   The Commission shall not be authorized to enter into any employment
contracts.
(Ord. 6256, approved 3-20-2014)
§ 199.05 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This article shall become effective 20 days after final enactment.
(Ord. 6256, approved 3-20-2014)
ARTICLE 201: ETHICS COMMISSION
Section
   
201.01   Creation.
   
201.02   Duties.
   
201.03   Membership; term.
   
201.04   Expenditures.
§ 201.01 CREATION.
   The city hereby creates an Ethics Commission.
(Ord. 6371, approved 9-12-2019)
§ 201.02 DUTIES.
   (a)   The city vests power in the Ethics Commission to research, write, and
recommend a Code of Ethics for the city, including ongoing duties of the Ethics
Commission and a recommended method for enforcement and penalties regarding the
same.
   (b)   The Ethics Commission shall provide quarterly reports to Council on
the progress of its recommended Code of Ethics. Upon the Ethics Commission's
completion of a recommended Code, the Commission shall present the same to the
City Council for its consideration.
   (c)   The Ethics Commission shall record and maintain audio records of all
of its public meetings.
   (d)   Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the proceedings of the Ethics
Commission on all matters not specially provided for herein.
(Ord. 6371, approved 9-12-2019)
§ 201.03 MEMBERSHIP; TERM.
   (a)   The Ethics Commission shall be comprised of five (5) members
(hereinafter "member" or "members"). Each member shall be a resident of the
city and may hold no other appointed, elected, or employment position within
the city. Members shall be appointed by City Council or the Mayor, as described
below, and members' terms of office shall commence on the effective date of
their appointment, as follows:
      (1)   Within 60 days of the passage of this ordinance, three (3) members
shall be appointed by City Council, and two (2) members shall be appointed by
the Mayor.
      (2)   Members shall serve staggered terms of three years, except for the
initial members, who shall serve in accordance with §
201.03(a)(3) below.
      (3)   For the purpose of creating staggered terms and alternating
appointments between City Council and the Mayor, members shall serve in one of
three classes of membership as follows:
         (A)   The first two (2) members appointed by City Council shall serve
as Class I members. Class I member appointments shall be made at the last
meeting of City Council before the end of the first full calendar year
following the formation of the Ethics Commission, and every three years
following. Class I members shall be appointed by City Council.
         (B)   The first two (2) members appointed by the Mayor shall serve as
Class II members. Class II member appointments shall be made at the last
meeting of City Council before the end of the second full calendar year
following the formation of the Ethics Commission, and every three years
following. Class II members shall be appointed by the Mayor.
         (C)   The third member appointed by City Council shall serve as a
Class III member. The Class III member appointment shall be made at the last
meeting of City Council before the end of the third full calendar year
following the formation of the Ethics Commission, and every three years
following. The Class III member shall be appointed by City Council.
   (b)   Members shall hold office until their successors have been appointed
and may succeed themselves.
   (c)   Upon petition of City Council or the Mayor, to the Court of Common
Pleas of Lycoming County, any member of the Ethics Commission may be removed
for incompetency, intemperance, neglect of duty, violation of any of the laws
of the Commonwealth or the city, or other improper conduct.
   (d)   Vacancies in the Ethics Commission occurring otherwise than by
expiration of term shall be for the unexpired term and shall be filled in the
same manner as the original appointments.
(Ord. 6371, approved 9-12-2019)
§ 201.04 EXPENDITURES.
   The power and authority of the Ethics Commission shall not be construed to,
nor shall the Commission have any power or authority to make any expenditures,
but the Ethics Commission shall have the authority to recommend expenditures to
be made to City Council and the Mayor. The Ethics Commission shall not be
authorized under any circumstances to enter into a contract on behalf of the
city in itself.
(Ord. 6371, approved 9-12-2019)
ARTICLE 203: ACCESSIBILITY ADVISORY COMMISSION
Section
   
203.01   Creation.
   
203.02   Duties.
   
203.03   Membership; term.
   
203.04   Expenditures.
§ 203.01 CREATION.
   The city hereby creates an Accessibility Advisory Commission.
(Ord. 6396, approved 9-10-2020)
§ 203.02 DUTIES.
   (a)   The city vests power in the Accessibility Advisory Commission to:
      (1)   Assist in evaluating the accessibility of the city's facilities,
programs, activities, and services city wide;
      (2)   Make recommendations for needed improvements city wide;
      (3)   Provide guidance in developing the city's access policy and a plan
for action;
      (4)   Serve as a resource and review mechanism, which may include
consultation on new programs, policies, projects and services city wide; and
aid in the development of programs for services to people with disabilities, in
cooperation with the public and private sectors;
      (5)   Assist in educating city administration, staff, city constituents
and businesses concerning disability services and access issues;
      (6)   Advocate the inclusion of accessibility awareness to equity,
diversity, and inclusion (EDI) conversations.
   (c)   Definition of Disability. A person has a disability, within the
meaning of these Rules, if that person:
      (1)   Has a mental or physical impairment which substantially limits one
or more major life activities, including, but not limited to, functions such as
caring for one's self, performing manual tasks, walking, seeing, hearing,
speaking, breathing, learning, and working;
      (2)   Has a record of such impairment; or
      (3)   Is regarded as having such an impairment.
   (d)   A written or electronic notice, tentative agenda, and minutes of the
previous meeting shall be prepared and distributed to each member and the city
clerk for publication at least three (3) days prior to the meeting for which
notice is given.
   (e)   The Accessibility Commission shall provide quarterly reports to
Council on the progress of its recommended actions.
   (f)   The Accessibility Commission shall record and maintain audio records
of all its public meetings.
   (g)   Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the proceedings of the
Accessibility Commission on all matters not specially provided for herein.
(Ord. 6396, approved 9-10-2020)
§ 203.03 MEMBERSHIP; TERM.
   (a)   The Accessibility Commission shall be comprised of nine (9) members
(hereinafter "member" or "members"): four (4) “non-voting” members, one (1)
City Council person, one (1) representative of codes, one (1) person with
knowledge of ADA law and the City Engineer and five (5) “voting” members which
can and should include persons with disabilities, a parent or family member of
a child or children / family member with a disability or individuals who work
for an organization that serve people with disabilities. Each member shall be a
resident of the city. Members shall be appointed by City Council or the Mayor,
as described below, and members' terms of office shall commence on the
effective date of their appointment, as follows:
      (1)   Within 60 days of the passage of this ordinance, three (3) members
shall be appointed by City Council, and two (2) members shall be appointed by
the Mayor.
      (2)   Members shall serve staggered terms of three years, except for the
initial members, who shall serve in accordance with § 203.03(a)(3) below.
      (3)   For the purpose of creating staggered terms and alternating
appointments between City Council and the Mayor, members shall serve in one of
three classes of membership as follows;
      (4)   (i)   The first two (2) members appointed by City Council shall
serve as Class I members. Class I member appointments shall be made at the last
meeting of City Council before the end of the first full calendar year
following the formation of the Accessibility Commission, and every three years
following. Class I members shall be appointed by City Council.
         (ii)   The first two (2) members appointed by the Mayor shall serve as
Class II members. Class II member appointments shall be made at the last
meeting of City Council before the end of the second full calendar year
following the formation of the Accessibility Commission, and every three years
following. Class II members shall be appointed by the Mayor.
         (iii)   The third member appointed by City Council shall serve as a
Class III member. The Class III member appointment shall be made at the last
meeting of City Council before the end of the third full calendar year
following the formation of the Accessibility Commission, and every three years
following. The Class III member shall be appointed by City Council.
   (b)   Any member of the Accessibility Commission may be removed at the will
of the Mayor with the approval of Council.
   (c)   Vacancies in the Accessibility Commission occurring otherwise than by
expiration of term shall be for the unexpired term and shall be filled in the
same manner as the original appointments.
(Ord. 6396, approved 9-10-2020)
§ 203.04 EXPENDITURES.
   The power and authority of the Accessibility Commission shall not be
construed to, nor shall the Commission have any power or authority to make any
expenditures, but the Accessibility Commission shall have the authority to
recommend expenditures to be made to City Council and the Mayor. The
Accessibility Commission shall not be authorized under any circumstances to
enter into a contract on behalf of the city in itself.
(Ord. 6396, approved 9-10-2020)

TITLE ONE: ADMINISTRATION
ARTICLE 301: LOCAL TAX HEARING OFFICER
Section
   
301.01   Creation, appointment and term, alternate.
   
301.02   Powers of the Hearing Officer.
   
301.03   Time and procedure for filing appeal.
   
301.04   Appeals process, procedure and conduct of hearing.
   
301.05   Judicial appeal.
   
301.06   Effective date.
Cross-reference:
   Act 511 taxes, see Part Three, Title Five
   Business licensing, see Part Three, Title Three
Statutory reference:
   Local Agency Law, see 2 Pa.C.S. §§ 551, 751 et seq.
§ 301.01 CREATION, APPOINTMENT AND TERM, ALTERNATE.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Local Tax Hearing Officer, who
shall have the power to hear and decide appeals made pursuant to and in
accordance with the Local Taxpayer Bill of Rights Act.
   (b)   The position of Local Tax Hearing Officer shall be filled by
appointment by Council from time to time. The Local Tax Hearing Officer shall
serve at the pleasure of Council and shall be compensated as may be fixed by
Council in the appointment or as modified from time to time.
   (c)   Council shall also appoint an Alternate Local Tax Hearing Officer who
shall serve as Local Tax Hearing Officer in the event the person appointed as
Local Tax Hearing Officer has a conflict of interest or is otherwise unable to
serve as hearing officer for purposes of any given appeal.
(Ord. 6339, approved 11-21-2017)
§ 301.02 POWERS OF THE HEARING OFFICER.
   (a)   The Local Tax Hearing Officer shall have the power to hear and
determine tax appeals filed pursuant to the Local Taxpayer Bill of Rights Act.
   (b)   The Local Tax Hearing Officer shall not have authority or discretion
to abate penalty or interest. With respect to an appeal seeking review of the
imposition of penalty and interest, the Hearing Officer may only determine
whether interest and penalty have been properly calculated or whether the Local
Taxpayer Bill of Rights Act requires a mandatory abatement of penalty and
interest.
(Ord. 6339, approved 11-21-2017)
§ 301.03 TIME AND PROCEDURE FOR FILING APPEAL.
   (a)   Form of petition. A taxpayer may appeal any tax assessment, tax
determination or denial of refund of tax by filing a Petition for Review by
Local Tax Hearing Officer. All petitions shall be mailed or delivered to: City
of Williamsport, Attn: City Treasurer, PO Box 1283, 245 W. Fourth Street,
Williamsport, PA 17701.
      (1)   Petitions for Review by Local Tax Hearing Officer shall be in
writing on a form prescribed by the City of Williamsport. A petition is timely
filed if the letter transmitting the petition is postmarked by the United
States Postal Service on or before the final day on which the petition is
required to be filed. If hand delivered, a petition will be deemed to be filed
on the date received in the City Treasurer’s office at the address shown above.
      (2)   Petitions shall:
         (A)   State the name, address and telephone number of the taxpayer and
taxpayer’s authorized representative (if applicable);
         (B)   Identify the tax and tax period(s) to which the petition
pertains;
         (C)   State the amount of tax appealed and the legal basis for the
appeal (i.e., state how or why the assessment is incorrect, or why a refund
request should have been granted);
         (D)   Provide copies of all supporting documentation and calculations;
         (E)   State whether a hearing before the Hearing Officer is requested;
and
         (F)   Certify under penalty of perjury that the facts in the petition
are true and correct and that the petition is not filed for purposes of delay.
      (3)   There shall be no fee for filing a Petition for Review by Local Tax
Hearing Officer.
   (b)   Time in which appeal must be filed. A petition seeking a refund must
be filed within three years after the due date for filing the report, or one
year after actual payment of tax, whichever is later. If no report is required,
the petition shall be filed within three years after the due date for payment
of the tax or within one year after actual payment, whichever is later.
      (1)   A petition seeking a review of a tax assessment shall be filed
within 90 days of the date of the notice of assessment.
      (2)   Under the Local Taxpayer Bill of Rights Act, business tax appeals
are not governed by the rules pertaining to practice and procedure of local
agencies or judicial review of agency decisions. 53 P.S. § 8432. Therefore, a
taxpayer is not required to file an appeal to the Local Tax Hearing Officer in
order to preserve its ability to defend against an action by the city to
collect an assessment of delinquent taxes. Where a taxpayer does file a
petition and a decision is made by the Local Tax Hearing Officer, such decision
may be appealed by either party to the Court of Common Pleas for Lycoming
County for de novo review.
(Ord. 6339, approved 11-21-2017)
§ 301.04 APPEALS PROCESS, PROCEDURE AND CONDUCT OF HEARING.
   (a)   (1)   Upon receipt of a timely filed Petition for Review by Local Tax
Hearing Officer, the city shall:
         (A)   Promptly schedule a hearing if a hearing has been requested by
the taxpayer (if a hearing is not requested, the petition will be determined on
the record before the Local Tax Hearing Officer);
         (B)   Provide the taxpayer with a notice of hearing (setting forth the
time, date, and location of the hearing); and
         (C)   Forward the taxpayer’s petition to the Local Tax Hearing Officer
appointed by the city.
      (2)   Unless the date of the hearing is agreed upon by all parties, the
city shall give at least seven days’ written notice of the hearing to taxpayer.
   (b)   Hearings. Hearings shall be held at City Hall, 245 W. Fourth Street,
Williamsport, PA 17701, and due to taxpayer confidentiality requirements shall
not be open to the public. Hearings will be informal in nature and technical
rules of evidence will not be applicable, except that no person may testify as
to matters about which he/she does not have personal knowledge. All persons who
testify shall do so under oath. At the discretion of the Hearing Officer, the
hearing may take place and/or witnesses may appear from remote locations.
      (1)   Representation. Taxpayers may appear before the Hearing Officer
with or without benefit of representation. Any person seeking to represent a
taxpayer at the hearing must first be so authorized by the taxpayer in writing.
A taxpayer’s representative may only testify as to matters about which he/she
has personal knowledge.
      (2)   Presentation of evidence. Evidence may be submitted and considered
that possesses probative value commonly accepted by reasonably prudent persons
in the conduct of their affairs. Testimony shall be under oath or affirmation,
administered by the Hearing Officer. Copies of all records and other exhibits
shall be provided to all parties and to the Hearing Officer. Any party may have
a recording or a transcript made of the hearing at the party’s expense.
      (3)   Failure to appear. The hearing may proceed in the absence of any
party who fails to appear despite notice, but the Hearing Officer’s decision
shall not be based solely upon the failure of a party to appear.
   (c)   Local Tax Hearing Officer’s decision. After the conclusion of the
hearing, the Hearing Officer shall issue a written decision to the parties
within 60 days from the date of the filing of the petition, unless the taxpayer
has waived its right to receive a decision within 60 days.
(Ord. 6339, approved 11-21-2017)
§ 301.05 JUDICIAL APPEAL.
   Any person aggrieved by a decision on a petition for review, who has a
direct interest in the decision, has the right to appeal to the Court of Common
Pleas of Lycoming County, Pennsylvania for a de novo review.
(Ord. 6339, approved 11-21-2017)
§ 301.06 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This article shall become effective January 1, 2018.
(Ord. 6339, approved 11-21-2017)
ARTICLE 302: INSTALLMENT PAYMENTS FOR CITY REAL ESTATE TAXES
Section
   
302.01   Definitions.
   
302.02   Authorization and implementation of installment payments.
   
302.03   Payment schedule and conditions.
   
302.04   Administration and enforcement.
   
302.05   Violations and penalties.
   
302.06   Severability.
   
302.07   Effective date.
§ 302.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, and words
shall have the meaning given herein.
   DUE DATE. The specific date by which an installment payment must be made to
avoid penalties.
   INSTALLMENT PLAN. A payment arrangement for city real estate taxes whereby
the total tax due is paid in three separate installments, as outlined in this
article.
   INSTALLMENT PLAN PAYMENT. A payment made pursuant to an installment plan
authorized by this article.
   TAXPAYER. Any individual, business entity, limited liability company,
partnership, corporation, or association liable for the payment of city real
estate taxes to the City of Williamsport.
(Ord. 6488, approved 12-5-2024)
§ 302.02 AUTHORIZATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF INSTALLMENT PAYMENTS.
   (a)   The City Council of the City of Williamsport hereby authorizes city
real estate taxes to be paid through an installment plan, in accordance with 72
Pa. Stat. § 5511.11.
   (b)   The City Treasurer and other appropriate officials are hereby
authorized and directed to implement and administer the installment plan
system.
   (c)   Any taxpayer liable for city real estate taxes may elect to pay via an
installment plan by providing payment for the first installment to the City
Treasurer on or before March 31 of the tax year.
(Ord. 6488, approved 12-5-2024)
§ 302.03 PAYMENT SCHEDULE AND CONDITIONS.
   (a)   Installment plan payments shall be divided into three equal payments
as follows:
      (1)   The first installment plan payment shall be due by March 31.
      (2)   The second installment plan payment shall be due by May 31.
      (3)   The third and final installment plan payment shall be due by July
31.
   (b)   Taxpayers electing the installment plan option shall pay the face
amount of the tax due, without discount.
   (c)   A penalty of 10% shall be applied to any installment payment collected
past the due date as required by state law.
(Ord. 6488, approved 12-5-2024)
§ 302.04 ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   Installment payments may be made via check, money order, or other
payment methods as deemed acceptable by the City Treasurer. The City Treasurer
shall have the authority to establish procedures for the efficient collection
of installment payments.
   (b)   The City Treasurer shall have the authority to collect the remaining
balance due if a taxpayer fails to make an installment payment by the
applicable due date.
   (c)   The City Treasurer shall issue written notice by the thirtieth of
November to any taxpayer who fails to make an installment payment by the due
date, indicating the penalty amount and the total amount now due.
   (d)   For taxpayers who elect the installment option and are delinquent by
more than ten days or more on installment payments, the City Treasurer shall
have the authority to disqualify the taxpayer from installments in the
following tax year.
(Ord. 6488, approved 12-5-2024)
§ 302.05 VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   (a)   Any taxpayer who elects the installment plan but fails to make timely
payments, as required herein, shall be subject to a penalty of 10% on the
overdue amount.
   (b)   The City Treasurer shall have the authority to pursue collection of
amounts due under this article in accordance with state and local law.
(Ord. 6488, approved 12-5-2024)
§ 302.06 SEVERABILITY.
   If any section, clause, provision, or portion of this article shall be held
invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such
decision shall not affect any other section, clause, provision, or portion of
this article so long as they remain enforceable.
(Ord. 6488, approved 12-5-2024)
§ 302.07 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This article shall become effective 20 days after final enactment by the
city.
(Ord. 6488, approved 12-5-2024)

property in the city, as referred to in § 602(2) of such Act, as amended, and
orders this ratio to be applied to the market valuation supplied by Lycoming
County. This ratio is set at the market valuation supplied by the county.
(Ord. 4079, approved 5-31-1966)

Mayor and duly certified, accompanied by a statement of the vote thereon, with
the names of the members of Council voting for and against such legislation,
shall be forwarded by the City Clerk to be filed in the office of the Secretary
of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 4079, approved 5-31-1966)
ARTICLE 304: BUSINESS IMPROVEMENT DISTRICT

§ 304.01 BOUNDARIES.
   The Williamsport Business Improvement District shall be bounded as follows:
on the north by the south side of Little League Boulevard; on the west by the
east side of Hepburn Street from the south side of Little League Boulevard to
the south side of West Third Street, along the south side West Third Street to
the east side of Government Place, then south on the east side of Government
Place to the south side of West Church Street, then east to the east side of
William Street, then south on William Street to the north side of Via Bella; on
the south by the north side of Via Bella; on the east by the west side of
Market Street from the south side of Little League Boulevard to the south side
of West Willow Street, then to the east side of Market Street, then south to
the north side of East Third Street, then east 145 feet, then south to the
south side of East Third Street, then west 145 feet to the east side of Market
Street, and then south on the east side of Market Street to the north side of
Via Bella. Properties within the Williamsport Business Improvement District
shall include properties abutting on the side of any street forming a boundary
of such district, as well as all properties within the boundaries of the
District.
(Ord. 4796, approved 1-10-1977; Ord. 4848, approved 9-12-1977)
§ 304.02 IMPROVEMENTS AND RESPECTIVE COSTS.
   The improvements and respective costs are estimated as follows:
                                     General conditions            $253,245
                                     Pavement removal              $98,926
                                     Paving                        $528,219
                                     Planting                      $171,932
                                     Street furniture              $243,424
                                     Reset catch basins, manholes, $161,931
                                     utilities, etc.
                                     Construction costs            $1,457,677
                                     Contingency                   $63,563
                                     Total construction costs      $1,521,240
                                     Design fees                   $118,760
                                     Anticipated signalization     $50,000
Less: Grants Redevelopment Authority $240,000                      $1,690,000
Lycoming County                      $50,000
William sport Foundation             $200,000
                                     $490,000                      $490,000
                                     Amount to be assessed         $1,200,000
Plus: financing for 20 years at 6%
 
(Ord. 4753, approved 6-21-1976)
§ 304.03 GIFTS, GRANTS OR CONTRIBUTIONS.
   The appropriate city officials are hereby authorized to accept and receive
gifts, grants or contributions from any individuals, associations, corporations
or local, state or federal governmental agency, which may be used in the
development and improvement of the District or for the retirement of any debt
incurred for the original construction of the mall.
(Ord. 4796, approved 1-10-1977)
§ 304.04 METHOD OF ASSESSMENT.
   The total cost of the improvements of the District including, but not
limited to, costs of planning, feasibility study, acquisition, construction,
materials, fees and matters related thereto that have not been met or satisfied
by gifts, grants or contributions, that the city or the Williamsport
Redevelopment Authority receive towards the costs of improving the District, as
authorized and provided for in this article, may be assessed to and against all
of the properties benefitted, accommodated or improved in the District by an
assessment determined by multiplying the total of such improvement costs by the
ratio of the county assessed value for real estate taxes of the benefitted
property to the total county assessment valuation for real estate taxes of all
benefitted properties in the District.
(Ord. 4796, approved 1-10-1977)
§ 304.05 FINANCING.
   The costs of the Business Improvement District shall be financed by the
issuance of notes by the city or an instrumentality thereof, and the proper
city officials are directed to take such action and do such things as necessary
to issue such notes as might be required for such purpose pursuant to and in
accordance with the applicable provisions of the Local Government Unit Debt
Act.
(Ord. 4796, approved 1-10-1977)
§ 304.06 PAYMENT OF ASSESSMENTS AND MUNICIPAL CLAIMS.
   (a)   (1)   The payment for the assessments made pursuant to § 304.04 shall
be due and payable within 60 days of notice of the assessment, unless
application for installment payments as hereinafter provided is made. If any
owner of property against which an assessment has been made and who has not
applied for installment payments, refuses or neglects to pay such assessment
within 60 days after service of the notice of assessment has been made in the
manner provided by law and within the time permitted by law, the City Solicitor
shall file a municipal claim or lien therefor, together with interest at the
rate of 6% per year from date of completion of the work.
      (2)   The Treasurer of the city shall certify to the Solicitor all unpaid
assessments and the Solicitor shall file municipal claims or liens therefor in
the proper office of Lycoming County, as provided by law against the property
or properties with respect to which such assessment or assessments have been
charged. The Solicitor, thereupon, shall proceed to collect all such
assessments under general laws relating to collection of municipal claims,
including, if so directed by the city, the filing of suit or suits in
assumpsit. In, no event shall any municipal claim be filed later than the last
day permitted by law for such filing. Certificates of the City Engineer or the
consulting engineers filed with the city pursuant to law shall be conclusive
with respect to the times of completion as therein set forth.
   (b)   Any owner or owners of property against which an assessment has been
made shall have the privilege, upon written request, in form specified by the
city filed with the city within 30 days after notice of assessment has been
given to the property owner and payment of the costs of preparation and filing
of the required lien form, to make payments of such assessment in 20 equal
annual installments. The first installment thereof shall be due and payable 10-
30-1977, and each subsequent installment shall be due the same date each
calendar year thereafter, together with interest on the balance due at the rate
of 6% per year. However, the granting of such privilege of paying any
assessment in installments shall not prevent the city from or relieve the city
of the duty of filing a municipal claim or lien for every assessment not paid
in full within 60 days of service of notice of assessment for such district
improvements.
   (c)   Notwithstanding the filing of such claims, all assessments which are
made payable in installments shall constitute liens and encumbrances upon the
respective benefitted properties at the beginning of each calendar year in an
amount equal to the sum of the annual installment becoming payable in such
year, with interest and penalties, if any, thereon, and the total of all
installments, with interest and penalties thereon, which became due during
prior years and which remain due and unpaid at the beginning of the current
year.
   (d)   In the event any installment payment of principal or interest payable
under the installment basis is not paid when due, and such installment payment
remains unpaid 60 days after it first became due, the Treasurer shall, when
such default has occurred, notify the Solicitor of such fact promptly, and the
Solicitor shall proceed to collect the same under the general laws relating to
collection of municipal claims, including, if so directed by the city, the
filing of suit or suits in assumpsit only as to the overdue installment with
interest and penalties. However, if any installment or portion thereof remains
due and unpaid for one year after it has become due and payable, then the
entire assessment with accrued interest and penalties shall become due and
become a lien from the due date of the installment.
   (e)   No action taken to enforce a claim for any installment or installments
shall affect the status of any subsequent installment of the same assessment,
each of which shall continue to become a lien upon the property annually
pursuant to subsection (d) hereof.
   (f)   Any owner of property, against whom an assessment has been made, may
pay the same in full, at any time, with accrued interest and costs thereon, and
such payment shall discharge the lien of assessment or installments then
constituting a lien, and also release the claim to any later installments.
(Ord. 4796, approved 1-10-1977)
§ 304.07 DISPOSITION OF PAYMENTS.
   All payments collected or received for payment of assessments and interest
pursuant to §
304.06 shall be paid into a separate account and shall be used solely for the
payment of interest and principal of the notes issued to finance the
Williamsport Business Improvement District.
(Ord. 4796, approved 1-10-1977)
§ 304.08 LEVY BASED ON RATIO VALUE.
   The city hereby levies, assesses and charges the cost of construction of
improvements within the Williamsport Business Improvement District against the
properties benefitted, improved or accommodated by multiplying the sum of
$1,272,248 by the ratio of the assessed valuation in 1977 of the benefitted
property to the total assessment valuation in 1977 of all benefitted property
in the District as determined by the county assessment on such benefitted
properties.
(Ord. 4842, approved 8-11-1977)
§ 304.09 ASSESSMENT NOTICE AND DATE DUE.
   (a)   The City Treasurer shall, within 20 days after passage of this
section, give notice of such assessments, by serving notice upon the owner by
certified mail at his or her last known address. If the owner cannot be
located, then such notice shall be served upon an adult person residing in or
occupying such premises and, in the absence of such occupancy, the notice shall
be posted in a conspicuous place upon such premises in a manner intended to
give notice thereof to the owner.
   (b)   Council shall cause the Treasurer to certify a complete duplicate copy
thereof to the Director of the Department of Finance and Personnel for record
in the office of the Department of Finance and Personnel. Such assessment shall
become due and payable to the Treasurer immediately upon notice of the
assessment as herein provided.
   (c)   It shall be the duty of the Treasurer to keep the moneys received by
him or her under this article separate and apart from all other moneys of the
city, and no part thereof shall be used for or be apportioned for any purpose
other than the payment of the improvements within the Williamsport Business
Improvement District provided in
Art. 304.
(Ord. 4842, approved 8-11-1977)
§ 304.10 INSTALLMENT PAYMENTS.
   Any owner of property against which an assessment has been made, as provided
by this article, shall have the privilege, upon written request, in form
specified by the city, filed with the Treasurer within 30 days, after the
notice of assessment has been given to the property owner together with the
costs of preparation and filing of the required lien form, to make payment of
the balance of such assessment in 20 equal annual installments within the next
following 20 calendar years with the first installment thereof being due and
payable 10-31-1977 and each subsequent installment due the same date each
calendar year thereafter, together with interest on the balance due at the rate
of 6% per year. However, the granting of such privilege of paying any
assessment in installments shall not prevent the city from or relieve the city
of the duty of filing a municipal claim or lien as authorized by 53 Pa.C.S. §§
5406.
(Ord. 4842, approved 8-11-1977)
§ 304.11 DELINQUENCY AND DEFAULT; COLLECTION.
   In the event any installment payment of principal or interest payable under
the installment basis is not paid when due, and such installment payment
remains unpaid 60 days after it first became due, the Treasurer shall, when
such default has occurred, notify the Solicitor of such fact promptly, and the
Solicitor shall proceed to collect the same under the general laws relating to
collection of municipal claims, including if so directed by the city the filing
of suit or suits in assumpsit only as to the overdue installment with interest
and penalties. However, if any installment or portion thereof remains due and
unpaid for one year after it has become due and payable, then the entire
assessment with accrued interest and penalties shall become due and become a
lien from the due date of the installment.
(Ord. 4842, approved 8-11-1977)
§ 304.12 PAYMENT IN FULL.
   Any such owner or owners who have been granted the privilege of paying any
assessment in installments, as provided herein, may pay the entire balance
remaining due at any time, with interest thereon to the next installment
payment date, and such payment shall discharge the municipal claim or lien.
(Ord. 4842, approved 8-11-1977)
§ 304.13 ENFORCEMENT BY MUNICIPAL CLAIM, LIEN OR SUIT.
   If any owner of property against which an assessment has been made refuses
or neglects to pay such assessment within 60 days after service of the notice
of assessment has been made in the manner provided by law and within the time
permitted by law, the City Solicitor shall file a municipal claim or lien
therefor, together with interest at the rate of 6% per year from 1977. The
Treasurer shall certify to the Solicitor all unpaid assessments in the proper
office of Lycoming County, as provided by law, against the property or
properties with respect to which such assessment or assessments have been
charged. The Solicitor thereupon shall proceed to collect all such assessments
under general laws relating to collection of municipal claims, including, if so
directed by the city, the filing of suit or suits in assumpsit, unless the
owner or owners shall have been granted the privilege of paying such assessment
or assessments in installments, as provided in § 304.10 herein, and at the time
shall not in default in payment of installments, including interest, as
provided in § 304.10 herein. Certificates of the Director of Public Services
filed with the city pursuant to law shall be conclusive with respect to the
times of completion as therein set forth.
(Ord. 4842, approved 8-11-1977)
ARTICLE 305: DELINQUENT TAXES
Section
   
305.01   Definitions.
   
305.02   Duty of Director of Finance and Personnel.
   
305.03   Indebtedness to city.
   
305.04   Demand for agreement with city.
   
305.05   Power of Council as to agreements.
   
305.06   Refusal to make agreement.
Statutory reference:
   State law provisions, see 72 P.S. §§ 5860.102 et seq.
§ 305.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article:
   CITY. The City of Williamsport.
   DELINQUENT TAXES AND MUNICIPAL CLAIMS. Includes all delinquent taxes and
municipal claims, whether or not liens for such taxes or claims have been filed
in the office of the Prothonotary of Lycoming County and includes also all
penalties, interest and costs due on such delinquent taxes and municipal
claims.
   PERSON. Includes any individual, association, copartnership and corporation.
(Ord. 1681, approved 12-12-1939)
§ 305.02 DUTY OF DIRECTOR OF FINANCE AND PERSONNEL.
   The Director of Finance and Personnel, before approving the claim or account
of any person against the city, shall have power to inquire of the City
Treasurer, whether such person is indebted to the city for or on account of any
delinquent taxes or municipal claims.
(Ord. 1681, approved 12-12-1939)
§ 305.03 INDEBTEDNESS TO CITY.
   In any case where it is found that any person is so indebted to the city,
the approval of such claim or account in whole or in part shall be withheld by
the Director of Finance and Personnel, until such person has entered into an
agreement with the city as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 1681, approved 12-12-1939)
§ 305.04 DEMAND FOR AGREEMENT WITH CITY.
   The Director of Finance and Personnel shall make demand, in writing, in the
name of the city upon the person claiming against the city and owing the city
delinquent taxes or municipal claims, as aforementioned, that such person enter
into an agreement with the city as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 1681, approved 12-12-1939)
§ 305.05 POWER OF COUNCIL AS TO AGREEMENTS.
   Council shall have power to enter into such agreements as it deems necessary
to assure the payment of delinquent taxes and municipal claims by persons
having claims or accounts against the city, including therein provision for the
application of moneys due by the city on any such claim or account to the
payment of such delinquent taxes and municipal claims and the satisfaction of
such taxes and municipal claims on the public records in whole or in part.
(Ord. 1681, approved 12-12-1939)
§ 305.06 REFUSAL TO MAKE AGREEMENT.
   If any person, after the Director of Finance and Personnel, makes the demand
mentioned in §
305.04, refuses to enter into any such agreement, the Director shall continue
to further withhold his approval of such claim or account against the city or
any part thereof, and advise such person that the city has a set-off against
his or her claim or account, or the part thereof not approved, for delinquent
taxes and municipal claims and that payment thereof shall be refused until such
delinquent taxes and municipal claims are paid or provision for their payment
is made.
(Ord. 1681, approved 12-12-1939)
ARTICLE 307: REAL ESTATE REGISTRY
Section
   
307.01   Creation of Registry under Director of Public Services.
   
307.02   Records to be kept; duty of Director.
   
307.03   Duty of owners to register.
   
307.04   Records in Director’s office; certified copies.
   
307.05   Use of records.
   
307.06   Registry of deeds; deed to be stamped.
   
307.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Realty transfer tax, see Part Three,
Art. 345
Statutory reference:
   State law provisions, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 12704
§ 307.01 CREATION OF REGISTRY UNDER DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICES.
   There is established in the city an office for the registration of the
ownership of all real estate situated in the city, which office shall be under
the direction and supervision of the Director of Public Services.
(Ord. 1070, approved 9-25-2007)
§ 307.02 RECORDS TO BE KEPT; DUTY OF DIRECTOR.
   The Director of Public Services shall cause to be made, all necessary books,
maps and plans of the city showing the situation and dimensions of each
property therein, with the city number and name of the owner or owners of each
lot, with provisions for the names of future owners and dates of future
transfer of title. For such purpose, the Director shall cause a search to be
made in any of the public records wherein the information necessary to
determine ownership may be obtainable and in any other place for any evidences
of title requisite for the completion of the books, maps or plans. The books,
maps and plans shall be carefully preserved in the office of the Director and
shall be so kept by addition from time to time as to show the ownership of
every lot, piece of real estate or subdivision thereof, within the city with
the successive transmissions of title from the date of the commencement of such
plans. Nothing herein shall invalidate any municipal or tax claim by reason
that the same is not assessed or levied against the registered owner. The
books, maps and plans, so prepared by the Director, before the final adoption
thereof, shall be approved by the City Solicitor.
(Ord. 1070, approved 9-25-2007)
§ 307.03 DUTY OF OWNERS TO REGISTER.
   It shall be the duty of all owners of unregistered real estate within the
city, and of every subsequent purchaser within one month after acquiring title,
to furnish the Director of Public Services, at his or her office, descriptions
of their respective properties, upon blanks to be furnished by the city, and at
the same time to present their conveyance to be stamped by the Director without
charge as evidence of the registration thereof.
(Ord. 1070, approved 9-25-2007)
§ 307.04 RECORDS IN DIRECTOR’S OFFICE; CERTIFIED COPIES.
   The books, maps or plans made by the Director of Public Services, or under
his or her direction, shall remain in the office of the Director and under his
or her custody and control, and in no event for any purpose shall be removed
therefrom by any person. However, the Director shall issue, to such persons as
may desire the same, certified copies of any of the entries in the books or
upon the maps or plans, upon payment of the fee of $1 for each separate
property described in each certificate; provided, not more than one full lot of
a frontage of 52 feet shall be embraced within one description. The fee, so
received by the Director for the certificates, shall be paid into the City
Treasury monthly, and an itemized statement thereof shall be furnished to the
City Treasurer and the City Controller, with the affidavit of the Director
appended thereto.
(Ord. 1070, approved 9-25-2007)
§ 307.05 USE OF RECORDS.
   The Board of Revision and Appeals shall, at all times, have full and free
use of the books, maps or plans, without removal from the office of the
Director of Public Services.
(Ord. 1070, approved 9-25-2007)
§ 307.06 REGISTRY OF DEEDS; DEED TO BE STAMPED.
   The Sheriff of Lycoming County shall present for registry the deeds of all
properties, within the limits of the city sold by him or her at any judicial
sales whether in partition or otherwise. The Prothonotary of the county shall
not admit for record any deed for any real estate within the city bearing date
subsequent to 9-25-1907, unless the same has first been duly stamped, as
required herein, as proof of registry.
(Ord. 1070, approved 9-25-2007)
§ 307.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates the provisions of §
307.03 for a period of 30 days after public notice of the requirements thereof,
shall be fined not more than $5. The presentation of the deeds for registry and
certification by the Recorder of Deeds or Sheriff, as now provided by law,
shall be in lieu of such presentation by the owner.
(Ord. 1070, approved 9-25-2007)

TITLE THREE: BUSINESS LICENSING AND REGULATION
ARTICLE 311: AUCTION SALES
Section
   
311.01   Permit required; fee and authority.
   
311.02   Permit application information.
   
311.03   Conduct of permittee’s employees; cappers; false bids.
   
311.04   Term of permit.
   
311.05   Place of sale.
   
311.06   Required length of time in business.
   
311.07   Subsequent permits.
   
311.08   Goods offered for sale.
   
311.09   Exceptions.
   
311.99   Penalty.
Statutory reference:
   Auctioneers License Act, see Act 708 of 9-29-1961 (P.L. 1745) (63 P.S. §§
701 et seq.)
   City limited to permit fee collection only, see 63 P.S. § 717
   Regulation of auctions, see 3rd Class § 2403(46) (53 P.S. § 37403(46))
§ 311.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE AND AUTHORITY.
   (a)   Each auctioneer or apprentice auctioneer, prior to conducting an
auction in the city, shall first obtain a permit from the City Treasurer for
each sale conducted for any one owner or person, and pay a permit fee as
provided in §
117.03(o).
   (b)   This fee is levied pursuant to authority by an Act of the General
Assembly approved 9-29-1961 (P.L. 1745).
(Ord. 2982, approved 2-7-1963)
§ 311.02 PERMIT APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   Applications for permits shall be made to the City Treasurer, upon suitable
forms to be provided by the City Treasurer, setting forth under oath:
   (a)   The name of the person whose goods, wares and merchandise are to be
sold;
   (b)   The stand or location where such goods, wares or merchandise are to be
sold under such permit;
   (c)   The names and addresses of the persons who are to act as auctioneers,
such auctioneers to be duly licensed;
   (d)   The reasons for desiring a permit for the sale of merchandise;
   (e)   The fact as to the kind, quality, quantity, value and condition of
such goods, wares and merchandise to be offered for sale;
   (f)   The name of the persons, firms or corporations, from whom the goods,
wares and merchandise to be sold under the permit, were last obtained.
(Ord. 1199, approved 3-26-1930)
§ 311.03 CONDUCT OF PERMITTEE’S EMPLOYEES; CAPPERS; FALSE BIDS.
   A permitte shall be held responsible for the conduct of such persons as may
be employed to sell the goods, wares and merchandise, and shall not make or
permit anyone conducting such sale, to make untruthful statements or
misrepresent articles to bidders as to the description, quality or kind of
goods, wares and merchandise offered for sale, nor shall he or she employ, use
or permit the employment or use of by-bidders, commonly called “cappers”, nor
shall he or she offer or make a false bid or a pretense of buying goods, wares
or merchandise, offered for sale by virtue of his or her permit, nor shall the
permittee offer or permit to be offered, or give or permit to be given, any
premium or any merchandise whatsoever as a premium or incentive to bidders.
(Ord. 1199, approved 3-26-1930)
§ 311.04 TERM OF PERMIT.
   No permit shall be granted under this article for a period longer than 15
successive days, Sundays and holidays excepted, at any one location in the
city.
(Ord. 1199, approved 3-26-1930)
§ 311.05 PLACE OF SALE.
   No person holding an auction permit shall conduct a sale at any other place
than that designated in the permit.
(Ord. 1199, approved 3-26-1930)
§ 311.06 REQUIRED LENGTH OF TIME IN BUSINESS.
   No person shall be granted an auction permit unless he or she has been
conducting business at the same place designated in the application for a
period of one year previous to the date of application under the same trade
name.
(Ord. 1199, approved 3-26-1930)
§ 311.07 SUBSEQUENT PERMITS.
   Subsequent permits shall not be granted to the same permittee at a given
location until one complete year has elapsed from the expiration of the former
permit.
(Ord. 1199, approved 3-26-1930)
§ 311.08 GOODS OFFERED FOR SALE.
   No holder of an auction permit shall sell or offer for sale, any goods,
wares or merchandise, other than those set forth in his or her application for
such permit.
(Ord. 1199, approved 3-26-1930)
§ 311.09 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this article shall not apply to judicial sales or sales by
executors or administrators, nor to sales of unredeemed pledges by or on behalf
of licensed pawnbrokers in the manner prescribed by law, nor to the sale of
farm products, farming implements, livestock, household goods sold from private
homes and secondhand household goods and antiques sold by any merchant, real
estate, machinery and equipment, nor to personal property not in the general
line of merchandise, nor to any sale at auction held by any church, charitable
or fraternal organization.
(Ord. 1565, approved 4-12-1937)
§ 311.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not less than
$50, nor more than $100, or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. Each
violation shall be considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 1199, approved 3-26-1930; Ord. 4566, approved 3-22-1973)

ARTICLE 321: PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
Section
   
321.01   License required; exceptions.
   
321.02   Trespassing in violation of posted signs.
   
321.03   License application, investigation and fee.
   
321.04   Hours and business restrictions.
   
321.05   License suspension or revocation.
   
321.06   Stopping and parking.
   
321.07   Center City Mall (repealed).
   
321.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Selling from parked vehicles prohibited, see Part Five, §
521.09
Statutory reference:
   General power to levy license taxes, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§
12601, 12601.1
§ 321.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   No person shall sell or offer for sale, order or exchange, or go from door
to door soliciting the purchase of, or gift of any products, wares, merchandise
or other articles of value or any money, or any services, in any place, in,
upon, along or through the streets, alleys or other public places within the
city, unless he is the holder of a license which is in full force and effect
and issued pursuant to provisions of this article. Such person shall at all
times have the license with him while exercising such calling, and shall
exhibit the license to any police officer, official or city resident upon
demand. Persons, who without compensation or remuneration, solicit on behalf of
or for any publicly recognized religious, educational, civic, charitable
organization and newspaper carriers along their regular delivery routes are not
required to obtain a license as provided herein.
(Ord. 4593, approved 8-23-1973; Ord. 6355, approved 1-31-2019)
§ 321.02 TRESPASSING IN VIOLATION OF POSTED SIGNS.
   No person, whether licensed or not, while engaged in any profit
solicitation, shall knock at the door or ring the bell of any home, apartment,
apartment building or other dwelling unit in the city upon which is displayed
at the entrance a notice which reads “No Peddlers or Solicitors Allowed”, or
which otherwise clearly purports to prohibit peddlers or solicitors on the
premises, unless such peddler or solicitor is or has been invited upon the
premises by the owner, licensee or occupant thereof. This section shall not be
applicable to persons who, without compensation or remuneration, solicit in
behalf of or for any publicly recognized religious, educational, civic or
charitable organization.
(Ord. 4593, approved 8-23-1973; Ord. 6355, approved 1-31-2019)
§ 321.03 LICENSE APPLICATION, INVESTIGATION AND FEE.
   (a)   Any person required to have a license under §
321.01 and who desires to engage in the business of a peddler or solicitor
shall make application in person for a license at the Williamsport Police
Department. Upon receipt of the application, the applicant shall provide the
proper background check information as required and additional information as
deemed necessary by the Williamsport Police Department to the character of the
applicant and the business to be conducted to protect the interest of the city
residents.
   (b)   Upon approval by the Police Chief or his designee, the applicant shall
pay a license fee as provided in §
117.03(p), depending on the term of the license applied for.
(Ord. 4593, approved 8-23-1973; Ord. 6355, approved 1-31-2019)
§ 321.04 HOURS AND BUSINESS RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   No person whether licensed or not shall engage in any profit
solicitation before the hour of 9:00 a.m. or after the hour of 5:00 p.m. nor on
Sundays or on any legal holiday.
   (b)   No licensed peddler or solicitor shall engage in or transact any type
of business or solicitation other than that specified on the license
application.
(Ord. 4593, approved 8-23-1973; Ord. 6355, approved 1-31-2019)
§ 321.05 LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   The Police Chief or anyone acting on his behalf may suspend or revoke any
peddler's or solicitor's license for violation of any city ordinance, false or
incorrect information submitted on the license application or for any fraud or
misrepresentation made in the solicitation. Such person whose license is
suspended above may not apply for a new license thereafter until one complete
calendar year after such revocation or license suspension.
(Ord. 4593, approved 8-23-1973; Ord. 6355, approved 1-31-2019)
§ 321.06 STOPPING AND PARKING.
   All peddlers or solicitors shall comply with
Art. 521 of the codified ordinances regulating the stopping and parking of
motor vehicles.
(Ord. 5045, approved 6-5-1980; Ord. 6355, approved 1-31-2019)
§ 321.07 CENTER CITY MALL.
   Editor’s note:
      This section was repealed by Ord. 6355, approved 1-31-2019.
§ 321.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not less than
$50 nor more than $600, or the maximum provided by state law, or imprisoned not
more than 90 days, or both.
(Ord. 5535, approved 9-5-1991; Ord. 6355, approved 1-31-2019)

§ 327.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This article shall be known and may be cited as the “Cable Television
Franchise Ordinance”.
(Ord. 5459, approved 12-14-1989; Ord. 6000, approved 7-21-2005)
§ 327.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense shall include the future;
words in the plural number include the singular number; and words in the
singular number include the plural number. “May” will be interpreted as
permissive and “shall” will be interpreted as mandatory. Other terms not
specifically defined will have the meanings generally accorded to them in the
cable television industry.
   ADDITIONAL SERVICES. Any video programming, including expanded basic tier
(the tier including basic service, plus additional satellite delivered
programming), premium channels (e.g., HBO, Showtime, Cinemax and the like) pay-
per-view events for additional charges above the charge to subscriber for basic
services and provided to subscribers over the cable television system, but not
including basic services.
   ANNUAL GROSS SUBSCRIBER REVENUES.
      (1)   Revenue received by the grantee from subscribers within the city
attributable to the following cable services: basic service, additional
services, installation or disconnection of service, equipment sales or rental,
revenues from home shopping and cable advertising (net of agency fees) and
revenues from channel leasing. ANNUAL GROSS SUBSCRIBER REVENUES excludes any
other revenues, including, but not limited to, revenues attributable to taxes
or franchise fees, refunds, credits, security deposits, revenues from the
provision of cable modem service or revenues from the sale or rental equipment
for telephony services or revenue from telephony or telecommunications
services.
      (2)   If during the term of this franchise federal law is amended or
interpreted by the FCC or a court of competent jurisdiction, which decision is
a final order not subject to further appeal, to permit local franchise
authorities to collect franchise fees on revenues for new or existing services
not currently subject to franchise fees or included in the definitions of
ANNUAL GROSS SUBSCRIBER REVENUES, then the grantee shall notify the city of its
right to have franchise fees remitted on services not previously subject to
franchise fees. Beginning 60 days after notice from the city, the grantee shall
begin to remit franchise fees on revenues attributable to such services and
revenues from such services going forward shall be considered a part of annual
gross subscriber revenues. Revenues collected on such services prior to the
effective date of the city’s notice shall not be subject to franchise fees. The
grantee shall notify the city at the time of such change in the federal law;
provided, however, that, such failure to notify shall not be a material default
under this franchise, and the city’s remedy shall be to collect franchise fees
back to the date of the change of the law, but in no event for more than one
year.
   BASIC SERVICE. The minimum service transmitted to all subscribers, which
includes at a minimum all signals of domestic television broadcast stations
entitled to “must carry” status under FCC rules.
   CABLE ACT. The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 (47 U.S.C. §§ 521 et
seq.), as amended by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition
Act of 1992 (47 U.S.C. §§ 521 et seq.) and as further amended by the
Telecommunications Competition and Deregulation Act of 1996 (47 U.S.C. Ch. 5,
Subchs. I, II, VI) and as it may be further amended.
   CABLE SERVICES. The one-way transmission to subscribers of video
programming.
   CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEM. A facility consisting of a set of closed
transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception and control
equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video
programming to multiple subscribers within the city, excluding however, those
facilities excluded from such definition of cable system in the Cable Act (47
U.S.C. §§ 521 et seq.).
   CITY. The City of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
   CITY COUNCIL. The governing body of the City of Williamsport.
   FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION or FCC. The present federal agency of that
name as constituted by the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. §§ 151 et
seq.), or any successor agency created by the United States Congress.
   FRANCHISE. The non-exclusive right, privilege and authority granted by this
article to construct, maintain or generate a cable television system in the
city, and shall permit, in addition to the privilege to operate within the
city, the grantee to construct, maintain and operate such cable television
system with whatever wires or components as are necessary over, under or within
all city streets and rights-of-way.
   FRANCHISE FEE. The monies required to be paid to the city by the grantee for
the right to operate in the city and which are permitted by any federal or
state statute or regulation.
   GRANTEE. A person, firm, partnership, association, corporation or
organization of any kind granted a franchise under this article.
   PARTICIPATING MUNICIPALITIES. The following municipalities who have signed
or will sign identical or substantially similar franchise agreements: Armstrong
Township; Duboistown Borough; Fairfield Township; Hepburn Township; Loyalsock
Township; Lycoming Township; Old Lycoming Township; Montoursville Borough;
South Williamsport Borough; Susquehanna Township; the City of Williamsport; and
Woodward Township.
   PEG. The acronym for public, educational and governmental, used in
conjunction with access channels, support and facilities.
   PERSON. Any person, firm, corporation, association, trust, organization or
other business entity.
   STATE. The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
   STREETS and RIGHTS-OF-WAY. The surface of as well as the space above and
below all streets, roadways, highways, freeways, avenues, lanes, alleys,
courts, places, squares, curbs, sidewalks, easements, rights-of-way or other
public ways in the city which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and
opened to public use, or such other public property so designated by law which
shall within their proper use and meaning entitle city and grantee to access
thereon for the purpose of installing cable transmission lines over poles,
wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes, amplifiers,
appliances, attachments and other property as may be necessary and pertinent to
the cable television system in the city.
   SUBSCRIBER. Any person receiving and paying for basic service.
(Ord. 5459, approved 12-14-1989; Ord. 6000, approved 7-21-2005)
§ 327.03 GRANT OF AUTHORITY.
   (a)   Grant of franchise. Effective 1-1-2006 (effective date), the city may
award a new exclusive franchise to a grantee to construct, erect, operate and
maintain for a period of 15 years a cable television system for the reception,
origination, amplification, distribution and sale of audio, video, digital and
other forms of electronic signals in, upon, along, across, above, over or under
the streets and rights-of-way in the city, consisting of all poles, wires,
cable, underground conduits, manholes and other conduits and fixtures necessary
for the maintenance and operation in the city of a cable television system with
all of the necessary and desirable appliances and appurtenances pertaining
thereto. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, this franchise and
grant shall and does hereby include the right in, over, under and upon the
streets and rights-of-way in the city to install, erect, operate all lines and
equipment necessary to a cable television system and the right to make
connections to subscribers and the right to repair, replace, enlarge and extend
said lines, equipment and connections. The rights herein granted for the
