passed 9-4-2025)
§ 353.05 NOTICE TO TAXPAYERS.
   There shall be placed of the form application for building, zoning and
alteration permits, or by separate document, the following:
 
   NOTICE TO TAXPAYERS
Under the provisions of Article 353 of the City’s Codified Ordinances you may
be entitled to a property tax exemption on your contemplated alteration or new
construction. An application for exemption may be secured from the Department
of Community and Economic Development and must be filed within 30 days of
securing a building permit.
 
(Ord. 5742, approved 2-19-1998; Ord. 6151, approved 11-12-2009; Ord. 6297,
passed 3-17-2016; Ord. 6348, passed 11-20-2018; Ord. 6493, passed 2-27-2025;
Ord. 6511, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 353.06 PROCEDURE FOR EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   Within 30 days of securing the building permit for which an exemption
will be requested, or if no building permit is required, within 30 days of the
commencement of construction, the taxpayer shall make formal application for
exemption to the City’s Department of Community and Economic Development.
   (b)   The Taxpayer shall pay an application fee of $500 to defray the
administrative costs of the program, due at the time the application is
submitted.
   (c)   Requests for exemption shall be made in writing, on an application
form to be furnished by the City’s Department of Community and Economic
Development.
   (d)   A copy of the request for exemption shall be forwarded to the City’s
Director of Finance, the City Tax Collector, and the Lycoming County Board of
Assessment. A copy of the request for exemption shall also be forwarded to the
Lycoming County and Williamsport Area School District taxing authorities, each
of whom shall have ten days to review the application and provide any
objections or relevant information to the City’s Department of Community and
Economic Development.
   (e)   The Director of the City’s Department of Community and Economic
Development shall, after ten days and within 30 days of receipt of the request
for exemption, make a determination in writing of whether the taxpayer is
eligible in whole or in part for an exemption. A copy of this determination
shall be forwarded to the taxpayer, the City Tax Collector, the Lycoming County
Board of Assessment, and each of the local taxing authorities that have current
LERTA resolutions or ordinances in effect.
   (f)   Upon completion of the new construction or improvement, the Lycoming
County Board of Assessment shall assess the new construction or improvements
separately for the purpose of calculating the amount of assessment eligible for
tax exemption in accordance with the limits established in this article.
   (g)   The Lycoming County Board of Assessment shall notify the City, the
taxpayer, and any other participating Local Taxing Authority of the
reassessment and amounts to the assessment eligible for exemption. The
Treasurer is authorized to make refunds, if applicable, 30 days after the Board
has notified the Treasurer of its separate assessment upon which an exemption
is granted and no appeals have been timely filed.
   (h)   The taxpayer or any Local Taxing Authority may appeal the
determination of eligibility or the assessment eligible for exemption under the
provisions of §
353.11.
   (i)   In the event that the taxpayer shall receive, by whatever means, a
changed assessment, with regard to part or all of their property which is
currently the subject of the tax exemption provided in this article, such
change in assessment shall be applied proportionately to the portion of the
assessed value which is subject to a tax exemption and the portion of the
assessed value which is not subject to a tax exemption, and shall result in a
change of the tax exemption which was initially granted for purposes of the
number of exemption years still remaining on the exemption schedule. This
recalculation shall not apply to increased assessments as a result of new
construction or improvements on said property.
   (j)   The exemption from real estate taxes authorized by this article shall
terminate irrevocably upon default in the payment in full of non-exempt real
estate taxes, together with accrued penalties and/or interest, due to be paid
upon the deteriorated property exempted by December 31 of the year the taxes
become due. The tax collector shall notify the Assessment Agency of any such
default.
(Ord. 5742, approved 2-19-1998; Ord. 6151, approved 11-12-2009; Ord. 6511,
passed 9-4-2025)
§ 353.07 TERMINATION.
   (a)   Unless otherwise repealed by Council, this article shall terminate on
12-31-2026. No later than October 1 annually, the Mayor shall submit a written
report to Council which shall inform the Council as to how this article has
been administered, the effects of this article on the community and include any
suggestions or recommendations for this article’s reenactment, modification or
repeal.
   (b)   Nothing contained herein shall act to prohibit Council from enacting a
similar ordinance after 12-31-2026.
(Ord. 5742, approved 2-19-1998; Ord. 5779, approved 5-13-1999; Ord. 5854,
approved 9-13-2001; Ord. 5979, approved 12-23-2004; Ord. 6077, approved 9-20-
2007; Ord. 6151, approved 11-12-2009; Ord. 6297, passed 3-17-2016; Ord. 6348,
passed 11-20-2018; Ord. 6459, passed 7-20-2023; Ord. 6493, passed 2-27-2025;
Ord. 6511, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 353.08 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The Director of the Department of Community and Economic Development
is hereby authorized to prepare, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations
made pursuant to the provisions of this article, unless modified, revoked or
repealed by Council.
   (b)   A copy of said rules and regulations shall be filed with the City
Clerk at least 20 days prior to their becoming effective.
(Ord. 5742, approved 2-19-1998; Ord. 6511, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 353.09 SEVERABILITY.
   (a)   The provisions of this article are severable and if any of its
sections, clauses or sentences shall be held illegal, invalid or
unconstitutional, such provisions shall not affect or impair any of the
remaining sections, clauses or sentences.
   (b)   It is hereby declared to be the intent of Council that this article
would have been adopted if such illegal, invalid or unconstitutional section,
clause or sentence had not been included.
(Ord. 5742, approved 2-19-1998; Ord. 6511, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 353.10 RESERVED.
§ 353.11 APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   (a)   The taxpayer, or any Local Taxing Authority, may appeal the
determination of eligibility or the assessment eligible for exemption to the
LERTA Appeal Board within 30 days of the date of the determination notice.
   (b)   All appeals shall be made in writing and delivered to the Director of
the City’s Department of Community and Economic Development and the City Clerk.
   (c)   The Director shall notify the members of the LERTA Appeal Board, the
City Tax Collector, the Director of Finance, the Lycoming County Board of
Assessment, and each participating Local Taxing Authority of the pending
appeal.
   (d)   The Director of Economic and Community Development shall notify all
parties of the date, time and place of the appeal at least ten days prior to
the date of the hearing.
   (e)   The LERTA Appeal Board shall issue a decision to all parties within 30
days of the conclusion of the appeals hearing.
(Ord. 5742, approved 2-19-1998; Ord. 6151, approved 11-12-2009; Ord. 6511,
passed 9-4-2025)
§ 353.12 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This article shall become effective immediately 20 days after final
enactment and remain in effect thereafter from year to year, unless repealed,
until December 31, 2026. It shall apply retroactively to January 1, 2025, and
shall cover all applications for the exemption sought for buildings or
alterations for which a building permit has been obtained in the prior 30 days.
(Ord. 5742, approved 2-19-1998; Ord. 5854, approved 9-13-2001; Ord. 5979,
approved 12-23-2004; Ord. 6151, approved 11-12-2009; Ord. 6297, passed 3-17-
2016; Ord. 6348, passed 11-20-2018; Ord. 6459, passed 7-20-2023; Ord. 6493,
passed 2-27-2025; Ord. 6511, passed 9-4-2025)
ARTICLE 355: RESIDENTIAL
Section
   
355.01   Short title.
   
355.02   Purpose.
   
355.03   Definitions.
   
355.04   Exemption for improvement relating to deteriorated neighborhoods;
permits and compliance with law required; termination for tax delinquency.
   
355.05   Exemption for new residential construction relating to deteriorating
area; permits and compliance with law required.
   
355.06   Exemption schedule relating to improvements to deteriorated property
in deteriorated neighborhoods and new construction in deteriorating areas.
   
355.07   Notice to taxpayers.
   
355.08   Procedure for obtaining exemption.
   
355.09   Termination.
   
355.10   Rules and regulations.
   
355.11   Severability.
   
355.12   Reserved.
   
355.13   Appeal procedure.
   
355.14   Subsequent change in assessment.
   
355.15   Effective date.
§ 355.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This article shall be known as and may be cited as the “Williamsport
Residential LERTA Ordinance.”
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.02 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this article is to encourage investment and reinvestment in
the housing inventory of the city, pursuant to the authority contained in the
Act of 7-9-1971, P.L. 206, No. 34, as re-enacted and amended by Act 42 of 8-5-
1977, and amended by the Act of 10-18-2000, P.L. 613, Act 83 and amended by the
Act of 12-30-2002, P.L. 2085, Act No. 235, 72 P.S. §§ 4711-101 et seq.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.03 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the
meaning set forth below.
   ASSESSMENT AGENCY. The Lycoming County Board of Assessment Appeals.
   CITY. The City of Williamsport.
   DETERIORATED AREA. That portion of the city which has been determined to be
physically blighted on the basis of one or more of the following standards:
      (1)   The residential buildings, by reason of age, obsolescence,
inadequate or outmoded design or physical deterioration have become economic
and/or social liabilities;
      (2)   The residential buildings are substandard or unsanitary for
healthful and safe living purposes;
      (3)   The residential buildings are overcrowded, poorly spaced or are so
lacking light, space and air as to be conducive to unwholesome living;
      (4)   The residential buildings are faultily arranged, cover the land to
an excessive extent, show a deleterious use of land or exhibit any combination
of the above which is detrimental to health, safety or welfare;
      (5)   A significant percentage of buildings used for residential purposes
are more than 20 years of age;
      (6)   A substantial amount of unimproved, overgrown and unsightly vacant
land exists which has remained so for a period of five years or more indicating
a growing or total lack of utilization of land for residential purposes; and
      (7)   A disproportionate number of tax exempt or delinquent properties
exists in the area.
   DETERIORATED NEIGHBORHOOD. A deteriorated neighborhood as defined in the
aforesaid statute. For the purpose of this article, Tax Wards 1 through 16
respectively, constitute deteriorated neighborhoods and deteriorating areas
within the purview of the previously cited statute.
   DETERIORATED PROPERTY. A dwelling unit located in a deteriorated
neighborhood, as hereinafter provided, or a dwelling which has been or upon
request is certified by a health, housing or building inspection agency as
unfit for human habitation, for rent withholding, or other health or welfare
purposes, or has been the subject of an order by such an agency requiring the
unit to be vacated, condemned or demolished by reason of non-compliance with
laws, articles or regulations.
   DWELLING UNIT. A house, double house or duplex, townhouse or row house,
apartment or any building intended for occupancy as living quarters by an
individual, a family or families or other groups of persons, which living
quarters contain a kitchen or cooking equipment for the exclusive use of the
occupant or occupants.
   IMPROVEMENT. Repair, construction or reconstruction commencing after the
effective date of this article, including alterations and additions, having the
effect of rehabilitating a structure so that it becomes habitable or attains
higher standards of housing safety, health or amenity, or is brought into
compliance with laws, articles or regulations governing housing standards.
Ordinary upkeep and maintenance shall not be deemed an IMPROVEMENT.
   LERTA APPEAL BOARD. The City Council of the City of Williamsport shall serve
as the LERTA APPEAL BOARD unless a separate LERTA APPEAL BOARD is appointed by
the City Council of the City of Williamsport, as provided by law.
   LOCAL TAXING AUTHORITY. The City of Williamsport, the Williamsport Area
School District, the County of Lycoming or any other governmental entity having
authority to levy real property taxes within the City of Williamsport.
   NEW RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION. The building or erection, commencing after the
effective date of this article, of dwelling units, as defined in “dwelling
unit” hereof, upon vacant land or land specifically prepared to receive such
structures.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6186, approved 4-14-2011; Ord. 6460, passed
7-20-2023; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.04 EXEMPTION FOR IMPROVEMENT RELATING TO DETERIORATED NEIGHBORHOODS;
PERMITS AND COMPLIANCE WITH LAW REQUIRED; TERMINATION FOR TAX DELINQUENCY.
   (a)   There is hereby exempted from real estate taxation, in the amounts and
in accordance with the provisions and limitations hereinafter provided, that
portion of the assessment attributable to the improvements made to deteriorated
property within a deteriorating neighborhood.
   (b)   In all cases, the exemption from real estate taxes shall be limited to
that portion of the additional assessment attributable to the actual cost of
the improvement, and for which a separate assessment has been made by the
Lycoming County Board of Assessment Appeals and for which an exemption has been
separately requested.
   (c)   No property shall be entitled to a tax exemption as herein provided
unless the necessary and proper permits prior to improving the property have
been applied for and obtained.
   (d)   No tax exemption shall be granted if the improvements as completed do
not comply with all articles, rules, regulations, statutes and other applicable
laws.
   (e)   No property shall be entitled to a tax exemption as herein provided
unless the property and taxpayer applying for exemption are in compliance with
all applicable tax levies.
   (f)   No property, except mixed use properties, shall be entitled to a tax
exemption as herein provided if the improvements to the existing structure or
structures result in an increase in the number of dwelling units.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.05 EXEMPTION FOR NEW RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION RELATING TO DETERIORATING
AREA; PERMITS AND COMPLIANCE WITH LAW REQUIRED.
   (a)   There is hereby exempted from real estate taxation, in the amounts and
in accordance with the provisions and limitations hereinafter provided, the
assessed valuation of any new residential construction built in a deteriorating
area.
   (b)   In all cases, the exemption from real estate taxes shall apply to the
total assessed valuation attributable to the actual cost of the new residential
construction, for which an assessment has been made by the Lycoming County
Board of Assessment Appeals and for which an exemption has been requested.
   (c)   No property shall be entitled to a tax exemption herein provided
unless the necessary and proper permits prior to building the property have
been applied for and obtained.
   (d)   No tax exemption shall be granted if the improvements as completed do
not comply with all articles, rules, regulations, statutes and other applicable
laws.
   (e)   No property shall be entitled to a tax exemption as herein provided
unless the property and taxpayer applying for exemption are in compliance with
all applicable tax levies.
   (f)   No property, except mixed use properties, shall be entitled to a tax
exemption as herein provided if the improvements to the existing structure or
structures result in an increase in the number of dwelling units.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.06 EXEMPTION SCHEDULE RELATING TO IMPROVEMENTS TO DETERIORATED PROPERTY
IN DETERIORATED NEIGHBORHOODS AND NEW CONSTRUCTION IN DETERIORATING AREAS.
   (a)   The portion of the assessment of a property attributable to
improvements as determined by the assessment agency to be exempted from
taxation each year for ten years shall be in accordance with the schedule
below:
 
Year   Percentage Exempted
1 - 10 100
 
   After the tenth year, the exemption shall terminate.
   (b)   The exemption from real estate taxes authorized by this article shall
be upon the property exempted and shall not terminate upon the sale or exchange
of the property.
   (c)   The exemption from real estate taxes authorized by this article shall
terminate irrevocably upon default in the payment in full of non-exempt real
estate taxes, together with accrued penalties and/or interest, due to be paid
upon the deteriorated property exempted by December 31 of the year the taxes
become due. The tax collector shall notify the Assessment Agency of any such
default.
   (d)   Nothing in this section shall affect in any way the schedule of
exemption of taxes for properties approved for tax abatement under prior
schedules. Properties approved for tax abatements under prior schedules shall
continue to follow such prior schedules.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6460, passed 7-20-2023; Ord. 6510, passed
9-4-2025)
§ 355.07 NOTICE TO TAXPAYERS.
   There shall be placed on the form application for building, zoning and
alteration permits, or by separate document, the following:
 
   NOTICE TO TAXPAYERS
Under the provisions of Article 355 of the City’s Codified Ordinances you may
be entitled to a property tax exemption on your contemplated alteration or new
construction. An application for exemption may be secured from the Department
of Community and Economic Development, and must be filed within 30 days of
securing a building permit.
 
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6186, approved 4-14-2011; Ord. 6460, passed
7-20-2023; Ord. 6494, passed 2-27-2025; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.08 PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING EXEMPTION.
   (a)   Within 30 days of securing the building permit for which an exemption
will be requested, or if no building permit is required, within 30 days of the
commencement of construction, the taxpayer shall make formal application for
exemption to the City’s Department of Community and Economic Development.
   (b)   Requests for exemption shall be made in writing, on an application
form to be furnished by the City’s Department of Community and Economic
Development.
   (c)   A copy of the request for exemption shall be forwarded to the City’s
Director of Finance, the City Tax Collector, and the Lycoming County Board of
Assessment. A copy of the request for exemption shall also be forwarded to the
Lycoming County and Williamsport Area School District taxing authorities, each
of whom shall have ten days to review the application and provide any
objections or relevant information to the City’s Department of Community and
Economic Development.
   (d)   The Director of the City’s Department of Community and Economic
Development shall, after ten days and within 30 days of receipt of the request
for exemption, make a determination in writing of whether the taxpayer is
eligible in whole or in part for an exemption. A copy of this determination
shall be forwarded to the taxpayer, the City Tax Collector, the Lycoming County
Board of Assessment, and each of the local taxing authorities that have current
LERTA resolutions or ordinances in effect.
   (e)   Upon completion of the new construction or improvement, the Lycoming
County Board of Assessment shall assess the new construction or improvements
separately for the purpose of calculating the amount of assessment eligible for
tax exemption in accordance with the limits established in this article.
   (f)   The Lycoming County Board of Assessment shall notify the City, the
taxpayer, and any other participating Local Taxing Authority of the
reassessment and amounts to the assessment eligible for exemption. The
Treasurer is authorized to make refunds, if applicable, 30 days after the Board
has notified the Treasurer of its separate assessment upon which an exemption
is granted and no appeals have been timely filed.
   (g)   The taxpayer or any Local Taxing Authority may appeal the
determination of eligibility or the assessment eligible for exemption under the
provisions of §
355.13.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6186, approved 4-14-2011; Ord. 6460, passed
7-20-2023; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.09 TERMINATION.
   Unless otherwise repealed by Council, this article shall terminate on
December 31, 2026. No later than October 1, annually, the Mayor shall submit a
written report to Council which shall inform the Council as to how this has
been administered, the effects of this article on the community and include any
suggestions or recommendations for this article’s reenactment, modification or
repeal. Nothing contained herein shall act to prohibit Council from enacting a
similar article after December 31, 2026. Any property tax exemptions granted
under the provisions of this article shall be permitted to continue according
to the exemption schedule in effect at the time of approval, even if this
article expires or is repealed.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6460, passed 7-20-2023; Ord. 6494, passed
2-27-2025; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)

   (a)   The Director of the Department of Community and Economic Development
is hereby authorized to prepare, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations
made pursuant to the provisions of this article unless modified, revoked or
repealed by Council.
   (b)   A copy of said rules and regulations shall be filed with the City
Clerk at least 20 days prior to their becoming effective.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6186, approved 4-14-2011; Ord. 6460, passed
7-20-2023; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)

   (a)   The provisions of this article are severable and if any of its

   (b)   It is hereby declared to be the intent of Council that this article
would have been adopted if such illegal, invalid or unconstitutional section,

(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)

§ 355.13 APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   (a)   The taxpayer, or any Local Taxing Authority, may appeal the
determination of eligibility or the assessment eligible for exemption to the
LERTA Appeal Board within 30 days of the date of the determination notice.
   (b)   All appeals shall be made in writing and delivered to the Director of
the City’s Department of Community and Economic Development and the City Clerk.
   (c)   The Director shall notify the members of the LERTA Appeal Board, the
City Tax Collector, the Director of Finance, the Lycoming County Board of
Assessment, and each LERTA participating Local Taxing Authority of the pending
appeal.
   (d)   The Director of Economic and Community Development shall notify all
parties of the date, time and place of the appeal at least ten days prior to
the date of the hearing.
   (e)   The LERTA Appeal Board shall issue a decision to all parties within 30
days of the conclusion of the appeals hearing.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6186, approved 4-14-2011; Ord. 6460, passed
7-20-2023; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.14 SUBSEQUENT CHANGE IN ASSESSMENT.
   In the event that the taxpayer shall receive, by whatever means, a changed
assessment, with regard to part or all of their property which is currently the
subject of the tax exemption provided in this article, such change in
assessment shall be applied proportionately to the portion of the assessed
value which is subject to a tax exemption and the portion of the assessed value
which is not subject to a tax exemption, and shall result in a change of the
tax exemption which was initially granted for purposes of the number of
exemption years still remaining on the exemption schedule. This recalculation
shall not apply to increased assessments as a result of new construction or
improvements on said property.
(Ord. 6181, approved 2-3-2011; Ord. 6510, passed 9-4-2025)
§ 355.15 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This article shall become effective 20 days after final enactment and remain
in effect thereafter from year to year, unless repealed, until December 31,

applications for the exemption sought for buildings or alterations for which a

§ 501.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This Part Five shall be known and may be cited as the Williamsport “Traffic
Code”.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 501.02 DEFINITIONS GENERALLY.
   In this Traffic Code, the terms used shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in the Vehicle Code of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, except as herein
otherwise defined.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 501.03 PARKING METER.
   PARKING METER means a device intended to assist public authorities in
enforcing ordinances limiting the time during which vehicles may be parked on
any highway within a parking meter zone.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 501.04 PARKING METER ZONES.
   PARKING METER ZONES mean highways or portions of highways on which parking
meters are installed, operated and used.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 501.05 STREET OR HIGHWAY.
   STREET or HIGHWAY means every way or place of whatever nature, open to the
use of the public as a matter of right, for purpose of vehicular travel. The
term HIGHWAY shall not be deemed to include roadway or driveway upon grounds
owned by private persons, colleges, universities or other institutions.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 501.06 TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE.
   TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE means any sign, signals, markings and devices not
inconsistent with this Traffic Code, placed or erected as herein provided, or
any temporary warning signs placed by authority of recognized agencies, for the
purpose of guiding, directing, safeguarding, warning or regulating traffic.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 501.07 VEHICLE CODE.
   VEHICLE CODE means the Vehicle Code of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania (75
Pa.C.S. §§ 101 et seq.) as amended.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)

§ 503.01 TEMPORARY REGULATIONS AUTHORIZED.
   The Mayor is authorized to establish any traffic regulation not provided for
by ordinance, by written executive order for a temporary period not to exceed
90 days; subject to the provisions of this article.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 503.02 WRITTEN NOTICE TO COUNCIL.
   During the first week of temporary period, a written communication shall be
sent by the Mayor to notify Council of such proposed regulation and the reasons
therefor.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)

   The temporary period shall begin upon the posting of signs or other
appropriate notice to the public.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 503.04 DISAPPROVAL BY COUNCIL.
   (a)   If an ordinance embodying any temporary regulation or any part thereof
fails to be enacted by Council, such regulation or any part thereof shall, at
the end of the temporary period of 90 days, cease to be effective.
   (b)   If Council directs that any temporary traffic regulation shall be
discontinued immediately, the traffic control devices affecting such temporary
regulation shall be removed at once and the regulation shall be void.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 503.05 SNOW EMERGENCY REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The Mayor or his or her designee is hereby authorized to declare an
emergency to exist when any of the streets or highways or parts thereof are
covered by snow which, in his or her discretion, causes or will cause a
condition of serious traffic congestion, such emergency to be known as a snow
emergency.
   (b)   During any snow emergency, no vehicle shall be parked on the following
snow emergency streets and routes: Third Street (full length); Fourth Street
(full length); High Street (full length); Washington Boulevard (full length);
Rural Avenue from Market Street to Campbell Street; Grampian Boulevard (full
length); Four Mile Drive from Grampian Boulevard to city line; Almond Street
from Washington Boulevard to Grampian Boulevard; Franklin Street (full length);
Market Street from Grampian Boulevard to Market Street Bridge; Campbell Street
from Rural Avenue to West Third Street; Arch Street/Dewey Avenue (full length);
Poplar Street from West Third Street to West Fourth Street; Mulberry Street
from Via Bella to Washington Boulevard; Basin Street from Fourth Street to Via
Bella; Hepburn Street from Rural Avenue to Via Bella; and Walnut Street from
Third Street to Rural Avenue; Penn Street from Grampian Boulevard to East Third
Street; Wayne Avenue from Linn Street to Hillside Avenue; Rose Street from High
Street to West Third Street; Maynard Street (full length); and Packer Street
from Washington Boulevard to Huffman Avenue. The “No Parking” rule on snow
emergency routes shall remain in effect for 24 hours after the snow stops or
the end of the time of the declared snow emergency, whichever is longer.
   (c)   During a snow emergency, no motor vehicle shall be driven upon a snow
emergency route, when the roadway is covered with ice and snow, unless the
vehicle is equipped with at least two mud and snow tires on a driven axle or
tire chains on two tires on a driven axle. A MUD AND SNOW TIRE means: a tire
which, when compared with conventional rib-type passenger car tires, has a
relatively aggressive tread pattern and is designed primarily to provide
additional starting, stopping and driving traction in mud and snow. The tread
shall also have ribs, lugs, blocks or buttons, be generally discontinuous and
have the following characteristics when inflated:
      (1)   A substantial portion of the lug, block or rib edges in the tread
design shall be at an angle greater than thirty degrees to the tire
circumferential centerline.
      (2)   On at least one side of the tread design, the shoulder lugs shall
protrude at least one-half inch in a direction generally perpendicular to the
direction of travel.
      (3)   Tires manufactured on or after 1-1-1976, shall be permanently
labeled on at least one sidewall with the words “Mud and Snow” or any
contraction using the letters “M” and “S”, such as MS, M/S, M-S, M&S and the
like.
   (d)   During any snow emergency, no vehicle shall be parked on any street in
the Central Business District (the area bounded, identified and delineated on
the zoning map of the city as enacted by Council on 4-9-1985, and specified in
§
1331.02 of the Zoning Code and any future delineation of such district by
Council, and generally the area bounded on the north by Little League
Boulevard, on the east by Mulberry Street, on the south by Via Bella and on the
west by Hepburn Street) from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. This “no parking” rule
shall remain in effect for one day after the end of the snow fall or the end of
the time of the declared snow emergency, whichever is longer.
   (e)   It shall be the duty of the Police Department to enforce the
provisions of this section.
   (f)   The Police Department is empowered to tow any vehicle to a city-
designated parking pound pursuant to the ordinances of the city, including §
525.01 of the codified ordinances, at the owner’s expense as provided for by
the city ordinances.
   (g)   The Department of Streets shall place signs as to the provisions of
this section at the beginning and at appropriate intervals on these designated
snow routes within the city.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961; Ord. 3094, approved 12-10-1964; Ord. 5623,
passed 5-12-1994)
§ 503.99 PENALTY.
   Whosoever violates any of the provisions of §
503.05 shall for each and every such violation, pay the sum of $25 within 15
days of such notice to the Bureau of Police for the use of the city. If, within
15 days the sum of $25 is not paid, a citation shall be issued in the office of
the District Justice, and the violator, upon conviction of violation of §
503.05, shall be guilty of a summary offense and shall be sentenced to pay a
fine of $50, plus costs of prosecution, and in default thereof, shall undergo
imprisonment for not more than one day. Each day that the condition exists
shall be considered a separate violation.
(Ord. 5623, passed 5-12-1994)

505.01   Traffic Control Maps.

§ 505.01 TRAFFIC CONTROL MAPS.
   There are established and adopted “Traffic Control Maps” as prepared by the
Director of Public Services or his or her designee, dated 4-1-1961 and
designated by letter, showing the city’s lawfully authorized traffic control
and restricted parking areas as follows:
   (a)   One-way streets;
   (b)   Through streets and stop intersections;
   (c)   Parking meter zones;
   (d)   No parking or stopping at any time;
   (e)   Restricted parking;
   (f)   Prohibited and restricted and required turns;
   (g)   Safety zones, loading and unloading zones, bus loading zones and
taxicab stands; and
   (h)   Snow emergency routes.
(Ord. 3094, approved 12-10-1964)
§ 505.02 CHANGES IN MAPS BY ORDINANCE.
   (a)   Amendments to the Traffic Control Maps shall be made by ordinance.
   (b)   This section shall not restrict the authority of the Mayor to
establish any traffic regulations for a temporary period not exceeding 90 days,
in conformity with
Art. 503.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 505.03 PROCEDURE FOR TRAFFIC MAP RECOMMENDED AMENDMENTS.
   (a)   At least every 90 days, the Chief of Police shall submit to Council
specific recommendation for additions, changes or deletions to the Traffic
Control Maps.
   (b)   Subsection (a) hereof shall not restrict the power of Council to amend
the Traffic Control Maps by ordinance at any time without prior recommendation
or study by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 505.04 PREPARATION AND MAINTENANCE OF MAPS.
   City Traffic Control Maps shall be prepared and maintained by the Director
of Public Services or his or her designee. At least one set of such Maps as
currently amended shall be kept on file in the office of the Director of Public
Services and the office of the Chief of Police. The Director of Public Services
or his or her designee may combine information for two or more Traffic Control
Maps upon a single map. All Traffic Control Maps shall be public records, but
the keeping of these maps shall not be a requisite condition for the
prosecution of any violation of this Traffic Code.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 505.05 FILE OF PROPOSED TRAFFIC MAP AMENDMENTS.
   The Chief of Police shall maintain a permanent file or record setting forth
all recommendations to Council for amendments to the Traffic Control Maps.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
ARTICLE 507: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY
Section
   
507.01   Obedience to police.
   
507.02   Obedience to official traffic equipment.
   
507.03   Damages to traffic devices, traffic tickets or summons.
   
507.04   Meter attendants.
   
507.99   Traffic Code penalty.
§ 507.01 OBEDIENCE TO POLICE.
   (a)   No person shall fail to comply with any lawful order, signal or
direction of a police officer.
   (b)   Police officers shall have the power and authority to direct vehicles
to proceed in a direction other than that in which the operator intended to
proceed lawfully, for the purpose of avoiding or relieving traffic congestion,
during emergencies and to enforce temporary restrictions incident to street
repairs or improvements.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 507.02 OBEDIENCE TO OFFICIAL TRAFFIC EQUIPMENT.
   No person shall fail to comply with the indications of any official traffic
equipment unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 507.03 DAMAGES TO TRAFFIC DEVICES, TRAFFIC TICKETS OR SUMMONS.
   No person shall deface, damage, move, obstruct, destroy, change the wording
of, alter or otherwise interfere with any traffic control device. No person
shall deface, change the wording of, discard, destroy or throw away any traffic
tickets, notice or summons.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 507.04 METER ATTENDANTS.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of meter attendants whose
duties shall be to enforce the parking provisions of the Traffic Code of the
city.
   (b)   The meter attendants shall be selected from the personnel of
Williamsport Parking Authority and deputized by the Mayor. The city in its name
shall prosecute anyone violating the provisions of the Traffic Code.
   (c)   The position of meter attendants is hereby established on a temporary
basis in order to enable Council to ascertain the effect of the same and shall
not be considered full-time employees of the city and shall be paid their wages
and benefits by the Williamsport Parking Authority.
   (d)   Nothing herein contained shall be deemed or construed to limit the
powers of the members of the Bureau of Police or other city personnel empowered
and authorized to enforce the parking provisions of the Traffic Code.
(Ord. 5154, approved 3-18-1982)
§ 507.99 TRAFFIC CODE PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Traffic Code, for which no other
penalty is provided, shall be fined not more than $50 or imprisoned not more
than ten days or both.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961; Ord. 4566, approved 3-22-1973)
TITLE THREE: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
ARTICLE 511: OPERATION OF VEHICLES
Section
   
511.01   Entering obstructed intersection.
   
511.02   Driving through funeral and other processions.
   
511.03   Driving or parking on sidewalk.
   
511.04   Pushcarts and animals to keep to right.
   
511.05   Horns and sounding devices; zones of quiet.
   
511.06   One-way streets.
   
511.07   Access to flood control system regulated.
   
511.08   Bicycles and other pedacycles.
   
511.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Parking to obstruct sidewalks, see Part Five, §
521.11
   Squealing of tires, see Part Seven, §
709.02
Statutory reference:
   State regulations of traffic operation, see 75 Pa.C.S. §§ 3101 et seq.
§ 511.01 ENTERING OBSTRUCTED INTERSECTION.
   No operator of a vehicle shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk
unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or
crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he or she is operating without obstructing
the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic
control signal to proceed.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 511.02 DRIVING THROUGH FUNERAL AND OTHER PROCESSIONS.
   No operator of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a
funeral when such vehicles are conspicuously designated, nor between vehicles
of any military convoys or other authorized processions while they are in
motion.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 511.03 DRIVING OR PARKING ON SIDEWALK.
   The operator of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area, except
at a permanent or temporary driveway, nor shall any person park a vehicle at
any place between the curb line and property line of any street.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 511.04 PUSHCARTS AND ANIMALS TO KEEP TO RIGHT.
   Every person operating a pushcart shall operate the same on sidewalks or
other pedestrian facilities when possible to do so without blocking pedestrian
traffic on same. Otherwise, the pushcart shall be operated on the extreme right
of the traffic lane if operated on the street. Every person using an animal or
animal-drawn conveyance in the city shall keep the same as close as possible to
the right side of the traffic lane and obey all traffic signals.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961; Ord. 6327, approved 6-8-2017)
§ 511.05 HORNS AND SOUNDING DEVICES; ZONES OF QUIET.
   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating a zone of quiet, no
operator of a vehicle within any such zone shall sound the horn or other
warning device of such vehicle, except in an emergency. No person shall at any
time sound the horn or other warning device of a vehicle, except when
absolutely necessary as a warning signal while actually driving such vehicle.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 511.06 ONE-WAY STREETS.
   (a)   Upon the streets and parts of streets designated for one-way traffic
upon the Traffic Control Maps or by temporary regulation, vehicular traffic
shall move only in the direction indicated by traffic control devices, unless
specifically directed otherwise by a police officer in conformity with §
507.01.
   (b)   A sign indicating the direction of traffic shall be erected and
maintained at every intersection where the movement in the opposite direction
is prohibited upon the Traffic Control Maps or by temporary regulation.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 511.07 ACCESS TO FLOOD CONTROL SYSTEM REGULATED.
   There shall be no vehicular traffic on any levees, dikes or any other part
of the flood control system including, but not limited to, wheeled vehicles or
motorized vehicles such as bicycles, except on designated bike routes, wagons,
mini-bikes, motorscooters, motorcycles, snowmobiles, automobiles, trucks and
the like. Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the use of existing roads
across the dike that are clearly delineated as constructed by the U.S. Army
Corps of Engineers.
(Ord. 5259, approved 10-25-1984)
§ 511.08 BICYCLES AND OTHER PEDACYCLES.
   In all cases, a person operating a bicycle or pedacycle shall operate same
in accordance with the Pennsylvania Vehicle Code (Title 75, Chapter 35,
Subchapter A) and other sections of the Pennsylvania Vehicle Code as
applicable. Bicycles and other pedacycles shall be considered vehicles when
operated on streets, and a person operating a bicycle or other pedacycle shall
be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties
applicable to the driver of any other vehicle, with the exception that bicycles
and pedacycle shall be prohibited from any street classified as an “expressway”
in accordance with the Codified Ordinances of the City of Williamsport, Part
13, Title 3, §
1311.90, except in circumstances outlined in 75 Pa.C.S.A. § 3511. A person
choosing to operate a bicycle or other pedacycle upon a sidewalk or pedacycle
path used by pedestrians shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and
shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing a pedestrian.
(Ord. 6327, approved 6-8-2017)
§ 511.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates §
511.07 shall be guilty of a summary offense and, upon conviction thereof,
before any Magistrate of the city and/or District Justice shall be fined not
more than $300 or shall be imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both.
(Ord. 4668, approved 11-22-1974)
ARTICLE 513: PEDESTRIANS AND PASSENGERS
Section
   
513.01   Keeping to right on crosswalks.

   Pedestrians right-of-way, see 75 Pa.C.S. §§ 3542, 3547
   Pedestrians soliciting rides, see 75 Pa.C.S. § 3545
§ 513.01 KEEPING TO RIGHT ON CROSSWALKS.
   Pedestrians shall move whenever practicable upon the right half of the
crosswalk.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 513.02 OVERTAKING VEHICLES PERMITTING PEDESTRIANS TO CROSS.
   Whenever any vehicle has stopped at a marked crosswalk or at an intersection
to permit a pedestrian to cross the highway, no operator of any other vehicle
approaching from the rear shall pass such stopped vehicle.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 513.03 PEDESTRIANS CROSSING AT INTERSECTION.
   (a)   Pedestrians shall not leave the curb to cross at controlled
intersections unless:
      (1)   Directed by a police officer;
      (2)   On the green or “go” traffic signal at intersection not having
pedestrian signals; or
      (3)   On the “walk” signal at intersections having pedestrian signals.
   (b)   Pedestrians shall not cross highways anywhere, except at
intersections, nor shall they cross at intersections having pedestrian signals
except at the places and in the manner directed.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 513.04 UNLAWFUL BOARDING OR RIDING.
   No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in
motion. No person shall ride on any portion of any vehicle not designated or
intended for the use of passengers, except employees engaged in the necessary
discharge of a duty, or persons riding within truck bodies in space intended
for merchandise.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
ARTICLE 515: REPORTING ACCIDENTS
Section
   
515.01   Duty to report accidents.
   
515.02   Supplemental reports; witness reports.
   
515.03   Occupant reporting for injured operator.
   
515.04   Reports confidential; not admissible in evidence.
Statutory reference:
   Duty to give information and render aid, see 75 Pa.C.S. § 3744
   Requiring accident reports, see 75 Pa.C.S. §§ 3746, 3747
§ 515.01 DUTY TO REPORT ACCIDENTS.
   The operator of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in bodily injury
or death to any person or damage to the property of any one person in excess of
$200, shall, within 24 hours after such accident, forward a written report of
such accident to the Bureau of Police, which report may be a copy of the
accident report required to be filed with the Department of Revenue of the
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 4598, approved 9-28-1973)
§ 515.02 SUPPLEMENTAL REPORTS; WITNESS REPORTS.
   The Bureau of Police may require any operator of a vehicle involved in such
an accident to file supplemental reports whenever the original report is
insufficient in the opinion of the Bureau, and may require witnesses of
accidents to render reports to the Bureau.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 515.03 OCCUPANT REPORTING FOR INJURED OPERATOR.
   Whenever the operator of a vehicle is physically incapable of making a
required accident report and there is another occupant in the vehicle at the
time of the accident who is capable of making a report, such occupant shall
make or cause to be made such report.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 515.04 REPORTS CONFIDENTIAL; NOT ADMISSIBLE IN EVIDENCE.
   All such accident reports shall be without prejudice, shall be for the
information of the Bureau of Police and shall not be open for public
inspection. No such report or part thereof, nor statement contained therein,
shall be admissible in evidence for any purpose in any trial, civil or criminal
arising out of such accident.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
ARTICLE 517: CRUISING
Section
   
517.01   Legislative findings.
   
517.02   Definitions.
   
517.03   Cruising prohibited.
   
517.04   Exclusions.
   
517.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Open alcohol container possession or consumption, see Part Seven, §
747.01
   Operation of vehicles, see Part Five,
Art. 511
   Tire squealing, see Part Seven, §
709.02
   Unreasonable use of mechanical devices; radios, see Part Seven, §
709.03
§ 517.01 LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS.
   It is hereby found by Council that a general public nuisance and threat to
the public health, safety and welfare results from the repetitive unnecessary
driving of motor vehicles, also known as cruising, in a designated area of
downtown Williamsport. The purpose of this article is to reduce the noise, air
pollution and congestion resulting from cruising, and to insure access for
safety vehicles to and through such designated area by restricting repetitive
driving of motor vehicles in such designated area.
(Ord. 5331, approved 11-20-1986)
§ 517.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply.
   CRUISING. Driving a motor vehicle on a street past a traffic control point,
designated by a police officer, in the designated area, at or near the control
point, three or more times within any one-hour period from 9:00 p.m. to 4:00
a.m. or six or more times within any three-hour period from 9:00 p.m. to 4:00
a.m. prevailing time, passing the control point a third time or sixth time
under the same conditions stated herein shall constitute cruising and therefore
a violation of this article.
   DESIGNATED AREA. The area of the city bounded by Campbell Street on the
west, Third Street on the south, Market Street on the east, and Fourth Street
on the north and shall include the aforementioned boundary streets.
   TRAFFIC CONTROL POINT. A reference point on a street in a designated area
selected by a police officer for the purpose of enforcing this article.
(Ord. 5331, approved 11-20-1986)
§ 517.03 CRUISING PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No driver of a motor vehicle or person having care, custody or control
of a motor vehicle shall cruise. For the purpose of this article, the person
having care, custody or control of a motor vehicle shall also be considered a
person cruising regardless of whether that person was actually driving the
motor vehicle. For the purposes of this article, the person having care,
custody or control of a motor vehicle shall mean either the owner of such
vehicle, if present in the vehicle at the time of the violation, or, if the
owner is not so present, the person or persons having the owner’s authority to
use the vehicle.
   (b)   Cruising shall be permitted within the designated area on Friday and
Saturday between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight prevailing time.
(Ord. 5331, approved 11-20-1986; Ord. 5479, approved 6-14-1990)
§ 517.04 EXCLUSIONS.
   This section shall not apply to official emergency or police vehicles,
licensed taxicabs, for hire, other commercial or passenger vehicles being
driven for business purposes, and for residents of the designated area
traveling to a specific destination.
(Ord. 5331, approved 11-20-1986)
§ 517.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this article, shall, upon
summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a district justice of
the city shall be sentenced, for a first offense, to pay a fine of not more
than $25 and costs and/or to be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not
exceeding 90 days. Upon conviction of a second offense, such person shall be
sentenced to pay a fine of not more than $75 and costs and/or to be imprisoned
in the county jail for a period not exceeding 90 days. Upon conviction of a
third and any subsequent offense, such person shall be sentenced to pay a fine
of not more than $150 and costs and/or to be imprisoned in the county jail for
a period not exceeding 90 days.
(Ord. 5331, approved 11-20-1986)
ARTICLE 519: ENGINE SUPPRESSION/BRAKE RETARDER/ENGINE BRAKE
Section
   
519.01   Title.
   
519.02   Legislative intent.
   
519.03   Engine brakes prohibited.
   
519.04   Streets.
   
519.05   Emergency situations.
   
519.06   Penalty.
§ 519.01 TITLE.
   This article shall be known as the “City of Williamsport Engine Suppression/
Brake Retarder/Engine Brake Ordinance”.
(Ord. 6168, approved 7-8-2010)
§ 519.02 LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   The City Council of the City of Williamsport, Lycoming County, Pennsylvania,
finds as a fact that the operation of an engine brake or an engine suppression
device or a compression brake on a gasoline powered or diesel powered motor
vehicle to create excessive noise through the use of said engine brake or
engine suppression device or compression brake, adversely affects the public
health, safety and welfare of the residents of the City of Williamsport and,
therefore, is a nuisance in fact.
(Ord. 6168, approved 7-8-2010)
§ 519.03 ENGINE BRAKES PROHIBITED.
   No gasoline powered or diesel powered motor vehicle shall be operated on the
streets, roads, alleys or highways listed below within the City of
Williamsport, Lycoming County, Pennsylvania, utilizing, in said operation, an
engine brake, engine suppression device or compression brake.
(Ord. 6168, approved 7-8-2010)
§ 519.04 STREETS.
   The Streets subject to this prohibition shall be as follows: State Route
2014 known as West Fourth Street beginning at Foresman Street and continuing
eastbound to the U.S. 15 Interchange.
(Ord. 6168, approved 7-8-2010)
§ 519.05 EMERGENCY SITUATIONS.
   This article shall not apply to emergency driving situations requiring the
utilization of an engine brake to protect the safety and property of the
residents of the City of Williamsport, other motor vehicle operators,
pedestrians and the operator and passengers of the motor vehicle involved in
said emergency situation.
(Ord. 6168, approved 7-8-2010)
§ 519.06 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, corporation or organization violating any of the
provisions of this article shall, upon summary conviction before a District
Magistrate having jurisdiction, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than
$50, or more than $300, and costs of prosecution, and in default of the payment
thereof, shall be sentenced to undergo imprisonment in any County Jail for a
period not to exceed ten days.
(Ord. 6168, approved 7-8-2010)
TITLE FIVE: STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING
ARTICLE 521: STOPPING AND PARKING GENERALLY
Section
   
521.01   Parking in prohibited areas.
   
521.02   Parking limited in designated areas.
   
521.03   Blocking garage entrance.
   
521.04   Greasing or repair work.
   
521.05   Unlicensed vehicles.
   
521.06   Parking Truck and trailers.
   
521.07   Storage of vehicles on streets.
   
521.08   Selling from parked cars.
   
521.09   Overnight parking prohibited in certain areas.
   
521.10   Parking to obstruct sidewalks.
   
521.11   Prohibited parking places.
   
521.12   Parking by facilities used for governmental purposes.
   
521.13   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Parking on sidewalk, see Part Five, §
511.03
   Resident permit parking, see Part Five,
Art. 522
Statutory reference:
   Parking unattended vehicle, see 75 Pa.C.S. §§ 3351 to 3353
   Power to regulate parking, see 75 Pa.C.S. § 6109(a), (f)
   Prohibited parking areas, see 75 Pa.C.S. §§ 3351 et seq.
§ 521.01 PARKING IN PROHIBITED AREAS.
   When signs prohibiting parking are erected lawfully giving notice thereof,
no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets or part of
streets designated as prohibited parking areas by the Traffic Control Maps or
by temporary regulations in conformity with
Art. 503.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.02 PARKING LIMITED IN DESIGNATED AREAS.
   When signs limiting parking are erected lawfully giving notice thereof, no
person shall park a vehicle longer than the time permitted, nor during
specified hours when parking is prohibited, upon any streets or parts of
streets designated as limited parking areas by the Traffic Control Maps or by
temporary regulations in conformity with
Art. 503.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.03 BLOCKING GARAGE ENTRANCE.
   No person shall park a vehicle at any time in front of, opposite to or in
such a position as to block entrance to or exit by a vehicle from a garage.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.04 GREASING OR REPAIR WORK.
   No vehicle shall stand on any street or sidewalk for the purpose of greasing
or repair work, except in the case of emergency repair.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.05 UNLICENSED VEHICLES.
   No vehicle shall stand or be parked upon any street unless the same bears a
motor vehicle license evidencing that it has been currently registered as a
motor vehicle under the provisions of the Vehicle Code.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.06 PARKING TRUCK AND TRAILERS.
   No truck trailer or trailer shall be parked upon any street without having
attached thereto a means of mechanical traction so constructed or designed for
the purpose of pulling or drawing such trailer.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.07 STORAGE OF VEHICLES ON STREETS.
   No vehicle shall be stored upon any street. As used herein, STORED means the
parking of a vehicle in one place upon any street continuously for over 72
hours.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.08 SELLING FROM PARKED VEHICLES.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon any street for the purpose of offering
for sale or selling therefrom any goods, wares or merchandise.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.09 OVERNIGHT PARKING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN AREAS.
   When signs are erected lawfully giving notice thereof, no person shall park
a vehicle longer than 30 minutes between 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.10 PARKING TO OBSTRUCT SIDEWALKS.
   No vehicle shall be parked on public or private property in such a manner
that any part of the vehicle shall overhang a sidewalk or any other pedestrian
right-of-way customarily used by pedestrians for passage.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.11 PROHIBITED PARKING PLACES.
   No person shall park a vehicle or tractor in any of the following places:
   (a)   Within an intersection;
   (b)   On a crosswalk;
   (c)   Within 25 feet from the intersection of curb lines or, if none, then
within 15 feet of the intersection of property lines at an intersection of
highways;
   (d)   Within 30 feet upon the approach to any official flashing signal, stop
sign or traffic signal located at the side of the roadway;
   (e)   Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant;
   (f)   In front of a public or private highway;
   (g)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the curb or
edge of the highway;
   (h)   Except when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic
signs or signals or where angle parking is permitted, the operator of a vehicle
shall not stop, stand or park such vehicle on the highway within a business or
residence district other than parallel with the edge of the highway, headed in
the direction of traffic, and with the curb side of the vehicle within six
inches of the edge of the highway or curb. Vehicles, which because of type or
construction cannot load or unload parallel to the curb, shall be exempt, while
loading or unloading only, from the requirements of standing parallel to the
curb;
   (i)   On any highway with the vehicle facing in a direction other than the
direction of travel on that side of the highway;
   (j)   Within any bus zone or commercial vehicle loading zone; and
   (k)   Within any area reserved for handicapped or severely disabled veteran
unless the vehicle is bearing a handicapped or severely disabled veteran plate
or displaying a handicapped or severely disabled veteran parking placard as
prescribed in the Motor Vehicle Code.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997)
§ 521.12 PARKING BY FACILITIES USED FOR GOVERNMENTAL PURPOSES.
   When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle
by a facility used for governmental purposes for a period of time not to exceed
15 minutes and while parked, the vehicle shall have its hazard warning signals
on.
(Ord. 5822, approved 7-20-2000)
§ 521.13 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this article, except §
521.11(k) shall be fined $10 or imprisoned not more than five days.
   (b)   Whoever violates §
521.11(k) shall be fined $25 or imprisoned not more than five days.
   (c)   Whoever violates §
521.12, shall be fined $10 or imprisoned not more than five days.
(Ord. 5723, approved 7-24-1997; Ord. 5822, approved 7-20-2000)
ARTICLE 522: RESTRICTING PARKING IN CERTAIN RESIDENTIAL/INSTITUTIONAL AREAS
Section
   
522.01   Definitions.
   
522.02   Resident permit parking.
   
522.03   Signs; time period.
   
522.04   Establishment of restricted areas.
   
522.05   Permit parking decals.
   
522.06   Issuance of permit parking decals.
   
522.07   Placement of decals.
   
522.08   Duplicate or replacement decal.
   
522.09   Falsification; transferability of decals.
   
522.10   Severability.
   
522.11   Enforcement.
   
522.99   Penalty.
§ 522.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AUTHORIZED DESIGNEE. Individual(s) who reside(s) on a full time basis in a
dwelling unit owned by another, with the permission of the owner.
   DWELLING UNIT. One or more rooms designed for or occupied by not more than
one family as a single housekeeping unit with cooking and sanitary facilities,
but not including units in motels, hotels, rooming houses, tourist homes or any
other buildings for which a fee is charged for a unit lacking cooking
facilities.
   OWNER. Any person who owns land improved for residential use within the
permit zone described in §
522.02, whether or not such person resides upon such land.
   PARKING AUTHORITY. The Williamsport Parking Authority, a body politic and
corporate established under the Parking Authority Law, exercising public powers
of the Commonwealth as an agency of the Commonwealth.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989; Ord. 6262, approved 8-7-2014)
§ 522.02 RESIDENT PERMIT PARKING.
   (a)   No person shall park a motor vehicle without a proper, valid permit
decal displayed thereon from August 15 through May 31, inclusive, in certain
areas designated by the city within the sections of the city hereinafter
referred to as “Zone Number 1”, “Zone Number 2” and “Zone Number 3” and bounded
and described as follows.
      (1)   Zone Number 1. West Side of Mulberry Street from East Fourth Street
to Duck Alley; east side of Market Street to Brandon Place; north side of
Brandon Place to Elizabeth Street; both sides of Elizabeth Street to Parkwood
Street; From Elizabeth Street and the north side of Hughes Street to the east
side of Penn Street; from the east side of Penn Street to Hughes Street to the
south side of Fourth Street; from Penn Street along the south side of East
Fourth Street to the west side of Mulberry Street.
      (2)   Zone Number 2. North side of First Street from Maynard Street to
Park Street; east side to Park Street to West Third Street; north side of West
Third Street to Grier Street; west side of Grier Street to Vine Avenue; north
side of Vine Avenue to Maynard Street; west side of Maynard Street to First
Street; north side of West Third Street from Grier Street to Rose Street.
      (3)   Zone Number 3. North and south side of Memorial Avenue between
Seventh Avenue and Grier Street.
   (b)   These areas within the zones designated by the city shall be subject
to the regulations contained herein. However, commercial or delivery vehicles
may be temporarily parked for the purposes of loading or unloading on any
street, alley or public way without being subject to the provisions of this
article.
   (c)   Any other regulations or restrictions upon parking imposed by any
other ordinance shall continue with full force and effect in the permit zone
described above, to the extent applicable.
   (d)   In addition, nothing contained in this article shall be construed as
prohibiting motor vehicles displaying a parking decal issued pursuant to this
article from being parked in other areas of the city outside of the permit
zone.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989; Ord. 5693, approved 8-15-1996; Ord. 5712,
approved 4-3-1997)
§ 522.03 SIGNS; TIME PERIOD.
   (a)   The areas established by the city within the zones described herein
shall be designated by signs erected thereon as “permit parking only”.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for anyone not having a permit to park his or her
motor vehicles in areas designated for resident permit parking during the
period from August 15 through May 31, inclusive, during times designated and,
if no time is designated, the restrictions shall be for a 24-hour period.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989)
§ 522.04 ESTABLISHMENT OF RESTRICTED AREAS.
   (a)   Designated blocks. Pursuant to
Art. 505, the city shall have the right to establish certain areas within the
zones and designate these areas as “permit parking only”.
   (b)   Designations by city. The designation of any areas within the zones as
restricted to resident parking only, shall be based on the requests of the
residents of a block and the recommendations of the Mayor, subject to the
approval of Council.
   (c)   Temporary regulations. Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent
the Mayor from establishing any restricted parking regulations within the
designated zones for a period not to exceed 90 days, in accordance with
Art. 503.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989; Ord. 5712, approved 4-3-1997)
§ 522.05 PERMIT PARKING DECALS.
   (a)   Resident permit parking decals shall be issued only to owners of land
improved for residential use in the permit zones described in §
522.02 or such owners’ lawfully authorized designees for those blocks
established by the city in the manner set forth in §
522.04.
   (b)   All permit parking decals shall be valid for a period beginning August
15 and ending May 31 of the following year. It shall be the responsibility of
each permittee to renew his or her permit(s) annually.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989)
§ 522.06 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT PARKING DECALS.
   (a)   Resident permit. Upon application to the Parking Authority on a form
to be provided, the owner of each residential dwelling unit within the
established permit zone, or such owner’s authorized designee, shall be issued a
resident permit parking decal for each vehicle to which they own and desire to
park within the permit zone, with a maximum of two permit parking decals for
any authorized designee. The owner of the dwelling unit or his or her
authorized designee, shall present a valid proof of registration of a motor
vehicle belonging to a resident of the dwelling unit in order to be issued a
residential permit parking decal. The owner or his or her authorized designee
may, present up to two valid proofs of registration of motor vehicles belonging
to residents of the dwelling unit.
      (1)   Any resident permit parking decals issued hereunder shall be used
only by the residents of a dwelling unit within the permit zone who desire to
park their motor vehicle(s), for which a motor vehicle belonging to a resident
of the dwelling unit in order to be issued a residential permit parking decal.
The owner or his or her authorized designee may present up to two valid proofs
of registration of motor vehicles belonging to residents of the dwelling unit.
      (2)   Any resident permit parking decals issued hereunder shall be used
only by the residents of a dwelling unit within the permit zone who desire to
park their motor vehicle(s), for which a permit parking decal has been issued,
at curbside, on the streets, alleys or public ways within the permit zone, as
designated. In no event shall more than two resident permit parking decals be
issued per dwelling unit in the permit zone.
   (b)   Guest permit. Upon application to the Parking Authority on a form to
be provided therefor, the owner of each residential dwelling unit within the
permit zone or his or her authorized designee, shall be issued two guest
parking decals, on which shall be printed the street address of the dwelling
unit for which such permit is issued and the date of issuance. No more than two
guest parking decals shall be issued per dwelling unit in the permit zone.
      (1)   Guest parking decals are intended for the use of guests of
residents of the permit zone, which guests desire to park their motor vehicles
at curbside on the streets, alleys and public ways within the designated areas
in the permit zone.
      (2)   A motor vehicle properly displaying a guest permit decal in
accordance with the provisions of §
522.07 shall be permitted to be parked in the resident permit parking
designated areas within the zones to the same extent as vehicles properly
displaying a resident permit parking decal under this article.
   (c)   Fee. For each permit issued, a fee of $1 will be collected annually.
   (d)   Non-transferable. Permit is non-transferable from one permit parking
zone to another permit parking zone.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989; Ord. 5824, approved 7-20-2000; Ord. 6262,
approved 8-7-2014)
§ 522.07 PLACEMENT OF DECALS.
   The resident permit parking decals and guest parking decals issued pursuant
to this article shall be fixed to the center, or as near thereto as possible,
on the inside of the motor vehicle’s front windshield, at the top thereof, or
hung from the back of the motor vehicle’s center inside rear view mirror, so
that the decal so affixed or hung shall be clearly visible through the front
windshield from the outside of the vehicle.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989)
§ 522.08 DUPLICATE OR REPLACEMENT DECAL.
   (a)   Any resident or guest permit parking decal which has been issued
pursuant to this article, which has been lost, stolen or destroyed, shall be
replaced in accordance with the following terms and conditions. The resident of
the permit zone for whose use the resident permit parking decal or guest
parking decal was issued shall apply to the Parking Authority for a duplicate
or replacement decal of the same type which has been lost, stolen or destroyed.
Thereupon, the Parking Authority shall issue a duplicate or replacement decal
of the same type which has been lost, stolen or destroyed for a fee of $50 for
the use of the Parking Authority. Whenever a duplicate or replacement decal is
issued pursuant to the terms of this section, the Parking Authority shall mark
in the records the name and address of the resident to whom the duplicate or
replacement decal has been issued and in the case of a resident permit parking
decal, any pertinent information pertaining to the registration of the
resident’s motor vehicle for which the resident intends to use the duplicate or
replacement resident permit parking decal, in the same manner as when an
original resident permit parking decal is issued. Also, whenever a duplicate or
replacement decal is issued, the Parking Authority shall indicate in the
records the fact that the previously issued decal has been lost, stolen or
destroyed and such lost, stolen or destroyed decal shall thenceforth be
invalid.
   (b)   Any duplicate or replacement decal issued pursuant to the terms of
this section shall be valid only for the remainder of the then current year for
which the original decal was issued.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989; Ord. 6262, approved 8-7-2014)
§ 522.09 FALSIFICATION, TRANSFERABILITY OF DECALS.
   Any person who falsifies, duplicates, forges, alters, transfers or attempts
to transfer any parking decal issued pursuant to this article, or who obtains a
duplicate or replacement resident parking decal or guest parking decal pursuant
to this article under false pretenses, shall be subject to arrest and
prosecution under the applicable provisions of the Crimes Code of Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989)
§ 522.10 SEVERABILITY.
   If any section or provision of this article shall be determined to be
unenforceable, then the remainder of this article shall continue in full force
and effect.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989)
§ 522.11 ENFORCEMENT.
   This article shall be enforced by the meter attendants or other designated
employees of the Parking Authority.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989; Ord. 6262, approved 8-7-2014)
§ 522.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall, for each and every
such violation, pay the sum of $25 to the Parking Authority for the use of the
Parking Authority within 15 days of notice of such violation. If, within 15
days, the sum of $25 is not paid, a citation shall be issued in the office of
the District Justice, and the violator, upon conviction of violation of this
article, shall be guilty of a summary offense and shall be sentenced to pay a
fine of $50, plus the costs of prosecution and in default thereof, shall
undergo imprisonment for not more than one day.
(Ord. 5431, approved 9-14-1989; Ord. 6262, approved 8-7-2014)
ARTICLE 523: PARKING METERS
Section
   
523.01   Parking zones.
   
523.02   Sunday and holiday exceptions.

523.07   Use of meter revenues.

501.03
   Parking meter zone defined, see Part Five, §
501.04
   Removal and impounding of vehicles, see Part Five, 525
§ 523.01 PARKING ZONES.
   Parking meter zones are established by the Traffic Control Maps or by
temporary regulations in conformity with
Art. 503.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.02 SUNDAY AND HOLIDAY EXCEPTIONS.
   Parking in any parking meter zone on Sundays and on the following holidays,
to wit: New Year’s Day; Memorial Day; Fourth of July; Labor Day; Veteran’s Day;
Thanksgiving Day; and Christmas; is specifically excluded from the provisions
of this Traffic Code.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.03 METER INSTALLATION; PARKING SPACES DESIGNATED.
   In all parking meter zones, a parking meter shall be installed for each
parking space. All parking spaces shall be plainly designated by lines or
marking on the highway and may be placed either parallel or diagonal to the
curb.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.04 METER LOCATIONS; INFORMATION UPON METER.
   Parking meters shall be placed upon the sidewalk or curb immediately
adjacent to each designated parking space and in such manner as to show or
display by a signal that the parking space controlled by such meter is or is
not legally occupied. Each parking meter shall indicate by a proper legend the
established legal parking time and, when in operation, shall also indicate on
or by its dial or pointer the duration of the period of legal parking and any
illegal or over-parking.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.05 MANNER OF PARKING IN SPACE.
   Every vehicle parked in any parking meter zone shall be entirely within the
lines of the designated parking space with the front end of such parked vehicle
at or immediately adjacent to the parking meter controlling such parking space.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.06 COIN DEPOSIT; LAWFUL PERIOD FOR PARKING.
   Upon parking any vehicle in a parking meter zone, the operator thereof
shall, upon entering the designated parking space, immediately deposit or cause
to be deposited in the parking meter controlling such parking space the proper
coin of the United States as designated for such parking on the parking meter.
Upon the deposit of such coin and the placing of the meter in operation, such
parking space may be lawfully occupied by any vehicle during the period of
parking time as indicated on the parking meter.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.07 USE OF METER REVENUES.
   The coins required to be deposited in parking meters are levied and assessed
as fees to provide for the proper regulation and control of traffic upon the
highways, including the cost of supervising and regulating the parking of
vehicles in the parking meter zones created hereby and the cost of the
purchase, supervision, protection, inspection, operation, maintenance, control
and use of the aforesaid parking meters.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.08 OVERTIME PARKING.
   No owner or operator of any vehicle shall cause, allow, permit or suffer
such vehicle to be parked overtime or beyond the period of the legal parking
time established for any parking meter zone.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.09 DEPOSIT TO EXTEND METER TIME.
   No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any
coin for the purpose of increasing or extending the parking time of any vehicle
beyond the legal parking time established for any parking meter zone.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.10 COUNTERFEIT FOR LEGAL COIN.
   No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any
slug, device or metallic substitute for the required legal coin of the United
States, except tokens issued by the city.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.11 INJURING OR TAMPERING WITH METER.
   No person shall deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break,
destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
§ 523.12 LOADING AREAS, BUS STOPS, TAXICAB STANDS.
   Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the city from
providing for free parking space for loading and unloading, for bus stops, for
taxicab stands or for other matters of a similar nature.
(Ord. 2868, approved 3-23-1961)
ARTICLE 525: TOWING, IMPOUNDING AND DISPOSAL OF ABANDONED VEHICLES AND
SELECTION OF TOWING AND IMPOUND CONTRACTORS
