525.05   Selection of towing and impound contractors.
   
525.06   Annual licenses required.
   
525.07   Requirements and qualifications.
   
525.08   Duties of tower(s).
   
525.09   Records of vehicles towed and/or stored.
   
525.10   Notice to owner; police records.
   
525.11   Record of vehicles removed/impounded.
   
525.12   Owner/operator liable for fine/penalty.
   
525.13   Conditions for release.
   
525.14   Owner liable to fine or penalty; effect of payment without protest.
   
525.15   Payment of towing and impounding charges under protest.
   
525.16   Sale of impounded or abandoned vehicles not redeemed.
   
525.17   Schedule of fee review.
   
525.18   Termination of license.
   
525.19   Authorization of city officials.
   
525.20   Repealer.
   
525.21   Effective date.
Statutory reference:
   Abandoned vehicles and cargo, see 75 Pa.C.S. §§ 7310 et seq.
   Abandonment prohibited, see 75 Pa.C.S. § 3712
§ 525.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This article shall be known and may be cited as the “Towing, Impounding and
Disposal of Abandoned Vehicles and Selection of Towing and Impound
Contractors”.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.02 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this article is to provide for a convenient and regulated
towing system for the timely removal of motor vehicles damaged, abandoned,
immobilized, illegally parked, seized or disabled on public rights-of-way or on
public or private property within the City of Williamsport. This article will
replace or eliminate the existing City Ord. 5626, passed 7-7-1994, or known as
Art. 525, “Impounding Vehicles”.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.03 AUTHORITY TO REMOVE AND IMPOUND.
   (a)   Public property.
      (1)   Any vehicle parked on any of the highways, public rights-of-way or
other public property in the City of Williamsport, which is parked in violation
of any provision of the law or of any ordinance of the city, immobilized due to
collision, or abandoned in excess of 72 hours in accordance with the provisions
of this article, may be removed under the provisions of this article; provided,
however, no vehicle shall be towed away if, at the time of the intended
removal, the owner or a person for the time being who is in charge thereof is
present and expresses an intent to immediately remove such vehicle.
      (2)   The Williamsport Bureau of Police or any officer of the Bureau is
authorized to make the decision whether or not to remove any vehicle. Removal
shall be done only by a licensed towing company. Any vehicle removed shall be
impounded in a storage facility, as herein defined, or on property controlled
by the City of Williamsport and designated for vehicle impoundment.
      (3)   Any operator or owner of a vehicle involved in a collision may
request a specific towing service not covered by this article.
      (4)   The Authority of the City of Williamsport Bureau of Police to
remove and impound illegally parked vehicles shall not exceed the Authority
outlined in this article of the City of Williamsport.
   (b)   Private property.
      (1)   Any motor vehicle left unattended on private property within the
City of Williamsport may be removed under the provisions of this article.
      (2)   The decision to remove any such motor vehicle shall be made by
either the property owner or in accordance with the Williamsport Bureau of
Police abandoned vehicle policy.
      (3)   Removal of such vehicle may be done only by a licensed salvager/
towing service. Any motor vehicle removed by authority of this article shall be
impounded in a storage facility, as herein defined.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.04 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BUSINESS. The physical location where employees report to work, equipment is
stored and dispatched from, all company dealings take place, record keeping and
daily activity and the like is performed. For purposes of this article, a
BUSINESS shall have employees at that address during normal business hours,
which is defined as 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, exclusive of
national holidays.
   CHIEF OF POLICE. The Chief of Police of the Williamsport Bureau of Police or
his or her designee.
   CITY. The City of Williamsport, County of Lycoming, State of Pennsylvania.
   CUSTODIAN. A person having permission from the vehicle owner to exercise
care and/or control over a vehicle.
   EMERGENCY TOWING SERVICE. A provider of road service; vehicle and cargo
recovery; and/or towing of light and medium vehicles as defined herein; who
operates in accordance with the following requirements:
      (1)   Is regularly open for the conduct of business, receiving of
payments due, release of vehicles, etc., a minimum of 40 hours, Monday through
Friday, between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.;
      (2)   Maintains a license to collect sales tax;
      (3)   Uses vehicles to provide service that are properly titled and
registered, with the appropriate sales tax paid;
      (4)   Display business name on vehicles, as required by Vehicle Code and
Title 67;
      (5)   Equips service vehicles with appropriate safety equipment (fire
extinguisher, warning devices and the like), and any other equipment necessary
to perform the function; and complies with the Vehicle Code regarding removal
of debris;
      (6)   Maintains liability insurance, ensuring compliance with the Vehicle
Code and Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations, as appropriate, and garage-
keeper’s insurance in the amount specified for that classification of towing
service;
      (7)   Charges fees that are reasonable and customary for the service
provided in the emergency towing service’s geographic area. Fees must be posted
for public inspection in the place of business of the emergency towing service;
      (8)   Towing service must be a licensed salvor within six months of the
signing of the towing contract. A contractor may not tow any abandoned vehicle
(s) without having the appropriate license(s); and
      (9)   No answering services or devices are permitted. A phone number will
be provided by the Williamsport Towing Association for the purposes of
receiving all calls related to this article. An operator(s) or other attendant
(s) shall be employed by the Williamsport Towing Association to receive phone
calls 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
   GVW. Gross vehicle weight.
   MOTOR VEHICLE. As defined in the Vehicle Code.
   PERSON. An individual, firm, partnership, association, employee,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   PRIVATE PARKING LOT. A non-municipal parking lot open to the public or used
for parking without charge, or a non-municipal parking lot used for parking
with charge.
   PRIVATE PROPERTY. Real property owned by an individual, firm, partnership,
association, corporation, company or organization including private parking
lots as defined in the Vehicle Code.
   PROPERTY OWNER. An individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company, organization or designee representing the owner of the property from
which the vehicle is being towed.
   SECURE STORAGE LOT. A location or facility capable of being locked and
preventing general access to vehicle(s) therein by means of a barrier at least
six feet high.
   STORAGE FACILITY. A secured area for the storage of towed vehicles.
   TIMELY RESPONSE. Generally, 20 minutes or less from the time the towing
company is requested until the wrecker arrives at the scene. At times, there
may be circumstances beyond a tower’s control that makes it impossible for a
towing company to arrive within 20 minutes.
   VEHICLE CODE. Title 75 of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes.
   WINCHING. When the cable that is attached to a motorized pulley system is
unwound and attached to a vehicle to then place that vehicle in such as
position that the vehicle may either be driven away or conventionally hooked to
a wrecker.
   WRECKER. A vehicle designed and used for removing and transporting motor
vehicles. This term shall also include a rollback truck, tow truck or other
vehicles commonly used to perform towing services.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.05 SELECTION OF TOWING AND IMPOUND CONTRACTORS.
   The Chief of Police and City Clerk are authorized to entering into
negotiations with the Williamsport Towing Association and make recommendation
to City Council, for its review and approval, a contract for a period of not
more than one year with this organization of local towing companies in
accordance with the City of Williamsport purchasing procedures. The
Williamsport Towing Association will operate in the following manner.
   (a)   The towing companies shall consist of: any towing service contracted
by the City of Williamsport.
   (b)   A rotation schedule for each towing company will be established in
accordance with the terms of the contract signed by the City of Williamsport
and the members of the Williamsport Towing Association.
   (c)   If the company on call is unavailable, the call would go to the next
company on the rotation list as identified in the rotation schedule of the
contract.
   (d)   The towing company on call will provide for the City of Williamsport
towing service for all city-owned vehicles within a ten-mile radius of the city
free of any charge or fees.
   (e)   A call center, paid for by the Williamsport Towing Association, will
be utilized for dispatching and tracking of all towing requests. This
information will be maintained and distributed to all parties involved in this
agreement on a weekly basis showing all towing activities and the company
assigned.
   (f)   The assigned towing company will be required to pay to the City of
Williamsport an amount determined by this process for each tow requested by the
Police Department or one of its officers. Payment would be submitted to the
City of Williamsport on a monthly basis. The City of Williamsport will not
charge a towing fee, from the towing company, when the vehicle towed is part of
a criminal investigation and the owner is the victim of a crime.
   (g)   An annual license fee will be required for each towing company that is
part of the Williamsport Towing Association. A towing agreement will coincide
with the calendar year and will be in effect for one year after the acceptance
of this article. The towing agreement will renew automatically each year unless
one of the participating parties requests review or cancellation.
   (h)   If any of the individual towing companies listed in subsection (b) of
this section shall have its contract terminated or cancelled, for any reason,
whether by the city or the individual contractor, the remaining individual
contractors will be bound to the contract subject to an amendment of the
rotation schedule.
   (i)   If any of the individual companies listed in subsection (b) of this
section shall have its contract terminated or cancelled, for any reason,
whether by the city or the individual, the towing agreement will not
automatically renew.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012; Ord. 6231, approved 5-2-2013; Ord. 6325,
approved 4-12-2017)
§ 525.06 ANNUAL LICENSES REQUIRED.
   A towing and impound License is required for any towing company engaged in
the business of towing vehicles at the request of officers from the City of
Williamsport Bureau of Police from roads, alleyways or highways, public rights-
of-way or other public property within the City of Williamsport shall be
licensed annually in accordance with the provisions of this section.
   (a)   Application for license. Applications for license shall be submitted
to the Chief of Police upon forms prepared and made available by the City of
Williamsport. The application form(s) shall be properly completed, signed and
accompanied by the application and license fee. The Chief of Police shall
review and inspect the required storage facility and towing equipment and all
applications for compliance with the terms of this article and other applicable
regulations.
   (b)   Issuance of license(s). A towing license shall be issued only to
towing companies that comply with the provisions of this article.
   (c)   License fee. The license fee under this article for the original
application shall be $500 for each towing license.
   (d)   License renewal. All Licenses, except those terminated for just cause
as provided herein, are subject to an annual renewal fee of $250 for a single
license. The annual renewal fee shall be paid to the city on or before the date
of enactment of this article each year. Failure to renew said license(s) will
result in termination of the license.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.07 REQUIREMENTS AND QUALIFICATIONS.
   Towing and impound companies shall be licensed under this article to tow
vehicles at the request of the City of Williamsport Bureau of Police off public
or private land and roadways and shall maintain the following minimum
requirements on all wreckers of rollbacks.
   (a)   Wreckers, rollbacks and general equipment.
      (1)   Business and equipment shall be located within five miles of the
City of Williamsport.
      (2)   All towing vehicles shall be clearly marked with the towing
company’s name and telephone number marked on each side of the vehicle.
      (3)   Towing vehicles shall be maintained in safe mechanical condition
and must display current state inspection and registration.
      (4)   Towing equipment required:
         (A)   A minimum of two wreckers with all necessary equipment used in
performing light-duty service, medium-duty service and recovery service on the
various types of vehicles operated within the City of Williamsport;
         (B)   Rotating amber overhead lights clearly visible from 360 degrees;
         (C)   All clean-up equipment and oil dry or similar approved material
needed to clean up after vehicle collisions and the ability to communicate
immediately with the towing company’s dispatcher;
         (D)   Any other equipment to properly tow vehicles; and
         (E)   All towing equipment shall be owned or leased by the towing
company.
      (5)   A wrecker used by a City of Williamsport licensed towing company
shall not be used or operated by any other towing company under this article
unless authorized to do so by the Chief of Police.
   (b)   Secure storage and impound lot.
      (1)   All secure storage lot used for impoundment of vehicles towed at
the request of the City of Williamsport Bureau of Police shall be located
within five miles of the city borders.
      (2)   Any storage facility or impound lot must be authorized by the Mayor
and approved by the City Council for the City of Williamsport in accordance
with this article of the City of Williamsport.
      (3)   Any storage facility or impound lot shall post a bond in the amount
of $10,000 to be filed with the Department of Finance and Personnel in
accordance with this article of the City of Williamsport.
      (4)   The storage facility shall be owned or leased by the towing company
owner.
      (5)   The storage facility shall comply with zoning regulations
applicable in the jurisdiction where the facility is located.
      (6)   The towing company owner is responsible for the security of the
stored vehicles.
      (7)   Release of towed vehicles under this article shall be completed
within a two-hour time period following any request for the release of the
towed vehicle as long as all payments associated with tow or any outstanding
fees are satisfied and when the request is made during normal business hours as
posted. Conditions of release shall also be governed by this article of the
City of Williamsport.
   (c)   Insurance. Towing companies shall be required to carry insurance at
the minimum policy limits as follows:
      (1)   Automobile liability insurance in an amount not less than $500,000
combined single limits;
      (2)   Workers’ compensation insurance, as required by statute;
      (3)   Garage keeper’s liability insurance in an amount not less than
$50,000 per location;
      (4)   Garage liability insurance in an amount not less than $500,000
combined single limit; and
      (5)   Miscellaneous coverage to provide complete protection to the City
of Williamsport against any and all risks of loss or liability including
comprehensive general liability.
   (d)   Criminal record. No towing company owner or employee shall have any
misdemeanor and/or felony criminal convictions for criminal violations that
would be inconsistent with providing professional towing service.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.08 DUTIES OF TOWER(S).
   Tower(s) will be responsible for fulfilling all duties and responsibilities
as specified in the contract for services. Tower(s) will provide towing
services for the City of Williamsport including, but not limited to, motor
vehicle accident tows as requested, removal of illegally parked or abandoned
vehicle, towing of city owned vehicles, removal of any vehicle requested by the
Bureau of Police.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.09 RECORDS OF VEHICLES TOWED AND/OR STORED.
   (a)   The towing and impounding company(s) providing service at the request
of the City of Williamsport Bureau of Police shall make a written record of
each vehicle towed or stored consisting of the following information:
      (1)   Incident number corresponding to the incident;
      (2)   Registration plate number and state VIN (vehicle identification
number);
      (3)   Time call was received and arrival time at the scene;
      (4)   Date vehicle was returned to owner/custodian;
      (5)   Towing and storage charges for each towed vehicle; and
      (6)   Condition of vehicle to include damage to interior or exterior.
   (b)   The towing company, on the second and fourth Friday of each month (bi-
weekly), shall send and/or bring a copy of their towing records for the
previous two weeks including the information listed in subsection (a) above to
the office of the Chief of Police. These records shall be maintained by the
towing company for two years and shall be subject to inspection by the Chief of
Police or his or her designee.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.10 NOTICE TO OWNER; POLICE RECORDS.
   The person removing or directing the removal of any vehicle shall make a
report as per departmental policy, giving all vehicle information and the
location of the where the vehicle was removed from along with the reason for
its removal. The owner of record shall be notified, by first-class mail using
the last known address or that address shown on the registration, that the
vehicle has been impounded. This will be done on the next business day after
the removal, providing that the vehicle has not already been released from the
impounding area.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.11 RECORD OF VEHICLES REMOVED/IMPOUNDED.
   The Chief of Police or designee shall keep a record of all towed or
impounded vehicles, and shall be able at all reasonable times to furnish the
owners/custodians with information as to the location of the storage facility
where such vehicles are impounded.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.12 OWNER/OPERATOR LIABLE FOR FINE/PENALTY.
   The payment of towing and storage charges authorized by this article shall
not operate to relieve the owner or operator of any vehicle from liability for
any fine or penalty for violation of any law or ordinance on account of which
such vehicle was removed and impounded.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.13 CONDITIONS FOR RELEASE.
   Before the owner, or his or her agent, shall be permitted to remove an
impounded vehicle from a designated impounding parking area, he or she shall
pay to the owner of such towing service and/or parking area the regularly
established rates for the towing and storage charges of that particular towing
or parking service incurred in connection with the said vehicle impounding,
towing and storage, and also sign a release in favor of the said towing
service, parking lot owner and the city in triplicate with the original to be
forwarded to the city. Such vehicle shall not be released, however, without
satisfactory evidence of identity and ownership of the vehicle.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.14 OWNER LIABLE TO FINE OR PENALTY; EFFECT OF PAYMENT WITHOUT PROTEST.
   The payment of the towing and storage charges shall not operate to relieve
the owner from liability for any fine or penalty for violation of any law or
ordinance on account of which the vehicle was impounded; and provided further
that, payment of such charges, unless made “under protest” shall be final and
conclusive, and shall constitute a waiver of any right to recover the money so
paid.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.15 PAYMENT OF TOWING AND IMPOUNDING CHARGES UNDER PROTEST.
   In the event that towing and impounding charges are paid “under protest”,
the offender or owner shall be entitled to a hearing, pursuant to a civil
complaint filed by the offender or owner, before a District Justice having
jurisdiction for the location from which the vehicle is towed. Such civil
complaint shall be filed pursuant to and in compliance with the Rules of Civil
Procedure Actions and Proceedings before District Justices (Pa. R.C.P.D.J. Rule
No. 201 et seq.). If the District Justice shall, in accordance with law, acquit
the defendant, the District Justice shall forthwith certify such finding to the
Chief of Police, towing operator and the parking lot owner and the towing
operator and/or parking lot owner shall repay those moneys heretofore paid by
the vehicle owner at the time the impounded vehicle was returned to the owner
by the impounding parking lot owner. If the city shall be at fault in
connection with the towing, storage and impounding, the city shall reimburse
the towing operator and/or the parking lot operator for the services so
incurred. Otherwise, the charges shall be returned to the prevailing vehicle
owner whose vehicle was improperly towed and/or stored personally by the towing
operator and/or parking lot impounding operator.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.16 SALE OF IMPOUNDED OR ABANDONED VEHICLES NOT REDEEMED.
   If the owner or operator shall fail, within 30 days after the mailing of the
notices provided by this article to redeem his or her property, the city may
proceed to collect those moneys due under this article for storage and towing
as authorized by law and pursuant to this article before the District Justice
of the Peace. The District Justice judgment may be enforced by the Chief of
Police for sale of the vehicle pursuant to this article and law. All monies
received in excess of any fees due shall be remitted to the owner of the
vehicle in accordance with this article of the City of Williamsport, unless the
vehicle is abandoned as defined by 75 Pa.C.S. § 102. If the vehicle is
abandoned as defined by 75 Pa.C.S. § 102, all moneys in excess of such fees
shall be remitted to the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation in
accordance with provisions of 75 Pa.C.S. § 7308. With respect to abandoned
vehicles as defined by 75 Pa.C.S. § 102, the contractor(s) shall comply with
the provisions of Ch. 73 of Title 75 of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.17 SCHEDULE OF FEE REVIEW.
   All charges and fees authorized by this article shall be reviewed by the
Chief of Police after two years (but no more than three years of the effective
date of this article) and every two to three years thereafter. This section
shall only be in effect when the Chief of Police receives a written request
from a licensed towing company owner to review the charges and fees within 90
days prior to the scheduled review date. Any rate changes in response to the
written request to the Chief of Police shall be made within 90 days after
having received the request. All other fees shall be governed by this article
of the City of Williamsport.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.18 TERMINATION OF LICENSE.
   The towing company or its employees who violate any provision of this
article shall be issued a written warning for the first violation during any
calendar year. Any subsequent violation during the same year may cause the
removal of the towing company from the rotation agreement. A towing company may
be removed for the first violations if it is deemed that the violation was
egregious and the conduct did not reflect well on the City of Williamsport or
the other towing agencies involved in this agreement. The towing company shall
be notified in writing by the Chief of Police no less than five calendar days
prior to their removal and notice of removal shall state the reason(s) and the
effective date. The towing company shall have 14 calendar days to appeal its
removal, in writing, to the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police or his or her
designee shall hold a hearing within 14 calendar days of written receipt and
the towing company’s request for an appeal. The towing company may appeal the
decision made by Chief of Police, in writing, to the City Council of the City
of Williamsport, within ten calendar days of the receipt of that decision.
(Ord. 6217, approved 9-6-2012)
§ 525.19 AUTHORIZATION OF CITY OFFICIALS.
   The proper city officials are hereby authorized and directed to change §
525.05 (F) of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Williamsport to reflect
the amendments set forth in §
525.05 (F).
(Ord. 6325, approved 4-12-2017)
§ 525.20 REPEALER.
   All ordinances or parts of ordinances inconsistent with Ord. 6325, codified
in this Article are hereby repealed.
(Ord. 6325, approved 4-12-2017)
§ 525.21 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   Ordinance 6325, codified in §§
525.05,
525.19 and
525.20 became effective 20 days after its enactment.
(Ord. 6325, approved 4-12-2017)
ARTICLE 527: CITY HALL PARKING
Section
   
527.01   City Hall lot established.
   
527.02   Parking lot hours.
   
527.03   Allocation of spaces for City officials.
   
527.04   Designation of spaces; list to Police Chief.
   
527.05   Use of lot by others prohibited.
   
527.06   Police Chief to enforce.
   
527.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Impounding, see Part Five,
Art. 525
   Stopping and parking generally, see Part Five,
Art. 521
§ 527.01 CITY HALL LOT ESTABLISHED.
   The grounds to the rear of City Hall and the grounds to the east side and
west side of City Hall shall be used as a lot for the parking of motor
vehicles.
(Ord. 5030, approved 2-29-1980)
§ 527.02 PARKING LOT HOURS.
   (a)   The hours for the parking areas on the east side and west side of City
Hall are Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.
   (b)   The above parking area hours are not applicable to the parking spaces
assigned to the Bureau of Police. Parking spaces assigned to the Bureau of
Police must be properly marked and identified. These spaces are reserved 24
hours per day.
(Ord. 4062, approved 2-10-1966; Ord. 5781, approved 6-24-1999)
§ 527.03 ALLOCATION OF SPACES FOR CITY OFFICIALS.
   The Mayor or his or her authorized designee will allocate parking spaces in
the parking lot at their discretion to the directors of the departments of the
city government, elected officials and tenants of City Hall.
(Ord. 5030, approved 2-29-1980)
§ 527.04 DESIGNATION OF SPACES; LIST TO POLICE CHIEF.
   (a)   The directors of the various departments of the city government and
elected officials shall:
      (1)   Assign to and/or designate the employees within their departments
or officials who are to use the allocated parking spaces; and
      (2)   Submit to the Chief of Police a written list of the names and
license numbers of all city employees and/or city officials to whom parking
spaces have been assigned.
   (b)   All authorized employees or city officials will be issued a permit
from the Bureau of Police which must be displayed on the rear view mirror of
the vehicle parked on the City Hall parking areas.
(Ord. 4062, approved 2-10-1966; Ord. 5781, approved 6-24-1999)
§ 527.05 USE OF LOT BY OTHERS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park a motor on the grounds of City Hall within the hours
designated in §
527.02, except those city officials to whom a parking space has been assigned
or issued a parking permit. The parking area on the south side of City Hall is
reserved for Bureau of Police vehicles, city-owned vehicles (which have not
been assigned a specific parking space) and for city officials who have been
assigned a permit and not a specific parking space.
(Ord. 4062, approved 2-10-1966; Ord. 5781, approved 6-24-1999)
§ 527.06 POLICE CHIEF TO ENFORCE.
   The Chief of Police is hereby charged and authorized to enforce the
provisions of this article.
(Ord. 4062, approved 2-10-1966)
§ 527.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision in this article shall be fined $10.
(Ord. 4062, approved 2-10-1966; Ord. 5466, approved 3-22-1973; Ord. 5781,
approved 6-24-1999)

ARTICLE 701: ANIMALS
Section
   
701.01   Wild animals prohibited; exception.
   
701.02   Police Bureau dogs.
   
701.03   Dog defecation.
   
701.04   Dogs prohibited or leashed in parks.
   
701.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Zoning use regulations, see Part XIII, §
1333.05(h)(86)
Statutory reference:
   Animals at large, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 12410
§ 701.01 WILD ANIMALS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION.
   (a)   The art, trade or business of keeping lions, tigers, leopards, bears,
wildcats, wolves, foxes or any other similar vicious wild animals within the
city is hereby declared to be noxious and offensive to the inhabitants of the
city and dangerous to the health of the inhabitants of the city, and is hereby
prohibited.
   (b)   However, nothing contained in this section shall prohibit any circus
or animal show from performing in the city; provided, the animals are not
within the city for a period greater than seven consecutive days.
(Ord. 2289, approved 1-10-1951)
§ 701.02 POLICE BUREAU DOGS.
   (a)   (1)   No person shall intentionally, willfully or maliciously torment,
tease, kick, beat, strike, injure, disable or kill any dog owned and/or used by
the City Bureau of Police or any other police department assisting the City
Bureau of Police.
      (2)   No person shall intentionally, willfully or maliciously interfere
with any such dog used by such police departments or any member thereof in the
performance of any of the functions or duties of such department or of such
member thereof.
   (b)   No person shall intentionally, willfully or maliciously attempt to
perform or commit the acts prohibited in subsection (a) above.
(Ord. 5001, approved 12-14-1979)
§ 701.03 DOG DEFECATION.
   (a)   No dog owner and/or person having possession, custody or control of a
dog shall allow such dog to defecate upon any gutter, street, driveway, alley,
curb or sidewalk in the city, or upon floors or stairways of any building or
place frequented by the public or used in common by the tenants, or upon the
outside walls, walkways, driveways, alleys, curbs or stairways of any building
abutting on the public street or park or upon the grounds of any public park,
public area or upon private property other than the property of the owner.
   (b)   Any dog owner or a person having possession, custody or control of a
dog which defecates in any area other than the private property of the owner of
such dog as prohibited in subsection (a) above shall be required to immediately
remove the feces from such surfaces and either:
      (1)   Carry same away for deposit in a toilet; or
      (2)   Place same in a non-leaking container for deposit in a trash or
litter receptacle.
   (c)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to a guide dog
accompanying any blind persons or to a dog used to assist any other physically
handicapped person, or to animals used in any police or fire activities of the
city.
   (d)   No dog owner shall allow dog defecation to accumulate on his or her
property to the point it becomes a health hazard and/or public nuisance.
(Ord. 5244, approved 5-24-1984)
§ 701.04 DOGS PROHIBITED OR LEASHED IN PARKS.
   (a)   No dog owner and/or person having possession, custody or control of a
dog shall permit or allow such dog in any public park or playground, operated
or maintained by the city, during any period the park is posted for any event
or function sponsored, in whole or in part, by the Department of Recreation or
any event for which the sponsoring entity is required to register the function
or event with the Department.
   (b)   The Department shall determine whether the function or event requires
the prohibition of dogs from the park or a portion thereof, and shall cause the
park to be posted in such places as to reasonably notify the public of the
prohibition of dogs from the parks or a portion thereof.
   (c)   Any person exercising a dog or other pet in any public park or
playground owned, operated or maintained by the city shall maintain control of
the animal by leash at all times.
   (d)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to a guide dog
accompanying any blind person or to a dog used to assist any other physically
handicapped person or to animals used in any police or fire activities of the
city.
(Ord. 5537, approved 10-3-1991)
§ 701.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not less
than $100, nor more than $600, or imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both.
   (b)   Any person violating any provision of §
701.02(a) shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to pay the cost of
replacement and the cost of training of any such dog as shall be killed or
disabled or to pay the costs of treatment and care of any such dog if same be
injured, plus a fine as stated above.
(Ord. 5438, approved 11-9-1989)
ARTICLE 705: DISORDERLY CONDUCT AND BREACH OF THE PEACE
Section
   
705.01   Disorderly conduct.
   
705.02   Breach of the peace.
   
705.03   Alcoholic beverages in Brandon Park.
   
705.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Disturbing the peace, see Part Seven,
Art. 709
   Loitering, see Part Seven,
Art. 713
Statutory reference:
   Disorderly conduct and power to define, see 75 Pa.C.S. § 12432
§ 705.01 DISORDERLY CONDUCT.
   No person shall disturb the good order and quiet of the city by
intoxication, drunkenness, fighting, quarreling, wrangling, committing assault
and battery, using obscene or profane language in the streets and any other
places within the city, or otherwise violating the public peace by indecent
and/or disorderly conduct, by lewd and lascivious behavior or by threatening or
inflicting violence or abuse upon the person or property of another.
(Ord. 4565, approved 3-22-1973)
§ 705.02 BREACH OF THE PEACE.
   No person shall conduct himself or herself in a disorderly manner by doing
any of the following:
   (a)   Knowingly utter any obscene, insulting, abusive, threatening or other
language that is reasonably likely to provoke immediate violent response or a
breach of the peace; or
   (b)   Knowingly commit any act or gesture which is reasonably likely to
intimidate or threaten others or provoke immediate violent response or a breach
of the peace.
(Ord. 4565, approved 3-22-1973)
§ 705.03 ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN BRANDON PARK.
   (a)   No person shall consume or possess alcoholic beverages in Brandon
Park.
   (b)   The term ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES includes liquors, wine, malt beverages or
any other beverage subject to control by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania
Liquor Control Board.
(Ord. 4928, approved 10-5-1978)
§ 705.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not more than
$600 or imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both.
(Ord. 5439, approved 11-9-1989)
ARTICLE 709: DISTURBING THE PEACE
Section
   
709.01   Unnecessary noises a nuisance.
   
709.02   Squealing of tires.
   
709.03   Unreasonable use of mechanical devices.
   
709.04   Issuance of permits for certain purposes.
   
709.05   Permit fee and display.
   709.06   Fireworks activity.
   
709.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Breach of the peace, see Part Seven, §
705.02
   Noise standards, see Part Thirteen, §
1344.02
Statutory reference:
   Fireworks law, see Act 43 of 2017 (House Bill No. 542 October 30, 2017)
   Preventing noises, see 3rd Class § 2403(25) (53 P.S. § 37403(25))
§ 709.01 UNNECESSARY NOISES A NUISANCE.
   The making of unnecessary, unusual noise or any noise which either annoys,
disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of
others, within the limits of the city is declared to be a public nuisance.
Enumeration of the particular offenses hereinafter particularly defined shall
not be construed as limiting the generality of the section or limiting the
offenses hereunder to particular offenses hereinafter enumerated.
(Ord. 6347, approved 9-13-2018)
§ 709.02 SQUEALING OF TIRES.
   No person operating any vehicle in the city shall cause the tires of his or
her vehicle to squeal and thereby cause noise and disturbance to the peace of
the community; such is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
(Ord. 6347, approved 9-13-2018)
§ 709.03 UNREASONABLE USE OF MECHANICAL DEVICES.
   No person shall use, operate or permit to be played, used or operated any
radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device
for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the
peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or the public at any
time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for persons
who are in the room, vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is
operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto, and such activity is hereby
declared to be a nuisance.
(Ord. 6347, approved 9-13-2018)
§ 709.04 ISSUANCE OF PERMITS FOR CERTAIN PURPOSES.
(EDITOR’S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 5357, approved August
13, 1987.)
§ 709.05 PERMIT FEE AND DISPLAY.
(EDITOR’S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 5357, approved August
13, 1987.)
§ 709.06 FIREWORKS ACTIVITY.
   The City of Williamsport recognizes Act 43 of 2017 House Bill No. 542
governing the sale, purchase and use of "Consumer Fireworks". All persons who
are using "Consumer Fireworks" shall follow all rules and regulations outlined
in Section 2404 Use of Consumer Fireworks as well as the following conditions.
   (a)   Conditions. A person who is at least 18 years of age and meets the
requirements of this article may purchase, possess and use consumer fireworks.
   (b)   Prohibitions. A person may not intentionally ignite or discharge:
      (1)   Consumer fireworks on public or private property without the
express permission of the owner.
      (2)   Consumer fireworks or sparkling devices within or throw consumer
fireworks or sparkling devices from a motor vehicle or building.
      (3)   Consumer fireworks or sparkling devices into or at a motor vehicle
or building or at another person.
      (4)   Consumer fireworks or sparkling devices while the person is under
the influence or alcohol, or a controlled substance or another drug.
      (5)   Consumer fireworks within 150 feet of any structure.
   (c)   Consumer fireworks shall be approved for use starting the weekend
before July 4 and be permitted for use through the following calendar weekend.
For purposes of this provision the weekend starts on Friday and then would
conclude the following Sunday. Times for approved consumer fireworks shall be
8:00 a.m. until 10:00 p.m. In addition, consumer fireworks shall also be
approved on New Year's Eve starting at 8pm and must conclude by 12:30 a.m. on
New Year's Day.
   (d)   No permission is granted by the City of Williamsport or its
subsidiaries for the ignition and display of consumer fireworks, the sidewalks
and streets of the City of Williamsport or on any other property owned by the
City of Williamsport, including, without limitation, all of the City's parks,
parking lots and public buildings.
   (e)   In addition to use of fireworks, all additional guidelines set forth
in House Bill No. 542 of 2017 shall strictly be followed and adhered to.
(Ord. 6347, approved 9-13-2018)
§ 709.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not more than
$600 or imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both.
(Ord. 6347, approved 9-13-2018)
ARTICLE 711: ENTERTAINMENT DISTRICTS
Section
   
711.01   Definitions.
   
711.02   Entertainment districts.
   
711.03   Permit requirements and fees.
   
711.04   Specified prohibited acts; violations.
   
711.05   Penalties.
   
711.06   Inconsistent provisions.
   
711.07   Effective dates.
§ 711.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meaning
indicated, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context.
   ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES. Any beverage with an alcohol content sufficient to
cause it to be regulated by the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board.
   AMPLIFIED MUSIC. To make noise by displaying speakers, a band, musician, DJ
or vocalist, where an amplifier is used, both inside and outside of a PLCB
licensed establishment.
   DECIBEL. A logarithmic unit of measure used in describing the amplitude of
sound. DECIBEL is noted as dB.
   ENTERTAINMENT. Amplified music which is a band, musician, disc jockey,
vocalist or speakers, etc.
   ENTERTAINMENT DISTRICT. The land use zones established to create approved
amplified music and arts locations.
   LIQUOR CONTROL BOARD EXEMPTED AREA. The area within the City of Williamsport
which, as approved by the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board and the City of
Williamsport, is exempted from the enforcement of Pennsylvania Liquor Control
Regulation regarding amplified music.
   NOISE NUISANCE. To make noise, to specifically include amplified music,
which disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of
individuals who reside or operate businesses adjacent or in proximity to said
entertainment district location.
(Ord. 6251, approved 1-23-2014)
§ 711.02 ENTERTAINMENT DISTRICTS.
   The City of Williamsport hereby creates three separate entertainment
districts, all of which shall be considered “Liquor Control Board exempted
areas” within which public safety officers of the city shall enforce all noise
nuisance violations related to amplified music at PLCB licensed establishments.
The districts shall be as follows:
   (a)   Area 1 as defined in Map 1 of the City of Williamsport attached to the
ordinance codified herein;
   (b)   Area 2 as defined in Map 1 of the City of Williamsport attached to the
ordinance codified herein; and
   (c)   Area 3 as defined in Map 1 of the City of Williamsport attached to the
ordinance codified herein.
(Ord. 6251, approved 1-23-2014)
§ 711.03 PERMIT REQUIREMENTS AND FEES.
   (a)   Permit required for outdoor entertainment. To define and abate a
nuisance, and to regulate or prohibit any amusement which tends to annoy
persons on a street or public ground, and to use the authority provided under
this article to preserve peace and order within the city.
      (1)   Persons desiring to sponsor, promote or put on any sort of event
which includes amplified outdoor entertainment of any kind which is open to the
public and located within the premises of a PLCB licensed establishment shall,
not less than 72 hours prior to the planned event, make application to the
Bureau of Codes for approval of a permit allowing the entertainment.
      (2)   Such application shall be on a form provided by Bureau of Codes and
shall include:
         (A)   The date of the event;
         (B)   The beginning and ending times of the event, which shall fall
between the hours of 12:00 noon to 10:00 p.m. on weekdays, and 12:00 noon to
11:00 p.m. on weekends and holidays;
         (C)   The location of the event (especially in relation to residential
areas and commercial establishments);
         (D)   The size of the event (number of participants and/or spectators
expected);
         (E)   The purpose of the event;
         (F)   A description of the event or entertainment to be provided;
         (G)   A diagram of the premises showing the location of activities,
emergency access and a description of how access to the event is to be
controlled and in accordance to this article shall be provided; and
         (H)   Other factors associated with public health and welfare,
security and safety of the event participants and the general public.
      (3)   The applicant may be required to consult with the Bureau of Codes
Administrator, Zoning Official, Fire Chief and/or Police Chief after submitting
an application, regarding appropriate plans for the event.
      (4)   Permitted outside areas for entertainment must be blocked off with
barriers (tape, plastic fencing and other like material is not permitted).
      (5)   Fees shall be as set forth in Part One,
Art. 117.
   (b)   Appeal. If the Codes Administrator denies a permit application, the
applicant may appeal the decision to the City Council. Such an appeal hearing
shall be held at the next regular City Council meeting. The failure of City
Council to act shall be a deemed denial of the application.
   (c)   Standards. Each special event shall meet the following standards.
      (1)   Compliance with other regulations. All special events must meet all
other applicable federal, state and local codes and ordinances.
      (2)   Cleanup of area. The person obtaining the permit for an outdoor
special event shall be responsible for the cleanup of the area used by the
event, plus the public rights-of-way within 150 feet of that area, within 24
hours of the close of the event.
(Ord. 6251, approved 1-23-2014)
§ 711.04 SPECIFIED PROHIBITED ACTS; VIOLATIONS.
   Violations of noise regulations will be enforced by the City of Williamsport
Police Department using the criteria established in
Art. 709 regarding noise nuisances.
(Ord. 6251, approved 1-23-2014)
§ 711.05 PENALTIES.
   Should a permit applicant fail substantially to adhere to the plan on which
permit approval was based, the city, through the Williamsport Police Department
and/or the Bureau of Codes, may order the event or function terminated
immediately on notice to the permittee. Any person who violates this article or
fails to follow the plan upon which the permit is based shall be subject to a
fine with the minimum fine amount of $250 to maximum fine amount of $500 for
first offense and second or additional offenses minimum of $250 with a maximum
of $600.
(Ord. 6251, approved 1-23-2014)
§ 711.06 INCONSISTENT PROVISIONS.
   In the event any ordinance or part thereof is inconsistent with this
article, the provisions of this article shall prevail.
(Ord. 6251, approved 1-23-2014)
§ 711.07 EFFECTIVE DATES.
   This article shall become effective 20 days after final enactment. This
article approved/vetoed on 1-23-2014.
(Ord. 6251, approved 1-23-2014)
ARTICLE 713: LOITERING
Section
   
713.01   Definitions.
   
713.02   Certain types of loitering prohibited.
   
713.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Disorderly conduct and breach of the peace, see Part Seven,
Art. 705
   Disturbing the peace, Part Seven,
Art. 709
§ 713.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meaning
indicated, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context.
   LOITERING. Remaining idle essentially in one location; lingering; spending
time idly; loafing or walking aimlessly in one vicinity or neighborhood; or
hanging around.
   PUBLIC PLACE. Any place to which the public has access, including any public
street or public sidewalk, the front of or the area immediately adjacent to any
school, parking lot, store, restaurant, tavern, billiard parlor or other place
of business, and also public grounds, areas or parks.
(Ord. 5686, approved 5-23-1996)
§ 713.02 CERTAIN TYPES OF LOITERING PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain
idle either alone and/or in consort with others in a public place in such a
manner so as to obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or
any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tending to
hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or
pedestrians or:
   (a)   Commit in or upon any public place, public highway, public sidewalk or
any other public place or building an act of which is an obstruction or
interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business
lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon facing or fronting on any such public
street, public highway, public sidewalk or other public place or building, all
of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress,
therein, thereon and thereto; and
   (b)   Create or cause to be created any annoyance to any person or persons.
(Ord. 5686, approved 5-23-1996)
§ 713.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall, for a first offense,
be fined $100 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both; and, for a second
offense, be fined $200 or imprisoned not more than 60 days or both; and, for
any third offense, be fined $300 or imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both;
and, for any subsequent offense, be fined $600 or imprisoned not more than 90
days or both.
(Ord. 5686, approved 5-23-1996)
ARTICLE 717: NUISANCES
Section
   
717.01   Definitions.
   
717.02   Maintenance prohibited.
   
717.03   Authority for removal; collection of costs.
   
717.04   Other applicable provisions.
   
717.05   Repeal exceptions.
   
717.06   Equitable enforcement.
   
717.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Refuse disposal, see Part Eleven,
Art. 1151
   Weeds and grass, see Part Eleven,
Art. 1153
   Zoning performance standards, see Part Thirteen,
Art. 1344
§ 717.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, certain terms are defined as follows.
   ABANDONED OR JUNK MATERIAL. Includes, but shall not be limited to furnaces,
parts of furnaces, electrical appliances and furniture of little value and not
properly housed.
   JUNK. Includes, but shall not be limited to, any and all forms of waste and
refuse of any type of material, including scrap metal, abandoned or junked
motor vehicles, glass, industrial waste and other salvable materials.
   NUISANCES. Include, but shall not be limited to, accumulations of garbage
and rubbish, the storage and accumulation of abandoned or junked motor vehicles
or motor vehicles not used or licensed, the storage or accumulation of other
abandoned or junk material, the carrying on of any offensive manufacture or
business and the accumulation of junk.
   PROPERTY. Includes both private and public property.
   PROPERTY OWNER. Includes all natural persons, corporations, associations,
school districts and churches, tenants or occupiers of property in the city.
(Ord. 4519, approved 4-13-1972)
§ 717.02 MAINTENANCE PROHIBITED.
   No property owner in the city shall maintain a nuisance.
(Ord. 4519, approved 4-13-1972)
§ 717.03 AUTHORITY FOR REMOVAL; COLLECTION OF COSTS.
   The Health Officer, or Zoning Officer, or any one acting under them or
either of them, shall have authority to remove any nuisance on public or
private grounds after notice to the owner to do so, and, in his or her default,
to collect the costs of such removal together with a penalty of 10%.
(Ord. 5013, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 717.04 OTHER APPLICABLE PROVISIONS.
   The provisions of this article shall be in addition to zoning, fire
prevention, sanitary and building laws, ordinances or resolutions now in force
and applicable to the locality in which the subject exists.
(Ord. 4519, approved 4-13-1972)
§ 717.05 REPEAL EXCEPTIONS.
   All ordinances or parts of ordinances, inconsistent herewith are hereby
repealed. However, this article shall in no way repeal any zoning ordinances or
zoning permits issued pursuant to such zoning ordinances, nor shall this
article be applicable to any licensed scrap or scrap processing dealer.
(Ord. 4519, approved 4-13-1972)
§ 717.06 EQUITABLE ENFORCEMENT.
   In addition, the Health Officer or Zoning Officer may institute proceedings
in courts of equity to enforce this article.
(Ord. 5013, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 717.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not more than
$600 or imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both.
(Ord. 5442, approved 11-9-1989)
ARTICLE 717A: NEIGHBORHOOD PRESERVATION AND NUISANCE ASSESSMENT

ARTICLE 720: BRANDON PARK CONDUCT

720.01   Prohibition against vehicles on unpaved portions of Brandon Park.
   
720.02   Restrictions on pets and requirement of excrement disposal.

physical property.
   
720.04   Prohibition against deposit of garbage, trash or refuse.
   
720.05   Restrictions on signs.
   
720.06   Restrictions on articles for sale.
   
720.07   Prohibition against defacing or destroying notices or rules and
regulations.
   
720.08   Prohibition against firearms and destructive weapons. (Repealed)
   
720.09   Prohibition against improper conduct.
   
720.10   Prohibition against alcoholic beverages and drugs.
   
720.11   Speed limit.
   
720.12   Restrictions on use of bicycles and similar items during and near
events.
   
720.13   Prohibition against disturbing, injuring or killing birds or animals.
   
720.14   Prohibition against attaching swings to or climbing trees.
   
720.15   Prohibition against events, parades or processions.
   
720.16   Prohibition against playing golf.
   
720.17   Prohibition against gambling.
   
720.18   Security deposit.
   
720.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Park and playground curfew, see Part Seven,
Art. 721
   Recreation Commission, see Part One,
Art. 183
Statutory reference:
   Parks and playgrounds, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 13703 et seq.
§ 720.01 PROHIBITION AGAINST VEHICLES ON UNPAVED PORTIONS OF BRANDON PARK.
   Except for purposes of maintenance, no person shall ride or drive on any
part of Brandon Park other than on the paved roads and driveways of the park,
except as approved by the Brandon Park Commission.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.02 RESTRICTIONS ON PETS AND REQUIREMENT OF EXCREMENT DISPOSAL.
   Any person exercising or accompanied by a dog or other pet in the park shall
maintain control of the animal by leash at all times. The pet owner shall be
responsible for immediate removal of any excrement of the animal. No pets shall
be allowed in the park during events.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.03 PROHIBITION AGAINST INJURY, DEFACEMENT OR REMOVAL OF PLANTS OR
PHYSICAL PROPERTY.
   No person shall in any way injure, deface, dig or remove any plant, material
or physical property within the park.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.04 PROHIBITION AGAINST DEPOSIT OF GARBAGE, TRASH OR REFUSE.
   All garbage generated within the boundaries of the park shall be deposited
in designated trash and garbage receptacles. Trash or garbage generated outside
of Brandon Park shall not be deposited within the park.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.05 RESTRICTIONS ON SIGNS.
   (a)   Signs may only be used in connection with an event that is approved in
accordance with the Brandon Park agreement form and this article governing the
use of Brandon Park.
   (b)   Signs must be approved as to design and location as part of the event
approval process by the Brandon Park Commission.
   (c)   Signs should be prepared in a professional manner and should not
exceed 32 square feet in area. Banners are prohibited.
   (d)   Signs may only be erected or installed the day of the event and must
be removed immediately following the event in connection with which they are
posted. No signs may be displayed before 6:00 a.m. or after 10:00 p.m.
   (e)   With respect to food or craft vendors, and their structures, booths or
vehicles from which they operate, only permanently painted or affixed signs
that are attached to the structure, booth or vehicle which are used to promote
or identify the vendor or craft are permitted.
   (f)   Signs or other advertising of alcoholic beverages, tobacco products or
firearms are prohibited.
   (g)   The foregoing restrictions shall not apply to signage located on the
inside fences of the A and B and senior ballfields in Brandon Park operated by
Brandon Little League to the extent that such signs are otherwise reviewed and
approved by the Brandon Park Commissions. Signage for Little League ballfields
may be posted only during the season (April through August). All signs must be
uniform in size, not to exceed four feet by eight feet and professionally
prepared with green backside.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.06 RESTRICTIONS ON ARTICLES FOR SALE OR AUCTION.
   Nothing may be sold or auctioned within the park, except sales of food,
beverages, crafts, souvenirs or other items approved by the Brandon Park
Commission pertaining to the approved event.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.07 PROHIBITION AGAINST DEFACING OR DESTROYING NOTICES OR RULES AND
REGULATIONS.
   No person shall injure, deface or destroy any notices, rules or regulations,
or other matters which have been posted in the park by order of, or with the
permission of, Brandon Park Commission.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.08 PROHIBITION AGAINST FIREARMS AND DESTRUCTIVE WEAPONS.
Editor’s note:
   This section was repealed by Ord. 6273, approved 3-19-2015.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000; Ord. 6273, approved 3-19-2015)
§ 720.09 PROHIBITION AGAINST IMPROPER CONDUCT.
   No person shall curse, swear or use threatening or abusive language or
otherwise behave in a riotous manner in the park.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.10 PROHIBITION AGAINST ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES AND DRUGS.
   No person shall possess, sell or use alcoholic beverages or drugs in the
park.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.11 SPEED LIMIT.
   No person shall operate a vehicle (as defined in 75 Pa. C.S.A. § 102) within
Brandon Park at a speed in excess of 15 mph.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.12 RESTRICTIONS ON USE OF BICYCLES AND SIMILAR ITEMS DURING AND NEAR
EVENTS.
   No person shall operate, ride or use a bicycle, roller skate, skateboard or
similar item within the vicinity of any event sponsored in whole or in part by
the Recreation Commission.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.13 PROHIBITION AGAINST DISTURBING, INJURING OR KILLING BIRDS OR ANIMALS.
   Except at the discretion of a representative of the city, no person shall
disturb birds, or annoy, strike, injure, maim or kill any animal within Brandon
Park.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.14 PROHIBITION AGAINST ATTACHING SWING TO OR CLIMBING TREES.
   Except as authorized by a representative of the city, no person shall attach
a swing to, nor climb, a tree in Brandon Park.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.15 PROHIBITION AGAINST EVENTS, PARADES OR PROCESSIONS.
   No event, parade or procession shall take place or pass through Brandon Park
without a city permit.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.16 PROHIBITION AGAINST PLAYING GOLF.
   No person shall engage in any aspect of the sport of golf within Brandon
Park.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.17 PROHIBITION AGAINST GAMBLING.
   Gambling is prohibited in the park, with the exception of 50/50 drawings for
the benefit of Brandon Park Little League.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.18 SECURITY DEPOSIT.
   (a)   In addition to any other requirements, any group or individual using
any part of Brandon Park for an approved event shall be required to submit a
security deposit or bond to ensure compliance with the rules and regulations
governing the use of Brandon Park, to include, without limitation, immediate
clean-up following the event, repair of any damage to the Park arising out of
the event and restoration of the Park to its pre-event condition.
   (b)   The amount of such security deposit or bond shall not be less than
$500 for each day (or portion thereof) of the event, unless the Brandon Park
Commission determines that the amount should be increased or decreased because
of special circumstances.
   (c)   The security deposit or bond shall be forfeited if rules and
regulations governing the event are not followed in all material respects.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
§ 720.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be
fined not more than $600 or imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both.
(Ord. 5807, approved 4-6-2000)
ARTICLE 721: PARK AND PLAYGROUND CURFEW
Section
   
721.01   Times when closed.
   
721.02   Exceptions for lighted areas.
   
721.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Recreation Commission, see Part One,
Art. 183
Statutory reference:
   Parks and playgrounds, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 13703 et seq.
§ 721.01 TIMES WHEN CLOSED.
   All public parks and playgrounds owned, operated, maintained or supported by
the city shall be closed during Daylight Saving time between the hours of 9:00
p.m. and 5:30 a.m. and between the hours of 6:30 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. during
Eastern Standard time.
(Ord. 4764, approved 8-26-1976; Ord. 5734, approved 12-11-1997)
§ 721.02 EXCEPTIONS FOR LIGHTED AREAS.
   Exceptions to the provisions of §
721.01 shall include all recreational areas, which are lighted for a specific
purpose (i.e., tennis courts, basketball courts, baseball or softball diamonds
and swimming pools). Such areas shall be closed 15 minutes after the lights are
turned out as regulated by the Department of Recreation via time clocks or
mechanical switches. Specially lighted areas are not to be construed as
lighting designated for security purposes.
(Ord. 5184, approved 11-4-1982)
§ 721.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall, for a first offense,
be fined not more than $25 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both; and,
for any subsequent offense, shall be fined not more than $100 or imprisoned not
more than 90 days, or both.
(Ord. 5184, approved 11-4-1982)

725.99   Penalty.

§ 725.01 REFRIGERATOR DOORS TO BE OPENABLE.

abandoning, discarding or discontinuing the use thereof for refrigeration or
