ARTICLE 733: SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL
Section
   
733.01   Duty to remove snow.
   
733.02   Duty to keep gutter free.
   
733.03   Duty of city employees.
   
733.04   Failure to comply; work by city and collection of cost.
   
733.05   Removed snow not to be piled on street, fire hydrant or block any
sewer opening.
   
733.06   Removed snow not to be piled on curb.
   
733.07   Removed snow not to be piled on storm sewer outlets and grates.
   
733.08   Fire hydrants.
   
733.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Debris on streets, see Part Seven, §
737.04
   Snow emergency regulations, see Part Five, §
503.05
§ 733.01 DUTY TO REMOVE SNOW.
   The owner of any building fronting on any street, lane or alley of the city
and the vacant lot owner where there is sidewalk in front (including corner
crosswalk) of such premises shall, within six hours after the ceasing to fall
of any snow, ice or sleet, in the daytime and before 10:00 a.m. in the forenoon
succeeding the nighttime fall of snow, ice or sleet, remove or cause to be
removed such snow, ice or sleet from the full width of such sidewalk.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
§ 733.02 DUTY TO KEEP GUTTER FREE.
   In all sections of the city where sidewalks extend from the property line to
the curb line of any street and such street is paved, the owner of the building
fronting on such street, or vacant lot owner, shall remove the snow, ice or
sleet from the sidewalk and crosswalks. CROSSWALKS shall mean that part of a
roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines
of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway, measured from the curbs or,
in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway and, in the
absence of a sidewalk on one side of the roadway, that part of a roadway
included within the extension of the lateral lines of the existing sidewalk. An
owner shall also be required to open a pedestrian passageway from the sidewalk
to the traveled portion of the street at some point on his or her property.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
§ 733.03 DUTY OF CITY EMPLOYEES.
   It shall be the duty of all police officers, and other city officers or
employees, to report any violations of the provisions of this article to the
Codes Office, in writing, giving the name of the owner of the premises, if
available, together with the number and street address.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
§ 733.04 FAILURE TO COMPLY; WORK BY CITY AND COLLECTION OF COST.
   If the owner of the premises fails to comply with the terms of this article
within the time limit specified to remove such snow, ice or sleet from the
sidewalks and open the gutters, then the Codes Office may remove or cause to be
removed the snow, ice or sleet and open the gutters at a cost of $30 per hour
per employee but with a minimum charge of $30. The expense noted shall be
charged and collected from such owner, tenant or occupant of such premises as
compensation for the work done, and shall not in any manner prevent the
imposition of the penalty mentioned in §
733.99.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
§ 733.05 REMOVED SNOW NOT TO BE PILED ON STREET, FIRE HYDRANT OR BLOCK ANY
SEWER OPENING.
   No person shall remove snow from any parking lot, sidewalk or driveway and
pile the same upon any city street or block any sewer opening or fire hydrant.
No person shall place snow removed from a curb area of the street unto the
cartway or traveled portion of the street. No person shall build mounds of snow
on the traveled portion of the city streets.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
§ 733.06 REMOVED SNOW NOT TO BE PILED ON CURB.
   No person, tenant, occupant or owner of any premises shall cause snow from
his or her premises, sidewalk or street to be placed within the curblines
(actual or projected) of any street within the city.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
§ 733.07 REMOVED SNOW NOT TO BE PILED ON STORM SEWER OUTLETS AND GRATES.
   Landowners shall not pile snow on storm sewer outlets. Landowners shall have
an affirmative duty to keep the storm sewer outlets and grates abutting on
their properties as clear as possible.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
§ 733.08 FIRE HYDRANTS.
   No owner shall plow, mound, pile or otherwise obstruct or cause to be
obstructed any city fire hydrant. Landowners shall have an affirmative duty to
keep fire hydrants abutting on their properties as clear as possible.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
§ 733.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined $25 for the
first offense; $50 for the second offense; and $100 for the third and
subsequent offense. Each day that the condition exists shall be considered a
separate violation.
(Ord. 5622, passed 5-12-1994)
ARTICLE 737: STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
Section
   
737.01   Definitions.
   
737.02   Purpose.
   
737.03   Obstructions prohibited.
   
737.04   Debris on streets.
   
737.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Snow and ice removal, see Part Seven,
Art. 733
   Trees, see Part Nine,
Art. 915
Statutory reference:
   Nuisances, see 11 Pa.C.S. § 12414
   Regulation of encroachments, see 11 Pa.C.S. § 12415
§ 737.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AREAWAYS. The portion of the highways between the property line and the curb
line, where curbs are set and where no curb is set, between the property line
and the point of location of the curb when the same is set.
   FOOTWAYS. The portion of the highway paved or set apart for public travel.
(Ord. 1203, approved 4-4-1930)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 Pa.C.S. § 10102 and 75 Pa.C.S. § 102   
§ 737.02 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this article is at all times to keep clear from interference
or obstruction the sidewalks and areaways of the city for public travel, and
especially to prevent the use of the footways and areaways by dealers or
merchants in the display of goods or merchandise.
(Ord. 1203, approved 4-4-1930)
§ 737.03 OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall place, cause to be placed or knowingly allow to be placed or
remain upon the footways of any of the highways of the city, nor upon the
areaways of any of such highways any box, crate, stone, plank, board, goods,
wares or merchandise or any other substance or material; provided that, this
article shall not forbid the use of the areaways by the owners of properties
abutting thereon, for the loading or unloading of merchandise, the delivery of
coal, wood, ice, groceries or supplies for such reasonable period as it may be
necessary for that purpose, and no commodity, merchandise, coal, wood, ice,
groceries or supplies shall be permitted to remain on any part of such
areaways, except on the outer or inner edge of the areaway, or footway where
the footway covers the entire areaway in front of any lot, store or building,
and shall be so placed as not to obstruct more than one-half of the sidewalk,
nor be placed within 15 feet of any fire hydrant, nor shall this article
prohibit the use of the areaways for the planting of shade or ornamental trees
or the cultivation of lawnage on the areaways, where the footwalk thereon shall
not occupy the whole of the areaways, nor where the same may be required for
building operations under existing regulations of the city for such purpose, or
such reasonable regulations hereafter provided by the city.
(Ord. 1203, approved 4-4-1930)
§ 737.04 DEBRIS ON STREETS.
   No person shall throw or place, or caused to be thrown or placed any ashes,
garbage, kitchen offal, grass, leaves, tree limbs, yard waste or other
offensive or noisome matter in any of the streets, lanes or alleys of the city.
During a designated spring time period, as indicated by the city, it is
permitted to place tree limbs and yard waste along the curb lines of main
streets for pickup. During a designated fall time period, as indicated by the
city, loose leaves only may be placed along curb lines of main streets for
pickup.
(Ord. 433, approved 3-28-1921; Ord. 6218, approved 10-18-2012)
§ 737.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates §
737.03 shall be fined not more than $5 for each and every hour or fraction
thereof that such obstruction shall remain or imprisoned not more than five
days, or both.
   (b)   Whoever violates §
737.04 shall be fined not less than $100, nor more than $1,000, or imprisoned
not more than 90 days. Each day or portion thereof that such violation
continues or is permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 433, approved 3-28-1921; Ord. 1255, approved 8-18-1930; Ord. 4566,
approved 3-22-1973; Ord. 6218, approved 10-18-2012)
ARTICLE 741: WEAPONS
Section
   
741.01   Firearms discharge prohibited.
   
741.02   Exceptions.
   
741.99   Penalty.
Statutory reference:
   Sale and use of air rifles, see Crimes Code § 6304 (18 Pa.C.S. § 6304)
   Uniform Firearms Act, see Crimes Code §§ 6101 et seq. (18 Pa.C.S. §§ 6101 et
seq.)
§ 741.01 FIREARMS DISCHARGE PROHIBITED.
   No person shall fire or shoot a pistol, rifle, shotgun, revolver, gun or
pistols loaded with blanks or other cartridges within the city limits.
(Ord. 4806, approved 3-10-1977)
§ 741.02 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of §
741.01 shall not apply to:
   (a)   Constables, sheriffs, prison or jail wardens, or their deputies,
police officers of this commonwealth, or its political subdivisions, or any
other law enforcement officers or private security officers;
   (b)   Members of the armed services of the United States, the Coast Guard,
the National Guard or organized reserves while on duty;
   (c)   The use and discharge of guns during the course of athletic, dramatic
and similar events;
   (d)   Veteran’s organizations while engaging in funerals, parades, memorial
services or as honor guards;
   (e)   Use by a private citizen in the protection of his or her life or
property, in situations constituting the legally recognized defense of self-
defense, or defense of one’s property;
   (f)   Use by a private citizen in the protection of the life and property of
another in situations constituting the legally recognized defense of defense of
another’s life or property;
   (g)   The discharge of guns at public or private firing ranges; or
   (h)   Any other person or organization granted special written permission to
fire or shoot a pistol, rifle, shotgun, revolver, gun or pistols loaded with
blanks or other cartridges, by the Chief of Police of the city or by persons
designated by the Chief to act in his or her stead.
(Ord. 4806, approved 3-10-1977)
§ 741.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not less than
$25, nor more than $100, for each offense or imprisoned not more than 30 days
or both.
(Ord. 4806, approved 3-10-1977)
ARTICLE 745: CENTER CITY MALL
Section
   
745.01   Definition and boundary.
   
745.02   Compliance.
   
745.03   Activities use permit and fee.
   
745.04   Alcoholic beverages.
   
745.05   Animals.
   
745.06   Bicycles.
   
745.07   Conduct.
   
745.08   Fountains.
   
745.09   Furniture.
   
745.10   Littering.
   
745.11   Mall structure protection.
   
745.12   Posting.
   
745.13   Prohibited uses.
   
745.14   Roller skates, skate boards and the like.
   
745.15   Selling.
   
745.16   Solicitation.
   
745.17   Sound amplification or musical instruments.
   
745.18   Storage.
   
745.19   Street and sidewalk cleaning and maintenance.
   
745.20   Traffic.
   
745.21   Motor vehicles.
   
745.22   Vacant property.
   
745.23   Vandalism.
   
745.24   Vending machines.
   
745.25   Visual demonstrations.
   
745.26   Exceptions to rules and regulations.
   
745.27   Existing ordinances.
   
745.99   Penalty.
§ 745.01 DEFINITION AND BOUNDARY.
   The Center City Mall, herein called “the Mall”, shall be defined and apply
to all the properties and streets bounded by the area described as follows: on
the north by the south side of Little League Boulevard; on the west by the east
side of Hepburn Street from the south side of Little League Boulevard to the
south side of West Third Street, along the south side of West Third Street to
the west side of Government Place; then south on the west side of Government
Place to the west side of William Street and then south to the north side of
Via Bella; on the south by the north side of Via Bella; on the east by the west
side of Market Street from the south side of Little League Boulevard to the
south side of West Willow Street, then to the east side of Market Street, then
south to the north side of East Third Street; then east 145 feet, then south to
the south side of East Third Street; then west 145 feet to the east side of
Market Street and then south on the east side of Market Street to the north
side of Via Bella.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.02 COMPLIANCE.
   All persons using the Mall shall be subject to all rules and regulations
established by the Mayor in addition to those herein set forth.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.03 ACTIVITIES USE PERMIT AND FEE.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety or Director of Public Services as
authorized by the Mayor shall review, schedule and grant final approval to all
activities on the Mall upon payment of a permit fee of $2.
   (b)   The activities which can be conducted upon the Mall are those which
would not interfere with the health, safety and/or welfare of the community,
and which would not be aesthetically or physically detrimental to the Mall, and
which would promote education, community spirit, bring interest to the
districts of the city surrounding the Mall or stimulate any other worthwhile
community enterprise.
   (c)   (1)   All users involved with activities on the Mall shall be
responsible for the cleaning and repairing of the Mall to assure that the Mall
will be returned to its prior condition previous to its use.
      (2)   Failure to comply with this provision shall result in the city
taking such action as is necessary to clean and repair the Mall and restore it
to its prior condition.
      (3)   In such case, the city shall bill the user for its costs of such
repairing or cleaning.
      (4)   This shall not preclude the city from performing normal routine
cleaning and maintenance activities.
   (d)   The city is not responsible for damages, accidents or incidents which
occur with activities on the Mall.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976; Ord. 5015, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 745.04 ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
   No person shall consume alcoholic beverages on the Mall, except by
permission.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.05 ANIMALS.
   No animals are allowed on the Mall unless controlled by leash or unless such
has been specifically authorized.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.06 BICYCLES.
   (a)   Bicycles shall be ridden in the street and not on the sidewalk at any
time. They may, however, be walked on the sidewalk area, providing that
bicycles are prohibited from being ridden on Pine Street between Fourth and
Church Streets.
   (b)   Bicycles shall be parked in the bicycle racks if such are provided.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.07 CONDUCT.
   Intoxication, indecent language and/or disorderly conduct are prohibited.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.08 FOUNTAINS.
   No person shall wade, swim or place any liquids or solid objects in any
fountain located on the Mall.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.09 FURNITURE.
   (a)   No permanent installation of any type shall be permitted on the Mall.
All tables, chairs or other furniture shall be removed within one hour of the
closing of store hours unless granted permission.
   (b)   Tables, chairs or other furniture shall not be placed on the Mall
prior to 9:00 a.m. to allow for Mall cleaning unless granted permission.
   (c)   Tables or other furniture shall be manned at all times (i.e., no
unmanned tables for distribution of literature).
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.10 LITTERING.
   All refuse, rubbish and litter shall be placed in receptacles provided for
that purpose.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.11 MALL STRUCTURE PROTECTION.
   Any exterior repair, rehabilitation, preventive maintenance and/or
renovations, that takes place on any building fronting the Mall shall be
reviewed by the Director of Public Safety or Director of Public Services to
assure adequate protection to the Mall.
(Ord. 5015, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 745.12 POSTING.
   No person shall post bills, advertisements, signs and the like, except by
permission.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.13 PROHIBITED USES.
   No person shall engage in any of the following activities upon the Mall
unless such activity has been specifically authorized by the Department of
Public Safety or Department of Public Services:
   (a)   Display of merchandise upon any area of the Mall;
   (b)   Streets sales of flowers, souvenirs or other merchandise; and
   (c)   Any other commercial activity not specifically authorized.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976; Ord. 5015, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 745.14 ROLLER SKATES, SKATEBOARDS AND THE LIKE.
   No person shall roller skate, ride on a skateboard or operate any device
having metal wheels.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.15 SELLING.
   No person shall use the Mall as a stand from which to sell, or expose for
sale, goods or other things, without permission. The city may impose such fees,
insurances and other requirements as it deems reasonable and necessary to
protect the public health, safety and general welfare.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.16 SOLICITATION.
   No person shall solicit funds or seek contributions for any purpose
whatsoever upon the Mall, except when the activity has been specifically
authorized by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 5015, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 745.17 SOUND AMPLIFICATION OR MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS.
   No person shall use any sound amplification other than those of a personal
nature or engage in the playing of musical instruments upon the Mall unless
such use has been specifically authorized. The term SOUND AMPLIFICATION
EQUIPMENT includes radios, tape recorders, phonographs and similar electronic
devices.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.18 STORAGE.
   No person shall store items, material, stock, etc. anywhere on or in the
Mall sidewalks, laybys and the like, except on approval.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.19 STREET AND SIDEWALK CLEANING AND MAINTENANCE.
   (a)   Sweeping of streets will be done by the city.
   (b)   Sidewalks, recessed store entrances, foyers or other areas within the
building lines shall at all times remain the responsibility of the tenants or
owners who shall maintain them. SIDEWALKS on Pine Street between Fourth and
Church Streets means that area eight feet in width from the building line
extending into Pine Street.
   (c)   The sweeping of refuse or other litter onto the Mall, dumping of
refuse or otherwise littering on the Mall, or in anyway impeding the
maintenance of the Mall in a clean and orderly fashion is prohibited.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.20 TRAFFIC.
   The Mayor, or his or her designee, shall have the authority to discontinue
traffic on the Mall to accommodate special activities, events or other
purposes.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.21 MOTOR VEHICLES.
   No motor vehicles, except emergency vehicles and city maintenance vehicles
are allowed on Pine Street between Fourth and Church Streets at any time,
except by permission of the Police Department. This prohibition shall not apply
to eastbound vehicles on West Third Street, crossing Pine Street at the
intersection of Pine and West Third Streets.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.22 VACANT PROPERTY.
   (a)   Owners of vacant property shall adhere to §
745.19.
   (b)   Owners of vacant property are encouraged to decorate windows in an
attractive manner or make them available for display purposes to the city, for
promotion of the Mall, for non-profit organizations and activities or for
manufacturing displays.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.23 VANDALISM.
   Cutting, mutilating, removing or the taking away of trees, shrubs and
flowers or the removal, defacing or damaging of property is prohibited.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.24 VENDING MACHINES.
   No vending machines or coin-operated amusement devices shall be placed upon
the Mall without special permission.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.25 VISUAL DEMONSTRATIONS.
   All movies, slide shows or any other visual demonstration, except for
designated areas or by special permission, shall have all equipment off the
sidewalk, and within the building lines.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.26 EXCEPTIONS TO RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   “By permission”, “as authorized” or “approved by” allows the Mayor or his or
her designee to make temporary exceptions to the restrictions of the rules and
regulations when appropriate, but not to exceed 60 calendar days. In all cases,
the exceptions shall be controlled by a permit procedure established by the
Department of Public Safety or Department of Public Services.
(Ord. 5015, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 745.27 EXISTING ORDINANCES.
   All applicable city ordinances now in effect apply to the Mall unless such
ordinance is superseded by one of the aforementioned rules and regulations.
(Ord. 4783, approved 12-6-1976)
§ 745.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be fined not more
than $600 or imprisoned not more than 90 days or both.
(Ord. 5444, approved 11-9-1989)
ARTICLE 747: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
Section
   
747.01   Open container possession or consumption.
   
747.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Consumption on Center City Mall, see Part Seven, §
745.04
Statutory reference:
   Liquor Code, see 47 P.S. §§ 1-101 et seq.
   Minors purchasing, consuming or possessing intoxicants, see 18 Pa.C.S. §
6308
§ 747.01 OPEN CONTAINER POSSESSION OR CONSUMPTION.
   (a)   No person shall transport or possess on his or her person or in a
motor vehicle any beer, wine or alcoholic beverage in an open container in or
upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys or public ways of the city, nor in or upon
the parking areas of private shopping centers under the jurisdiction of the
Bureau of Police, except as hereinafter provided.
   (b)   No person shall consume or possess beer, wine or alcoholic beverages
in an open container in or upon the property of another unless that person is a
guest, licensee or invitee of the owner or occupier of the property.
(Ord. 5085, approved 11-20-1980)
§ 747.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be
fined not more than $600 or imprisoned not more than 30 days.
(Ord. 5445, approved 11-9-1989)
ARTICLE 749: BOTTLE CLUBS
Section
   
749.01   Findings of Council.
   
749.02   Definition.
   
749.03   Prohibited acts.
   
749.04   Severability.
   
749.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Open containers, see Part Seven, §
747.01
Statutory reference:
   Liquor Control Code, see 47 P.S. §§ 1-101 et seq.
§ 749.01 FINDINGS OF COUNCIL.
   Council hereby determines that the consumption of alcoholic beverages
between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. on business premises not
licensed by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board creates
conditions which disrupt the peaceable living conditions of the neighborhood in
which such activities are conducted; and it further finds that the permitting
of minors to frequent such business premises is not in the best interest of the
public health, welfare and safety of the community.
(Ord. 5551, approved 3-5-1992)
§ 749.02 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definition apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BOTTLE CLUB. Business premises used primarily for social, entertainment, the
selling of food and beverages or other similar activities for profit. Business
premises shall not include any premises owned, operated, leased or controlled
by a religious organization and/or organization exempt under § 501(c)(3) of the
Internal Revenue Code.
(Ord. 5551, approved 3-5-1992)
§ 749.03 PROHIBITED ACTS.
   (a)   No person or persons shall allow in a bottle club the storage by
others of alcoholic beverages, as defined in the Pennsylvania Liquor Control
Code, whether or not such club is owned, operated, leased or controlled by him,
her or them, which are not licensed by the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board,
or consumption by anyone of such alcoholic beverages in such club between the
hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. prevailing time of each day or to allow
on such business premises any person or persons to consume alcoholic beverages
on such premises, whether or not stored in such clubs between the hours of 12:
00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. prevailing time of each day.
   (b)   No person or persons shall be present in bottle clubs in which
alcoholic beverages are stored or consumed in violation of this article,
between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. prevailing time of each day.
   (c)   No owner, operator, lessor and/or controller of any such clubs or
their servants, agents or employees shall permit minors to frequent the bottle
club or any premises operated in connection therewith, except minors
accompanied by parents, guardians or other proper supervision or except minors
who frequent any restaurant where sales of food and non-alcoholic beverages are
the primary business conducted thereon, on the condition that alcoholic
beverages may not be consumed at the table or booth at which the minor is under
proper supervision as hereinafter provided; provided, however, that, it shall
not be unlawful for any such bottle club to permit minors under proper
supervision upon such premises or any premises operated in connection therewith
for the purpose of social gathering even if such gathering is exclusively for
minors; provided further that, no liquor shall be sold, furnished or given to
such minors nor consumed by such minors, nor shall clubs’ operators, servants,
agents or employees knowingly permit any liquor or malt beverages to be sold,
furnished or given to be consumed by any minor, and the area of such gathering
shall be segregated from the remainder of the bottle club, all alcoholic
beverages shall be either removed from such club or placed under lock and key
during the time the gathering is taking place.
   (d)   PROPER SUPERVISION, as used in this clause, means the presence on that
portion of such premises where a minor or minors are present or one person 25
years of age or older for each 50 minors or part thereof who is directly
responsible for the care and conduct of such minor or minors while on such
premises and in such proximity that the minor or minors are constantly within
the sight and hearing. The presence of the proprietor, operators or any
employee or security officer of the proprietor or operator shall not constitute
proper supervision.
   (e)   Each day activities prescribed by this article are engaged in or
conducted shall constitute a separate offense.
   (f)   In the event any of the aforesaid activity is conducted by or in the
name of a corporation, partnership, joint venture, trust, firm or association
and/or the premises in which such activities are conducted are owned or leased
by a corporation, partnership, joint venture, trust, firm or association of the
officers, partners or agents of the corporation, partnership, joint venture,
trust, firm or association, shall be deemed in violation of this article, as
well as the person or persons engaged in the prohibited activity set forth in
this article.
(Ord. 5551, approved 3-5-1992)
§ 749.04 SEVERABILITY.
   (a)   The provisions of this article are severable. If any sentence, clause
or section of this article is, for any reason, found to be unconstitutional,
illegal or invalid, such unconstitutionality, illegality or invalidity shall
not affect or impair any of the remaining provisions, sentences, clauses or
sections of this article. It is hereby declared that this article would have
been adopted had such unconstitutional, illegal or invalid sentence, clause or
section not been included therein.
   (b)   All ordinances or parts of ordinances inconsistent with this article
are hereby repealed so far as they may be inconsistent herewith.
(Ord. 5551, approved 3-5-1992)
§ 749.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates this article shall be guilty of a summary offense and
shall, upon conviction of same, be sentenced to a fine not exceeding $600 and/
or to imprisonment not exceeding 90 days.
(Ord. 5551, approved 3-5-1992)
ARTICLE 751: SPRAY PAINT AND INDELIBLE MARKERS
Section
   
751.01   Definitions and interpretation.
   
751.02   Prohibited conduct.
   
751.03   Parental liability.
   
751.99   Penalty.
§ 751.01 DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATION.
   The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article shall have
the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning. When not inconsistent with the context, words
used in the present tense include the future; words in the plural number
include the singular number; words in the singular shall include the plural,
and words in the masculine shall include the feminine and neuter.
   ETCHING EQUIPMENT OR MATERIALS. Any tool, device, equipment or substance
that can be used to make permanent marks on metal, glass, plastic, concrete or
stone.
   INDELIBLE MARKER. Any marker containing a fluid which is not water soluble
and which has a point, brush, applicator or other writing surface of three-
eights of an inch or greater.
   MINOR. A person under 18 years of age.
   PERSON. Any individual, partnership, corporation, trust, association, owner,
contractor, salesperson or any other legal entity.
(Ord. 5687, approved 5-23-1996)
§ 751.02 PROHIBITED CONDUCT.
   (a)   No person shall sell at retail to any minor paint in spray cans or any
marker containing a fluid which is not water soluble and which has a point,
brush, applicator or other writing surface of three-eights of an inch or
greater. For purposes of this section, to SELL AT RETAIL means to sell to a
consumer for ultimate use, and not for purposes of resale.
   (b)   No person shall possess a spray paint container, liquid paint or
indelible marker on the property of another or in any public building or upon
any public facility, unless the owner, manager or other person having control
of the property, building or facility consented to the presence of the
materials.
   (c)   No person shall possess a spray paint container, liquid paint,
indelible marker or etching equipment or materials on any public right-of-way
(including, without limitation, any street or sidewalk) with intent to use the
same to deface any building, structure or property.
   (d)   No minor shall possess any spray paint container or indelible marker,
except:
      (1)   A minor may possess spray paint containers or indelible markers
while under the immediate supervision of his or her parent, legal guardian or
teacher; and/or
      (2)   A minor employee may possess spray paint containers or indelible
markers at the direction and under the supervision of his or her employer.
   (e)   No person shall aid, assist or abet a minor in obtaining spray paint
cans or indelible markers in violations of subsection (d) above.
   (f)   No person shall intentionally deface or otherwise damage tangible
public property or tangible property of another with an aerosol spray paint
can, broad-tipped indelible marker or similar marking device (including, but
not limited to, crayons or chalk).
(Ord. 5687, approved 5-23-1996)
§ 751.03 PARENTAL LIABILITY.
   Pursuant to 23 Pa.C.S. Ch. 55 of the Judicial Code, the Court, in any
proceeding against a minor, shall ascertain the amount sufficient to fully
reimburse any owner of property who has suffered injury because of the tortious
act of the minor and direct the parents to make payments in an amount not to
exceed the limitations set forth in 23 Pa.C.S. § 5505 of the Judicial Code.
(Ord. 5687, approved 5-23-1996)
§ 751.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall, for a first offense,
be fined $100 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both; and, for a second
offense, be fined $200 or imprisoned not more than 60 days, or both; for any
third offense, be fined $300 or imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both; for
any subsequent offense, be fined $600 or imprisoned for not more than 90 days,
or both. In addition, such person, upon conviction, shall be liable for
restitution and performance of community service as determined by the court.
(Ord. 5687, approved 5-23-1996)
ARTICLE 753: CURFEW
Section
   
753.01   Title.
   
753.02   Legislative intent.
   
753.03   Definitions.
   
753.04   Unlawful conduct of minors.
   
753.05   Unlawful conduct of parent or guardian.
   
753.06   Unlawful conduct of establishment operator.
   
753.07   Penalties.
   
753.08   Police procedure.
   
753.09   Exceptions.
   
753.10   Annual review.
§ 753.01 TITLE.
   This article shall be known as the “City of Williamsport Curfew Ordinance”.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.02 LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   The City of Williamsport recognizes that there is a health, safety and
welfare concern relating to crimes committed by and committed against minors
during nighttime hours; and believes that this problem can be dealt with more
effectively by regulating the hours during which minors may remain in public
places and certain establishments without adult supervision; and by defining
more clearly certain duties and responsibilities upon those who have the
custody and responsibility for care of such minors. Therefore, the City of
Williamsport hereby enacts this article to enhance the health, safety and
welfare of minors within the City of Williamsport, whose youth and inexperience
renders them particularly vulnerable to becoming participants in criminal
activity and in being victimized by perpetrators of crime, to foster and
strengthen parental responsibility for such minors, and to protect and promote
the welfare of the general public through reduction of juvenile crime and
violence within the City of Williamsport.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases and words shall
have the meaning given herein.
   CITY. The City of Williamsport, Lycoming County, Pennsylvania.
   ESTABLISHMENT. Any privately owned place of business operated for profit to
which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any place of
amusement or entertainment.
   MINOR. Any person under the age of 18.
   OPERATOR. Any individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation
operating, managing or conducting any establishment. The term includes the
members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of the
corporation.
   PARENT. Any person having legal custody of a minor as a natural or adoptive
parent or as a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of court.
   PUBLIC PLACE. Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the
public has access and includes, but is not limited to, the common areas of
schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities
and shops.
   REMAIN. To linger or unnecessarily stay or fail to leave premises when
requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator or other person
in control of the premises.
   STREETS.
      (1)   A way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to use by the public as
a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel, or in the case of a
sidewalk thereof, for pedestrian travel.
      (2)   This includes the legal right-of-way, including, but not limited
to, the cartway or traffic lanes, the curb, the sidewalks, whether paved or
unpaved, and any grass plots or other grounds found within the legal right-of-
way of a street.
      (3)   The term STREET applies irrespective of what it is called or
formally named, whether alley, avenue, court, road or otherwise.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.04 UNLAWFUL CONDUCT OF MINORS.
   No minor shall be or remain upon any public place, street or any
establishment between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., unless such minor
is accompanied by a parent, guardian or a person who stands in loco parentis,
subject to the exceptions specified in § 753.09 of this article.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.05 UNLAWFUL CONDUCT OF PARENT OR GUARDIAN.
   No parent, guardian or custodian of a minor shall allow or permit said minor
to remain in or upon any public place, street or any establishment in violation
of §
753.04 of this article.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.06 UNLAWFUL CONDUCT OF ESTABLISHMENT OPERATOR.
   No operator of an establishment, firm or corporation, or in charge of any
place of amusement, entertainment or refreshment, or other place of business,
shall allow or permit any minor to remain in or upon any public place or
establishment in violation of §
753.04 of this article.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.07 PENALTIES.
   (a)   Any minor who violates §
753.04 of this article, and any parent or guardian who violates §
753.05 of this article, is guilty of a summary offense and, upon conviction,
shall be sentenced to pay a fine and other action as follows:
      (1)   First offense: up to $25;
      (2)   Second offense: up to $50; and
      (3)   Third or subsequent offense: up to $300. Minors are subject to
referral to the juvenile court system or Lycoming County Children and Youth
Services.
   (b)   Any operator who violates §
753.06 of this article is guilty of a summary offense and, upon conviction,
shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than $50, nor more than $1,000,
for each minor present in violation this article.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.08 POLICE PROCEDURE.
   (a)   Every police officer while on duty upon finding or having attention
called to any minor upon a public place, street or establishment in prima facie
violation of this article is hereby authorized to detain said minor.
   (b)   Upon determination of a violation, a minor in possession of valid
photo identification or for whom a parent or guardian has verified the minor’s
name, date of birth and address may be issued a summary citation. The minor may
be released from the scene of detention either into the custody of a parent or
guardian or to return directly home.
   (c)   A minor so detained for whom no identification can be verified may be
taken into custody and transported to police headquarters. Once identified,
said minor may be issued a summary citation and released to a parent, guardian
or responsible adult. If no one can be contacted to take custody of said minor,
the police officer shall contact Lycoming County Children and Youth Services
for placement of said minor.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.09 EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to any minor who is
engaged in gainful, lawful employment during the curfew hours or who is
traveling to or from such employment.
   (b)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to any minor who is on
active duty in the United States Armed Forces.
   (c)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to any minor who is
attending any scheduled school, artistic, civic, cultural, educational,
religious or sporting event.
   (d)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to a minor who is
returning home from by a direct route and within 30 minutes of the termination
of any event mentioned in subsection (c) above.
   (e)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to a minor who is
married or emancipated by state law.
   (f)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to a minor who is on
the sidewalk of the place where the minor resides or on the sidewalk abutting
the minor’s residence.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
§ 753.10 ANNUAL REVIEW.
   This article and the need for it shall be reviewed annually. By October 31
of each year, the Mayor and/or the Police Chief of the City of Williamsport
shall review this article and report and make recommendations to the
Williamsport City Council concerning the effectiveness of and the continuing
need for this article. This report shall include the following information:
   (a)   The practicality of enforcing this article and any problems with
enforcement identified by the Williamsport Bureau of Police;
   (b)   The impact of this article on juvenile crime;
   (c)   The number of citations issued to minors;
   (d)   The number of minors referred to the juvenile court system and
Lycoming County Children and Youth Services; and
   (e)   The number of official complaints filed regarding the enforcement of
this article and the disposition and/or resolution of any such complaints.
(Ord. 6002, approved 9-15-2005)
ARTICLE 755: FEEDING OF DEER
Section
   
755.01   Title.
   
755.02   Purpose.
   
755.03   Applicability.
   
755.04   Enforcement.
   
755.05   Violations and penalties.
§ 755.01 TITLE.
   This article shall be known as the “Williamsport Deer Feeding Ordinance”.
(Ord. 6093, approved 12-20-2007)
§ 755.02 PURPOSE.
   White-tailed deer (Odocoileus Virginianus) are entering the City of
Williamsport, causing danger to pedestrians, bicycle and street traffic as well
as damaging hillside and neighborhood vegetation in private and public areas.
The provision of supplemental food for the deer in private yards attracts the
deer and causes their overfeeding. Attracting deer in this manner is seen as a
health and safety hazard for the environment and affects storm water runoff.
(Ord. 6093, approved 12-20-2007)
§ 755.03 APPLICABILITY.
   (a)   Persons or businesses who purposely or knowingly feed or supply salt,
corn or other food to white-tailed deer on land either publicly or privately
owned or who otherwise cause deer to congregate or habituate an area shall be
subject to the penalty this article provides.
   (b)   Nothing in this article shall affect state, county or regional deer
management plans or anyone possessing a special deer management permit that has
been issued by any governmental agency.
(Ord. 6093, approved 12-20-2007)
§ 755.04 ENFORCEMENT.
   The Williamsport Bureau of Codes will be responsible for enforcing this
article.
(Ord. 6093, approved 12-20-2007)
§ 755.05 VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   If otherwise lawful feeding is attracting deer to congregate or habituate,
the Bureau of Codes may provide written notice to the property owner
prohibiting such activity. After said written notice, any person who violates
any of the provisions of this article shall, upon first summary conviction
thereof, be punishable by a minimum fine of up to $100. Each violation of any
of the provisions of this article shall be deemed to be a separate and distinct
offense. When a second and or subsequent violations are committed by the same
person or entity within any 12-month period, the fine shall be double the
amount of the previous fine up to a maximum of $1,000 for each separate and
distinct offense.
(Ord. 6093, approved 12-20-2007)
ARTICLE 757: SYNTHETIC CANNABIS AND OTHER SYNTHETIC DRUGS
Section
   
757.01   Control and prohibition of synthetic cannabis and other synthetic
drugs.
   
757.02   Unlawful activity.
   
757.03   Penalties.
   
757.04   Effective date.
§ 757.01 CONTROL AND PROHIBITION OF SYNTHETIC CANNABIS AND OTHER SYNTHETIC
DRUGS.
   The following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context
clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended.
   DELIVER or DELIVERY. Actual, constructive or attempted transfer of
possession of synthetic cannabis and synthetic drugs, with or without
consideration, whether or not there is an agency relationship.
   KNOWLEDGE. Knows, acts knowingly or with knowledge:
      (1)   The nature or attendant circumstances of his or her conduct,
described by the section defining the offense, when he or she is consciously
aware that his or her conduct is of such nature or that such circumstances
exist. KNOWLEDGE of a material fact includes awareness of the substantial
probability that such fact exists;
      (2)   The results of his or her conduct, described by the section
defining the offense, when he or she is consciously aware that such result is
likely to be caused by his or her conduct; and
      (3)   Knowledge may be inferred from the surrounding circumstances.
   MANUFACTURE. The production, preparation, propagation, compounding,
conversion or processing of synthetic cannabis or synthetic drugs, either
directly or indirectly, by extraction from substances of natural origin, or
independently by means of chemical synthesis, and includes any packaging or
repackaging of synthetic cannabis or synthetic drugs or labeling of its
container; except that, this term does not include the preparation,
compounding, packaging or labeling of synthetic cannabis or synthetic drugs as
an incident to lawful research, teaching or chemical analysis and not for sale.
   METHYLENEDIOXYPYROVALERONE (MDPV). A psychoactive drug with stimulant
properties which acts as a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI).
Reportedly, it has been sold since around 2004 as a research chemical. It is
also known as MDPK, Magic, Super Coke and PV. In 2010, it was reportedly sold
as a legal drug alternative and marketed in the United States as “bath salts”
(under such names as Cloud 9, Ivory Wave, Ocean, Charge Plus, White Lightning,
Scarface, Hurricane Charlie, Vanella Sky, Bonzai Grow, Blue Silk, Serenity Now,
Lovey Dovey, Euphoria, Aura, Red Dove and White Dove), 2C-E (2,5-dimethoxy-4-
ethylphenethylamine), sometimes known as “Europa”, is a phenethylamine of the
2C family and a psychedelic. Forms of 2C-E include colorless oil, clear gelatin
capsules containing coarse white powder, fine white powder, grayish powder or
white crystalline powder.
   PERSON. Any individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust,
partnership or association or any other entity.
   POSSESSION. Possession may be either actual or constructive:
      (1)   Actual possession means exercising physical dominion; and
      (2)   Constructive possession may be inferred if the defendant has intent
and capacity to maintain control and dominion over the cannabis, synthetic drug
or drug paraphernalia.
   PRODUCE or PRODUCTION. Manufacture, creation, planting, cultivating, tending
or harvesting.
   SYNTHETIC CANNABIS. Includes the brand names K2 and Spice. It is an herbal
and chemical product which mimics the effects of Cannabis including, but not
limited to, synthetic cannabinoids, cannabicyclohexanol, JWH-018, JWH-073, JWH-
200, HU-210, CP-47, 497, CP 55 and 2 12-2.
(Ord. 6189, approved 5-26-2011)
§ 757.02 UNLAWFUL ACTIVITY.
   (a)   It is unlawful for any person(s), as defined above, knowingly, or
under circumstances where one reasonably should know to sell, lend, rent,
lease, give, exchange or otherwise distribute to any persons or corporation any
product containing the following chemicals: JWH-018; JWH-073; JWH-200; CP-47;
497; Cannabicyclohexanol; CP 55; 490; HU-210; 2C-E; or
Methylenedioxypyrovalerone and marketed as products known as, but not limited
to, Cloud 9, Ivory Wave, Ocean, Charge Plus, White Lightning, Scarface,
Hurricane Charlie, Vanella Sky, Bonzai Grow, Blue Silk, Serenity Now, Lovey
Dovey, Euphoria, Aura, Red Dove and White Dove, spice, K-Blaze and Red X Dawn,
but not limited to incense, potpourri, plant fertilizers, insect repellant or
bath salts.
   (b)   It is unlawful for any person(s), as defined above, knowingly, or
under any circum stances where one reasonably should know, to display for sale
or possess with intent to distribute any product containing the following
chemicals: JWH-018; JWH-073; JWH-200; CP-47; 497; 2C-E; Cannabicyclohexanol; or
Methylenedioxypyrovalerone and marketed as products known as, but not limited
to, Cloud 9, Ivory Wave, Ocean, Charge Plus, White Lightning, Scarface,
Hurricane Charlie, Red Dove and White Dove, spice, K-2, Blaze and Red X Dawn,
but not limited to, incense, potpourri, plant fertilizers, insect repellant or
bath salts.
   (c)   It is unlawful for any person(s), as defined above, or use, or to
possess with intent to use, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the
human body any product containing the following chemicals: JWH-018; JWH-073;
JWH-200; CP-47; 497; 2C-E; Cannabicyclohexanol; or Methylenedioxypyrovalerone
and marketed as products known as, but not limited to, Cloud 9, Ivory Wave,
Ocean, Charge Plus, White Lightning, Scarface, Hurricane Charlie, Red Dove and
White Dove, spice, K-2, Blaze and Red X Dawn, but not limited to, incense,
potpourri, plant fertilizers, insect repellant or bath salts.
   (d)   These above described activities are declared unlawful because the
improper use of and/or ingestion of the product causes unpredictable,
uncontrollable and profound effects on humans and places those who ingest it
and those around them at grave risk of physical harm.
(Ord. 6189, approved 5-26-2011)
§ 757.03 PENALTIES.
   (a)   Violation. A violation of this article shall be prosecuted through the
filling of criminal summary offense charge in the appropriate court.
   (b)   Penalty. Any person who pleads guilty or is found guilty by a court of
law shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1,000 and/or undergo
imprisonment for not more than 30 days.
   (c)   Administrative fee. In addition, any person who violates any provision
of this section and is convicted, pleads guilty, receives court supervision or
probation by a court of law shall be ordered to pay an administrative fee to
the law enforcement agency for testing of the substance(s) collected.
   (d)   Forfeiture. Any items which may be seized or forfeited pursuant to
statutes or guidelines for the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, may be forfeited
in the same manner as described therein for a violation of this section.
(Ord. 6189, approved 5-26-2011)
§ 757.04 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This article shall become effective 20 days after final enactment.
(Ord. 6189, approved 5-26-2011)
