TITLE ONE: STREET AREAS AND SEWERS
ARTICLE 901: STREET EXCAVATIONS
Section
   
901.01   Definitions.
   
901.02   Application for permit.
   
901.03   Permit fees.
   
901.04   Exhibiting permit; enforcement by Director.
   
901.05   Surety bond.
   
901.06   Compliance required.
   
901.07   Excavation guards and lanterns; liability.
   
901.08   Size of opening limited.
   
901.09   Limitations on obstruction of traffic.
   
901.10   Separation of removed material. (repealed)
   
901.11   Excavation, backfilling and restoration.
   
901.12   Emergency action.
   
901.13   Non-completion or abandonment.
   
901.14   Insurance.
   
901.15   Indemnification.
   
901.16   Refusal of permits.
   
901.99   Penalty.
Cross-references:
   Sidewalk construction and curbing, see Part Nine,
Art. 905
Statutory reference:
   Closed streets to have detours, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 12975
(a)(5—7), (b), (c)
   Ordinance to open street, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 12916 et
seq.
   Penalty for removing or disregarding any barricade or detour sign, see 3rd
Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 12975(d) to (f)
   Petition to open street, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 12918 et
seq.
   Power to open streets, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 12915(a), (b)
§ 901.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future; words in
the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number
include the plural number. The word “shall” is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
   APPLICANT. Any person making application to the city for an excavation
permit hereunder.
   CITY. The City of Williamsport.
   CURB CUT. A cut in the area between the sidewalk and the curb, or in the
event there is no curb in place, then a cut in the area between the sidewalk
and the location where the curb would be if in place.
   EXCAVATION WORK. The excavation and other work permitted under an excavation
permit and required to be performed under this article, except such term does
not include curb cut as defined herein.
   PERMITTEE. Any person who has been granted and has in full force and effect
an excavation permit issued hereunder.
   PERSON. Any individual, firm, partnership, association or organization of
any kind.
   STREET. Any street, highway, sidewalk, alley, avenue, lane, areaway or other
public way or ground or public easement in the city.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976; Ord. 4917, approved 8-28-1978)
§ 901.02 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   (a)   No person shall dig up, break, excavate, tunnel, bore, undermine or in
any manner break up any street or make or cause to be made any excavation in or
under the surface of any street, except a state highway, or place, deposit or
leave upon any street, any earth or unexcavated material obstructing or tending
to interfere with the free use of the street unless such person has first
obtained an excavation permit therefor from the city as herein provided.
   (b)   No excavation permit shall be issued unless an application, on forms
provided for that purpose, is submitted to the city. The application shall
state the name and address of the applicant, the nature, location and purpose
of the excavation, the date of commencement and date of completion of the
excavation and other data as may reasonably be required by the city. In the
event extensive excavation and construction is planned, the application shall
be accompanied by plans showing the extent of the proposed excavation work, the
dimensions and elevations of both the existing ground prior to such excavation
and of the proposed elevated surfaces, the location of the excavation work and
such other information as may be prescribed by the city. It is permissible for
applicants to telephone the city to submit permit information to perform
maintenance work on their facilities.
   (c)   Permits for such work on state highways are issued by the District
Office of the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976; Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993)
§ 901.03 PERMIT FEES.
   (a)   Upon approval of the application for the excavation permit, the
applicant shall pay a fee to the city as specified in
Art. 117 of the codified ordinances to cover reasonable costs for the issuance
of the permit and inspection of the excavation and backfilling. Applicants
shall be billed for permit fees on a monthly or annual basis at the discretion
of the city.
   (b)   Upon approval of the application for a curb cut, the applicant shall
pay a fee to the city as specified in
Art. 117 of the codified ordinances to cover reasonable costs for the issuance
of the curb cut permit and inspection of the excavation and backfilling.
Applicants shall be billed for curb cut permit fees on a monthly or annual
basis at the discretion of the city.
(Ord. 5043, approved 5-22-1980; Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993)
§ 901.04 EXHIBITING PERMIT; ENFORCEMENT BY DIRECTOR.
   Every person making or superintending any excavation shall exhibit the
permit to any police officer, or any other authorized representative of the
city, when required to do so. No person shall exhibit such permit at or about
any excavation not covered by such permit or misrepresent the permit number or
the date of expiration. It shall be the duty of any officer to report to the
Director of Public Services the name of any person making any excavation
without a permit, or who is violating or who has violated any of the provisions
of this article. The Director is charged with the duty of enforcing the
provisions of this article.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976)
§ 901.05 SURETY BOND.
   (a)   Before an excavation permit is issued, the applicant shall deposit
with the City Clerk a surety bond in the amount of $5,000 in favor of the city.
Such bond shall be:
      (1)   With good and sufficient surety by a surety company authorized to
do business in the state;
      (2)   Satisfactory to the City Attorney in form and substance;
      (3)   Conditioned that the applicant shall faithfully comply with all the
terms and conditions of this article; all rules, regulations and requirements
pursuant thereto and as required by the city; and all reasonable requirements
of the city; and
      (4)   Conditioned that the applicant shall secure and hold the city and
its officers harmless against any and all claims, judgments or other costs
arising from the excavation permit or for which the city, Council or any city
officer may be made liable by reason of any accident or injury to persons or
property through the fault of the permittee.
   (b)   Recovery on such surety bond for any injury or accident shall not
exhaust the bond, but it shall, in its entirety, cover any or all future
accidents or injuries during the excavation work for which it is given.
   (c)   When any suit or claim against the city involves negligence or default
by the permittee, upon the city giving written notice to the permittee of such
suit or claim, any final judgment against the city requiring it to pay for such
damage shall be conclusive upon the permittee and his or her surety.
   (d)   An annual bond may be given under this provision which shall remain in
force for five years conditioned as above, in the amount specified herein and
in other respects as specified herein, but applicable to all excavation work in
streets by the permittee during the term of five years from such date.
(Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993; Ord. 6245, approved 11-21-2013)
§ 901.06 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   All work done pursuant to an excavation permit issued under the provisions
of this article shall be performed under the direction and to the satisfaction
of the city or its duly authorized agent.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976)
§ 901.07 EXCAVATION GUARDS AND LANTERNS; LIABILITY.
   (a)   Every person whether owner or contractor, excavating or tearing up any
street, lane or alley of the city for any purpose, shall place good and
sufficient guards by day about the excavations and maintain a lighted amber
flasher unit or an approved substitute, from sunset until sunrise, at each end
of the excavation and every intersection of the excavation with any street,
alley or sidewalk, and at such sufficient close intervals elsewhere to give
effectual notice of such excavation.
   (b)   On streets heavily traveled, it shall be mandatory to plate existing
ditch when not present on the job. Streets to be plated shall be determined by
a representative of the Department of Public Services.
   (c)   The issuance of a permit shall not operate to release the holder
thereof from any liability for damages on account of any negligence upon the
part of the permittee or any employees thereof, on or about any excavation
authorized by such permit.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976)
§ 901.08 SIZE OF OPENING LIMITED.
   When excavating in any street, lane or alley for the purpose of laying,
relaying, taking up or repairing any gas, water, sewer or other pipes, mains or
conduits, not more than 100 feet lineal measure shall be opened at one time. No
excavation shall be any larger than to complete the job.
(Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993)
§ 901.09 LIMITATIONS ON OBSTRUCTION OF TRAFFIC.
   (a)   (1)   No portion of any street, lane or alley shall be or remain
impassable for vehicular or pedestrian traffic by reason of any excavation for
more than one week from the beginning of any work on the same. The Bureau of
Fire shall in each case be notified by the permittee at least 24 hours in
advance of the proposed street closing.
      (2)   Any extension of the street closing time without penalty shall
first be approved by the Director of Public Services or his or her authorized
representative.
   (b)   (1)   No portion of any street, lane or alley shall be or remain
impassable for vehicular or pedestrian traffic by reason of any excavation for
repairing mains, conduits or other pipes or appurtenances, or for laying or
relaying, new house connections, for more than two days from the beginning of
any work on same. The Bureau of Fire shall in each case be notified by the
permittee at least 24 hours in advance of proposed street closing.
      (2)   Any extension of the street closing time without penalty shall
first be approved by the Director or his or her authorized representative.
   (c)   (1)   No intersection of the streets, lanes or alleys of the city
shall be or remain impassable for vehicular or pedestrian traffic for more than
five hours, during the work upon any excavation mentioned in this article.
      (2)   Any extension of the street closing time without penalty shall
first be approved by the Director or his or her authorized representative.
   (d)   Maintenance and protection of traffic shall be carried out by the
permittee in accordance with the applicable provisions of the city’s street
restoration requirements and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation
Publication 213 and current supplements, Work Zone Traffic Control.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976; Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993; Ord. 6245,
approved 11-21-2013)
§ 901.10 SEPARATION OF REMOVED MATERIALS.
Editor’s note:
   This section was repealed by Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993.
§ 901.11 EXCAVATION, BACKFILLING AND RESTORATION.
   (a)   General.
      (1)   Any person or firm contemplating an excavation within the public
rights-of-way must first obtain an excavation permit from the city as provided
in this article.
      (2)   Any person or firm to whom a street excavation permit or work
contract has been issued shall notify all utility companies of the intent to
excavate. This notification shall be given not less than 48 hours in advance of
the commencement of the work and shall indicate the time, place and purpose of
the street excavation.
      (3)   Any person or firm to whom a street excavation permit or work
contract has been issued shall have the duty of determining the location and
depth of all existing underground utility installations. If a utility line is
broken or damaged in any way, the permittee or contractor shall immediately
notify the utility owner.
      (4)   All excavation, backfilling and restoration shall be carried out by
the permittee in accordance with the applicable provisions of the city’s street
restoration requirements and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation
Regulations, Occupancy of Highways by Utilities (67 Pa. Code Ch. 459.8 and
current supplements).
   (b)   Pavement restoration guarantee. The contractor shall remedy, at his or
her own expense, any defects that appear in the backfill or restoration for a
period of five years following completion.
   (c)   Restoration of brick paved streets. The restoration of brick paved
streets shall be carried out by the permittee in accordance with
Art. 902.
(Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993; Ord. 6245, approved 11-21-2013)
§ 901.12 EMERGENCY ACTION.
   In the event of any emergency in which a main, conduit or utility facility
in or under any street breaks, bursts or otherwise is in such condition as to
immediately endanger the property, life, health or safety of any individual,
the person owning or controlling such main, conduit or utility facility,
without first applying for and obtaining an excavation permit hereunder, shall
immediately take proper emergency measures to cure or remedy the dangerous
conditions for the protection of property, life, health and safety of
individuals. However, such person owning or controlling such facility shall
apply for an excavation permit not later than the end of the next succeeding
day during which the city office is open for business.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976)
§ 901.13 NON-COMPLETION OR ABANDONMENT.
   Work shall progress in an expeditious manner until completion in order to
avoid unnecessary inconvenience to the general public. In the event that the
work is not performed in accordance with the applicable regulations of the
Department of Public Service, or in accordance with the provisions of this
article, or ceases or is abandoned without due cause, the city may, after six
hours’ notice in writing to the holder of the permit of intent to do so,
correct such work or fill the excavation and repair the street, and in any such
event the entire cost to the city for such work shall be a liability of and
shall be paid by the person to whom the permit was issued and his or her
surety.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976)
§ 901.14 INSURANCE.
   A permittee, prior to the commencement of excavation work, shall furnish the
city satisfactory evidence in writing that the permittee has in force and will
maintain in force during the performance of the excavation work and the period
of the excavation permit, commercial general liability insurance of not less
than $500,000 each occurrence and $1,000,000 annual aggregate, duly issued by
an insurance company authorized to do business in the state and on which policy
the city is named as a co-insured.
(Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993)
§ 901.15 INDEMNIFICATION.
   The permittee shall indemnify, keep and hold the city free and harmless from
liability on account of injury or damage to persons or property arising or
growing out of the permittee’s negligence in making any street excavation. In
the event that suit is brought against the city, either independently or
jointly with the permittee on account thereof, the permittee, upon notice to it
by the city, shall defend the city in any suit at the cost of the permittee
and, in the event of a final judgment being obtained against the city, either
independently or jointly with the permittee, the permittee shall pay such
judgment with all costs and hold the city harmless therefrom.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976)
§ 901.16 REFUSAL OF PERMITS.
   If any person fails, refuses or neglects to comply with the provisions of
this article, or any rules or regulations, or any reasonable order or direction
of the city representative in reference thereto, the Director of Public
Services or his or her authorized agent, may take any one or a combination of
the following actions in reference to such contractor:
   (a)   Deny such contractor the privilege of making additional street cuts
for a period of two years until such work and restoration has been done in
accordance with specifications and to the satisfaction of the Department of
Public Services; or
   (b)   The Director may restore the street in accordance with specifications
and cause the contractor to be charged and held responsible for the cost of the
same.
(Ord. 4749, approved 5-6-1976)
§ 901.99 PENALTY.
   In addition to any remedies existing at law or in equity, whoever violates
any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than
$500, nor more than $1,000, or imprisoned not more than 90 days or both, for
each and every violation. Each day a violation continues shall be deemed a
separate violation.
(Ord. 5587, approved 6-10-1993; Ord. 6245, approved 11-21-2013)
ARTICLE 902: PRESERVATION OF BRICK PAVED STREETS
Section
   
902.01   Streets to be preserved.
   
902.02   Maintenance and repair.
   
902.03   Excavations.
   
902.04   Brick streets as line item in budget.
   
902.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Street Excavations, see Title Nine,
Art. 901
§ 902.01 STREETS TO BE PRESERVED.
   The following portions of city streets shall be preserved as brick paved
streets:
Beeber Street, Oliver Street and West Fourth Street intersection
Brandon Place between Franklin Street and St. Boniface Street
Campbell Street from First Street south to Bethlehem Street
Court Street between Sixth Street and a point 50 feet south of the southern
right-of-way line of DuBois Street
Dubois Street between Laurel Street and Market Street
Fifth Avenue between Park Avenue and Rural Avenue
First Street between Campbell Street and Walnut Street
Harris Place between Hepburn Street and Market Street
Laurel Street between Sixth Street and Dubois Street
Rural Avenue between Campbell Street and Fifth Avenue
Trinity Place between Nichols Place and West Fourth Street including the 36
feet by 26 feet new brick pattern with modified curbing adjacent to West Fourth
Street
Wayne Avenue between West Fourth Street and Hillside Avenue
 
(Ord. 5501, approved 11-8-1990; Ord. 5570, approved 9-24-1992; Ord. 5574,
approved 12-21-1992; Ord. 5966, approved 9-2-2004; Ord. 6233, approved 5-16-
2013; Ord. 6375, approved 10-10-2019)
§ 902.02 MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR.
   All future restoration, maintenance and repair of such portions of streets
shall be in such manner as to preserve the streets’ brick paving.
(Ord. 5501, approved 11-8-1990; Ord. 5570, approved 9-24-1992)
§ 902.03 EXCAVATIONS.
   In the event any excavations or cuts are required to be made in such
streets, all such work shall be made pursuant to
Art. 901 except as follows.
   (a)   The restoration of the excavation or cut shall be with brick paving,
so as to match the size and color as closely as possible to the existing brick.
The brick to be used for replacement shall be approved by the Manager of
Contracts/Public Services or by the City Engineer.
   (b)   The restoration shall be completed within one year of such cut or
excavation and such person or entity shall be responsible for any defects that
appear in the hardfill or restoration for a period of two years following
completion.
   (c)   All work performed shall be inspected by the Department of Streets and
Parks.
(Ord. 5501, approved 11-8-1990; Ord. 5570, approved9-24-1992; Ord. 5806,
approved 4-6-2000; Ord. 5966, approved 9-2-2004)
§ 902.04 BRICK STREETS AS LINE ITEM IN BUDGET.
   Beginning in 2006, the Six-Year Capital Projects Budget shall include a line
item “Brick Streets” under “Public Services, Street Improvements”, which shall
be addressed each year in preparing the annual budget.
(Ord. 5989, approved 6-23-2005)
§ 902.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be fined not more
than $600 or imprisoned not more than 90 days or both.
(Ord. 5806, approved 4-6-2000)
ARTICLE 903: UTILITY POLES AND WIRES
Section
   
903.01   License and fee.
   
903.02   Specifications for erection of poles.
   
903.03   Removal of poles by owner.
   
903.04   Removal of poles by city.
   
903.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Mercantile tax on utility companies, see Title Three, §
333.16
Statutory reference:
   Power to require underground electric wires - see 3rd Class City Code, 11
Pa.C.S. § 12445(b)
§ 903.01 LICENSE AND FEE.
   No utility pole or guy wire shall be erected, replaced or relocated unless a
license has first been obtained from the engineering department. Every licensee
shall pay for each permit, the fee as specified in
Art. 117 of the codified ordinances.
(Ord. 5352, approved 5-28-1987)
§ 903.02 SPECIFICATIONS FOR ERECTION OF POLES.
   (a)   The location, construction, erection, maintenance and repair of
telegraph, telephone, electric light poles, wires, guy wires, power wires,
conduits and electrical equipment, now erected and constructed, and hereafter
to be located, erected and constructed in, or affecting the streets, lanes,
alleys and public places of the city, shall in all respects be governed by and
conform to the rules, regulations and specifications provided for in Circular
of the Bureau of Standards, No. 54, National Electrical Safety Code, issued by
the U.S. Department of Commerce. These rules, regulations and specifications
are adopted and approved as the standard for the government of the location,
erection, construction, maintenance and repair of poles, wires, conduits and
equipment now erected, and to be erected in, or affecting the streets, lanes,
alleys, highways and public places of the city.
   (b)   The Engineering Department shall cause to be furnished to all persons
affected by the terms of this section, copies of the aforesaid rules and
regulations.
(Ord. 314, approved 5-13-1918; Ord. 5016, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 903.03 REMOVAL OF POLES BY OWNER.
   When any person, owning telephone, telegraph, electric light or other poles,
within the city, removes the wires from the poles for the purpose of placing
them underground, or for any cause, removes the wires and discontinues the
actual use of the poles, or where such wires have already been removed, then
the poles shall be immediately removed by the person owning them. The poles
from which such wires have been removed or are intended to be removed shall not
be leased, transferred, sold or assigned to any other person without the prior
consent of Council.
(Ord. 376, approved 7-14-1919)
§ 903.04 REMOVAL OF POLES BY CITY.
   In the event of the failure of a person to remove poles referred to in §
903.03 within ten days, the poles may be removed by the city, and the cost and
expense of such removal shall be collected from the person owning them. In the
event of the removal of the poles by the city, they shall be delivered to such
point within the city as the owner may designate. If the owner fails to
designate such point, then the poles shall be hauled to the property of the
owner.
(Ord. 376, approved 7-14-1919)
§ 903.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not more than
$25.
(Ord. 376, approved 7-14-1919)
ARTICLE 905: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND CURBING
Section
   
905.01   Permit required.
   
905.02   Permit application.
   
905.03   Permit fee.
   
905.04   Permit conditions.
   
905.05   Compliance with specifications.
   
905.06   Non-liability of city.
   
905.07   Line and grade differentials.
   
905.08   Deposit of construction materials.
   
905.99   Penalty.
Statutory reference:
   Emergency repairs, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. § 13003
   Power to compel construction of sidewalks, see 3rd Class City Code, 11
Pa.C.S. § 13001
§ 905.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall construct curbing or a sidewalk or a driveway in any public
street in the city without first obtaining a permit from the Engineering
Department. The permit shall be good for a period of four months from the date
of issuance and is valid only to construct a curb and/or sidewalk pursuant to
line and grade which shall be supplied by the Engineering Department.
(Ord. 5017, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 905.02 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   The application for permit shall contain a statement showing the location of
the proposed curbing or sidewalk or driveway and separate permits shall be
obtained for each piece of property involved.
(Ord. 2829, approved 9-1-1960)
§ 905.03 PERMIT FEE.
   The fee for the issuance of sidewalk, driveway or curb permits shall be as
specified in
Art. 117 of the codified ordinances.
§ 905.04 PERMIT CONDITIONS.
   Any person for and in consideration of the issuance of a permit under this
article agrees to be legally bound by the conditions set forth on the reverse
side of the permit and the conditions are incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 2829, approved 9-1-1960)
§ 905.05 COMPLIANCE WITH SPECIFICATIONS.
   All construction shall be in accordance with specifications now on file in
the office of the Engineering Department and it shall be the duty of the
Engineering Department to supervise the construction of all sidewalks within
the city.
(Ord. 5017, approved 1-31-1980)
§ 905.06 NON-LIABILITY OF CITY.
   Any permittee for the construction of curbing, sidewalk or driveway shall
save and hold the city harmless from any and all claims whatever by adjoining
property owners which could, may or have arisen as a result of the issuance by
the city of a particular line and grade if the line and grade is not in
conformity with adjoining lines and grades.
(Ord. 2829, approved 9-1-1960)
§ 905.07 LINE AND GRADE DIFFERENTIALS.
   It shall be the sole responsibility of the permittee to provide for
differentials in line and grade with that of adjoining property owners, when
the established line and grade is not in conformity with that of existing lines
and grades.
(Ord. 2829, approved 9-1-1960)
§ 905.08 DEPOSIT OF CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS.
   The issuance of a permit for construction of a curbing, sidewalk or driveway
shall authorize the necessary and reasonable use of sidewalks or street space
for the deposit of materials needed for the construction, subject to any rules
or regulations governing such temporary deposits of material.
(Ord. 2829, approved 9-1-1960)
§ 905.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not
more than $25 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. Each day a
violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2829, approved 9-1-1960; Ord. 4566, approved 3-22-1973)
ARTICLE 907: SANITARY SEWERS; SANITARY AUTHORITY
Section
   
907.01   Definitions.
   
907.02   Sewer connections required.
   
907.03   Compliance with law.
   
907.04   Prohibited sewage receptacles.
   
907.05   Violation to constitute a nuisance.
   
907.06   Prohibited substances; cross traps.
   
907.07   Industrial waste; violation.
   
907.99   Penalty.
Cross-reference:
   Excavation for sewers, see Title Nine, §§
901.02(e),
901.03
Statutory reference:
   Sewer construction, see 3rd Class City Code, 11 Pa.C.S. §§ 13201 et seq.
§ 907.01 DEFINITIONS
   As used in this article, certain terms are defined as follows.
   AUTHORITY. The Williamsport Sanitary Authority.
   CITY. The City of Williamsport.
   INDUSTRIAL WASTE or NON-DOMESTIC WASTE. Any water-borne pollutant or waste
(gaseous, liquid or solid) from industrial processes or commercial
establishments or other sources as distinct from sanitary sewage.
   OCCUPIED BUILDING. Any structure erected and intended for continuous or
periodic habitation, occupancy or use by human beings or animals and from which
structure sanitary sewage and industrial wastes, or either thereof, is or may
be discharged.
   PERSON. Any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company,
corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental
entity or any other legal entity; or their legal representatives, agents, or
assigns. This definition includes all federal, state and local governmental
entities.
   PREMISES ACCESSIBLE TO THE SEWER SYSTEM. Real estate which adjoins, abuts on
or is adjacent to the sewer system.
   SANITARY SEWAGE. The normal water-carried household and toilet wastes from
residences, business buildings, institutions, industries and commercial
establishments.
   SEWER SYSTEM or PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS. A “treatment works” as
defined by § 212 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended (33
U.S.C. § 1251), which is owned by the Authority. This definition includes any
devices or systems used in the collection, storage, treatment, recycling and
reclamation of sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature, and any
conveyances which convey wastewater to a treatment plant, and any additions,
extensions or improvements that hereafter may be made thereto by the Authority
of the city, or any part or parts or tributaries of any or all thereof.
(Ord. 2422, approved 5-26-1953; Ord. 5836, approved 12-21-2000)
§ 907.02 SEWER CONNECTIONS REQUIRED.
   (a)   All persons owning any occupied building now erected upon premises
accessible to the sewer system shall, if not already connected, at their own
expense, make the connection with the sewer system within three months after
the effective date of Ord. 2422, approved 5-26-1953.
   (b)   All persons owning any premises accessible to the sewer system upon
which a building is hereafter erected shall at the time of the erection of such
building and at their own expense make the connection with the sewer system.
   (c)   All persons owning any occupied building upon premises which hereafter
become accessible to the sewer system shall at their own expense make the
connection with the sewer system within three months after notice to do so from
the Authority or its authorized representative.
(Ord. 2422, approved 5-26-1953)
§ 907.03 COMPLIANCE WITH LAW.
   All persons owning and/or occupying buildings or other structures connected
to the sewer system and any person who contributes, causes or permits the
contribution of wastewater into the sewer system shall comply with the
ordinances, rules and regulations of Council and the Board of the Authority and
as may be otherwise provided by law. No connection shall be made to the sewer
system and no discharge, either directly or indirectly, shall be made to the
sewer system, except in compliance with the ordinances, rules and regulations
of Council and the Board of the Authority and as may be otherwise provided by
law.
(Ord. 5228, approved 1-26-1984)
§ 907.04 PROHIBITED SEWAGE RECEPTACLES.
   No person owning any occupied building or premises accessible to the sewer
system shall erect, construct or use or maintain or cause to be erected,
constructed, used or maintained, any privy cesspool, sinkhole, septic tank or
other receptacle on such premises for receiving sewage.
(Ord. 2422, approved 5-26-1953)
§ 907.05 VIOLATION TO CONSTITUTE A NUISANCE.
   Any person who erects, constructs or maintains a privy, cesspool, sinkhole
or septic tank or other receptacle for receiving sewage, on any property
accessible to the sewer system in violation of this article, shall be deemed,
and shall be declared to be erecting, constructing and maintaining a nuisance,
which nuisance the city is authorized and directed to abate in the manner
provided by law.
(Ord. 2422, approved 5-26-1953)
§ 907.06 PROHIBITED SUBSTANCES; CROSS TRAPS.
   (a)   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the sewer
system any substances prohibited by the rules and regulations of the Authority.
Additionally, no roof, storm, cellar seepage, surface or ground waters shall be
discharged to the sewer system.
   (b)   Any vent pipe from an interceptor or trap which permits surface water
to enter the sewer system shall be repaired so that the top of the vent pipe is
at least six inches above the top of the adjacent ground level.
(Ord. 5228, approved 1-26-1984)
§ 907.07 NON-DOMESTIC WASTE.
   (a)   No person shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the sewer
system any non-domestic waste, except as in compliance with the rules and
regulations adopted by the Board of the Authority. No permit shall be issued
for a connection, nor shall any connection be made to the sewer system for the
purpose of discharging non-domestic waste therein, until the Authority or its
representative shall have first determined whether such non-domestic waste to
be discharged into the sewer system is in compliance with the rules and
regulations of the Board of the Authority including the issuance of any
approvals or permits required for the discharge of such waste by the Authority.
   (b)   The representative of the Authority and the city shall have access at
all reasonable times to plants and buildings from which non-domestic waste is
or may be discharged into the sewer system for the purpose of determining
compliance with the provisions of this article.
   (c)   In the event of any violation of this section, the city shall, in
addition to the penalties provided for in this article, have the right to
compel the discontinuance of the discharge of such non-domestic waste.
(Ord. 2422, approved 5-26-1953; Ord. 5836, approved 12-21-2000)
§ 907.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this article or any rule or
regulation of the Authority pertaining to discharge limitations or non-domestic
waste discharge permits shall be fined not less than $100, nor more than
$1,000, or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. For a third or subsequent
offense, such person may be imprisoned for not more than 90 days. Each day
during which a violation continues shall be deemed and taken to be a separate
offense and punishable as such.
   (b)   In addition to the penalties provided hereinabove, any person found to
have violated any provisions of this article or any rule or regulation of the
Authority shall reimburse the city for any and all attorneys’ fees, court costs
and other expenses of litigation.
   (c)   Any action to enforce the penalty provisions of this article shall not
be a bar to enforcement of this article or the rules and regulations of the
Authority, or any notices orders or permits issued by the Authority, by
injunction or other appropriate remedy, and the Authority shall have the power
to institute and maintain in the name of the Authority and/or the name of the
city any and all such enforcement proceedings.
   (d)   Nothing in this article shall be construed to abridge, limit or
otherwise impair the right of any person to damages or other relief on account
of injuries to persons or property and to maintain any action or other
appropriate proceeding therefor.
(Ord. 5228, approved 1-26-1984; Ord. 5447, approved 11-98-1989)
ARTICLE 909: HOLDING TANKS
Section
   
909.01   Definitions.
   
909.02   Right and privileges granted.
   
909.03   Rules and regulations.
   
909.04   Rules and regulations to be in conformity with applicable law.
   
909.05   Rates and charges.
   
909.06   Exclusiveness of rights and privileges.
   
909.07   Duties of improved property owner.
   
909.08   Abatement of nuisances.
   
909.09   Repeal.
   
909.10   Severability.
   
909.99   Penalty.
Statutory reference:
   Sewage disposal standards, see 25 Pa. Code §§ 73.1 et seq.
   Standards for holding tanks, see 25 Pa. Code § 73.62
§ 909.01 DEFINITIONS.
   Unless the context specifically and clearly indicates otherwise, the meaning
of terms used in this article shall be as follows.
   AUTHORITY. The Bureau of Codes of the City of Williamsport, Lycoming County,
Pennsylvania.
   HOLDING TANK. A water-tight receptacle, whether permanent or temporary which
receives and retains sewage conveyed by a water-carrying system and is designed
and constructed to facilitate the ultimate disposal of the sewage at another
site.
   IMPROVED PROPERTY. Any property within the city upon which there is erected
a structure intended for continuous or periodic habitation, occupancy or use by
human beings or animals and from which structure sewage shall or may be
discharged.
   MUNICIPALITY. The City of Williamsport, Lycoming County, Pennsylvania.
   OWNER. Any person vested with ownership, legal or equitable, sole or
partial, of any property located in the city.
   PERSON. Any individual, partnership, company, association, corporation or
other group or entity.
   SEWAGE. Any substance that contains any of the waste products or excrement
or other discharge from the bodies of human beings or animals and any noxious
or deleterious substance being harmful or inimical to the public health, or to
animal or aquatic life or to the use of water for domestic water supply or for
recreation.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.02 RIGHT AND PRIVILEGES GRANTED.
   The Bureau of Codes is hereby authorized and empowered to undertake within
the city the control and methods of holding tank use, sewage disposal and
sewage collection and transportation thereof.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.03 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Bureau of Codes is hereby authorized and empowered to adopt such rules
and regulations concerning sewage which it may deem necessary from time to time
to effect the purposes herein, as are approved by Council.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.04 RULES AND REGULATIONS TO BE IN CONFORMITY WITH APPLICABLE LAW.
   All such rules and regulations adopted by the Bureau of Codes shall be in
conformity with the provisions herein, all other ordinances of the city, and
all applicable laws, and applicable rules and regulations of administrative
agencies of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.05 RATES AND CHARGES.
   The Bureau of Codes shall have the right and power to fix, alter, charge and
collect rates, assessments and other charges in the area served by its
facilities at reasonable and uniform rates as authorized by applicable law.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.06 EXCLUSIVENESS OF RIGHTS AND PRIVILEGES.
   (a)   The collection and transportation of all sewage from any improved
property utilizing a holding tank shall be done solely by or under the
direction and control of the Bureau of Codes and the disposal thereof shall be
made only at such site or sites as may be approved by the Department of
Environmental Resources of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
   (b)   The Bureau shall receive, review and retain pumping receipts from
permitted holding tanks.
   (c)   The Bureau shall complete and retain annual inspection reports for
each permitted tank.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.07 DUTIES OF IMPROVED PROPERTY OWNER.
   The owner of an improved property that utilizes a holding tank shall:
   (a)   Maintain the holding tank in conformance with this article or any
ordinance of this city, the provisions of any applicable law, and the rules and
regulations of the Bureau of Codes and any administrative agency of the
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania;
   (b)   Permit only the Bureau or its agent to inspect holding tanks on an
annual basis; and
   (c)   Permit only the Bureau or its agent to collect, transport and dispose
of the contents therein.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.08 ABATEMENT OF NUISANCES.
   In addition to any other remedies provided in this article, any violation of
this article above shall constitute a nuisance and shall be abated by the city
or the Bureau of Codes by either seeking mitigation of the nuisance or
appropriate equitable or legal relief from a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.09 REPEAL.
   Former Ord. 4808, as amended is hereby repealed and all other ordinances or
resolutions or parts of ordinances or resolutions, insofar as they are
inconsistent herewith, be and the same are hereby repealed.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.10 SEVERABILITY.
   If any sentence, clause, section or part of this article is for any reason
found to be unconstitutional, illegal or invalid, such unconstitutionality,
illegality or invalidity shall not affect or impair any of the remaining
provisions, sentences, clauses, sections or parts of this article. It is hereby
declared as the intent of the city, that this article would have been adopted
had such unconstitutional, illegal or invalid sentence, clause, section or part
thereof not been included therein.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)
§ 909.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction
thereof by summary proceedings, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than
$100, and not more than $600, or the maximum provided by state statute, plus
costs, and in default of such fine and costs to undergo imprisonment in the
county prison for a period not in excess of 30 days.
(Ord. 5540, approved 10-17-1991)

ARTICLE 911: MUNICIPAL COMMUNITY AMBULANCE

ARTICLE 913: BROWN MEMORIAL PARK; ORIGINAL LITTLE LEAGUE
Section

913.02   Exclusive use of playing field.
   
913.03   Right to make improvements.

§ 913.01 ESTABLISHMENT OF PLAYGROUND AND PUBLIC PARK.
   The part of the Max M. Brown Memorial Park bounded on the east by Elm
Street, and on the north by West Fourth Street, on the west by a road (entrance
to area occupied by the Model Airplane Club, and on the south by Lycoming
Creek, except the area occupied by the dike and the area occupied by the public
rest rooms is expressly set aside for use as a playground and public park for
little league baseball and the public’s enjoyment thereof.
(Ord. 2290, approved 1-20-1951)
§ 913.02 EXCLUSIVE USE OF PLAYING FIELD.
   The playing field of the area shall be used exclusively for the practice and
scheduled and tournament playing of Little League Baseball.
(Ord. 2290, approved 1-20-1951)
§ 913.03 RIGHT TO MAKE IMPROVEMENTS.
   The Original Little League Inc. shall have the right to make improvements on
such portion of the park after obtaining the consent thereto by Council, as
well as obtaining any zoning or building permits required by any city
ordinance.
(Ord. 2290, approved 1-20-1951)
§ 913.04 OWNERSHIP OF IMPROVEMENTS; MAINTENANCE.
   Any improvements heretofore made by the Original Little League Inc., and any
improvements which are made in the future by the Original Little League Inc.,
shall remain the property of the Original Little League Inc., and the Original
Little League Inc., shall have the right to remove any or all of the
improvements; provided that, such removal can be and is effected without damage
to the property. The Original Little League Inc. shall maintain the area
described in §
913.01.
(Ord. 2290, approved 1-20-1951)
§ 913.05 PUBLIC USE OF PARK.
   This article shall not be construed to exclude the public from the use and
enjoyment of such area. The city shall at all times have the power and
authority to adopt suitable rules and regulations concerning the use and
occupation of the area by the public generally, pursuant to § 3710 of the Act
of 6-23-1931, P.L. 932, Art. 37.
(Ord. 2290, approved 1-20-1951)
§ 913.06 DEED RESTRICTIONS.
   This article is subject to the conditions, restrictions and limitations
contained in a certain deed from Jacob C. Brown to the city, dated 5-16-1922,
recorded in the office of the Lycoming County Recorder of Deeds in Deed Book
246, at page 42.
(Ord. 2290, approved 1-20-1951)

§ 915.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, certain terms are defined as follows.
   DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICES. The Director of Public Services or his or her
designee.
   PERSON. Includes a firm, association, public body, partnership, trust,
company or corporation, as well as an individual.
   PUBLIC PLACES. All other lands owned by the city, including parks,
playgrounds, municipal building sites and all land held by municipal
authorities or commissions.
   PUBLIC STREET. All lands between the property lines on either side of all
public highways, streets, roads, boulevards and alleys.
   TREE. Any tree, shrub or other woody vegetation or plant in any public
street or public place, or that part of any tree, shrub or other woody
vegetation or plant which extends within the lines of any public street or
public place.
(Ord. 4006, approved 1-19-1965)
§ 915.02 POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICES.
   (a)   The Director of Public Services shall have exclusive custody and
control of trees in the city, and may plant, remove, maintain and protect trees
on public streets and public places in the city. The Director may require the
planting and replanting of trees. The kind of tree and the alignment and
locations of the trees shall be determined by the Director, but shall not
prevent the necessary or reasonable use of public streets, sidewalks, abutting
property or the conduct of business.
   (b)   The Director may, with the approval of Council, either employ and pay
superintendents, engineers, foresters, tree wardens or other assistants, or may
contract for personal and professional services, for the proper performance of
his or her duties.
(Ord. 4006, approved 1-19-1965)
§ 915.03 NOTICE OF WORK TO ABUTTING PROPERTY OWNERS.
   Whenever the Director of Public Services proposes to plant, transplant or
remove trees on any public street, notice of the proposed work shall be given
the abutting property owner. The notice shall specify the public streets or
portions thereof upon which trees are proposed to be so planted, replanted or
removed.
(Ord. 4006, approved 1-19-1965)
§ 915.04 PAYMENT BY PROPERTY OWNERS.
   The cost of furnishing, maintaining, planting, transplanting or removing any
trees in or along the public streets of the city, the necessary and suitable
guards, curbing or grading for the protection thereof and the replacing of any
pavement or sidewalk necessarily disturbed in the execution of such work, shall
be paid by the owner of the real estate in front of whose property the work is
done. The amount each owner is to pay shall be ascertained and certified by the
Director of Public Services to Council and the City Treasurer.
(Ord. 4624, approved 12-21-1973)
§ 915.05 ASSESSMENTS AND LIENS.
   Upon the filing of the certificate with Council, the City Clerk shall cause
30 days’ written notice to be given by mail to the persons against whose
property an assessment has been made. The notice shall state the amount of the
assessment and the time and place of payment, and shall be accompanied by a
copy of the certificate. The expense of the notice shall be paid by the city.
The amount assessed against the real estate shall be a lien from the time of
the filing of the certificate with Council and, if not paid within the time
designated in the notice, a claim may be filed and collected in the same manner
as municipal claims are filed and collected.
(Ord. 4006, approved 1-19-1965)
§ 915.06 MAINTENANCE COST BY CITY (REPEALED).
Editor’s note:
   Section 915.06 was repealed by Ord. 4624, approved 12-21-1973.
§ 915.07 PERMIT REQUIRED TO PLANT, TREAT OR REMOVE.
   (a)   No person shall hereafter plant, move, spray, fertilize, brace, trim,
do surgery work, cut above or below ground, disturb or alter any tree or shrub
in any public street or public place in the city, or cause such acts to be done
by others, without first obtaining a written permit from the Director of Public
Services who shall issue the permit if, in his or her judgment, the work is
necessary, and the proposed methods of workmanship are of a satisfactory
nature. A permit shall not be required to cultivate and water. The person
receiving a permit shall abide by specifications adopted by the Director.
   (b)   As a condition to any permit to remove any public tree or shrub, the
Director may require that the permittee plant one or more trees or shrubs in
place of the one removed. Whenever such tree or shrub has been removed or
destroyed pursuant to any such conditional permit, no permittee shall fail,
refuse or neglect to comply with the conditions of the permit.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.08 PERMIT CONTENTS.
   Every written permit issued by the Director of Public Services shall
describe the work to be done, specify the species or variety, size, nursery,
grade and location, and briefly specify the method of planting, support and
pruning of trees or shrubs concerned, and shall contain a definite expiration
date. Any permit may be declared void if its terms are violated.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.09 PROHIBITED ACTS; PROTECTION OF TREES AND SHRUBS.
   No person shall break, injure, mutilate, kill or destroy any public tree or
shrub, or permit any fire to burn where it could injure any portion of any
public tree or shrub. No person shall knowingly permit any leak to exist in any
gas pipe within the root zone of any public tree or shrub. No person shall
permit any toxic chemical, such as oil or salt water, to seep, drain or be
emptied on or about any public tree or shrub. No person shall knowingly permit
any wires designed to carry electric current to come in contact with any public
tree or shrub unless protected by approved methods. No person shall damage or
remove any device placed to protect public trees or shrubs, except in case of
emergencies. No person shall attach any electrical installation to any public
tree or shall excavate any ditches, tunnels or trenches, or lay any driveway
within a radius of ten feet from any public tree or shrub without first
obtaining a written permit from the Director of Public Services. During
building and demolition operations, the contractor shall erect suitable
protective barriers around public trees or shrubs apt to be injured, after
obtaining a written permit from the Director.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.10 BLOCKING WATER OR AIR FROM ROOTS.
   No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any public street or
public place any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other materials which could
impede the free passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any public
tree or shrub, except by written permit of the Director of Public Services.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.11 FASTENING MATERIALS TO TREES.
   No person shall fasten any sign, advertisement, wire, rope or other material
to, around or through any public tree or shrub, except by written permit of the
Director of Public Services, except in emergencies such as storms or accidents.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.12 MOVING BUILDING; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall move any building or other large object along any street
without first having obtained a written permit from the Director of Public
Services who may require the mover to furnish bond or cash deposit in an amount
sufficient to cover any damage to or destruction of trees or shrubs on such
public street as a result of the moving operations. The Director may direct the
route of any such moving so as to minimize damage to public trees or shrubs.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.13 PERMITS FOR UTILITY WORK AFFECTING TREES.
   All permits issued for the installation of public utilities that affect
public trees or shrubs shall be certified by the Director of Public Services.
When a permit is issued to a public utility to trim public trees or do other
operations affecting public trees or shrubs, the work shall be limited to the
actual necessities of the service of the company. Such work shall be done in a
neat and workmanlike manner according to specifications outlined by the
Director who may assign an inspector to supervise the provisions of the permit.
The cost of such service shall be charged to the public utility at cost.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.14 TEMPORARY ELECTRICITY CUT-OFF.
   Whenever the Director of Public Services determines it necessary, in order
to prune or remove any tree or for any other reason, to temporarily move,
protect or cut off the electricity from any service wire so that tree work can
be safely and properly done, he or she shall serve written notice on the owner
of such wire, and such owner shall comply with such notice within a reasonable
period of time.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.15 TREES DAMAGED BY PERSONS; CHARGES.
   If a public tree is damaged by any person, the Director of Public Services
may make a charge for repairs to the tree, plus the devaluation of the tree,
against the person causing the damage to the tree. If a tree is destroyed by
any person, the Director may make a charge for the appraised value of the tree,
plus the cost of removal and replacement thereof, against the person causing
the destruction of the tree.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.16 TREES FELLED BY CASUALTY.
   If any public trees or portions thereof are felled by storm or other
casualty, the trees, branches or stumps thereof shall be removed from the
street by the city and the costs of such removal shall be assessed against the
property owners in accordance with §§ 915.04 and 915.05. Replacement of such
trees shall be required where the area between the street and curb line is at
least 30 inches at the expense of the property owner.
(Ord. 5538, approved 10-3-1991)
§ 915.17 NOTICE TO TRIM OR REMOVE TREE CREATING NUISANCE.
   Any tree or shrub or part thereof growing upon private property, but
overhanging or interfering with the use of any public street or public place,
which in the opinion of the Director of Public Services, endanger the life,
health, safety or property of the public, shall be declared a public nuisance.
The owner shall be notified in writing of the existence of the nuisance and
given reasonable time for its correction or removal. If not corrected or
removed within the time allotted, the Director shall cause the nuisance to be
corrected or removed and the cost shall be assessed to the owner as provided by
law.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.18 INTERFERENCE WITH EMPLOYEES; LEGAL REMEDIES.
   No person shall prevent, delay or interfere with any employees or
contractors of the Director of Public Services in the execution or enforcement
of this article. However, nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to
prohibit a public hearing or the permitting of any remedy legal or equitable in
a Court of Common Pleas by the owner of any property within the city.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.19 COOPERATION WITH OTHER CITY DEPARTMENTS.
   There shall be close cooperation between the Director of Public Services and
other city departments when their work affects the public trees. The Director
shall approve all building permits that may cause injury to or removal of
public trees or shrubs. All sewer, lighting, water and paving plans shall be
cleared with the Director. The city’s Planning Commission and the Director
shall work together planning for the present and future of the city. The
Bureaus of Fire and Police shall work closely with the Director in the interest
of the public trees and shrubs and public safety. The cooperation in all cases
shall work equally both ways.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.20 PRUNING LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   (a)   All pruning, trimming and removal of public trees and shrubs shall be
done in accordance with specifications adopted by the Director of Public
Services. No person shall prune any public trees or shrubs without first
obtaining a license from the Director. Such license shall be granted to any
person when, on application and examination, he or she shall be considered by
the Director sufficiently skilled and competent to do such work in a proper
manner. In the case of a firm, association or corporation engaged in the
business of tree maintenance work, the license shall extend only to those
persons so considered by the Director.
   (b)   The Director may revoke the pruning license of any person who does
work improperly or in a negligent manner. Such person shall be prohibited from
doing any further pruning of public trees or shrubs until such time as the
Director is convinced of his or her competence to do the work. The fee for a
pruning license shall be as specified in
Art. 117 of the codified ordinances.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967; Ord. 4624, approved 12-21-1973)
§ 915.21 LIABILITY AND PROPERTY DAMAGE REQUIREMENTS.
   All applicants for licenses and permits to work on the public shade trees
shall comply with the local public liability and property damage requirements
as established within the discretion of the Director of Public Services.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.22 PRUNING PERMIT FOR PROPERTY OWNER.
   The Director of Public Services may issue a yearly pruning permit in lieu of
the regular license, without charge, to any property owner, to personally prune
or trim the public trees in front of his or her property only, upon his or her
declaration of intent to do the work himself or herself; and, provided, the
Director is satisfied that he or she is competent to do the work in accordance
with the specifications of the Director. The Director may revoke and refuse to
re-issue any pruning permit to such property owner who does his or her own work
in an improper or incompetent manner.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.23 PLANTING.
   (a)   Size.
      (1)   All street trees shall be of sufficient size to warrant
satisfactory results.
      (2)   All standard trees shall be at least one to one and one-half inches
in diameter, six inches above the ground and at least six to ten feet high.
      (3)   All small trees shall be at least six to eight feet high and have
five or more branches, unless otherwise approved the Director of Public
Services.
   (b)   Grade.
      (1)   All standard trees shall have comparatively straight characteristic
trunks, well developed leaders and tops and roots characteristic of the species
or variety. All plants shall be free of insects, disease, mechanical injuries
and other objectionable features at the time of planting.
      (2)   All shrubs shall be well branched and normal in height and spread
according to species. They shall possess healthy, normal and adequate root
systems and shall be free from insects, diseases and mechanical injuries at the
time of planting.
   (c)   Location.
      (1)   Based on a 40-year cycle, no tree which will attain a trunk
diameter greater than 12 to 15 inches shall be planted in a tree lawn less than
three to five feet in width unless otherwise approved by the Director of Public
Services. In tree lawns less than three feet in width and where overhead wires
or building setback present a special problem, the selection of site and
species shall be determined by the Director.
      (2)   Where there is a tree lawn of less than three feet in width, legal
steps should be taken to obtain easement rights to plant on private property
inside the sidewalk. Such easements should contain provisions granting the city
permission to select, plant, maintain and remove such trees under the direction
of the Director.
      (3)   The tree should be planted in the middle of the tree lawn, except
under special conditions such as conflict with overhead wires. In these cases,
the Director shall select the species and planting location.
      (4)   Tree species that produce large mature trees should be planted
where the tree lawn is at least 20 feet wide; where existing overhead wires
will not interfere when trees are mature; with at least a 60-foot setback and
on a street 60 feet wide from curb to curb. Any deviations from this requires
special permission of the Director.
      (5)   Trees shall be planted at least 20 feet from street intersections,
and at least five feet from driveways for small growing trees and 15 feet for
large growing trees.
      (6)   Spacing of trees shall be determined by the Director according to
local conditions and species to be used, their mature height, spread and form.
      (7)   All planting on unpaved streets without curb shall have the special
permission of the Director who shall determine the tree’s location so it will
not be injured or destroyed when the street is paved.
   (d)   Method of planting.
      (1)   Holes shall be of sufficient size to accommodate the roots without
crowding.
      (2)   In poorly drained soil, artificial drainage shall be provided.
      (3)   Plants shall be set no deeper than previously grown.
      (4)   Good soil, compost, peat moss or other suitable soil mixtures shall
be used about the roots or in the backfill around the soil ball.
      (5)   Newly planted trees shall be mulched to a depth of three inches or
more.
   (e)   Methods of support. Standard trees shall be guyed or supported in an
upright position with cable, wire or stakes according to accepted
arboricultural practices. The guys shall be so fastened that they will not
girdle, nor cause serious injury to, the tree or endanger public safety.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.24 TRIMMING AND REMOVAL.
   (a)   No topping or dehorning of trees shall be permitted except by written
permission of the Director of Public Services.
   (b)   When possible, all small established standard trees shall be trimmed
of branches to a height of at least seven feet from the ground and the first
branch not to be over nine feet from the ground. Newly planted, small trees
need not have all the lower branches removed until they are well established.
All large, established trees shall be trimmed to sufficient height to allow
free passage of pedestrians and vehicular traffic with a clearance of ten feet
over sidewalks, 14 feet over public streets and 16 feet over principal traffic
thoroughfares.
   (c)   It shall be the policy of the Director of Public Services in the
development of a system of tree trimming to give effective street illumination
and the placement of lighting standards.
   (d)   All cuts shall be made with a saw or pruner and only at the nodes or
crotches. No stubs shall be left. No spurs or climbing irons shall be used in
the trees.
   (e)   All dead, cross and rubbing limbs shall be removed.
   (f)   All old and new wounds over one inch in diameter shall be treated with
a good quality tree wound dressing unless decayed.
   (g)   All tools being used on a tree suspected to be infected with a
contagious disease shall be thoroughly disinfected before being used on another
tree.
   (h)   Whenever public streets are to be blocked off for public service, the
Police and Fire Bureaus shall be notified of the location and length of time
the street will be blocked.
   (i)   Suitable street and sidewalk barriers and signs shall be used when
trimming a tree to protect the public from danger. A flagger with a red flag
shall be stationed in the public street whenever trees are to be trimmed over
public streets that are open to traffic. A red lantern or flares shall be
placed on all barriers or obstructions remaining in the traveled portion of the
public street after dark.
   (j)   All trees removed shall be cut at least four to five inches below the
ground, and the soil shall be replaced and the area leveled.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.25 SPECIES AND VARIETY.
   (a)   Only desirable trees shall be planted. In general these are trees of:
      (1)   Good appearance, exceptional beauty, adaptability, long lived and
generally free from injurious insects or disease; or
      (2)   Those of exceptional value in particular locations or of selected
variety.
   (b)   Where street blocks have been assigned one species or variety on the
master street plan, only these may be planted subject to revision by the
Director of Public Services.
   (c)   The Director shall prepare a list of trees undesirable for planting in
the public areas of the city. These shall not be recommended for general
planting and their use, if any, shall be restricted to special locations where,
because of certain characteristics of adaptability or landscape effect, they
can be used to advantage.
   (d)   (1)   The Director shall prepare lists of trees desirable for planting
in the public areas of the city.
 
Size Tree Feet
Large     Over 40
Medium    25 - 40
Small     15 - 25
 
      (2)   These trees shall dominate the plantings for the public areas.
Other species may be added to the list by the Director as experience proves
their value.
   (e)   The choice of shrub species for planting on the public areas shall
follow the recommendations of the Director.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.26 FERTILIZATION.
   (a)   Fertilization of public trees shall follow the accepted standards.
   (b)   No fertilizer containing less than 20% available essential elements
shall be used unless approved by the Director of Public Services.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.27 SPRAYING.
   (a)   Suitable precautions shall be taken to protect and warn the public
that spraying is being done. Many spraying materials are poisonous to persons
so due caution in their use must be exercised.
   (b)   Spraying shall be done only for the control of specific diseases or
insects with the proper materials in the necessary strength and applied at the
proper time to obtain the desired control. General spraying for insect and
disease control is to be discouraged.
   (c)   Spray materials containing lime-sulfur should not be used near painted
buildings.
   (d)   Dormant oil spray must not be applied when the temperature is below
40°F, or when it may fall below this before the spray has dried. No person
shall use oil sprays on hard maple, hickory, beech or walnut trees.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.28 CAVITIES, BARK TRACING AND BRACING.
   Generally accepted practices shall be followed for tree cavities, bark
tracing and bracing.
(Ord. 4138, approved 2-2-1967)
§ 915.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
article or any order of the Director of Public Services shall be fined not less
than $100, nor more than $600, or the maximum penalty permitted by the state
law for each and every offense or imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or
both. Whenever such person has been notified by the Director or by service or
summons in prosecution, or in any other way, that he or she is committing a
violation, each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 5538, approved 10-3-1991)
ARTICLE 917: PHILLIP E. “PHIL” PREZIOSI PARK
Section
   
917.01   Designated as Phillip E. “Phil” Preziosi Park.
§ 917.01 DESIGNATED AS PHILLIP E. “PHIL” PREZIOSI PARK.
   The present Newberry Park located in the Newberry Section of the City of
Williamsport which is bounded by Linn Street west to Pearl Street, north to
Baker Street, west to Seneca Avenue, north to Cherry Alley, east to Huckleberry
Alley, south to Linn Street at the beginning. Newberry Park will now be
designated as Phillip E. “Phil” Preziosi Park.
(Ord. 6326, approved 5-11-2017; Ord. 6354, approved 1-31-2019)
