§ 1727.12 PLUMBER EXAMINERS BOARD.
   (a)   Definitions. As used in this section, certain terms are defined as
follows.
      APPRENTICE PLUMBER. A registered person who labors at the trade of
plumbing or sewer systems under to supervision and in the immediate presence of
a master journeyman plumber for all plumbing work done in the city.
      JOURNEYMAN PLUMBER. A certified person who may labor at the business of
plumbing, including all facets of sewer systems, under the supervision of a
master plumber for all plumbing work done in the city.
      MASTER PLUMBER. A certified person who may conduct, carry on or engage in
the business of plumbing, including all facets of sewer systems.
      PLUMBING CONTRACTOR. A registered person, firm or corporation who may
conduct, carry on or engage in the business of plumbing, including all facets
of sewer systems. A PLUMBING CONTRACTOR need not be a master plumber but shall
have a full time certified master plumber in his or her employment.
      SEWAGE CONTRACTOR. A registered person who may conduct, carry on or
engage in the business of clearing or cleaning sewer lines outside structures.
   (b)   Certification or registration required.
      (1)   No person shall conduct or labor at the trade of plumbing including
installing, altering or repairing sewer systems in the capacity of a master,
journeyman or apprentice plumber without having had issued to him or her a
valid master, journeyman or apprentice certification and current registration
card by the Board of Plumber Examiners.
      (2)   Before any person or persons under a firm or corporation shall
engage in the plumbing business, including installing, altering or repairing
sewer systems, he or she shall be certified and registered as set forth under
the adopted provisions of the City Plumbing Code.
      (3)   A person desiring to learn the plumbing trade may register as an
apprentice with the Board. Any person registering with the Board shall do so
yearly.
   (c)   Board of Plumbing Examiners.
      (1)   The Board of Plumbing Examiners shall be under the Bureau of Codes.
      (2)   The Board shall be composed of, unless otherwise provided by law,
one member of the Board of Health, one plumbing inspector and two certified
plumbers.
      (3)   The four members of the Board shall be appointed by the Mayor. At
the conception of the first appointments, one shall be for two years; a second
member for a term of three years, a third member for a term of four years and
the fourth member for a term of five years. Thereafter, appointments to the
Board shall be for five-year terms.
      (4)   Vacancies in the Board occurring otherwise than by expiration of
term shall be for the unexpired term and shall be filled in the same manner as
the original appointments.
   (d)   Duties of Board of Plumber Examiners. The duties of the Board of
Plumber Examiners shall be:
      (1)   To elect a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson annually from members
of the Board. The Vice Chairperson shall preside in the absence of the
Chairperson. The Board Secretary shall be the City Plumbing Inspector;
      (2)   To formulate an objective written plumbing test composed of
questions and problem drawings for the purpose of determining the competency
and knowledge of plumbing and sewer system work of persons who desire to be
certified as master or journeyman plumbers;
      (3)   To advertise and administer examinations twice a year, in May and
November, regardless of the number of applicants. The Board shall determine
time and place for administering each examination;
      (4)   To keep accurate records of all examination results,
certifications, registrations, official transactions and to render any
pertinent reports to statistics as the administrative authority may require;
      (5)   To attend all examinations and appeals. For such attendance he
shall be paid $10 by the city;
      (6)   To account and forward all application and registration fees to the
proper city-appointed department; and
      (7)   To act as a Board of Appeals in making a correct determination of
any appeal arising from actions involving revocation of certification and/or
registration.
   (e)   Certification. The Board of Plumber Examiners shall issue master or
journeyman certification to persons pursuant to the following provisions.
      (1)   Plumbing certification shall be issued to every person who makes
application for specific certification; provided, he or she attests to the
required years of experience, pays the required application fee and
successfully passes the examination with a score of 70 or higher total points.
      (2)   In lieu of the examination, the Board of Plumber Examiners may
issue appropriate certification to persons who make application, pay the
required application fee and possess and present to the Board a valid
certification issued to him or her by any governmental agency who requires an
examination of similar scope and character to that given by the Board of
Plumbers Examiners; provided, such governmental agency, if a municipality,
reciprocates with the city.
      (3)   Every person applying for certification shall pay $10 to the
Secretary of the Board at the time of application.
      (4)   Any person desiring to take the journeyman plumber examination
shall have three years’ practical experience under the control or direction of
a master plumber engaged in the business or work of plumbing, house or building
drainage. One-year credit shall be allowed for successful completion of a one-
year or a two-year plumbing course at the Pennsylvania College of Technology,
or equivalent thereof. The course shall be approved by the Board.
      (5)   Any person desiring to take the master plumber certification
examination shall have five years’ practical experience, including the three
years’ practical experience required to become a journeyman plumber, under the
control and direction of a master plumber engaged in the business or work of
plumbing, house or building drainage. One-year credit shall be allowed for
successful completion of a one- or a two-year plumbing course at the
Pennsylvania College of Technology, or equivalent thereof. The course must be
approved by the Board. In addition any such person shall have successfully
passed the journeyman plumber examination.
   (f)   Re-examination. Any person who fails to pass the certification
examination as prescribed by the Board of Plumber Examiners may apply for re-
examination after the expiration of six months and the payment of the required
application fee. Should such person fail to pass the second time, the Board
shall refuse a third application until after the expiration of one year.
   (g)   Registration.
      (1)   Every person engaged in the plumbing business and/or cleaning of
sewer systems shall apply for an annual registration card to the Secretary of
the Board of Plumber Examiners. The annual fee at time of application shall be
in accordance with
Art. 117 of the codified ordinances.
      (2)   Registration cards are valid for one year beginning January 1 and
ending December 31. Application for renewal or registration cards shall be made
within 30 days of the new year.
   (h)   Revocation of certification or registration.
      (1)   The Board of Plumber Examiners may cancel or revoke any
certification or registration issued by them to any person for the following
reasons:
         (A)   Incompetency;
         (B)   Lack of knowledge;
         (C)   Obtained by fraud;
         (D)   Transferred to another person;
         (E)   Lending of registration; and
         (F)   Obtaining permits under false pretenses.
      (2)   Persons charged with any of the preceding violations shall be
notified in writing and served either personally or by registered mail stating
specifically what the charges are and of the time, date and place of a hearing
before the Board. Such hearing shall conform to the procedures under the Local
Agency Law, 2 Pa.C.S. §§ 551, 751 et seq..
      (3)   If certification or registration is revoked, another certification
and/or registration shall not be granted to such persons within 12 months after
the date of cancellation or revocation. Persons desiring reinstatement after 12
months shall appear before the Board of Plumber Examiners.
(Ord. 4709, approved 10-24-1975; Ord. 5422, approved 7-27-1989; Ord. 5716,
approved 5-15-1997)
§ 1727.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be fined not less than
$50, nor more than $1,000, or imprisoned not more than 90 days, or both, for
each and every violation.
(Ord. 5452, approved 11-9-1989)
ARTICLE 1729: HISTORICAL DISTRICTS
Section
   
1729.01   Authority; district creation and map.

1729.04   Board created; organization.

1729.06   Board meetings; certificates.
   
1729.07   Certificate of appropriateness required.
   
1729.08   Permit application procedures.
   
1729.09   Permit application hearing.
   
1729.10   Standards for certificate issuance.
   
1729.11   Certificate disapproval; changes recommended.
   
1729.12   Board’s report to Council.
   
1729.13   Certificate application hearing by Council.
   
1729.14   Appeal from disapproval.
   
1729.15   Enforcement.
   
1729.16   Effect on other enforcement officers.
   
1729.17   Historic district as line item in budget.
   
1729.99   Penalty.
Statutory reference:
   State law provisions, see 53 P.S. §§ 8001 et seq.
§ 1729.01 AUTHORITY; DISTRICT CREATION AND MAP.
   (a)   Pursuant to the authority contained in Act 167 (P.L. 282), as amended
(53 P.S. §§ 8001 et seq.) and in the Optional Charter Law for third class
cities, historical district or districts are hereby created as shown on the
“Williamsport Historical District Map”, which, together with all explanatory
matter thereon, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be part of this
article. The “Williamsport Historical Map” shall be identified by the signature
of the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk, and bearing the seal of the city
under the following words: “This is to certify that this is the official
historical district map referred to in Section 1 of 4720 of the City of
Williamsport, Pennsylvania”, together with the date of the adoption of the
ordinance.
   (b)   The historic district as shown on the Williamsport Historical District
map shall be know as the “Dr. Randall F. Hipple Williamsport Historic
District”.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975; Ord. 5999, approved 7-21-2005)
§ 1729.02 AMENDMENT OF DISTRICT MAP.
   No change of any nature shall be made in the map or matter shown on the
District Map, except by ordinance in conformity with the procedures set forth
in § 1729.05 and generally with the procedures set forth in the Optional
Charter Law for third class cities. Regardless of the existence or purported
copies of the official Williamsport Historical District Map which may from time
to time be made or published, the official Williamsport Historical District
Map, which is located in the office of the Building Inspector, shall be the
final authority as to the boundaries of such districts.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
Editor’s note:
   The Williamsport Historical District Map has been amended by Ord. 5189,
approved 12-21-1982.
§ 1729.03 UNCERTAINTY IN BOUNDARIES.
   Where uncertainty exists as to the boundaries of districts, the following
rules shall apply.
   (a)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following the centerlines of
streets, highways or alleys shall be construed to follow such centerlines.
   (b)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following plotted lot lines
shall be construed as following such lot lines.
   (c)   Distances not specifically indicated on the Williamsport Historical
District Map shall be determined by the scale of the Map.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.04 BOARD CREATED; ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   The Board of Historical Architectural Review is hereby established and
shall be composed of 11 members appointed by Council, one of whom shall be a
registered architect, one a licensed real estate broker, one the City Building
Inspector or the Codes Administrator of the city, one a member of the City
Planning Commission, one the Preservation Finance Officer so long as such
position is in existence and filled, and six or seven additional persons,
depending on whether the Preservation Finance Officer position is filled, with
knowledge of and interest in the preservation of historic buildings and the
district.
   (b)   Any appointed member to the Board who misses three meetings per year
without giving prior notification shall be deemed to have tendered his or her
resignation from the Board and that person’s position shall be deemed vacant
and Council shall appoint someone to fill that vacancy at Council’s earliest
possible convenience.
   (c)   The 11 members of the Board (except for one City Building Inspector or
the Codes Administrator, one member of the Planning Commission and the
Preservation Finance Officer) shall serve a five-year term. The terms of the
remaining eight members of the Board shall be so fixed that no more than two
shall be reappointed or replaced during any future calendar year. One of these
eight members shall be a registered architect, one a licensed real estate
broker, with the other six members having knowledge of and interest in the
preservation of historic buildings and the district. If the position of the
Preservation Finance Officer is not in existence or is not filled, a person may
be appointed to fill that position for a five-year term.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975; Ord. 5365, approved 11-24-1987; Ord.
5582, approved 3-18-1993; Ord. 5722, approved 7-10-1997; Ord. 5805, approved 3-
23-2000)
§ 1729.05 BOARD’S RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   The Board of Historical Architectural Review shall be charged with the
responsibility of reviewing the Historic District limits as outlined in §
1729.03, and from time to time to make recommendation for amendments in the
Williamsport Historical District Map to Council, which recommendations shall be
in the form of an ordinance. The Board is charged with the responsibility of
developing and continuing an effective program of landmark recognition and
preservation. Within such District, the Board shall survey and designate in a
suitable manner such areas, buildings, structures, monuments, works of art and
other objects having special historical, architectural, community or esthetics
interest or value and worthy of preservation.
   (b)   Whenever a project requires State Labor and Industry approval, the
Board shall require an approved and sealed set of drawings which shall be kept
as a permanent record. Such drawings shall be required before consideration for
approval.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975; Ord. 5365, approved 11-24-1987)
§ 1729.06 BOARD MEETINGS; CERTIFICATES.
   The Board of Historical Architectural Review shall advise Council regarding
the advisability of issuing any certificates required to be issued pursuant to
this article and the enabling legislation pursuant to which it was adopted. For
this purpose, the Board shall elect a chairperson from its membership and may
prescribe rules and regulations for its organization and procedures, consistent
with city ordinances and the laws of the commonwealth. Meetings of the Board
shall be open to the public. A majority of the Board shall constitute a quorum
and action taken at any meeting shall require the affirmative vote of a
majority of the Board. The members of the Board shall serve without
compensation and shall make an annual report of their transactions to Council.
The Board may, pursuant to appropriations by Council, employ secretarial
assistance, pay salaries and wages for secretarial assistance and incur other
necessary expenses. However, the Board shall not incur any expense whatever
without a prior resolution of Council authorizing such action. Minutes, tape
recordings or whatever stenographic or mechanical recordings or records deemed
to be appropriate by the Board shall be taken of all evidentiary proceedings
and proceedings where it is necessary to record or note relevant data and the
votes of each of the members shall be faithfully recorded in the minutes by the
Secretary of the Board in each case.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.07 CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS REQUIRED.
   Except for interior alterations or modifications, no person shall erect,
construct, reconstruct, alter, restore, demolish, paint, raze or change in
appearance, in whole or in part, any building or structure within the
Historical District without first obtaining a certificate of appropriateness as
required by this article.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.08 PERMIT APPLICATION PROCEDURES.
   Upon receipt of an application for a building permit for exterior work,
including signs, to be done in the Historic District, the Building Inspector
shall act in accordance with the procedures presently being followed in that
office, except as those procedures are necessarily modified by the following
requirements.
   (a)   He or she shall forward to the Chairperson of the Board of Historical
Architectural Review a copy of the application for a building permit, together
with a copy of the plot plan and the building plans and specifications filed by
the applicant.
   (b)   He or she shall maintain in his or her office a record of all such
applications and of his or her handling and final disposition of the same,
which shall be in addition to and appropriately cross-referenced to his or her
other records.
   (c)   He or she shall require applicants to submit a sufficient number of
additional copies of material required to be attached to an application for a
building permit to permit compliance with the foregoing.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.09 PERMIT APPLICATION HEARING.
   Upon receipt by the Board of Historical Architectural Review of a notice
that an application for a building permit for the erection of a new structure
or modifications to the exterior of an existing structure located within the
Historic District has been filed in the office of the Building Inspector, the
Board shall schedule a meeting to consider the advice which the Board will give
to Council. The person applying for the permit shall be given not less than
five days’ written notice of the time and place of such meeting and that he may
appear to explain his or her reasons therefor. However, the applicant may
execute and file a written waiver of the five-day notice requirement if he or
she elects to do so in order that the meeting may be scheduled at an earlier
date. The Board may invite such other persons as it desires to attend its
meetings. The Board shall submit its advice in writing to Council within 30
days of the date of the application, unless the time limitation is waived in
writing by the applicant.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.10 STANDARDS FOR CERTIFICATE ISSUANCE.
   The criteria to be used by the Board of Historical Architectural Review in
making its recommendations to Council concerning the issuance of a certificate
of appropriateness for a permit for the erection, construction, alteration,
restoration, demolition or razing of all or a part of the exterior of any
building within the Historical District are as follows:
   (a)   Broad historical values representing the cultural, political, economic
or social history of the city;
   (b)   The relationship of the structure with historic personages or events;
   (c)   Specimen architectural types representative of a certain period and a
style or method of construction;
   (d)   The effect of the proposed change upon the general historic and
architectural nature of the district;
   (e)   The appropriateness of exterior architectural features which can be
seen from a public street or way only; and
   (f)   The general design, arrangement, texture, material and color of the
building or structure and the relation of such factors to similar features of
buildings and structures in the district.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.11 CERTIFICATE DISAPPROVAL; CHANGES RECOMMENDED.
   If the Board of Historical Architectural Review, on the basis of the
information received at the meeting and from its general background and
knowledge, decides to recommend against the granting of a certificate of
appropriateness, it shall indicate to the applicant for a building permit the
changes in plans and specifications, if any, which, in the opinion of the
Board, would protect the distinctive historical character of the Historic
District. The Board shall withhold its report to Council for a period of five
days following its decision to allow the applicant to decide whether or not to
make the suggested changes in his or her plans and specifications. If the
applicant determines that he or she will make the suggested changes, he or she
shall so advise the Board which shall advise Council accordingly.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.12 BOARD’S REPORT TO COUNCIL.
   The Board of Historical Architectural Review, after the meeting provided for
in §
1729.09 and after the making of any change in the plans and specifications as
provided in §
1729.11, shall submit to Council, in writing, its recommendation concerning the
issuance of a certificate of appropriateness for the grant or refusal of a
permit for the erection, reconstruction, alteration, restoration, demolition or
razing of all or a part of any building within the Historic District. The
written report shall set out the following matters:
   (a)   The exact location of the area in which the work is to be done;
   (b)   The exterior changes to be made or the exterior character of the
structure to be erected;
   (c)   A list of the surrounding structures with their general exterior
characteristics;
   (d)   The effect of the proposed change upon the general historic and
architectural nature of the district;
   (e)   The appropriateness of exterior architectural features which can be
seen from a public street or way only;
   (f)   The general design, arrangement, texture, material and color of the
building or structure and the relation of such factors to similar features of
buildings or structures in the district;
   (g)   The opinion of the Board, including any dissent, as to the
appropriateness of the work proposed as it will preserve or destroy the
historic aspect and nature of the district; and
   (h)   The specific recommendations of the Board as to the issuance by
Council or its refusal to issue a certificate of appropriateness.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.13 CERTIFICATE APPLICATION HEARING BY COUNCIL.
   Upon receipt of the written advice or recommendations of the Board of
Historical Architectural Review as provided in §
1729.12, Council shall consider at a regular or special meeting the question of
issuing to the Building Inspector a certificate of appropriateness authorizing
a permit for the work covered by the application. The City Clerk shall give the
applicant not less than five days’ written notice of the time and place of the
meeting at which his or her application will be considered and of the fact that
he or she has the right to attend and be heard as to his or her reasons for
filing the same. However, the applicant may execute and file a written waiver
of the five-day notice requirement if he or she elects to do so in order that
the meeting may be scheduled at an earlier date. In determining whether or not
to certify to the appropriateness of the proposed erection, reconstruction,
alteration, restoration, demolition or razing of all or part of such building,
Council shall consider the same factors as the Board as set forth in §
1729.10 and the report of the Board. If Council approves the application, it
shall issue a certificate of appropriateness authorizing the Building Inspector
to issue a permit for the work covered. If Council disapproves, it shall do so
in writing, giving reasons therefor; and a copy thereof shall be given to the
applicant, to the Building Inspector and to the Pennsylvania Historical and
Museum Commission. The disapproval shall indicate what changes in the plans and
specifications would meet the conditions for protecting the distinctive
historical character of the district. In any event, Council shall render its
decision no later than 30 days from receipt of the written recommendations of
the Board.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.14 APPEAL FROM DISAPPROVAL.
   Upon receipt of the written disapproval of Council, the Building Inspector
shall disapprove the application for a building permit and so advise the
applicant. The applicant may appeal from the disapproval as provided by the
Local Agency Law, 2 Pa.C.S. §§ 551, 751 et seq..
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.15 ENFORCEMENT.
   The Building Inspector shall have the power to institute any proceedings at
law or in equity necessary for the enforcement of this article in the same
manner as in his or her enforcement of other building, zoning or planning
legislation or regulations of the city.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.16 EFFECT ON OTHER ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS.
   All ordinances or parts of ordinances inconsistent herewith are hereby
repealed; provided, however, that, nothing in this article shall be construed
to take away or detract from the powers of the Board of Health Officer or
Building Officer or other codes officer to abate a nuisance or to enforce any
other codes of the city relating to dilapidated structures.
(Ord. 4720, passed over veto 12-4-1975)
§ 1729.17 HISTORIC DISTRICT AS LINE ITEM IN BUDGET.
   Beginning in 2006, the Six-Year Capital Projects Budget shall establish and
include a line item “Historic District”, which shall be addressed each year in
preparing the annual budget.
(Ord. 5990, approved 6-23-2005)
§ 1729.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this article, fails to obtain a
certificate of appropriateness when such a certificate is required, or performs
work within the designated districts without a building permit, shall, upon
conviction thereof before a District Justice of the Peace in a summary
proceeding, be fined not more than $600, or imprisoned not more than 90 days,
or both.
(Ord. 5453, approved 11-9-1989)
ARTICLE 1731: SOBRIETY HOUSES
Section
   
1731.01   Purposes.
   
1731.02   Definitions.
   
1731.03   License required, application, term and issuance.
   
1731.04   Minimum standards for facility.
   
1731.05   Minimum standards for residents.
   
1731.06   Sobriety House Advisory Group.
   
1731.07   Enforcement.
   
1731.08   Severability.
   
1731.99   Penalty.
§ 1731.01 PURPOSES.
   The purposes of this article are as follows:
   (a)   To recognize the usefulness of sobriety houses in the scheme of
recovery programs for alcohol and chemical dependency;
   (b)   To provide minimum safeguards for individuals who reside in a sobriety
house as part of their own personal recovery;
   (c)   To protect the privacy and individual rights of residents of sobriety
houses;
   (d)   To promote the health, safety and welfare of the community where
sobriety houses are located;
   (e)   To promote and facilitate the flow of public and private funds to
legitimate facilities being used to aid the recovery of persons recovering from
alcohol and chemical dependency;
   (f)   To facilitate the transfer of medical records into the community where
recovering persons are living;
   (g)   To promote the goals of law enforcement agencies to supervise
recovering people who are on probation or parole; and
   (h)   To promote safe and sanitary living conditions among sobriety houses.
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
§ 1731.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, certain terms are defined as follows.
   CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY. A medical condition wherein a person is physically or
psychologically dependent on a substance controlled under Pennsylvania law.
   ENFORCEMENT OFFICER. The zoning building code enforcement officer or other
person designated by the municipality.
   RECOVERING PERSON. Any person who has been medically diagnosed or self-
diagnosed as suffering from an alcohol or chemical dependency.
   SOBRIETY HOUSE. A residence in which three or more untreated persons who are
recovering from alcohol or chemical dependency dwell; and which is operated so
as to promote that recovery.
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
§ 1731.03 LICENSE REQUIRED, APPLICATION, TERM AND ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Required. It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership or
corporation to operate a sobriety house without first obtaining a license
therefor.
   (b)   Application. Any person, partnership, corporation or any other legal
entity desiring to operate a sobriety house shall first apply for a license
using forms and procedures prescribed by the issuing authority. Each
application for a license and renewal application shall be accompanied by a fee
as specified in
Art. 117 of the codified ordinances which cost is reasonably related to the
cost of administering and enforcing this article. This shall be in lieu of any
rooming house license fees.
   (c)   Term. Each license shall be issued for a term of one year.
   (d)   Existing sobriety houses. Existing sobriety houses shall have three
months from the effective date of this section to apply for a license.
   (e)   Inspections.
      (1)   Each sobriety house shall be inspected by the appropriate
enforcement official and shall meet the minimum standards as set forth in §§
1731.04 and
1731.05 prior to issuance of a license and shall be subject to an annual
inspection prior to the issuance of a renewal license.
      (2)   Every sobriety house shall be subject to additional inspections, if
a specific complaint is made to the Enforcement Officer or if the Enforcement
Officer has a reasonable suspicion that the provisions of this article have
been violated.
   (f)   Issuance. The license shall be issued upon compliance with the
provisions of this article, for a sobriety house at a particular address. The
license shall be displayed in a prominent location on the premises.
   (g)   Effect of changes. Any changes in ownership or name of the sobriety
house shall be reported immediately to the enforcement officer. The license
shall expire immediately if the facility changes location.
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
§ 1731.04 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR FACILITY.
   (a)   Location.
      (1)   Sobriety houses may be located only in areas which are zoned to
permit group homes or boarding houses.
      (2)   In the event a special use permit is requested from the Zoning
Board, the applicant shall divulge to that board that the intended purpose is
to operate a sobriety house.
   (b)   Structure. The applicant shall demonstrate that occupancy will meet
all requirements of the appropriate building codes, labor and industry
standards and zoning ordinances.
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
§ 1731.05 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR RESIDENTS.
   (a)   House rules. Each applicant shall submit to the enforcement office, at
the time of application for a license, written “house rules” for the residents,
which at a minimum shall include:
      (1)   Prohibition of the use of alcohol or controlled substances by the
resident;
      (2)   Prohibition of the residents being on the premises in an
intoxicated condition or under the influence of controlled substances;
      (3)   Rules governing behavior, noise and activities that are designed to
promote an environment of tranquility, including, but not limited to,
restriction of television and music to certain hours and listing certain types
of behavior and activities which are not permitted; and
      (4)   Requirement that residents comply with the laws of the Commonwealth
of Pennsylvania, the laws of the United States, and the ordinances of the City
of Williamsport both on and off the premises.
   (b)   Handbook of responsibilities of sobriety house. Each applicant shall
submit to the enforcement officer, at the time of application for a license or
renewal of a license, a written handbook setting forth, at a minimum, the
following responsibilities of the sobriety house:
      (1)   Procedure for making available to residents the schedules of
meetings of various self-help groups;
      (2)   Procedure for disseminating to the residents information of
available aid from human service agencies and counseling services;
      (3)   Designation of a house manager and a list of hours that the house
manager will be at the premises and will be available to answer non-treatment
questions concerning the facility, resource material and the community;
      (4)   Procedure for facilitating the transfer of medical history
information to the appropriate community medical facility;
      (5)   Procedure for determining whether residents are on probation or
parole and method by which the proper law enforcement agencies are advised of
the resident’s new address;
      (6)   List of resident’s rights including, but not limited to, the
resident’s right of privacy and designation of locked area for resident’s
valuable belongings;
      (7)   A blank copy of the lease agreement provided to each resident
setting forth the term of the lease along with a list of actions by the
residents which would cause termination of the lease; and
      (8)   Written provisions governing the house-cleaning of the sobriety
house ensuring a clean and sanitary environment for the residents, which shall
provide for cleaning on a not less than weekly basis. Residents may be
responsible for cleaning the sobriety house in consideration of a reduced
rental amount.
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
§ 1731.06 SOBRIETY HOUSE ADVISORY GROUP.
   (a)   Every sobriety house shall obtain community support and advice by
establishing an advisory group made up of not less than three persons who are
residents of the municipality where the sobriety house is located.
   (b)   Each Sobriety House Advisory Group shall meet no less than three times
each year to discuss internal matters concerning the sobriety house and to
discuss the impact of the sobriety house on the residents of the facility
surrounding neighborhood, and the community in general.
   (c)   Members of the Advisory Group may not be employed by the sobriety
house or be present residents of the sobriety house.
   (d)   At the time application is made for a license or renewal thereof, the
names, addresses and telephone numbers of the Advisory Group shall be submitted
to the Enforcement Officer.
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
§ 1731.07 ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   Revocation. A license issued under this statute may be. revoked if the
sobriety house violates any provisions of this article or because of
information obtained during an inspection.
   (b)   Prohibited activities. No sobriety house may engage in counseling for
drug and alcohol dependency or engage in activities or programs which resemble
treatment for drug and alcohol dependency (as set forth in regulations
governing treatment facilities and transitional living centers).
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
§ 1731.08 SEVERABILITY.
   If any section, sentence or any other part of this article is adjudged
unconstitutional or invalid, such judgment shall not affect, impair or
invalidate the remainder of this article, but shall be confined in its effect
to the section, sentence or other part of this article directly involved in the
controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered. It is hereby
declared to be the intent of the City that this article would have been adopted
if such illegal, invalid or unconstitutional section, clause, sentence, part or
provision had not been included therein.
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
§ 1731.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Any person, partnership or corporation operating a sobriety house, as
defined in this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not
more than $50 per day or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. Each day
that a violation is permitted shall constitute a separate offense.
   (b)   Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to prohibit the city from
pursuing any other legal or equitable remedies available to it, including
obtaining an injunction to enjoin further operation of the facility.
(Ord. 5471, approved 3-8-1990)
ARTICLE 1733: DEMOLITION
Section
   
1733.01   Purpose.
   
1733.02   State and city permits required.
   
1733.03   Required proofs and information.
   
1733.04   City permit fee.
   
1733.05   Demolition permit review required.
   
1733.06   Required information for City Council review.
   
1733.07    Review criteria.
   
1733.08    Public meeting.
   
1733.09    Work restrictions.
   
1733.99   Penalty.
§ 1733.01 PURPOSE.
   This article establishes the procedure for demolition work in the city.
(Ord. 4887, approved 2-16-1978; Ord. 6048, approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413,
approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.02 STATE AND CITY PERMITS REQUIRED.
   Any individual, partnership or corporation engaging in demolition work in
the city shall be required to obtain two demolition permits prior to
undertaking any demolition work within the city. One demolition permit, when
required, shall be obtained from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Department of
Environmental Protection, Williamsport, Pennsylvania. The other permit shall be
obtained in the office of the Bureau of Codes for the city at the City Hall
Building, as outlined in this article.
(Ord. 4887, approved 2-16-1978; Ord. 5932, approved 8-7-2003; Ord. 6048,
approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413, approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.03 REQUIRED PROOFS AND INFORMATION.
   At the time an application for a demolition permit is made at the office of
the Bureau of Codes for the city, or prior to the actual issuance of the
permit, the following proofs and information shall be provided to the Bureau of
Codes:
   (a)   A certification of utility disconnects for gas lines, water lines and
electrical lines. In addition, all sanitary and storm sewers shall be
disconnected and sealed in an appropriate manner subject to inspection by the
City Plumbing Inspector;
   (b)   A bond or certificate of insurance evidencing that the individual,
partnership or corporation undertaking the demolition work has insurance
coverage, the minimum of which provides for $100,000 of coverage for each
person, $300,000 for each occasion and $100,000 for property damage;
   (c)   In addition to the aforesaid bond or certificate of insurance, the
individual, partnership or corporation undertaking the demolition work shall
agree in writing to indemnify and hold harmless the city against any and all
claims for personal injuries or property damage arising out of or as a result
of the demolition work to be undertaken;
   (d)   The individual, partnership or corporation undertaking the demolition
work shall provide adequate safeguards for the protection of the public,
workmen on the site and surrounding property, as required by the Building Code
as adopted by the city. Inspection of the demolition site to ensure compliance
with the Building Code shall be made by the Bureau of Codes of the city;
   (e)   If the demolition work requires the temporary removal of any wires or
other impediments in order to facilitate the demolition work, the demolition
contractor shall give the owners of the wires or other impediments which are to
be temporarily removed notification of the temporary removal, so that such
owners have an opportunity to be heard on the subject of the temporary removal;
   (f)   Once demolition is complete per time limitation established by the
Bureau of Codes, as required by this article and the permits granted
thereunder, ground cover (i.e., contractor’s mix grass or equivalent) must be
established within 30 days unless seasonal restrictions based on the timing of
the demolition prevent this, in which case ground cover shall be established
within 30 days of the onset of the next growing season. Where demolition will
be followed by new construction within a three-month period, this ground cover
requirement will not apply, so long as the plans for the new construction
include ground cover and/or acceptable paving as part of the design; and
   (g)   A state solid waste disposal permit issued by the Pennsylvania
Department of Environmental Protection or a letter of approval from the
Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection for the use of a proposed
or existing disposal facility which has a permit or is under review for a
permit shall be presented.
(Ord. 4887, approved 2-16-1979; Ord. 5932, approved 8-7-2003; Ord. 6048,
approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413, approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.04 CITY PERMIT FEE.
   The charge for the demolition permit issued by the city for the demolition
of a building or structure shall be based upon the total cost of demolition,
and it shall be in accord with the building permit fee schedule currently set
and charged by the city. The building permit fee schedule is incorporated
herein by reference and made a part hereof, and at such time as such schedule
may be amended or modified, such amended or modified building permit fee
schedule shall likewise apply to the demolition permit fee.
(Ord. 4887, approved 2-16-1978; Ord. 6048, approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413,
approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.05 DEMOLITION PERMIT REVIEW REQUIRED.
   When any proposed demolition activity is of a principal building or
principal structure as defined in
Art. 1311 of the codified ordinances of Williamsport, Pennsylvania, Planning
and Zoning Code, a demolition permit shall be issued by the Building Official
only following review and approval of same by City Council. Demolition ordered
by the Board of Health, the Bureau of Codes or order of court in which the city
is party shall be exempt from the requirement of a demolition permit reviewed
and approved by City Council.
(Ord. 6048, approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413, approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.06 REQUIRED INFORMATION FOR CITY COUNCIL REVIEW.
   (a)   In addition to any proof and information required in §
1733.03, applications for a demolition permit shall include the following
information:
      (1)   Name and address of the owner;
      (2)   Date of acquisition of the property by the current owner;
      (3)   Name and address of any equitable owner, if applicable;
      (4)   Current use of the lot or part thereof occupied by the building or
structure proposed for demolition and, if vacant, number of years vacant and
years and description of most recent use;
      (5)   Reason(s) for the demolition; and
      (6)   Explanation why rehabilitation, reuse, plan alteration or
stabilization with the intent to market or sell the property is not feasible or
not desirable.
   (b)   And, if applicable:
      (1)   Proposed future use of the lot or part thereof occupied by the
building or structure proposed for demolition;
      (2)   Preliminary design of any proposed construction;
      (3)   Time line for construction and occupancy of proposed future use;
      (4)   Verification and appropriateness of reuse with applicable zoning;
and
      (5)   Any additional information required by City Council as relevant to
its decision.
   (c)   In those instances where the application for a demolition permit
accompanies a proposed land development plan, a permit for the proposed
demolition, as approved by City Council, shall not be issued by the Building
Official prior to the following, where applicable: the recording of an approved
subdivision or land development plan for the lot where the demolition activity
is proposed; and, the issuance of any necessary zoning approvals.
(Ord. 6048, approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413, approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.07 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   City Council will review the application utilizing the following criteria,
consistent with the health, safety and welfare of citizens and their property:
   (a)   Compatibility with the enumerated objectives of the city’s
Comprehensive Plan;
   (b)   Consistency with Zoning Ordinance and Building Ordinance requirements;
   (c)   Potential impact on surrounding structures and property; and
   (d)   Public safety considerations, including the integrity, stability and
habitability of the structure.
(Ord. 6048, approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413, approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.08 PUBLIC MEETING.
   (a)   Meeting. The completed application for a demolition shall be sent to
City Council for consideration at its next regularly scheduled meeting, and the
Building Official shall provide the applicant notice of the time and place of
the City Council meeting at which said application will be considered and shall
advise the applicant to attend such meeting in order to explain the
application.
   (b)   Decision of Council.
      (1)   City Council shall, within five business days following the
conclusion of the meeting or meetings at which the application is reviewed,
either:
         (A)   Issue written approval directing the Building Official to issue
the demolition permit for the proposed demolition activity;
         (B)   Issue written approval, with conditions, directing the Building
Office to issue the demolition permit subject to specific changes or conditions
not included in the application as submitted, but which would protect any
distinctive architectural or archaeological character of the building,
structure or area which is subject to change as a result of the proposed
demolition activity; or
         (C)   Issue a written denial to the application with a decision
setting forth the reason for the denial of the demolition permit.
      (2)   Failure of City Council to so act within the said period shall be
deemed to constitute a decision against the applicant. In the event that
approval is granted subject to conditions, the applicant may, within five
business days after receiving a written copy of other decision, give notice of
his, her or its refusal to accept all the conditions, in which case City
Council shall be deemed to have denied a demolition permit. In the event the
applicant does not, within the said period, notify City Council of his, her or
its refusal to accept all of the said conditions, the approval, with all
conditions, shall stand as granted.
   (c)   Appeals. Upon receipt of the written denial by City Council, the
applicant may appeal the decision as permitted by law and the ordinances of the
City of Williamsport.
(Ord. 6048, approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413, approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.09 WORK RESTRICTIONS.
   The following restrictions shall be adhered to by the demolition contractor
with respect to the demolition work.
   (a)   Demolition work shall start within seven days of the issuance of the
demolition permit by the city and such work shall be completed within 30 days
of the issuance of the permit. Extensions of demolition time may be granted for
valid reasons. All applications for time extensions shall be submitted to the
Code Administrator for the city no later than 24 hours before the expiration of
the 30-day period.
   (b)   All debris shall be removed from the demolition site, with the
exception of brick, stone, concrete or slate, which may be used to fill in the
cellar excavation to within two feet of the surrounding terrain. The top two
feet of any filled-in excavation shall be earthen fill. No piece larger than
six inches through its smallest diameter nor more than 12 inches long will be
permitted in the backfill in the subsurface spaces.
   (c)   Burning of any debris on the demolition site is prohibited.
   (d)   If dust from the demolition or loading of debris is excessive,
watering of the building and rubble shall be done as the work progresses. The
determination of whether the dust from the demolition or loading is excessive
shall be made by the Code Administrator or his or her authorized designee.
(Ord. 4887, approved 2-16-1979; Ord. 6048, approved 1-11-2007; Ord. 6413,
approved 4-29-2021)
§ 1733.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provision of this article, upon conviction
thereof by summary proceedings, shall be fined not more than $1,000 and costs,
and in default of payment of such fine and costs shall be imprisoned not more
than 30 days.
(Ord. 5451, approved 11-9-1989; Ord. 6048, approved 1-11-2007)
TITLE FIVE: HOUSING
ARTICLE 1741: INTERNATIONAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE
