Maintenance Code have been moved to Art. 1713, pursuant to Ord. 6413.
ARTICLE 1743: RENT WITHHOLDING
Section
   
1743.01   Authority.
   
1743.02   Rent suspension upon certification; termination.
   
1743.03   Inspection request; rent payment statement.
   
1743.04   Inspection fee payment by applicant; refund.
   
1743.05   Use of inspection form by City Inspectors.
   
1743.06   System for determination of unfit for human habitation.
   
1743.07   Unfit for human habitation defined.
   
1743.08   Duties of Public Safety Director.
   
1743.09   Certification procedure and notice.
   
1743.10   Appeal procedure before Board of Health.
   
1743.11   Use of funds in escrow account.
   
1743.12   Deposit of rent.
   
1743.13   Duration of suspension.
   
1743.14   Payment of escrow funds.
   
1743.15   Certification of dwelling as fit for human habitation.
   
1743.16   Termination of tenancy.
   
1743.17   Negligent or willful conduct of tenant.
   
1743.18   Delegation of authority.
Cross-reference:
   Unfit for occupancy, see Part Seventeen, §
1713.02(d)
Statutory reference:
   Authority, see 35 P.S. § 1700-1
§ 1743.01 AUTHORITY.
   This article is enacted under the authority of the Act of 1-24-1966 (P.L.
1534), as amended, and for the purpose of implementing the provisions thereof.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.02 RENT SUSPENSION UPON CERTIFICATION; TERMINATION.
   Notwithstanding any other provisions of law, or any agreement, oral or
written, whenever the Director of Public Safety certifies a dwelling unfit for
human habitation, the duty of any tenant of such dwelling to pay and the right
of the landlord to collect, rent, shall be suspended without affecting any
other terms or conditions of the landlord/tenant relationship until the
dwelling is certified as fit for human habitation as provided for hereinafter
or until the passage of six months from the date of such certification,
whichever occurs first. However, no such suspension shall begin unless and
until the tenant is current in his or her payment of rent to the landlord and
the Director of Public Safety so certifies.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.03 INSPECTION REQUEST; RENT PAYMENT STATEMENT.
   Any interested party may request in writing that the Director of Public
Safety have conducted an inspection of a dwelling unit for the purpose of
determining whether the dwelling is unfit for human habitation for rent
withholding purposes. Such written request for inspection shall contain a
certification from a tenant making such a request that his or her rent is
current and include a statement of the amount of rent paid and the date on
which the next rental payment is due.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.04 INSPECTION FEE PAYMENT BY APPLICANT; REFUND.
   When a written request for an inspection for the purpose of determining
whether a dwelling is unfit for human habitation for rent withholding purposes
is made, such person making the request for inspection shall pay an inspection
fee of $15 to the Director of Public Safety. In the event that the inspection
results in a determination that the inspected dwelling is unfit for human
habitation for rent withholding purposes, the fee shall be returned to the
party who made the payment. However, in the event that such inspection results
in a determination that the dwelling is not unfit for human habitation for rent
withholding purposes, the inspection fee shall not be returned, but rather
shall be turned over to the city as partial reimbursement for the expenses
incident to the inspection.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.05 USE OF INSPECTION FORM BY CITY INSPECTORS.
   Any requested inspection as set forth above shall be handled by the City
Health Officer or other City Inspectors employed in the Codes Enforcement
Department. Such Inspector making the inspection shall be provided with a form
setting forth the criteria and guidelines for ascertaining whether a dwelling
unit is unfit for human habitation for rent withholding purposes and such form
shall be completed and signed by the person making the inspection and shall
contain a statement as to whether the dwelling is or is not unfit for human
habitation for rent withholding purposes.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.06 SYSTEM FOR DETERMINATION OF UNFIT FOR HUMAN HABITATION.
   The Director of Public Safety shall establish in writing a system to be
utilized for the purpose of determining whether or not a dwelling is fit or
unfit for human habitation for rent withholding purposes. This system shall set
forth in detail the conditions, or combination of conditions which render a
dwelling fit or unfit for human habitation for rent withholding purposes.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.07 UNFIT FOR HUMAN HABITATION DEFINED.
   (a)   Unfit for human habitation for rent withholding purposes means either:
      (1)   That the owner of the dwelling has been convicted of a violation of
the Williamsport Housing Code; or
      (2)   That the dwelling qualifies for rent withholding status due to
substantial violations of the Code or because of failure to conform to the
minimum requirements of the Code.
   (b)   Throughout the various sections of this ordinance, any reference to
the term “unfit for human habitation” is a reference to a dwelling being unfit
for human habitation for rent withholding purposes as opposed to “unfit for
human habitation” under any other codes or ordinances of the city.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.08 DUTIES OF PUBLIC SAFETY DIRECTOR.
   Upon written complaint, it shall be the duty of the Public Safety Director
to require inspection of dwellings within the city to determine whether any
such dwellings are unfit for human habitation, in accordance with the criteria
established by the Director of Public Safety. In the case of multiple dwelling
buildings a determination shall be made whether each tenement is unfit, taking
into account the condition of the common facilities of the building. Upon
making a determination that the dwelling is unfit for human habitation for rent
withholding purposes, the Inspector shall immediately prepare a written report
substantiating the findings and submit such report to the Director of Public
Safety. Upon making the determination that the dwelling is unfit for human
habitation for rent withholding purposes, the Inspector shall also determine
whether the tenant who leases the dwelling is current in his or her payment of
rent to the landlord. The Inspector shall include in the written report to the
Director of Public Safety, a statement as to whether the rent is current and
shall also indicate in the report what evidence of current payment was
exhibited by the tenant to the Inspector, for example, the Inspector was shown
a rent receipt or the Inspector was shown a cancelled check. In the event the
payment of rent is not current, the tenant may bring such payments to a current
status by paying the necessary sums to the landlord.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.09 CERTIFICATION PROCEDURE AND NOTICE.
   (a)   Upon receipt of the Director of Public Safety of reports from the
Inspectors relating to the unfitness of a dwelling for human habitation, and
whether or not the tenant of such dwelling is current in his or her payment of
rent to the landlord, the Director of Public Safety shall promptly consider the
reports, and based on the contents thereof and any additional information
obtained by the Director of Public Safety, determine whether such dwelling
should be certified as unfit for human habitation and further whether a
certification should be issued that the tenant of the dwelling is current in
the payment of rent to the landlord.
   (b)   In the event that a certification is issued signifying that a dwelling
is unfit for human habitation, the Director of Public Safety shall immediately
send to both landlord and tenant copies of the report submitted by the
Inspector together with the Inspector’s recommendation, along with a
notification which shall advise both landlord and tenant that the tenant is
entitled to withhold his or her rent and put it into escrow until the premises
are certified as fit for human habitation by the Director of Public Safety. The
tenant shall be advised of the procedure for paying rent into escrow and that
person desiring to avail themselves of rent withholding should immediately
contact the Department of Public Safety for such purpose. Until such time as
the property is certified as being fit for human habitation by the Director of
Public Safety, the right of the landlord to collect rent shall be suspended,
and until further notice, all rental payments shall be directed to the bank or
trust company approved by the city for the purpose of holding such rental
payments in an escrow account.
   (c)   If the building is determined to be fit for human habitation, the
Director of Public Safety shall immediately notify the tenant in writing of
this determination.
   (d)   The landlord shall have ten days from the date of the mailing of a
notification that a dwelling has been certified as unfit for human habitation,
to file a written response to the certification and the Inspector’s report and
request a hearing before the Board of Health for the purpose of contesting the
certification based upon an erroneous inspection report or based upon the
allegation that some of the defective conditions noted in the Inspector’s
report were the result of tenant-caused damage, or to contest whether the
tenant is current in his payment of rent to the landlord.
   (e)   Any reports, certifications, or written determinations required under
this article shall be directed to the landlord and the tenant, or the
respective legal representatives, at their last known addresses by ordinary
mail.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.10 APPEAL PROCEDURE BEFORE BOARD OF HEALTH.
   (a)   Upon receipt of written request for a hearing before the Board of
Health, the Director of Public Safety shall transmit the copy of the written
request for a hearing, together with any written response to the Secretary of
the Board of Health, who shall place the matter on the agenda for the next
regularly scheduled meeting of the Board. Both the landlord and the tenant
shall be sent notification by the Secretary of the date, time and place of the
appeal hearing, and the tenant shall be provided with a copy of the landlord’s
written response, if any. The notifications to be sent by the Secretary shall
be directed to the landlord and tenant, or their respective legal
representatives, at their last known addresses by ordinary mail.
   (b)   The Chairperson or acting chairperson of the Board shall preside over
the appeal and shall have the power to administer oaths, issue subpoenas, to
compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of documents and papers,
if requested to issue such subpoenas by either party.
   (c)   Both the landlord and the tenant shall have the right to be
represented by counsel and shall be afforded the opportunity to respond and
present evidence and cross-examine witnesses.
   (d)   Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but irrelevant, immaterial
and repetitious evidence may be excluded.
   (e)   Within 15 days after any such hearing, the Board shall issue a written
order affirming or revoking the certification of the Director of Public Safety
and the Secretary shall immediately direct a copy of its order to both the
landlord and tenant, or their legal representatives, at their last known
addresses by ordinary mail.
   (f)   Where the Director of Public Safety has certified that a dwelling is
unfit for human habitation, and that the tenant is current in his or her
payment of rent to the landlord, the duty to pay rent by the tenant to the
landlord shall remain suspended during the pendency of any proceedings before
the Board of Health, as well as during the pendency of any appeal from an order
of the Board, but in no event longer than six months from the date of such
certification. The suspension of the duty of the tenant to pay rent shall
terminate upon the revocation of a certification of the Director of Public
Safety, and the tenant’s duty to pay rent to the landlord shall be reinstated
as of the date of the Board’s order. Any rent which was paid to an escrow agent
during the pendency of an appeal, shall be paid to the landlord less any amount
used to pay the cost of making the premises fit for human habitation, or any
amount used for the payment of utility services for which the landlord was
obligated but refused or was unable to pay, and less any administrative costs
incurred by the escrow agent as a result of setting up, administering and
terminating the escrow account.
   (g)   If the Director of Public Safety has determined that a dwelling is fit
for human habitation or certifies that a dwelling is unfit for human
habitation, but determines that a tenant is not current in the payment of his
or her rent to the landlord, the duty to pay rent shall continue during the
pendency of any proceeding before the Board of Health, as well as during the
pendency of any appeal from an order of the Board thereon. However, the duty to
pay rent shall terminate upon the revocation of the certification of the
Director of Public Safety, which revocation is final in nature and such
suspension of the duty to pay shall continue for a period of six months from
the date of any such revocation.
   (h)   Any party aggrieved by the decision by the Board of Health shall have
the right of appeal from such decision in accordance with the Local Agency Law,
2 Pa.C.S. §§ 551, 751 et seq..
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.11 USE OF FUNDS IN ESCROW ACCOUNT.
   (a)   The escrow agent shall have the right to make monthly deductions from
the individual escrow accounts for the costs of administration of the
individual escrow account as set forth in the agreement drawn up between the
city and the escrow agent. Such monthly administrative costs shall be made
known to the landlord and tenant as part of the notification sent to the
respective parties when a dwelling has been certified as unfit for human
habitation for rent withholding purposes.
   (b)   Any funds deposited in escrow may be used for the purpose of making a
dwelling fit for human habitation, and for the payment of utility services for
which the landlord is obligated, but which he or she refuses or is unable to
pay. All such payments shall be made at the direction of the Director of Public
Safety. Escrow funds may not be used for the purpose of making the dwelling fit
for human habitation during the pendency of any appeal, unless the landlord and
tenant agree to the use of such funds.
   (c)   The landlord or tenant may submit to the Director of Public Safety,
requests for the payment of escrow funds for the purpose of the performance or
work which will assist in making a dwelling fit for human habitation. This
request shall be accompanied by a written description of the work to be
performed as well as a written estimate of the cost thereof prepared by the
contractor who is to perform such work.
   (d)   The Director of Public Safety shall determine whether the contemplated
use of such funds will assist in causing the dwelling to be fit for human
habitation. Written notice of the determination of the Director shall be given
to the landlord and the tenant, or their authorized legal representatives by
ordinary mail, and, in the event that determination is favorable relative to
the intended use of such funds the notice shall set forth the specific purpose
for which such funds are to be used, as well as the amounts thereof. In no
event shall the Director of Public Safety authorize the expenditures of moneys
in excess of the amount deposited in escrow.
   (e)   Any party aggrieved by the determination of the Director of Public
Safety may request a hearing before the Board of Health of the city, which
hearing in all matters relating thereto, shall be held in accordance with the
appeal procedure as previously set forth in this article.
   (f)   If a determination is made that the contemplated use of escrow funds
will assist in causing a dwelling to be fit for human habitation, and a hearing
by the Board of Health is not requested as aforesaid, or in the event a hearing
is requested and a determination which is final in nature is made which
provides that the funds are to be used as requested, then in that event, the
Director of Public Safety shall notify the contractor who is to perform repairs
to the dwellings that the expenses of the repairs will be paid from the funds
in the escrow account; provided that, after the work has been completed, an
inspection reveals that the authorized repairs were in fact completed, and were
completed in a worker-like fashion. The Director of Public Safety shall also
notify the contractor of the specific repairs which have been approved.
   (g)   The Director of Public Safety shall direct an inspection of any
repairs made to a dwelling, the expenses for which are to be paid from the
escrow account, prior to the time at which any funds are paid to the
contractor. The Inspector shall then report to the Director of Public Safety as
to whether the repairs were completed in a worker-like fashion. The inspection
and report must be made prior to the date on which any funds are paid to the
contractor. The Director of Public Safety shall not have a duty to pay the
contractor unless such repairs were completed in a worker-like manner.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.12 DEPOSIT OF RENT.
   During any period when the duty to pay rent has been suspended and the
tenant continues to occupy the dwelling, the rent withheld shall be deposited
by the tenant in an escrow account in a bank or trust company approved by the
city which escrow account shall be the subject of an agreement between the city
and the bank setting forth the conditions and terms of the escrow agreement.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.13 DURATION OF SUSPENSION.
   (a)   The suspension of the duty of the tenant to pay rent to the landlord
shall begin on the date on which the dwelling was certified as unfit for human
habitation and the tenant was certified as being current in his or her payment
of rent to the landlord and continue for a period of six months or until the
dwelling is certified to be fit for human habitation, whichever is sooner, and
such suspension may be renewed for successive periods of six months pursuant to
subsequent certifications by the Director of Public Safety in accordance with
the provisions of this article.
   (b)   Where the duty of the tenant is suspended and the tenant at any time
thereafter during the suspension of such duty refuses to pay or discontinues
paying rent into the escrow account for a period of 15 days after the withheld
rent was due, the suspension of the duty to pay rent shall be ended
automatically on the fifteenth day after the rent was due and it shall again be
the duty of the tenant to pay rent to the landlord. In such event, any funds
remaining in the escrow account shall be paid to the landlord, less any
administrative costs of the escrow agent.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.14 PAYMENT OF ESCROW FUNDS.
   (a)   All sums paid into the escrow account, less any sum or sums utilized
for the purpose of making a dwelling fit for human habitation or for the
payment of utility services for which the landlord is obligated, but for which
he refuses or is unable to pay, or any administrative charges of the escrow
agent, shall be paid to the landlord in the event the dwelling is certified as
fit for human habitation within six months from the date on which it was
certified as unfit for human habitation.
   (b)   (1)   All sums paid into the escrow account, less any money utilized
for the purpose of making the dwelling fit for human habitation or for payment
of utility services for which the landlord is obligated but for which he or she
refuses or is unable to pay, or any administrative charges of the escrow agent,
shall be paid to the tenant of the escrow account if the dwelling has not been
certified as fit for human habitation at the end of six months after the date
on which the dwelling was certified as unfit for human habitation.
      (2)   No funds shall be paid to either the landlord or the tenant during
the pendency of any proceedings before the Board of Health or during the
pendency of an appeal from an order of the Board. During the pendency of any
such proceeding, the funds shall remain in the escrow account subject to the
terms and provisions of the escrow agreement and this article and such funds
shall not be distributed to the landlord or the tenant except after a final
determination of the matter at which time the funds will be distributed in
accordance with such determination.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.15 CERTIFICATION OF DWELLING AS FIT FOR HUMAN HABITATION.
   At any time within six months from the date on which a dwelling has been
certified as being unfit for human habitation, the landlord or the tenant may
request in writing that the Director of Public Safety certify a dwelling as
being fit for human habitation. The Director shall thereupon have an inspection
made of the premises to determine whether it is fit for human habitation. The
Inspector shall prepare a written report to the Director of Public Safety
substantiating the findings of his or her inspection. Based on the written
report submitted by the Inspector and any other additional information obtained
by him or her, the Director shall certify whether or not such dwelling is fit
for human habitation. Copies of such report and certification shall be sent to
both the landlord and tenant at their last known addresses by ordinary mail.
Any party aggrieved by this determination may request a hearing pursuant to the
previously set forth appeal procedure.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.16 TERMINATION OF TENANCY.
   Where subsequent to the date on which a dwelling is certified to be fit for
human habitation by the Director of Public Safety, the landlord thereof elects
to terminate the tenancy of any person who was a tenant thereof on the date
such dwelling was certified as being unfit for human habitation, other than for
the reason that such tenant has violated his or her obligations as a tenant,
including the obligation to pay rent at a rate no higher than that existing
prior to the date of certification, then the landlord shall provide any tenant
with written notice of his or her intention to terminate such tenancy at least
six months prior to the date for termination unless a lease provides for a
longer period.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.17 NEGLIGENT OR WILLFUL CONDUCT OF TENANT.
   (a)   A dwelling shall not be certified as unfit for human habitation if the
condition or conditions responsible for such a determination are due to the
negligence or willful conduct of the tenant, his or her agents, or any person
under the supervision or control of the tenant.
   (b)   Where a dwelling has been certified as unfit for human habitation, and
a request is made by the landlord for a certification that the dwelling is fit
for human habitation, such certification shall not be refused if at the time of
the request, the dwelling is unfit for human habitation because of conditions
caused by negligent or willful conduct of the tenant, his or her agent, or any
person under the supervision or control of the tenant.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
§ 1743.18 DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY.
   Any duty conferred herein upon the Director of Public Safety may be
delegated in writing by the Director to any official of the Code Enforcement
Bureau of the city, or in the event there is no Director of Public Safety or
acting Director of Public Safety in office, the Mayor may delegate to any
official of the executive branch of city government, the duties herein
conferred upon the Director of Public Safety.
(Ord. 4831, approved 5-12-1977)
ARTICLE 1745: FAIR HOUSING
Section
   
1745.01   Definitions.
   
1745.02   Scope.
   
1745.03   Prohibited acts.
   
1745.04   Exemptions.
   
1745.05   Fair Housing Commission.
   
1745.06   Enforcement.
   
1745.07   Severability.
Statutory reference:
   Housing and Redevelopment Assistance Law, see 35 P.S. §§ 1661 et seq.
   Housing discrimination, see 35 P.S. § 1664
   Urban Redevelopment Law prohibition, see 35 P.S. § 1711
§ 1745.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the
meaning set forth below.
   COMMISSION. The Fair Housing Commission of the City of Williamsport.
   DISCRIMINATE or DISCRIMINATION. Any difference in treatment in the sale,
lease, rental, financing, provision of brokerage services or other disposition
of residential property and related facilities, including land to be developed
for residential use, or occupancy thereof of housing units or housing
accommodations because of race, color, religion, creed, age, sex, national
origin, handicap or use of guide dogs because of blindness of the user.
   HOUSING UNIT. A single room or suite of rooms, or an apartment or dwelling,
occupied or intended for occupancy as separate living quarters by an individual
or a family, or a parcel of real property or a lot available for construction
of a housing unit.
   LENDING INSTITUTION. Any person, as defined in this section, regularly
engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans.
   OWNER. Includes the lessee, sublessee, assignee, managing agent or other
person having the right of ownership or possession, or the right to sell, rent
or lease any housing unit which is part of a housing accommodation or to
furnish services in connection therewith.
   PERSON. Includes an association, partnership or corporation, as well as a
natural person. When applied to partnerships or other associations, it includes
their members, and as applied to corporations, it includes the officers of the
corporations.
   REAL ESTATE BROKER. Any natural person, partnership, association or
corporation who, for a fee or other valuable consideration, or other purposes,
sells, purchases, exchanges or rents, or negotiates or offers or attempts to
negotiate, the sale, purchase, exchange or rental of the real property of
another or holds himself or herself out as engaged in the business of selling,
purchasing, exchanging or renting the real property of another, or collects
rental for the use of the real property of another or attempts to secure the
listing for sale or rental of a housing unit by representing that a change has
occurred or will or may occur with respect to the racial, religious or ethnic
composition of the street, block, neighborhood or area in which such housing
accommodation is located.
   REAL ESTATE SALESPERSON OR AGENT. Any person employed by a real estate
broker or providing any services in connection therewith.
(Ord. 5251, approved 7-9-1984)
§ 1745.02 SCOPE.
   This article applies to discriminatory housing units located within the
corporate limits of the city.
(Ord. 5251, approved 7-9-1984)
§ 1745.03 PROHIBITED ACTS.
   (a)   No real estate broker or real estate salesperson or agent, or owner or
other person shall refuse to sell, lease, sublease, rent, assign or otherwise
transfer, or refuse to negotiate for the sale, lease, sublease, rental,
assignment or other transfer of the title, leasehold or other interest in any
housing unit to any person, or represent that a housing unit is not available
for inspection, sale, lease, sublease, rental, assignment or other transfer
when in fact it is so available, or otherwise deny or withhold any housing unit
from any person because of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex,
national origin, handicap or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the
user.
   (b)   No owner shall refuse to sell, lease, sublease, rent, assign or
otherwise transfer the title, leasehold or other interest in any housing unit,
which is part of a housing unit to any person, or otherwise deny or withhold
such housing unit or deny or withhold the furnishing of services in connection
therewith from a person because of race, color, religion, creed, age, sex,
national origin, handicap or use of a guide dog because of blindness of the
user.
   (c)   No real estate broker or real estate salesperson or agent shall
include in the terms, conditions or privileges, or services in connection
therewith of any sale, lease, sublease, rental, assignment or other transfer of
any housing unit, any clause, condition or restriction discriminating against
any person in the use or occupancy of such housing unit because of race, color,
religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap or use of guide
dog because of the blindness of the user.
   (d)   No person shall include in the terms, conditions or privileges of the
sale, lease, sublease, rental, assignment or other transfer of a housing unit
which is part of a housing accommodation, any clause, condition or restriction
that discriminates against any person in the use or occupancy of such housing
unit because of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national
origin, handicap or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user.
   (e)   No person shall discriminate in the furnishing of any facilities or
services for a housing unit, which is part of a housing accommodation, because
of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap
or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user.
   (f)   No real estate broker, real estate salesperson or agent, owner or any
person or any lending institution shall publish or circulate, or cause to be
published or circulated, any form of application for the purchase, lease,
rental or financing of housing, or make any record or inquiry in connection
with the prospective purchase, rental or lease of housing, which expresses
directly or indirectly any limitation, specification or discrimination as to
race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap or
use of guide dog because of the blindness of the user, or any intent to make
any such limitation, specification or discrimination.
   (g)   No person, whether or not a real estate broker, real estate
salesperson or agent, owner or lending institution, shall aid, incite, compel,
coerce or participate in the doing of any act declared to be unlawful housing
practice under this article or obstruct or prevent enforcement or compliance
with the provisions of this article of any rule, regulation or order of the
Commission, or attempt directly or indirectly to commit any act declared by
this article to be an unlawful housing practice.
(Ord. 5251, approved 7-9-1984)
§ 1745.04 EXEMPTIONS.
   Nothing in this article shall bar any religious or denominational
institution or religious or denominational organization which is operated,
supervised or controlled by or in connection with a religious organization,
from limiting admission to or giving preference to persons of the same religion
or denomination or from making such selection as is calculated by such
organization to promote the religious principles for which it is established or
maintained, as long as such selection or preference is not on the basis of
race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap or
use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user.
(Ord. 5251, approved 7-9-1984)
§ 1745.05 FAIR HOUSING COMMISSION.
   (a)   The city shall establish a five-member board, which shall serve as the
Fair Housing Commission for the city. This Commission shall be appointed by the
Mayor with the advice and consent of Council.
   (b)   All members of the Fair Housing Commission shall be residents of the
city and may include representatives of local lending institutions, real estate
brokers or salespersons, landlords, tenants and any other persons with an
interest in the purposes and principles of the article. At the time of the
first appointment, one appointee shall serve for a term of one year, a second
member for a term of two years, a third member for a term three years, a fourth
member for a term of four years, a fifth member for a term of five years. After
the initial appointment, the term of members shall be for five years. All
vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired terms. Members of the Commission
shall serve without compensation.
   (c)   In addition to its duties to enforce this article, the Commission
shall have the duty to promote housing education, credit repair, counseling,
distribute fair housing practice information and to promote and encourage home
ownership.
   (d)   The Commission shall, at least annually, hold such additional
meetings, as it deems necessary. The members of the Commission shall elect a
Chairperson and adopt rules and regulations for its organization and procedures
consistent with city ordinances. The Commission shall, at least annually,
submit a report to Council describing in detail the investigations,
proceedings, hearings and outreach it has conducted.
(Ord. 5251, approved 7-9-1984; Ord. 6022, approved 11-9-2006)
§ 1745.06 ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the Fair Housing
Commission of the City pursuant to procedures and regulations which they shall
establish.
   (b)   The Mayor shall appoint a Fair Housing Officer to act as staff for the
Commission and shall perform the necessary investigations resulting from
complaints. The Fair Housing Officer may be appointed from existing staff or
may be appointed from a duly authorized and H.U.D. recognized local Human
Relations Commission whose primary purpose is to advocate anti-discrimination
laws and practices.
   (c)   All hearings conducted by the Commission shall be public and the
complainant and respondent shall have the right to be represented by an
attorney and to cross-examine witnesses and to present evidence through
witnesses and exhibits as the Commission deems relevant. Formal rules of
evidence shall not apply.
   (d)   The Commission shall have the power to issue subpoenas to compel the
attendance of witnesses and/or the production of documents.
(Ord. 5251, approved 7-9-1984)
§ 1745.07 SEVERABILITY.
   The provisions of this article are severable and if any of its sections,
clauses or sentences shall be held illegal, invalid or unconstitutional, such
provisions shall not affect or impair any of the remaining sections, clauses or
sentences. It is hereby declared to be the intent of Council that this article
would have been adopted if such illegal, invalid or unconstitutional section,
clause or sentence had not been included herein.
(Ord. 5251, approved 7-9-1984)
ARTICLE 1747: CONTRACTOR REGULATIONS
Section
   
1747.01   Introduction.
   
1747.02   Applicability.
   
1747.03   Required application for contractor registration.
   
1747.04   Registration fees.
   
1747.05   Registration suspension; appeals therefrom.
   
1747.06   Penalty.
§ 1747.01 INTRODUCTION.
   This article shall be known as the “Contractor Registration Ordinance”.
(Ord. 5699, approved 12-12-1996)
§ 1747.02 APPLICABILITY.
   This article shall apply to all persons, companies, corporations,
individuals, partnerships or other entities doing construction, demolition,
excavation or other similar work which would require a permit in the City of
Williamsport with the exception of the owner or occupant of the property or
building who is doing their own work.
(Ord. 5699, approved 12-12-1996)
§ 1747.03 REQUIRED APPLICATION FOR CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION.
   No entity shall engage in construction service in the City of Williamsport
without first making make application to the Codes Administrator or other
designated officer for registration. The application shall be on a form
provided by the city and shall contain at least the following information:
   (a)   Full name of applicant and mailing address;
   (b)   Type of entity and if other than an individual, the person responsible
to provide the required information;
   (c)   Business telephone number;
   (d)   The applicant shall also provide the following documents:
      (1)   A copy of the certificate of workers compensation insurance from
his insurance company or certificate of self insurance from the Department of
Labor and Industry or a notarized affidavit of exemption from workers
compensation insurance stating that the individual, company, corporation and
the like will not hire any employees to work on the construction project;
      (2)   A copy of the certificate of liability insurance; and
      (3)   If the workers compensation or liability insurance policy expires,
lapses, terminates or is canceled before the end of the calendar year for which
registration has been accomplished with the city, or if the applicant changes
the coverage to a different policy or company, the applicant shall be
responsible to submit a new copy of the certificate of insurance coverage to
the city.
   (e)   Contractor’s federal or state employer identification number.
(Ord. 5699, approved 12-12-1996; Ord. 5921, approved 5-29-2003)
§ 1747.04 REGISTRATION FEES.
   No registration shall be accepted under this article until the proper fee
shall be paid to the city which shall be used by the city to defray
administrative and enforcement costs. Said fee shall be $50 for each
registration filed with the city. All registrations shall be effective only for
the calendar year in which they are filed and must be renewed yearly on or
before January 31 of each year. Any person paying a license fee pursuant to
Art. 1727 (Plumbing) shall receive a credit toward the registration fee.
(Ord. 5699, approved 12-12-1996)
§ 1747.05 REGISTRATION SUSPENSION; APPEALS THEREFROM.
   Any registration filed under this article may be suspended at any time by
the Codes Administrator for violation of the city’s building code, zoning
ordinance, property maintenance code or other ordinances, loss of insurance
coverage, failure to pay business privilege tax that is due and owing or other
good reason. Appeals from any suspension may be made to the BOCA Appeal Board
at any time within ten days after such suspension. No part of a registration
fee shall be refunded to any person who’s registration shall have been
suspended.
(Ord. 5699, approved 12-12-1996)
§ 1747.06 PENALTY.
   Any person, company, corporation or individual who shall violate any
provision of this article or fails to register as required shall, upon
conviction thereof in a summary proceeding, be fined not less than $100, nor
more than $600, and cost of prosecution for each offense. In default of payment
thereof, he or she shall undergo imprisonment in the Lycoming County prison for
a period not exceeding 30 days. Each day or portion of day a contractor works
without having a valid registration shall be considered a separate offense. All
fines collected for such violations shall be paid over to the city.
(Ord. 5699, approved 12-12-1996; Ord. 5921, approved 5-29-2003)
ARTICLE 1749: RENTAL INSPECTION
Section
   
1749.01   Title and purpose.
   
1749.02   Definitions.
   
1749.03   Certificate of inspection required for occupancy.
   
1749.04   Inspection requirements.
   
1749.05   Issuance and filing of certificate of inspection.
   
1749.06   Notice requirement.
   
1749.07   Registration of rental property.
   
1749.08   Transfer of certificate of inspection.
   
1749.09   Responsible party.
   
1749.10   Grounds for denial, non-renewal, suspension or revocation of license.
   
1749.11   Means of appeal.
   
1749.12   Violations and penalties.
   
1749.13   Fees.
§ 1749.01 TITLE AND PURPOSE.
   (a)   This article shall be known as Williamsport Rental Inspection.
   (b)   The City of Williamsport has experienced problems with the maintenance
of non-owner occupied properties from time to time and the health, life safety
and welfare of occupants of these non-owner occupied properties within the city
is a concern. The purpose of this article is to enhance the safety of non-owner
occupied properties through a system of inspections, and penalties for failure
to comply with the city’s laws, which focuses on compliance with the basic
property maintenance codes governing existing structures in the City of
Williamsport.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings
indicated, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context.
   CODE. Any property maintenance code adopted or enacted by the city.
   OWNER. Any person, copartnership, association, corporation or fiduciary
having legal or equitable title, or any interest in any real property. Whenever
used in any clause prescribing or imposing a penalty, the term OWNER, as
applied to co partnership and associations, shall mean the partners or members
thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof.
   PUBLIC HOUSING UNIT. All housing units owned and operated or managed by a
public housing authority under contract with the U.S. Department of Housing and
Urban Development (HUD). PUBLIC HOUSING UNIT does not include Section 8 or any
other equivalent program.
   REGULATED RENTAL UNIT/REGULATED DWELLING UNIT. A residential unit occupied
by other than the owner.
   RESIDENTIAL UNIT. Any structurally enclosed area including or intended to be
used as a living quarters for one or more individuals.
   RESPONSIBLE AGENT. See §
1713.02.
   STRUCTURE. That which is built or constructed or a portion thereof.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.03 CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION REQUIRED FOR OCCUPANCY.
   No residential unit shall be occupied by any person or persons other than
the owner thereof, unless a certificate of inspection is kept on file by the
owner or designated agent as required by the provisions of this article.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.04 INSPECTION REQUIREMENTS.
   Regulated rental units shall be subject to inspection in accordance with the
provisions of this article.
   (a)   Purpose. Inspections required by this article shall be for the purpose
of determining compliance with the provisions of the Code as in effect in the
city on the date of inspection.
   (b)   Permitted inspectors. Inspections required by tins article shall be
conducted by members of the Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control
and Code Enforcement.
   (c)   Timing of inspections.
      (1) As for any residential unit unoccupied or occupied by the owner on or
after the effective date hereof, a certificate of inspection shall be issued
and on file prior to occupancy of such residential unit by anyone other than
the owner, and subsequent inspections shall occur as set forth in subsection
(c)(2).
      (2) As for any residential unit occupied by other than the owner as of
the effective date hereof and for all subsequent inspections, inspections
required by this article shall be completed and the certificate of inspection
issued and on file no later than June 30 of the following year for which
inspection is required. In no event shall such an inspection be conducted prior
to July 1 of the year for which inspection is required.
   (d)   Tax wards shall be used for determining district boundaries.
      (1)   The city shall be divided into districts as follows:
         (A)   District I: Wards 5, 9, 11, 14;
         (B)   District II: Wards 4, 8, 10, 16;
         (C)   District III: Wards 3, 6, 13, 15; and
         (D)   District IV: Wards 1, 2, 7, 12.
      (2)   The Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code
Enforcement, shall be responsible for maintaining the ward map of these
districts in a place easily accessible to the public.
   (e)   Required inspection dates. Residential units subject to the inspection
requirements of this article and located in District I shall be inspected
between July 1 of the calendar year in which the article shall become effective
and June 30 of the following year and within the same time period every fourth
year thereafter. Residential units subject to the inspection requirements of
this article and located in District II shall be inspected between July 1 of
the subsequent calendar year in which the article shall become effective and
June 30 of the following year and within the same time period every fourth year
thereafter. Residential units subject to the inspection requirements of this
article and located in District III shall be inspected between July 1 of the
second calendar year subsequent to the year in which the article shall become
effective and June 30 of the following year and within the same time period
every fourth year thereafter. Residential units subject to the inspection
requirements of this article and located in District IV shall be inspected
between July 1 of the third calendar year subsequent to the year in which the
article shall become effective and June 30 of the following year and within the
same time period every fourth year thereafter.
      (1)   Within District I, the inspections will be scheduled as follows:
         (A)   Ward 5: July 1 through September 30;
         (B)   Ward 9: October 1 through December 31;
         (C)   Ward 11: January 1 through March 31; and
         (D)   Ward 14: April 1 through June 30.
      (2)   Within District II, the inspections will be scheduled as follows:
         (A)   Ward 4: July 1 through September 30;
         (B)   Ward 8: October 1 through December 31;
         (C)   Ward 10: January 1 through March 31; and
         (D)   Ward 16: April 1 through June 30.
      (3)   Within District III, the inspections will be scheduled as follows:
         (A)   Ward 3: July 1 through September 30;
         (B)   Ward 6: October 1 through December 31;
         (C)   Ward 13: January 1 through March 31; and
         (D)   Ward 15: April 1 through June 30.
      (4)   Within District IV, the inspections will be scheduled as follows:
         (A)   Ward 1: July 1 through September 30;
         (B)   Ward 2: October 1 through December 31;
         (C)   Ward 7: January 1 through March 31; and
         (D)   Ward 12: April 1 through June 30.
      (5)   Any property that has been inspected as set forth in subsection (c)
(2) and subsequently becomes vacant or a non-regulated rental unit/non-
regulated dwelling unit for a period of one year must be re-inspected prior to
occupancy as a regulated rental unit/dwelling unit.
   (f)   Exceptions.
      (1)   No residential unit which would otherwise be subject to the
inspection requirements of this article shall be required to be inspected
within the fourth calendar year subsequent to the year in which any certificate
of occupancy required before occupancy of new construction is issued.
      (2)   Structures, which require annual rooming house inspections, shall
not be subject to this article.
      (3)   Structures, which require annual student residence inspections as
required by §
1333.05 of the Williamsport Zoning Ordinance, shall not be subject to this
article.
      (4)   Public housing unit; provided:
         (A)   The housing units owned and operated or managed by a public
housing authority are required to be inspected at least annually to ensure
compliance with HUD’s Housing Quality Standards, 24 C.F.R. part 882, so long as
said standards are comparable to the International Property Maintenance Code;
         (B)   The inspections are conducted by HUD, the public housing
authority, or its duly authorized agent;
         (C)   The inspection reports are available for inspection by the
Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code Enforcement, and a
list of the properties inspected filed with the Department of Public Safety,
Environmental Control and Code Enforcement, annually; and
         (D)   Nothing contained in this exception shall be deemed to exclude
the properties from being subject to any other provisions or subsections of
this article, or other city ordinance or code and closure option.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.05 ISSUANCE AND FILING OF CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION.
   (a)   General provision. Upon completion of an inspection and that there
were no violations found of the Code as in effect on the date of inspection or
that any such violations have been corrected in accordance with said Code, the
Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code Enforcement, shall
issue a certificate of inspection for the structure with each residential unit
therein which was inspected listed upon said certificate and said certification
shall constitute a license to rent a regulated rental unit. The certificate of
inspection shall be kept on file by the owner or designated agent and made
available to the Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code
Enforcement, upon request.
   (b)   Form of proof of inspection. Proof of inspection and absence of any
violations of the Code shall be in such form as approved from time to time, by
the Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code Enforcement.
   (c)   Report of inspection appeals. Any report of inspection, which
indicated any violations of any code, shall be provided to the owner within 15
days of the date of inspection. Any appeals from the report of inspection shall
be filed and heard in the manner provided for in §
1749.11 of this article.
   (d)   Multi-unit structures. The units within a structure, which are in
compliance with the city’s codes, may continue to be occupied if units in other
portions of the structure which either do not apply or have not passed
inspection do not create a hazard to the health and life safety to the persons
occupying these units.
   (e)   Compliance with International Property Maintenance Code. The issuance
of a certificate of inspection does not relieve the property owner from
complying with said codes and city ordinances.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.06 NOTICE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Timeliness of notice. Reasonable notice must be given to the property
owner or responsible agent prior to inspections hereunder. The property owner
or responsible agent shall provide the tenant with reasonable notice of the
inspection.
   (b)   Delivery of notice. Notices under this article shall be considered to
have been received when it is actually delivered, as verified by an affidavit
of personal delivery, a certified receipt or through a courier verification or,
in the case of regular mail, it shall be considered to have been received no
later than five days after mailing, whichever is earlier.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.07 REGISTRATION OF RENTAL PROPERTY.
   (a)   The owner or responsible agent shall register each regulated rental
unit to the Williamsport Code Enforcement Office in writing at the time of
registration on a form provided by the city all of the following:
      (1)   The name, address, telephone number and emergency number of the
owner/landlord of the premises;
      (2)   The name, address, telephone number and emergency number of the
designated agent, if applicable;
      (3)   The property address and number of residential rental units; and
      (4)   The owner or responsible agent shall provide a current business
privilege/mercantile license tax number.
   (b)   The owner or responsible agent shall update the registration
information on record within 30 days of any changes to said information.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.08 TRANSFER OF CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION.
   A certificate of inspection issued hereunder is transferable to any person
who has acquired ownership of a licensed non-owner-occupied residential unit
for the unexpired portions of the four-year term for which it was issued or
reissued; provided that, the application to transfer such certificate is filed
with the Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code
Enforcement, for change of ownership, a new registration form is filed and the
licensed non-owner-occupied residential unit is in compliance with Williamsport
Building Codes and Williamsport Zoning Ordinances. A certificate shall
terminate upon failure to apply for its transfer within 30 days of the date of
sale or transfer of ownership of the non-owner-occupied residential unit.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.09 RESPONSIBLE PARTY.
   The owner and property manager, if any exist, of any residential unit which
is subject to the inspection requirements of this article shall be jointly and
severally responsible for compliance with the provisions of this article.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.10 GROUNDS FOR DENIAL, NON-RENEWAL, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (a)   General.
      (1)   The Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code
Enforcement, may initiate disciplinary action against an owner that may result
in a formal warning, non-renewal, suspension or revocation of the owner’s
license for violating any provisions of this article that impose a duty upon
the owner subject to the right of appeal pursuant to §
1749.11.
      (2)   In order for an owner to obtain or retain a license, all
requirements of the nine minimum standards from the International Property
Maintenance Code shall he followed:
         (A)   Interior and exterior sanitary conditions;
         (B)   Infestation and rodent harborage;
         (C)   Structural members and foundation walls;
         (D)   Plumbing/water systems;
         (E)   Heating/mechanical systems ventilation;
         (F)   Electrical system hazards;
         (G)   Smoke detection system;
         (H)   Fire escape routes; and
         (I)   Over occupancy.
      (3)   The Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code
Enforcement, shall maintain a field inspection checklist to guide monitoring of
compliance with these nine minimum standards. Said field checklist shall be
made available to owners or responsible agents of regulated rental units/
regulated dwelling units.
   (b)   Definitions of options.
      (1)   Denial. The violations found at the lime of the inspection would
render the property unsafe.
      (2)   Formal warning. Formal written notification of at least one
violation of this article. Upon satisfactory compliance with this article and
any conditions imposed by the Department of Public Safety, Environmental
Control and Code Enforcement, the formal warning shall be removed when the
owner applies for the license renewal at a time set by the Department of Public
Safety, Environmental Control and Code Enforcement.
      (3)   Non-renewal. The denial of the right to apply for license renewal
after expiration of the license term. The city will permit the owner to
maintain occupants in the premises until the end of the license term unless the
property is unfit for habitation, but will not accept applications for renewal
of the license until the property passes inspection by the Department of Public
Safety, Environmental Control and Code Enforcement.
      (4)   Suspension. The immediate loss of the right to rent regulated
rental units for a period of time set by the Department of Public Safety,
Environmental Control and Code Enforcement. The owner, after the expiration of
the suspension period, may apply for license renewal without the need to show
cause why the owner’s right to apply for the renewal license should be
reinstated. Upon suspension, the owner shall take immediate steps to evict the
occupants.
      (5)   Revocation. The immediate loss of the right to rent regulated
rental units for a period of time set by the Department of Public Safety,
Environmental Control and Code Enforcement, and winch may result in the loss of
the right to apply for renewal of the license at the expiration of the time
period. Upon revocation, the owner shall take immediate steps to evict the
occupants.
   (c)   Criteria for applying discipline. Department of Public Safety,
Environmental Control and Code Enforcement, when applying discipline, shall
consider the following:
      (1)   The effect of the violation on the health, life safety and welfare
of the occupant(s) of the regulated rental unit and other residents of the
premises;
      (2)   The effect of the violation on the neighborhood;
      (3)   Whether the owner has prior violations of this article and other
ordinances of the city or has received notices of violations as provided for in
this article;
      (4)   Whether the owner has been subject to disciplinary proceedings
under this article;
      (5)   The effect of disciplinary action on the occupants;
      (6)   The action taken by the owner to remedy the violation and to
prevent future violations, including any written plan submitted by the owner;
      (7)   The policies and lease language employed by the owner to manage the
regulated dwelling unit to enable the owner to comply with the provisions of
this article; and
      (8)   In addition to applying discipline as set forth above, the
Department impose upon the existing or subsequent licenses reasonable
conditions related to fulfilling the purpose of this article.
   (d)   Grounds for imposing discipline. Any of the following may subject an
owner to discipline as provided for in this article:
      (1)   Failure to abate a violation of this article that applies to the
premises within the time directed by the Department of Public Safety,
Environmental Control and Code Enforcement;
      (2)   Refusal to permit the inspection of the premises by the Department
of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code Enforcement, as provided for
in this article; and
      (3)   Three violations of this article or other ordinances of the city
that apply to the premises within a license term. For purpose of this article,
there need be no criminal conviction before a violation can be found to exist
before a prior violation can be considered under this section, the owner must
have received notice in writing of this violation within 30 days after the
Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and Code Enforcement,
received notice of the violation.
   (e)   Procedure for denial non-renewal, suspension or revocation of license
notification. Following a determination that grounds for denial, non-renewal,
suspension or revocation of a license exist, the Department of Public Safety,
Environmental Control and Code Enforcement, shall notify the owner of the
action to be taken and the reason therefor. Such notification shall be in
writing, addressed to the owner in question and shall contain the following
information:
      (1)   The address of the premises in question and identification of the
particular regulated rental unit(s) affected;
      (2)   A description of the violation, which has been found to exist;
      (3)   A statement that the license for said regulated rental unit(s)
shall be either suspended or revoked, or will not be renewed for the next
license year beginning January 1 or that the owner will receive a formal
warning. In the case of a suspension or revocation, the notice shall state the
date upon which such suspension or revocation will commence, and in the case of
a suspension shall also state the duration of said suspension;
      (4)   A statement that, due to the denial, non-renewal, suspension or
revocation (as the case may be), the owner or any person acting on his, her or
its behalf is prohibited from renting, letting or permitting occupancy of the
dwelling unit(s) subject to said enforcement action, from and during the period
said action is in effect;
      (5)   A statement informing the owner that he, she, or it has a right to
appeal the decision denying, suspending, revoking or declining to renew the
license to the Board of Health in accordance with §
1749.11 of this article submitting in writing to the Secretary of the Board of
Health, within 20 days after the notice was sent, a detailed statement of the
appeal, including the grounds therefor and the reason(s) alleged as to why the
determination of the Department of Public Safety, Environmental Control and
Code Enforcement, is incorrect or should be overturned, and a statement of the
relief requested by the appellant. Such notice of appeal may be required to be
submitted on a form to be prescribed therefor by the city, to be signed by the
appellant. There is hereby imposed a fee for filing of such appeals, the amount
shall be determined and established from time to time by ordinance of City
Council; and
      (6)   Upon receipt of such an appeal in proper form, accompanied with
requisite filing fee, the Secretary shall schedule a hearing to be held in
accordance with §
1749.11 of this article.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.11 MEANS OF APPEAL.
   (a)   Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection
with the enforcement of any provision of this article, or of any rule or
regulation adopted pursuant thereto, may request and shall be granted a hearing
on the matter before the Board of Health; provided that, such person files in
the office of the Bureau of Codes a written appeal requesting such hearing and
setting forth a statement of the grounds therefor within 20 days after the
notice was served. Upon receipt of such appeal, the Board shall set a lime and
place for such hearing and shall give the applicant written notice thereof. At
such hearing the applicant shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to
show why such notice should be modified or withdrawn. The hearing shall be
commenced not later than ten days after the date on which the appeal was filed.
Upon application of the applicant, the Board may postpone the date of the
hearing for a reasonable time beyond such ten-day period, if, in its judgment,
the applicant has submitted a good and sufficient reason for such postponement.
   (b)   After such hearing the Board shall sustain, modify or withdraw the
notice, depending upon its finding as to whether the provisions of this article
and of the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto have been complied
with.
   (c)   The proceedings at such hearing, including the findings and decision
of the Board, shall be summarized, reduced to writing and entered as a matter
of public record in the office of the Board. Such record shall also include a
copy of every notice or order issued in connection with the matter. The
proceedings shall be conducted in accordance with the Local Agency Law, 2
Pa.C.S. §§ 551, 751 et seq..
   (d)   Whenever a member or the Department of Public Safety and Environmental
Control and Code Enforcement finds that an emergency exists which requires
immediate action to protect the public health, he or she may, without notice of
hearing, issue an order reciting the existence of such emergency and requiring
that such action be taken, as he or she deems necessary to meet the emergency.
Notwithstanding the other provisions of this article, such order shall be
effective immediately. Any person to whom such order is directed shall comply
therewith immediately, but upon petition to the Board shall be afforded a
hearing as soon as possible. After such hearing, depending upon its findings as
to whether the provisions of this article and of the rules and regulations
adopted pursuant thereto have been complied with, the Board shall continue such
order in effect, or modify it, or revoke it.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.12 VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any violation of this section of this article shall constitute a summary
offense punishable, upon conviction thereof, by a fine not to exceed $600, plus
costs of prosecution or by a term of imprisonment not to exceed 30 days, or
both. Each violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
§ 1749.13 FEES.
   The fee for any residential rental building inspection shall be set forth in
Art. 117, General Fee Schedule.
(Ord. 6319, passed 10-27-2016)
